webTitle: Celtic make the gap a chasm

fields.headline: Celtic make the gap a chasm
fields.trailText: The timing of Celtic's victory in yesterday's Old Firm meeting could hardly have been more exquisitely calculated. A year to the day after their cup defeat at the modest hands of Inverness Caledonian Thistle cost John Barnes his first managerial job, Martin O'Neill's rebuilt team took what may prove to have been a decisive step on the way to regaining the championship.
fields.body:
The timing of Celtic's victory in yesterday's Old Firm meeting could hardly have been more exquisitely calculated. A year to the day after their cup defeat at the modest hands of Inverness Caledonian Thistle cost John Barnes his first managerial job, Martin O'Neill's rebuilt team took what may prove to have been a decisive step on the way to regaining the championship.

Last year Rangers won the title by a record margin of 21 points and appeared invulnerable. Celtic, meanwhile, looked like a basket case. This morning, with 12 games left to play, the Parkhead club lead Hibernian by 11 points and Rangers by 12, and the quality of Celtic's play yesterday afternoon suggested that another record may be in the offing. In a little over six months, by switching a handful of players and applying the sort of basic tactical principles that characterised the teams of his mentor, Brian Clough, O'Neill has wrought something close to a miracle.

Although Alan Thompson's first-half goal was enough to win the game, the gap in every other sense was wide enough to induce terminal gloom in Celtic's ancestral rivals. "We have to be realistic," Dick Advocaat, Rangers' manager, said afterwards. "It will be very difficult to catch them now."

There had been fears, following the overheated meeting between the teams in the CIS Insurance Cup on Wednesday, which featured three sending-offs during the game and a stabbing and 41 arrests afterwards, that yesterday's rendezvous would provide the excuse for further trouble on and off the pitch. Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, was discouraged from adding his support to the home team. But, although the atmosphere among the 59,496 spectators was electric throughout the en counter, the only significant blemish came with a red card for Fernando Ricksen, Rangers' right wing-back, on the stroke of half-time.

Both managers volunteered praise for the handling of the match by the experienced referee, Hugh Dallas, who was perhaps a little fortunate that half-time arrived just in time to put an end to a five-minute period of fraying tempers which included bookings for Bobby Petta and Bert Konterman as well as Ricksen's dismissal. "In terms of discipline I thought we were excellent," O'Neill said. "I told the players not to get involved in anything but to walk away. It was important for us to keep all our players on the pitch."

Yet such is the way of things that the removal of Ricksen - shown a second yellow card for a foul on Tom Boyd - proved the catalyst for the transformation of Rangers from an utterly toothless outfit into a team capable of offering at least a moderate threat. With Tugay Kerimoglu arriving to support Barry Ferguson in midfield, and with Neil McCann moving up to support Tore Andre Flo, Rangers began to induce regular bouts of discomfort in the Celtic defence, most notably after 62 minutes, when Konterman's opportunistic volley was headed off the line by Olivier Tebily, a second-half substitute for Johan Mjallby.

Ricksen had been replaced after 23 torrid minutes of the first meeting between the clubs this season, at Celtic Park back in August, when Celtic won 6-2. He had not featured in either Rangers' subsequent 5-1 revenge at Ibrox in November or the midweek cup defeat and Advocaat admitted that he had been aware of the risk involved in exposing him, pleading a lack of a suitable replacements. The Dutch defender's contribution was calamitous, his unwise attempt to steal ground at a throw-in leading to the decisive goal.

Everyone swipes the odd apple from a convenient tree. To take the whole orchard, however, invites trouble and Ricksen's attempt to gain half the length of the touchline left Dallas with no option other than to award the throw to Celtic. Henrik Larsson received the ball before exchanging short passes with Chris Sutton and racing into the area, where his half-blocked shot fell into the stride of Thompson, who was racing through on the blind side of the defence and beat Stefan Klos without fuss.

The three previous meetings between the teams this season produced 18 goals and a commensurate degree of mayhem but, although this latest match was never less than hectic, it was devoid of malevolence. On this occasion the emotions involved in an Old Firm encounter were expressed in a scruffiness matched by the pitch, upon which hamburger cartons and crisp packets blew hither and thither in the gusting wind, which also brought a second-half downpour to douse untoward passions.

Ramon Vega appeared to have given Celtic the lead after eight minutes with a header direct from Boyd's corner but the referee had spotted an offence in the goalmouth. O'Neill's formation, with Didier Agathe and Petta providing width on both wings, kept the visitors' defence stretched, also ensuring that Ricksen and Arthur Numan were unable to support Flo and Kenny Miller, who languished in isolation until the interval.

Rangers' efforts to push forward after half-time inevitably left gaps at the rear, offering Celtic several opportunities to kill the match off. The best of them came when Larsson darted on to a through-ball and drew the entire defence before squaring at speed to the unmarked Thompson, who fired over the bar from the edge of the area.

"This was a fantastic result for us," O'Neill said. "When they were down to 10 players they had to go for everything. We had a chance or two to wrap it up but the longer it went on the more you felt anything could happen. There's no triumphalism in the dressing room. It was a big win and it gives us a bit of a cushion. But there are plenty of games to go yet and plenty of mistakes to be made."

fields.headline: Europe round-up
fields.trailText: The Valencia coach Hector Cuper said his team's 3-0 win over Numancia at the weekend proved they were back to form before Wednesday's Champions League Group A clash with Manchester United.
fields.body:
The Valencia coach Hector Cuper said his team's 3-0 win over Numancia at the weekend proved they were back to form before Wednesday's Champions League Group A clash with Manchester United.

"The team has shown that it still has a lot to say this season," said Cuper after Saturday's match.

"It hasn't been an easy period, because of the recent results, and Numancia were tough opponents . . . but we worked well and took a vital and thoroughly deserved win."

The result was a boost for Cuper's team, who had not won in their four previous league outings.

Fine goals from the strikers Juan Sanchez and Diego Alonso and a penalty from Gaizka Mendieta sealed a comfortable victory against a battling Numancia side.

Last year's Champions League finalists will also be able to count on the presence of their record signing, the 21-year-old Argentine Pablo Aimar, who is finally available to make his debut.

Also in Spain, Stan Collymore's arrival as a second-half substitute saw Real Oviedo throw away their one-goal lead and lose 3-1 against 10-man Villarreal yesterday.

The controversial striker, who joined from Bradford last month, came on 12 minutes into the second half with Oviedo leading 1-0 thanks to a goal by Dordje Tomic in first-half injury-time.

But within 10 minutes of Collymore's arrival his side had leaked three goals. Strikes by Martin Palermo and Montana Jorge Lopez either side of a deflected free-kick by Unai turned the game around for the visitors.

Lyon , Arsenal's Champions League Group C opponents tomorrow, knocked St Etienne out of the French cup on penalties after drawing 1-1. Fifth-placed Lyon are currently the French league's draw specialists: their 1-1 game with Marseille last week was their 12th draw of the season.

Anderlecht warmed up for their Group D match with Leeds tomorrow with a 2-0 home win over Antwerp. The Brussels-based team extended their lead over Club Bruges at the top of the Belgian league to five points.

Meanwhile Roma , who entertain Liverpool in the Uefa Cup on Thursday, moved eight points clear at the top of Serie A after a 2-1 win at Bologna yesterday.

Roma, without the influential Francesco Totti, went in front in the 11th minute through a Gabriel Batistuta penalty. Bologna were down to 10 men in the 22nd minute after Jonatan Binotto was sent off for kicking Roma's Emerson while the Brazilian lay on the floor. Emerson then scored his first goal in Italy with a fine shot in the 34th minute.

Bologna pulled one back just after half-time through Emanuele Brioschi.

Second-placed Lazio had drawn with Atalanta 0-0 on Saturday, and Milan's inconsistent season continued with a 2-0 defeat at lowly Vicenza. Parma picked up a first win under their new coach Renzo Ulivieri with a sixth-minute goal from Sergio Conceicao giving them a 1-0 win at Fiorentina.

webTitle: Sunderland struck by the Tring thing

fields.headline: Sunderland struck by the Tring thing
fields.trailText: Should Sunderland's unlikely challenge for a Champions League berth peter out, Mackems may point accusing fingers less at their team's few shortcomings and more at an innocuous commuter town in Hertfordshire.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield  at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Should Sunderland's unlikely challenge for a Champions League berth peter out, Mackems may point accusing fingers less at their team's few shortcomings and more at an innocuous commuter town in Hertfordshire.

Ten days after Graham Poll failed to spot Andy Cole's handball in the build-up to the Manchester United goal that ended a nine-month unbeaten home record, along came Tring's other officiating Graham - Barber - to scupper a first home win against Liverpool in 43 years.

With three players reported for over-zealous celebrations and a ridiculous penalty award wrecking Sunderland's afternoon, at least a linesman ruled out a legitimate late goal from Robbie Fowler to spare them the injustice of a third successive league defeat.

Even one point was hard on Sunderland. After a prickly first half they were revitalised after the interval and, after only six minutes, Kevin Phillips advanced into the area only to be bulldozed off the ball by Sami Hyypia, prompting frenzied protests from the bench. Play continued and Gregory Vignal, the young French full-back who narrowly lost out to Barber for the "most torrid afternoon" award, scuffed his clearance against Stefan Schwarz. Don Hutchison gathered the loose ball and blasted past Sander Westerveld, who was unsighted by the dithering Frenchman.

Hutchison, who played 45 league games for Liverpool earlier in his career, tore off towards the north stand to celebrate, leaping over the advertising hoarding to bury himself in the ecstatic supporters. He was joined by Gavin McCann and Julio Arca; all three have been reported to the Football Association.

"You score a goal, celebrate and get reported," said Hutchison. "That sums him [Barber] up. The gaffer just laughed when he heard. When the ref came over I thought he was going to send me off, because I'd already been booked. When you score, particularly against your old club, you can't just put your finger up in the air and walk away."

The advantage gleaned, Sunderland could have put the match beyond their disjointed opponents. Arca, who arrived on an 18-hour flight from South America only on Thursday, lobbed just over the bar and Phillips's low shot was deflected wide by the scurrying Westerveld. But with the flashes of yellow cards growing ever more frequent, the penalty spared the visitors a pointless journey.

Michael Owen, on for the injured Steven Gerrard, spun and slid a precise pass through the centre of Sunderland's rearguard for Gary McAllister to chase. The 36-year-old Scot has been sufficiently reinvigorated at Liverpool to announce that he is willing to return to the international game after a two-year absence, but he failed to escape the defence fully and had his heel clipped by Stanislav Varga's desperate challenge while clearly outside the area. In keeping with the officials' baffling display, a penalty was awarded, although the outstanding Slovakian, booked nine minutes earlier, somehow escaped a red card.

"It was never a penalty," said Hutchison. "We asked Mr Barber to consult his linesman and he did, but he couldn't help him at all. It's going to be hard to challenge Liverpool for that third place now after this draw. They're a better side than us with better players." One of them, Jari Litmanen, sent Thomas Sorensen the wrong way from the spot to claim his first Liverpool goal since joining from Barcelona last month.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier, apparently unsighted over the penalty, could see enough from the dugout to rule Fowler's strike "a good goal". The draw kept his side a point clear of their hosts with a game in hand, although an ankle injury to Emile Heskey and Gerrard's sore groin left him fretting as Thursday's Uefa Cup trip to Roma looms large.

fields.headline: Kewell's half-hour offers hope
fields.trailText: Leeds United's prospects of further advancement in the Champions League depend largely upon the fate of one man: Harry Kewell. His fitness will remain dubious but when Anderlecht visit Elland Road tomorrow the importance of his presence can hardly be overstated.
fields.body:
Leeds United's prospects of further advancement in the Champions League depend largely upon the fate of one man: Harry Kewell. His fitness will remain dubious but when Anderlecht visit Elland Road tomorrow the importance of his presence can hardly be overstated.

During Kewell's absence Elland Road has become a land of phobias. David O'Leary's team of bright young things have begun to doubt their own potential, fifth place in the Premiership has been salvaged amid considerable mystified shaking of heads, and a crowd once as clamorous as any in the land now resounds too readily to the uneasy shuffle of feet.

It is doubtful whether there has been such a thunderous ovation at Elland Road all season as the one that greeted Kewell's rise from the substitutes' bench after little more than an hour of this frustrating goalless spectacle. In the Australian's absence his worth has become even more appreciated. He is not only Leeds's creative heart, he is the catalyst without which they barely function.

Derby defended pluckily and in depth, determined to atone for the five goals they had shipped in one half against Blackburn in a midweek FA Cup embarrassment. Taribo West and Horacio Carbonari were outstanding as they suppressed Mark Viduka and Robbie Keane.

Other than the surging runs of Olivier Dacourt and the occasional dead-ball menace of Ian Harte, Leeds were stricken by timidity. If Derby, threatened by relegation, could resist the best Leeds could muster, what price Anderlecht?

Kewell's sleek evasiveness down the left might, with better fortune, have made the question unnecessary as he inspired a second-half rally that deserved victory. As Jim Smith, Derby's manager, said: "If the danger was going to come from anywhere, it was going to come from him."

Had Danny Mills not been laid low overnight by a stomach bug, Kewell would not have made even the bench. "There is no way he can play 90 minutes against Anderlecht," O'Leary said. "But 30 minutes might do the trick. We are trying to ease him back in. Our game has lacked his individual brilliance."

Kewell has already made one abortive comeback after his achilles operation over the summer. This time one twisting run between Chris Riggott and Malcolm Christie suggested that his return might not be premature.

Also encouraging for Leeds, Rio Ferdinand is coming to terms with the tactical demands of a back four, but Derby still had three opportunities to steal victory; Christie had a goal disallowed for a foul on Nigel Martyn, then fired straight at the keeper, and Branko Strupar, another striker back from a long lay-off, headed over with two minutes left.

Derby seemed most at risk from the referee Jeff Winter, who insists upon games of honest endeavour and was properly intolerant of timewasting, play-acting or backchat. This clearly is the Winter of no dissent, as Shakespeare's Richard III almost put it.

fields.headline: Ehiogu proves his point
fields.trailText: The manager of the month was in philosophical mood on Saturday evening. "The journey of 90 minutes can take you many ways," he opined. "It's not much different from the whole season." Terry Venables might have been talking about his whole life.
fields.body:
The manager of the month was in philosophical mood on Saturday evening. "The journey of 90 minutes can take you many ways," he opined. "It's not much different from the whole season." Terry Venables might have been talking about his whole life.

For anyone hitching a ride on the latest Venables wagon, it has been safe rather than spectacular. Boring? "For everyone else maybe, but we'll keep on doing what we believe in," Venables retorted.

The so-called saviour of Teesside is not for the moment a visionary but a pragmatist thumbing tested textbooks. "So many times you think when you are drawing 'we can win this' and push people forward and you end up getting nothing. You can get carried away, but then the brain must come in. I've got to get habits in whereby we get results." The end - a four-point distance from the dread zone - justifies the means.

Ugo Ehiogu used to call Villa Park "my manor" but, now running with a different gang, the £8m defender was jeered from his first touch. His crushing header from a corner saw him wheel away, conspicuously cocking his left ear to his tormentors. Almost instantly came the defiant chant: "You'll never play for England."

He has, of course, if only once - under Venables. That was in China during the infamous run-up to Euro 96. "I have been disappointed he hasn't gone on to earn more," said the former England coach. "I'm happy he's on our side."

John Gregory, without a trace of grudge, complimented Ehiogu, even if Villa's manager thought his goal was as soft as the header from the 5ft 8in Steve Stone from another corner that briefly raised hopes of a first home league win for three months.

Villa Park waited 12 minutes for Juan Pablo Angel's first touch - a misplaced header - and another 63 for his overdue replacement by Dion Dublin.

It is not only the striker's lack of a goal - or even the hint of one - that made Angel look, in Gregory's words, "the most anxious I've seen him in his five games". Villa's manager revealed that his £9.5m record signing "is having a tough time off the field in particular. His wife has been very ill and his three-week-old baby has also been ill, and the player's living out of a suitcase".

Angel's wife Paula is in hospital undergoing tests after suffering abdominal pains, but the baby boy has now recovered after being affected by the long flight to England. Gregory also underlined the striker's professional problems. "It's not much different from the whole season." Terry Venables might have been talking about his whole life. For anyone hitching a ride on the latest Venables wagon, it has been safe rather than spectacular. Boring? "For everyone else maybe, but we'll keep on doing what we believe in," Venables retorted. The so-called saviour of Teesside is not for the moment a visionary but a pragmatist thumbing tested textbooks. "So many times you think when you are drawing 'we can win this' and push people forward and you end up getting nothing. You can get carried away, but then the brain must come in. I've got to get habits in whereby we get results." The end - a four-point distance from the dread zone - justifies the means. Ugo Ehiogu used to call Villa Park "my manor" but, now running with a different gang, the £8m defender was jeered from his first touch. His crushing header from a corner saw him wheel away, conspicuously cocking his left ear to his tormentors. Almost instantly came the defiant chant: "You'll never play for England." fields.headline: 'Pathetic' Magpies stung by Svensson
fields.trailText: The generosity with which Bobby Robson agreed to present Alan Curbishley with a crystal bowl to mark his 500th game in charge at Charlton was typical. So, unfortunately, was that with which his team feebly conceded the match that followed.
fields.body:
The generosity with which Bobby Robson agreed to present Alan Curbishley with a crystal bowl to mark his 500th game in charge at Charlton was typical. So, unfortunately, was that with which his team feebly conceded the match that followed.

Even worse, the Toon Army had travelled expecting nothing more. They have now made the long journey to London 24 times without seeing their side win, and the conversation on the train heading for King's Cross was instructive.

"Getting on for £100m this club has spent on players in the last five years, and for what? Nowt, man." Both maths and sentiment were spot on, and no doubt that unhappy supporter will be less than impressed by the fact the squad flew off for a short break in the Spanish sun last night.

They are unlikely to enjoy it, judging by Robson's furious reaction to their lack of commitment. "We were pathetic, abysmal," raged the splendidly passionate old manager. "I'm as angry as I've ever been with this team. When we competed in the second half and put our bloody foot in, like they did all match, we were fine. Too bloody late by then."

Charlton's players are going nowhere, at least not until the end of the season, despite reaching the magic 40 points after putting together a run of seven games without defeat, their best in the top division for half a century. Instead Curbishley intends to subject his team to a series of tests to establish how fit they are, leav ing them, as P G Wodehouse put it, if not exactly disgruntled, very far from being gruntled.

At least they should have no problems with the tests themselves, judging by the first half at least. Starting with three at the back gave his team a satisfying width going forward, and Newcastle, given their susceptibility to crosses, were quickly in trouble.

Richard Rufus and Mathias Svensson had already put good chances wide when, with half an hour gone, Shay Given pushed Sean Bartlett's crisp header on to the post.

The South African was again involved seven minutes later when the Addicks took a deserved lead. Nolberto Solano was favourite to win a loose ball in front of his own area but the Peruvian with a Greek passport pulled out as Claus Jensen steamed in.

The Dane, hugely influential throughout, found Chris Powell on the left, Bartlett headed the cross back across goal and Svensson volleyed past Given.

A minute later Svensson should have made it two but just before half-time Bartlett, who has scored against Newcastle for Zurich in the Uefa Cup, did so again. Seeing the linesman's flag, Newcastle stopped playing, allowing Svensson to cross. The referee Paul Durkin waved play on and the ball reached Bartlett, who turned it in. "Schoolboy stuff. You play to the whistle," fumed Robson. Durkin later confirmed the flag had been for a handball against the Newcastle defender Aaron Hughes.

After losing a two-goal lead against Spurs in the FA Cup in midweek no one at the Valley needed reminding the game was not over by a long chalk but Curbishley spent half-time reminding his players just the same. "I'd picked the same side, kept faith in them and I asked for something I didn't get against Spurs," he said.

The result, for the neutral at least, was a far less exciting second half. "It was a bit negative but the result justified the approach," said Curbishley.

Despite their relatively lofty league position, no one at Charlton is talking about Europe - well, other than as a holiday destination.

"We've got 11 games left and I've seen teams go 11 games without winning in this division," said Curbishley. It is unlikely to happen to Charlton; this run has been compiled despite a long injury list . Several of those injured, including the top scorer Jonatan Johansson and Mark Kinsella, are available again. Now that is strength in depth.

webTitle: No Yanks, get us a Jay or a Brewer

fields.headline: No Yanks, get us a Jay or a Brewer
fields.trailText: Friday
fields.body:
Friday

Rodney is on the mobe early doors.

"I have exciting news, boy," he says, when I finally finds the phone under the debris of what looks like a promising night. "You heard of the Man U Yankees deal? Becks gets to wear a baseball cap the wrong way round and their third base pitcher is given a replica shirt with his name on and somehow this makes the Man U share price jump 15 points?"

"So?" I says, not wholly chuffed to be woken at the crack for an update on movements in Rodders's share portfolio. "May I remind you, Rodders, you is my agent. What's in it for me?"

"Glad to see you thinking positive, boy. I has come up with, as I say, an innovative plan. We is going to cut to the chase: get you teamed up with a great individual American sportsman for mutual exploitation of image rights."

"You've lost me Rodds," I says, shaking a couple of cans in the hope that one of them might have a dribble of Red Bull. "Mutual exploitation? What poofter stuff and that?"

"No Dazz, I am talking image, merchandising, marketing, maximising revenues. Exciting times, boy."

"And which particular American sportsman has you got in mind, Rodds?"

"No names yet, boy. Don't fret, though. Plenty of pebbles on that particular beach."

Saturday

What is it with Gary Neville? As if looking like that Dot Cotton off of EastEnders and not knowing where your knives is kept when Becks comes to call is not enough, now the geezer is telling the world that the days of drink ing and boozing and aleing and that is over for the modern professional footballer. All he'll ever have, he says, is the odd alcopop in celebration of a job well done. Well, hark at Miss LaDiDa. Get back to playing girly netball with your sister and leave the manly stuff to them what has the hairs on their chest.

Sunday

That's it, never again. I am going on the Neville. We was all at it, a mass team-bonding session including Vic's new bird, the one he picked up after she done a streak across the Daihatsu during the Liverpool game and bent over to tie up her shoe laces just in front of where he was adjusting his shin pads. Apparently they saw eye to eye straight off. Quality woman.

Anyhow, Wattsy reckoned that a goalless home draw was an occasion what needed to be properly celebrated and we should restrict ourselves to alcopops like proper modern professionals. Trouble was the alcopop in question - Mad Dog, a contemporary blast of banana daiquiri and dandelion and burdock - was not a big success, and most of the party moved to Kosovan lager within the half-hour. Since the pop was being given out for nowt as a tester down at the Cross Bar, yours truly reckoned it would be churlish not to stick to it.

So I comes downstairs this morning wearing a bear's head (someone must have whipped it off the wall in the hunting-lodge area of the new multi-themed bar complex off of River Street). And I finds Rodders on the dog.

"Good news, boy. Our partners in New York think they may have come up with an appropriately tooled match for you. We've a choice of three American sportsmen: Roy "Psycho Bob" O'Grady, linebacker for the Des Moines Mad Axemen, Pablo "Fists of Steel" Gardinez from the Santa Monica Illegals basketball outfit and Darius "The Death" Warzinski of the Nebraska Skulls ice hockey side."

"I was hoping more for your Andre Agassi or Michael Jordan," I says.

"Hey, let's be realistic," he says. "There's only one sportsman over here what's got the level of image they would be interested in linking up with: Gary Neville."

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Hartlepool secured their eighth win in 10 unbeaten games, two goals from Kevin Henderson helping them to a 3-1 victory against another of the division's form teams, Blackpool , who had won their previous four matches.
fields.body:
Hartlepool secured their eighth win in 10 unbeaten games, two goals from Kevin Henderson helping them to a 3-1 victory against another of the division's form teams, Blackpool , who had won their previous four matches.

Another long run came to an end at Glanford Park where Scunthorpe , after seven games without a win, beat York 4-0. Guy Ipoua's two goals took his tally to 18 for the season and plunged the Minstermen, now with one point from six games, deep into relegation trouble.

Halifax stay a point ahead of them despite taking nothing from the most remarkable match of the weekend. The Shaymen took a 3-2 lead into the interval against Mansfield but Chris Greenacre's second goal of the day levelled the scores after 75 minutes. The Stags then secured a 4-3 victory through a Chris Clarke own goal in injury time.

Torquay eased away from the danger zone with a 2-1 win at Lincoln, only their second away victory of the campaign. Barnet are similarly unhappy on their travels - their 2-1 defeat at Kidderminster was their fourth in succession on the road.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Wigan stole into second place by winning 2-0 at Colchester while Walsall fell to a first home league defeat of the season.
fields.body:
Wigan stole into second place by winning 2-0 at Colchester while Walsall fell to a first home league defeat of the season.

Stefan Bidstrup - in the third minute - and Andy Liddell scored Wigan's goals while Bury won 2-1 at the Bescot. Walsall's Gabor Bukran was sent off just before the interval for violent conduct with the scores tied at 1-1; Steve Redmond's 69th minute strike sealed the points.

Alan Lee scored a hat-trick against Cambridge to keep Rotherham in touch with the leaders. His first, the fastest of the day, came after 78 seconds. The 3-0 scoreline went some way towards banishing the memories of a 6-1 rout at the Abbey Stadium in September.

Stoke had an even more comfortable afternoon at Peterborough , scoring after two minutes through Peter Thorne and completing a 4-0 win with goals from Bjarni Gudjonsson, Rikhardur Dadason and James O'Connor.

But the weekend's most impressive goalscoring performance came from Oldham ' s Carlo Corazzin. The striker, without a goal in his 10 previ ous games, scored four in his team's 5-1 rout of Wrexham , despite being 16 minutes before the finish.

Reading remain in the last play-off place after a 2-1 win at Brentford , their goals from Phil Parkinson and Sammy Igoe.

At the foot of the table, Oxford 's 2-1 home defeat to Wycombe - courtesy of Keith Ryan's injury-time strike - was their third in succession. They are now seven points clear at the bottom following Luton 's 1-0 win at Northampton in Lil Fuccillo's last match before Joe Kinnear takes over the team.

Another injury-time goal, from Neil Brisco, gave Port Vale a 2-1 win over Bournemouth that moved them out of the bottom four.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: It was a bad weekend for teams at both ends of the table. None of the top six won and nor did any of the bottom 10, with the bottom three playing to relegation form.
fields.body:
It was a bad weekend for teams at both ends of the table. None of the top six won and nor did any of the bottom 10, with the bottom three playing to relegation form.

Sheffield Wednesday 's season continues to deteriorate. On Saturday they played what a year ago would have been a Premiership fixture - at Wimbledon - and lost 4-1. Paul Jewell's side were 2-0 down after nine minutes and, though Efan Ekoku pulled one back against his old club, their own goalkeeper Marlon Beresford completed the scoring for Wimbledon.

Second-bottom QPR did even worse, somehow turning a respectable 0-0 half-time scoreline against Preston into a 5-0 defeat. "I was very, very embarrassed by their performance today," said Gerry Francis, the losing manager. Tranmere still occupy the third relegation spot after a 2-0 home defeat to Wolves .

Life at the top was little better. Second-placed Bolton came back from 2-0 down at home to Huddersfield to draw 2-2 courtesy of Per Frandsen's last-minute strike. "It was a great game from a spectator's point of view, but not from a manager's health point of view," said the Bolton boss Sam Allardyce.

It was a similar story at Vicarage Road, where Watford threw away a two-goal lead to draw 2-2 with Portsmouth . Two Tommy Smith strikes within four minutes had put the Hornets in the driving seat but Pompey were on level terms before half-time through Nigel Quashie and Steve Claridge.

Clinton Morrison's 18th goal of the season, scored in injury-time, gave Crystal Palace a 2-1 win over Burnley , their first at Turf Moor. Gillingham stay with them on 36 points after Marlon King's second-half strike secured a 1-0 victory over Grimsby at Priestfield.

webTitle: Veteran keeper denies Millwall unearned win

fields.headline: Veteran keeper denies Millwall unearned win
fields.trailText: Roger Freestone yesterday marked his 500th league appearance with a series of acrobatic saves in the final five minutes to deny the Second Division leaders Millwall what should have been a routine three points.
fields.body:
Roger Freestone yesterday marked his 500th league appearance with a series of acrobatic saves in the final five minutes to deny the Second Division leaders Millwall what should have been a routine three points.

Millwall showed more purpose, ideas and organisation than Swansea, who had won only one of their previous 16 league matches, but gradually found themselves worn down on a muddy pitch.

A heavy police presence made itself felt early in the second half after a bottle was thrown at a referee's assistant from the Millwall supporters' enclosure. The linesman, who had flagged for a Swansea free-kick disputed by Millwall, sought sanctuary in the middle of the pitch.

Order was quickly restored and threats by supporters to clamber into areas of the ground where they were not welcome faded as police in riot gear moved in; and the referee Phil Dowd then turned down Millwall claims for a penalty for handball.

The players did everything to ensure passions did not run high by producing an insipid 90 minutes of football in which both sides indulged in the long-ball game for long periods despite a swirling wind.

Midway through the second half Swansea produced their one move of quality. Damien Lacey's through-ball found David Romo on the right and the midfielder took the ball to the byline and crossed perfectly for Matthias Verschave, one of two loan signings by the Swans from Paris St-Germain last week, who was unmarked five yards from goal but sent his header over the bar.

Swansea have now taken only 10 out of a possible 51 league points. Millwall are in much better shape and nearly snatched a win at the end when Freestone, 32, saved from Richard Sadlier, Neil Harris and Marc Bircham but, despite forcing 16 corners, a draw was as much as they deserved.

webTitle: Threatened Tigers find something in their tanks

fields.headline: Threatened Tigers find something in their tanks
fields.trailText: They're changing locks at Boothferry Park.
fields.body:
They're changing locks at Boothferry Park.

David Lloyd is playing the shark.

Hull have defaulted on paying the rent.

The football club's life is one long lament.

If Lloyd, former owner of Hull City and still landlord, really wanted to make them pay, he would lock them in, not out. The ground - two sides tarted up, two run down - testifies to the grandiose ambition of one bad regime after another.

The latest departed last week as administrators were called in and the high court granted a 14-day stay of a winding-up order brought by customs and excise and the inland revenue. Hull's debts are around £2m.

None of this is new. Lloyd changes locks as often as others change socks and the manager Brian Little, who went there only last April, has been locked out of Wolves and Middlesbrough before.

In 1982, too, the club went into receivership. It was saved by Dr Death, the former wrestler Don Robinson, now chairman of Hull Kingston Rovers. He gave City six years in the old Second Division. They have since seen nothing of £20m worth of East Riding boys, including Nick Barmby, Paul Robinson and David Prutton.

Saturday's game may have been the last at the ground. In case it was, 8,782 turned up, more than 50% above average. They tossed coins into buckets, drops in the ocean of undying support. The Hull Daily Mail gave away 4,000 placards saying "Hull City AFC - We'll Support You Ever More". It hardly looked a lifetime commitment.

The ground's exterior is a corrugated patchwork of black and assorted amber that betrays cover-up and short-term residence. The club is under investigation by the Humberside police fraud squad, the Department of Trade and the Football Association. In 1999 a programme wrote: "The future is bright, the future is amber." Now it is only black.

Yet only two League clubs have not completed their post- war fixtures: Accrington (1962) and Aldershot (1992). By that progression it is not Hull's turn next but Arsenal in 2022. Mike Moore, joint administrator, is "pretty confident of sorting it out. We've seen five or six interested parties, including two or three serious players. I think we'll get at least one bid this week." The most promising might come from a group headed by Tom Belton, whose ousting as chairman in 1999 led to the investigations. He retains a 30% shareholding. A Tigers Co-operative, boasting 1,100 members, is interested too.

The serious players, those on the field, might also "get something from today," said Moore. Like Little and other staff, they have not been paid for five weeks and fall out of contract on Wednesday, when they would be available on free transfers. Last week they were allegedly the club's assets, temporarily frozen. The thaw was in time for them to show it.

The distraction did no harm to spirit, which gratified Little. "If I have to drive them to a club who'll pay them, I'll do it; that's humane. We talk about the problems every day, then get on with training hard. It's all we can do. Deep down we just want to play football.

"The result was not the most important thing today but it was a good day's work on a mucky day. A lot of bad things have been done at this club but we are looking for one conversation that gives us a chance to go on further." They are only three places off the play-offs.

Hull had no trouble picking out Kevin Francis, their lighthouse of a striker, though he was not wearing pink with yellow spots, and Rodney Rowe got the goal, their first at home for 5 hours, though Lloyd never moved the goalposts. The questions now are whether it is their last and whether Kroll Buchler Phillips get the administrator of the month award.

fields.headline: New Blade cuts family ties
fields.trailText: Paul Peschisolido insists that he and his wife do not take football home with them. Chances are that this last weekend was an exception. Mrs Peschisolido, aka Birmingham City's managing director Karren Brady, was not at Bramall Lane to watch her husband torment her club on his home debut for the Blades. The conversation over dinner on Saturday night can only be left to the imagination.
fields.body:
Paul Peschisolido insists that he and his wife do not take football home with them. Chances are that this last weekend was an exception. Mrs Peschisolido, aka Birmingham City's managing director Karren Brady, was not at Bramall Lane to watch her husband torment her club on his home debut for the Blades. The conversation over dinner on Saturday night can only be left to the imagination.

The 29-year-old Canadian striker, on loan from the champions-in-waiting Fulham until the end of the season, has wasted little time in endearing himself to the hardy folk of South Yorkshire.

Now his aim is to show Fulham's manager Jean Tigana just what he is missing. Having tormented one former club all afternoon, the former Blues favourite revealed that he is also keen to consign Fulham to the past as well.

"It's pretty much over for me there," he admitted. "I haven't played and it's clear that I don't figure in the manager's plans. Now I would like to do well here, score some goals and make the move a permanent one. The play-offs are still a possibility for United this season."

Peschisolido was one of three former Birmingham players in the Blades' front line. And, with both Paul Devlin and Peter Ndlovu providing the pace down the flanks, the Worthington Cup finalists were cruelly exposed at the back.

Shaun Murphy prodded home the first on 31 minutes and then Devlin converted a penalty after Nicky Eaden's handball had prevented Peschisolido from turning in the area. The Canadian applied the killer touch himself midway through the second half. Geoff Horsfield did pull one back for City two minutes from time but it was purely academic.

Blues' manager Trevor Fran cis said: "This was a difficult game for us with Cardiff on the horizon. Had anyone been sent off then they would have missed out on what will probably be the biggest day of their careers."

The United manager Neil Warnock, meanwhile, was delighted with his new-look team. Peschisolido and Ndlovu appear to have transformed a hard-working yet often pedestrian side into an attack-minded unit thriving on the full width of the pitch.

"I think it was D-Day for us," said Warnock, smiling. "We had to win to keep in touch with a play-off place. But I will have to be careful. I thought we were entertaining and that won't be good for my reputation."

Much of the Blades' cutting edge was provided by the quicksilver Peschisolido. And, although he may have looked like the cat who got the cream, he was honest enough to confess that his immediate destination from Sheffield on Saturday evening would be the doghouse.

fields.headline: Miller saves draw praise
fields.trailText: Nigel Spackman's first two decisions when he took over at Barnsley were to impose a stricter fitness programme and introduce the passing game, a style which was never a priority during the time of his predecessor Dave Bassett. Graft and craft, then, are the new watchwords at Oakwell and both qualities were evident as they held the top scorers in the English leagues - Jean Tigana's team have scored 14 more than the best of their top-six rivals - and denied them a 10th away win.
fields.body:
Nigel Spackman's first two decisions when he took over at Barnsley were to impose a stricter fitness programme and introduce the passing game, a style which was never a priority during the time of his predecessor Dave Bassett. Graft and craft, then, are the new watchwords at Oakwell and both qualities were evident as they held the top scorers in the English leagues - Jean Tigana's team have scored 14 more than the best of their top-six rivals - and denied them a 10th away win.

Barnsley pushed the ball around from the back, like Fulham, and ran marathons to close down the leaders. The home fans were reminded of the days when they could chant "It's just like watching Brazil" under Danny Wilson.

Add to that some exceptional stops by Kevin Miller that, for only the second time, prevented Fulham scoring away from Craven Cottage in the league, and it might be argued that Barnsley merited a point.

At 31, Miller has been around - you could say he has had more clubs than Johnny Miller - but cannot have made many saves better than the two that kept Fulham out as they poured on the pressure.

He parried close-in headers from Sean Davis on the hour and his own defender Steve Chettle in the 78th minute to guarantee a point.

Then he predicted that the influence of the new manager would keep them in the First Division this season. Already a fitness coach, Ed Baronowski, and a new first-team coach, Derek Fazackerley, have been appointed. And Ian Rush has arrived to help the strikers.

Miller said: "We've had to work hard on our fitness but it will help us battle right to the end. In the last two games we've taken a point at Blackburn and now Fulham and kept clean sheets, and if we play like that we won't have to worry about staying up.

"I was pleased with my performance but I'm fed up with saving great headers from our defenders; I had to do it last week as well."

Miller even prompted praise from his opposite number, Northern Ireland's Maik Taylor. "Kevin made two fantastic saves . . . he's one of the best in the league and he's won the point for them."

A point was also a good result for Tigana's team, with none of the top six winning. "The other results have gone for us," added Taylor. "We're disappointed at not winning because, the way things are going, we're looking to win every time. Spackman has got Barnsley well organised and they made it difficult and invited us to break them down, but they had to work hard to do it and tired in the last 15 minutes. We had chances then."

Spackman's game plan - four at the back, five in midfield and one up to stifle Fulham and hit them on the break, worked, though the dangerous Luis Boa Morte hit a post and was inches away from a winner.

Barnsley were unfortunate not to be awarded a penalty when Louis Saha climbed all over Neil Shipperley, and Lee Jones wasted a late, rare chance.

fields.headline: Forest find a spark
fields.trailText: The 15 miles from Derby to Nottingham seemed harmless enough but Blackburn found crossing the Trent a bridge too far on Saturday. Despite battering the Rams 5-2 and welcoming Eyal Berkovic on loan from Celtic last week, Rovers suffered a first defeat in 13 outings.
fields.byline: Matthew Hancock at the City Ground
fields.body:
The 15 miles from Derby to Nottingham seemed harmless enough but Blackburn found crossing the Trent a bridge too far on Saturday. Despite battering the Rams 5-2 and welcoming Eyal Berkovic on loan from Celtic last week, Rovers suffered a first defeat in 13 outings.

The Forest fire that singed them took a long time to get going. An ugly rumble in midfield before half-time made way for a coruscating second period, capped by two superb free-kicks from Chris Bart-Williams.

The first, a 20-yarder, oozed perfection and curled in beyond the reach of Brad Friedel in the Blackburn goal. Fourteen minutes later the Forest captain swung one in from the left and the 25-year-old defender Christian Edwards led a surge at the back post to nod in only the sixth league goal of his career. Matt Jansen's late strike, though classy in its right-foot left-foot execution, salvaged pride alone.

"Who needs a 20-goal striker when you've got a 20-goal sweeper, eh?" grinned Forest's manager, David Platt, whose team had not won since New Year's Day but are again threatening Birmingham in the final play-off place.

"I believe that we are one of the top six sides in the division," he added, "and if we do get into the play-offs we'll come from the back of the pack and our form will be right to get in."

The second half was rousing stuff though, as the Blackburn boss Graeme Souness pointed out, Freidel had little to do in goal all afternoon except twice hoof the ball back to the halfway line in disgust. Rovers might consider defeat here a blip; Platt definitely does.

"I still believe Blackburn will be the other automatically promoted side along with Fulham," he said. "I look at the resources they have got and know they can cope with any injuries and suspensions that will come."

Any side which lists Craig Short, Jansen, Berkovic and Keith Gillespie on the bench, as Rovers did, certainly has the squad for an arduous promotion campaign. With his side trailing 1-0, Berkovic sprang into competitive action for only the fifth time this season - the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill had not so much left him out in the cold as locked him in the freezer - and received a standing ovation from the away support for his troubles. He had a quiet time of it, apart from the home fans' relieved jeer when his defence-splitting pass proved an

attack-splitting one too and the ball bobbled tamely out for a goal-kick.

Souness bore defeat with good grace and reflected: "We've been punched on the nose today; let's see what reaction we get from that."

Two spicy portions of Lancashire hotpot are on the menu in the next 11 days -Bolton lie in wait in both Cup and league - while Forest travel to Fulham on Saturday with Platt wisely keeping his feet on the ground.

"I'm never happy," he said. "It's something that served me well as a player. It drives you on to strive for perfection in the knowledge that you're never going to get that. The moment you're content with what you've got is the moment you start going backwards."

He need not worry. The team huddle before the match and the clenched fists afterwards told of a spirited team moving in the right direction.

webTitle: Cork fails to keep it bottled up

fields.headline: Cork fails to keep it bottled up
fields.trailText: Dinner was on Alan Cork on Saturday night. He and Micky Adams, who have worked together at Fulham, Swansea and Brighton, have a long-standing arrangement: loser pays.
fields.body:
Dinner was on Alan Cork on Saturday night. He and Micky Adams, who have worked together at Fulham, Swansea and Brighton, have a long-standing arrangement: loser pays.

It is likely to be an expensive day for Cork. The Cardiff manager, upset particularly by Gavin Gordon's sending-off 10 minutes from time, invited retribution from the FA when he laid into the referee, Paul Armstrong, publically doubting his honesty, courage and competence. The final bill should be known this week.

Gordon had tangled with Mark Cartwright, the Brighton goalkeeper, in going for a high ball. Cartwright went down - he said afterwards that he had been caught round the ear - and Paul Watson remonstrated with the big striker, then suddenly fell backwards over his goalkeeper. Armstrong consulted a linesman, then showed the red card.

"The fans start shouting and the referee bottled it as usual," Cork said. "The referee obviously wasn't capable of refereeing this match today."

If, as Armstrong said and Cork believed, Gordon was sent off for his challenge on the goalkeeper, the decision was indeed a poor one. The striker had his back to Cartwright and his eye on the ball. It looked an entirely honest attempt at a header. It was scarcely worthy of a free-kick. Yet Cardiff had been warned when Armstrong booked Leo Fortune-West for a similar challenge in the first half. "It's hard to work out," Cork said. "Maybe it's because he's 6ft 4in and black."

Gordon's first name is actually Kenyatta, after one of the heroes of the liberation movement. The struggle goes on, of course, but Cork might have been wiser to stay out of it. He has more pressing tasks, which he should be better qualified to deal with.

On Saturday he appeared to have picked an excess of central defenders - three started and two more were on the bench - for the task of containing Brighton's single striker, the prolific 20-year-old Bobby Zamora. None of them could be blamed for the goal, which was set up by Matt Brazier's misplaced pass.

Cardiff had no coherent response, but they eventually made a fight of it when Zamora went off with a kick on the ankle. "For 70 minutes I was delighted," said Adams, who will be the best man at Cork's wedding this summer.

It was a scrappy, physical, desperate game appropriate to a poorly refereed Third Division promotion tussle played in wind and rain, but Brighton could not complain. The damage to Zamora did not appear lasting. The repaired pitch stood up sturdily to the downpour. And the best man won.

fields.headline: A difference of interest
fields.standfirst: The Champions League and Uefa Cup return this week with English clubs' hopes still high. But demands for more money could transform the European game as we know it, reports  Vivek Chaudhary
fields.trailText: The Champions League and Uefa Cup return this week with English clubs' hopes still high. But demands for more money could transform the European game as we know it, reports Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
European competition returns to the football calendar this week with the resumption of the Champions League and the Uefa Cup. Manchester United, Arsenal, Leeds United and Liverpool are all guaranteed further continental excursions this spring, but the future shape of the European club competitions is anything but predictable as the big clubs increasingly assert their power.

A two-day meeting of 70 of Europe's leading clubs at Uefa's headquarters in Nyon, Switzerland, was largely concerned with tinkering with the format of the two European club competitions, but around the Uefa water cooler the talk was of superleagues and breakaways. Underlying the whole gathering was the tension between Uefa, which is trying to safeguard the integrity of its competitions for all teams, and the continent's richest clubs, who are keen to guarantee the income that regular meetings with other European powerhouses ensures.

The main resolution from the Nyon meeting, which included representatives of Manchester United, Arsenal, Chelsea, Leeds and Liverpool, was that the Uefa Cup should in future have a group stage, guaranteeing more games to those clubs that have missed out on the Champions League. The clubs resolved that the structure of the premier competition itself should remain unchanged for the time being, despite opposition from Uefa; concerns have been raised that the two initial group stages are boring and are driving fans away, and Uefa's general secretary Gerhard Aigner has promised to examine its format.

"There is a feeling that there is too much football on television and this leads to saturation coverage," said Aigner. "Also, I feel that many fans have trouble following two league structures, one in the Champions League and the other in their own domestic league. The Champions League television contract ends in 2003 and we need to have a serious examination of the competition before then. But guaranteed places for a number of the continent's top clubs is not the way forward."

The latter view is not one shared by Barcelona, to name just one big club. The Catalan giants, who have in the past found qualification to the Champions League troublesome, want to see guaranteed entry into the competition for a fixed three-year period and for the group-stage matches to be preserved. Others such as Bayern Munich want to see fewer group-stage matches and an emphasis on knockout football.

Both clubs are members of the so-called G14, the group of 14 rich European clubs which includes Arsenal, Manchester United and Liverpool. The current distended Champions League structure is the product of an earlier move by leading clubs to split from Uefa and form their own competition. Likewise Thomas Kurth, the G14's new general manager, insists that the organisation has no intention of challenging Uefa's power or threatening a breakaway league. "We have not even formally opened our offices yet," he said. "It is just about a group of clubs with a common economic interest coming together."

With negotiations for a new Champions League television contract due to begin by the end of this year, many within football feel that the G14 will have a big say.

Uefa insists that it is not too concerned. Its communications director Mike Lee said: "The G14 have made it clear to us that they are not interested in a separate competition. At the moment, though, the biggest impediment to a breakaway may be disunity within the G14 itself, as evidenced by the disagreement between Barcelona and Bayern Munich.

At the end of the first day in Nyon, representatives of 13 clubs proposing the Atlantic League met privately to discuss their proposal. Led by Peter Fossen, general manager of PSV, they have been warned by Uefa that they will be kicked out by the European body if they attempt to leave their domestic leagues and form a pan-European weekly competition.

Bu the threat has not dented their resolve. Fossen claims that the European tide is too strong to turn back and that cross-border leagues are an inevitability in the future landscape of the game.

"Uefa has to realise that we are living in a different environment; we are within a European community," he said. "The mindset of the organisation has to change and it has to come to terms with the fact that a cross-border European league is going to become a reality. The entire continent is changing and football must change with it."

European Cup winners 1956, 1957, 1958, 1959, 1960, 1966, 1998, 2000

Affiliation G14

Status One of Europe's mega-clubs, who combine huge turnover with seemingly permanent success on the field. The disaggregation of the Spanish TV market, meaning that clubs may sell their rights individually, should make Real Madrid the club with the largest turnover in Europe in the next few years.

They want to be certain of playing the top sides in Europe every year and G14 are threatening to set up their own competition if Uefa does not give the clubs an even bigger share of Champions League revenue (currently 75%) or guarantee access to the latter stages for the biggest clubs. Real Madrid made £18m by winning the Champions League last year but they believe the competition's television rights are under-sold and that clubs could make more by selling them individually.

PSV Eindhoven

Winners 1988

Affiliation G14 and Atlantic League

Status One of the big three of Dutch football and the current champions, though times have been thinner since their golden age of the late 80s and early 90s. Financially sound through the backing of Philips corporation, they have not reached even the quarter-finals of the European Cup since 1990.

Ambitions "The big clubs in the smaller leagues can no longer guarantee their places in the Champions League or compete with the richer clubs from countries like England, Spain and Italy," argues the PSV director Peter Fossen. As a result, PSV have become prime movers behind the Atlantic League. That also suggests they are trying to hedge their bets. Although part of G14 as well, PSV are perhaps not certain they will share fully in any further largesse that can be extracted from Uefa.

Red Star

Belgrade

Winners 1991

Affiliation None

Status Once one of Europe's perennial contenders, Red Star are in no state to compete with the money-machines of the west any more. The last team from eastern Europe to win the European Cup, they have suffered grievously from the break-up of Yugoslavia, but also from their lack of TV appeal in west European markets. Like Romania's Steaua Bucharest, also former winners, they form no part of G14's plans and rely on Uefa to funnel at least a small part of the Champions League revenue their way.

Thanks to their long absence from Europe the Yugoslavs have to enter the Champions League at the first qualifying round stage, with the champions of countries such as Luxembourg and Malta. Red Star dream of the days when they rivalled Manchester United but at the moment they would probably settle for regular encounters with Rapid Vienna.

webTitle: United find the vein for Spain

fields.headline: United find the vein for Spain
fields.standfirst: The champions enjoy a true test as they pick up the pace for Europe and their return to Valencia
fields.trailText: Claims from Spain that Manchester United colluded with Valencia last March to produce the scoreless draw that guaranteed each a place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League are unlikely to disturb the concentration of Sir Alex Ferguson's players as they prepare to pick up the thread of their latest pursuit of the European Cup back at the Mestalla Stadium on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Claims from Spain that Manchester United colluded with Valencia last March to produce the scoreless draw that guaranteed each a place in the quarter-finals of the Champions League are unlikely to disturb the concentration of Sir Alex Ferguson's players as they prepare to pick up the thread of their latest pursuit of the European Cup back at the Mestalla Stadium on Wednesday.

Perhaps Miguel Angel Angulo seriously believes that, as he has announced on a Spanish website, the clubs signed a non-aggression pact. If so the Valencia striker appears to have forgotten the series of outstanding saves by a limping Mark Bosnich in that game which denied his team victory, including at least one from Angulo himself, not to mention Jocelyn Angloma hitting a post from 25 yards.

When Angulo's dodgy dotcom comments were relayed to Ferguson after Saturday's 1-1 draw with Chelsea at Stamford Bridge the United manager scarcely raised an eyebrow. He knew nothing about the allegation and therefore could say nothing. In any event, Uefa has already said that there is no case to answer.

For United this sort of stuff is all so much water under the bridge. For Ferguson what was more to the point was the way his team had performed with so much water falling over the Bridge.

If Manchester United can reproduce in Valencia this week the quality of passing and movement which enabled them to dominate Chelsea for much of a game that defied the saturated conditions to provide entertaining, intelligent football from both sides, then they should not lose.

In the first round of this season's Champions League United's form away from Old Trafford was poor. But now, with Jaap Stam fit, Roy Keane in sublime form and Ryan Giggs and David Beckham still the masters of their respective crafts, it will be a major surprise if they do not again make the knockout stage.

It was a good time to meet a Chelsea side retaining fond memories not only of the 5-0 drubbing they gave the champions at Stamford Bridge last season but also their recovery, in Claudio Ranieri's inaugural game as coach, to force a 3-3 draw at Old Trafford last September after being 3-1 down at half-time.

Even with a 15-point (now 13-point) lead at the top of the Premiership Ferguson had little inclination to rest players, although he did keep Teddy Sheringham, his leading scorer, on the bench and Fabien Barthez was not risked because of a troublesome hamstring. United responded with a performance that never suggested their minds were elsewhere, so much so in fact that Chelsea spent the last 20 minutes trapped in their own half.

So maybe it was prescience that persuaded Ranieri to withdraw Jesper Gronkjaer, his most likely match-winner, immediately after Andy Cole had brought the scores level midway through the second half. Or maybe replacing Gronkjaer with Slavisa Jokanovic, a defensive midfielder, was just Italian prudence.

Either way the quick, strong Dane was beginning to go past Gary Neville with sufficient ease to give Ranieri's attack the edge that United, for all their possession, were struggling to achieve. In the opening minute of the second half Gronkjaer swept through the defence before leaving Jimmy Hasselbaink with just Raimond van der Gouw to beat from close range. Somehow Mikael Silvestre saved United with an excellent covering tackle, and in that moment Chelsea's best chance of victory disappeared.

That they had had a chance at all was down to a rare moment of aberration by Paul Scholes, who after Stam had cleared the ball tried to nod it back to the goalkeeper but instead set up Hasselbaink, lingering in the penalty area, for a simple header past Van der Gouw.

Just before the hour Van der Gouw messed around with a back pass to the extent that he became trapped near a corner flag by Gianfranco Zola, who then gained possession and found the net from a tight angle only to find the linesman had given a throw-in. Nevertheless United probably still said a prayer for the wellbeing of Barthez's hamstring.

They avoided a third Premiership defeat when Andy Cole finally escaped the diligent marking of John Terry and reached a through-pass from Giggs ahead of Marcel Desailly to slip the ball past Carlo Cudicini. "Our best performance for two weeks," said Ferguson, for whom there will never be any time like the present.

fields.headline: Noose tightens on Bradford
fields.trailText: Bradford will cling to the faint hope of survival until their relegation is mathematically confirmed but, when the manager and captain both admit that the team is simply not good enough, it suggests that their belief is finally ebbing away.
fields.body:
Bradford will cling to the faint hope of survival until their relegation is mathematically confirmed but, when the manager and captain both admit that the team is simply not good enough, it suggests that their belief is finally ebbing away.

As a final throw of the dice, Jim Jefferies is to take his side away to Portugal in an attempt to revive waning spirits and flagging resolve. After their 16th defeat of the season and their sixth consecutive game without scoring, searching for a miracle cure in Lourdes may be more appropriate.

"The final ball has not been good enough to score or even create a chance," Jefferies said. Whither Benito Carbone? The Italian, unavailable through injury on Saturday, may yet be hauled off the transfer list to add zest and imagination to Bradford's attack before he heads to Italy in the summer.

An 11-point gap to safety is already looking insurmountable, however; and, even if Car bone is given the chance, it is difficult to see who could link up with him to score the goals City so desperately need.

With the exception of a Dean Windass header after 21 minutes, which forced Southampton's keeper Paul Jones into his only save of the afternoon, Bradford's threat was so minimal that it made Jefferies' claim afterwards that he had sent out an attack-minded team with a view to winning the game look faintly ridiculous.

Yet, as the Scot, who replaced Chris Hutchings in November, pointed out, "the writing was on the wall before I came and basically we haven't been good enough". His captain Stuart McCall agreed that the chances of staying up to enjoy a third season in the Premiership are slim.

"We need to win at least seven games to stay up and we have only won three all season, so it's looking very difficult," McCall said. "Last season we managed to stay up because there were a couple of teams below us who struggled even more, but it's looking tough now because the gap keeps widening."

For Southampton this is also true. But, for once, it is the relegation zone they are stretching away from. Their advance this season has been built on improving the defence and this was their sixth successive clean sheet at home in the league.

As with Bradford, scoring has proved the more difficult problem to solve although Glenn Hoddle was encouraged that James Beattie and Marian Pahars both ended barren spells, albeit of differing lengths, on Saturday.

When Pahars headed back across Bradford's keeper Gary Walsh from a Jo Tessem cross to make it 1-0 after an hour, it was his first goal since September. Three minutes later Beattie beat Robert Molenaar to the near post to guide home a cross from Dan Petrescu for his first league goal of the year.

Hoddle later talked up the international potential of Beattie and the defenders Wayne Bridge and Dean Richards. He is anxious, though, that the club does not get carried away with the unfamiliar feeling of security and maintained his safety first, enjoyment later policy.

Safety at any time would suit Jefferies, yet it is already almost out of reach this season.

fields.headline: Lifeless Leicester squeezed out
fields.trailText: It was shortly before half-time that Peter Taylor decided there was a need for more than just the occasional shake of the head. So after watching, for the umpteenth time, one of his charges deliver the sort of lazy pass that has callous indifference written all over it, the Leicester manager eased himself out of his seat in the directors' box and headed for the touchline.
fields.body:
It was shortly before half-time that Peter Taylor decided there was a need for more than just the occasional shake of the head. So after watching, for the umpteenth time, one of his charges deliver the sort of lazy pass that has callous indifference written all over it, the Leicester manager eased himself out of his seat in the directors' box and headed for the touchline.

His team were performing so ineptly that the prospect of defeat had been replaced by the distinct possibility of utter embarrassment.

Though nobody could ever accuse Leicester of promoting flair as a virtue, there is a certain compelling orderliness to a team who, slowly but surely, are coming to mirror the methodical demeanour of their manager. Even their critics would concede that they are powerful and unyielding at the back, disciplined in midfield and boast players of cunning and robust enthusiasm up front.

Well, normally. On Saturday, in the 68 minutes before Dean Sturridge headed their first chance of the afternoon wide of the mark, they were a shambles.

"The manager is trying to change things but it'll take time," said their centre-back Gerry Taggart. "He could have come to this club and simply carried on with Martin O'Neill's methods, but he hasn't."

Everton, having logged only one win in their previous 11 Premiership outings, could hardly believe their good fortune. Even so, it was to their immense credit that they summoned up sufficient courage to grab the game by its throat and apply sufficient pressure to squeeze the life out of their opponents.

That Leicester seemed capable of salvaging the most improbable of draws in the frantic, dying moments says much about the pressure from under which Everton are currently attempting to crawl. Having lost the magnificent Richard Gough to injury just after the half-hour, the home team looked as though they might undermine their highly impressive early work.

For 45 minutes Everton had been almost majestic, passing, moving and combining well. They even had a cutting edge, Francis Jeffers marking his first senior start in six months with a smartly taken goal on eight minutes and Kevin Campbell finding the bottom corner as the interval beckoned.

Taylor was not best pleased and, by throwing on the age- ing but still gloriously stylish Roberto Mancini he did at least restore a competitive edge to affairs.

Sturridge ensured scouse nails would be gnawed to the quick with an opportunist strike on 79 minutes, but Everton's commendably dogged resistance removed the threat of a travesty.

"We were better in the second half and might even have taken a point," said Taylor, drawing consolation where, in truth, there was none to be had.

Though nobody could ever accuse Leicester of promoting flair as a virtue, there is a certain compelling orderliness to a team who, slowly but surely, are coming to mirror the methodical demeanour of their manager. Even their critics would concede that they are powerful and unyielding at the back, disciplined in midfield and boast players of cunning and robust enthusiasm up front. Well, normally. On Saturday, in the 68 minutes before Dean Sturridge headed their first chance of the afternoon wide of the mark, they were a shambles. "The manager is trying to change things but it'll take time," said their centre-back Gerry Taggart. "He could have come to this club and simply carried on with Martin O'Neill's methods, but he hasn't." Everton, having logged only one win in their previous 11 Premiership outings, could hardly believe their good fortune. Even so, it was to their immense credit that they summoned up sufficient courage to grab the game by its throat and apply sufficient pressure to squeeze the life out of their opponents. That Leicester seemed capable of salvaging the most improbable of draws in the frantic, dying moments says much about the pressure from under which Everton are currently attempting to crawl. Having lost the magnificent Richard Gough to injury just after the half-hour, the home team looked as though they might undermine their highly impressive early work. For 45 minutes Everton had been almost majestic, passing, moving and combining well. They even had a cutting edge, Francis Jeffers marking his first senior start in six months with a smartly taken goal on eight minutes and Kevin Campbell finding the bottom corner as the interval beckoned. Taylor was not best pleased and, by throwing on the age- ing but still gloriously stylish Roberto Mancini he did at least restore a competitive edge to affairs. Sturridge ensured scouse nails would be gnawed to the quick with an opportunist strike on 79 minutes, but Everton's commendably dogged resistance removed the threat of a travesty. "We were better in the second half and might even have taken a point," said Taylor, drawing consolation where, in truth, there was none to be had.

webTitle: Fair stands the win for France

fields.headline: Fair stands the win for France
fields.trailText: On the day that plans were published showing how Highbury will look when it is redeveloped as an upmarket housing estate in four years' time, Arsenal continued the rebuilding of their season.
fields.body:
On the day that plans were published showing how Highbury will look when it is redeveloped as an upmarket housing estate in four years' time, Arsenal continued the rebuilding of their season.

After a shaky December and January Arsène Wenger's players notched up their third win in a row to re-establish their hold on second place in the Premiership and provide a boost in confidence before the res- umption of Champions League duties in Lyon tomorrow.

The foundation of Arsenal's improvement has been the defence, which has kept four consecutive clean sheets, a run coinciding with the return of David Seaman in goal and Tony Adams to his injury-free best.

It has long been suggested that the Gunners' back line should be served with a preservation order similar to that which protects two other Highbury monuments, the east and west stands. But time is catching up on all three edifices and transformation is just around the corner. Thankfully for the traditionalists, the changes are being made with sympathy and intelligence.

When the club's proposed move to nearby Ashburton Grove goes through, the two listed stands at Highbury will be transformed into luxury flats overlooking flowers and conifers in a landscaped garden where once they afforded the Arsenal faithful a view of Dennis Bergkamp planting free-kicks past rooted keepers.

Similarly Wenger is making sure that the club's defensive traditions remain intact. "To find another Tony Adams or Martin Keown is impossible," the Arsenal manager admits. "So I've brought in three or four defenders to work with and see who comes through."

The favourite is Igor Stepanovs, presently standing in for the injured Keown and maturing with every game. "Playing with Tony can add five years to your career," Wenger, said, "and Igor is learning from him all the time. There is more aggression to his game now and he has shown more consistency in the air without compromising his passing. And he never panics under pressure."

Unfortunately for Wenger the Latvian is cup-tied for tomorrow's game. With Keown and Silvinho also out, that poses a problem. Wenger is resting Bergkamp but will have Patrick Vieira back from suspension and Thierry Henry back from the doldrums.

Since scoring 13 league goals before Christmas the Frenchman has been dogged by an ankle injury and has struggled to find the net. But on 67 minutes he latched on to Bergkamp's pass and speared the ball coolly past Richard Wright for a goal that provided him with a timely pick-me-up and sweet-passing Arsenal with another timely win.

Ipswich, who saw Gary Croft join a lengthening injury list, avoided a heavier defeat only because of a string of stunning saves by Wright, no doubt noted by the watching Tord Grip. They looked like scoring only once, when Marcus Stewart got the ball caught under his foot with an open goal beckoning. They have now lost five games on the trot.

Things are not that bad for Arsenal but they do know their championship hopes are dead for this season. "As far as the title is concerned, we have had it," admits the striker Sylvain Wiltord. But he wants Arsenal to learn from that. "Manchester United have been stronger than us. They have a consistent team that plays the same way all the time, and that is something we should give some thought to."

Meanwhile Arsenal's upcoming European ties, sandwiched between games against Chelsea and United, will test the strength of the rebuilding work to date.

 An investigation into the death of Niccolo Galli , a 17-year-old Arsenal defender on loan at Bologna, has been ordered after he was killed in a scooter accident on Friday.
