webTitle: Bad luck of being taken for a goat

fields.headline: Bad luck of being taken for a goat
fields.trailText: For the time being it is difficult to know which is the more apt: that Tottenham invariably win the FA Cup when the year ends in 1 or that their Premiership form is guaranteed to induce tedium whenever the day ends in "y".
fields.body:
For the time being it is difficult to know which is the more apt: that Tottenham invariably win the FA Cup when the year ends in 1 or that their Premiership form is guaranteed to induce tedium whenever the day ends in "y".

This was the incapable blundering into the incoherent and, though there was less than a cigarette paper between which team fitted which category, the only surprise was that George Graham should be denied the glory of pontificating about five scoreless Premiership draws in numbing succession.

Instead, in the face of Machiavellian rumours that the club's prospective owners Enic plan to make Glenn Hoddle a born-again Spur, Sergei Rebrov's late and wholly unexpected winner gave the Tottenham manager the chance to get his retaliation in first.

It was an opportunity he did not squander. There were far too many divisive factions behind the scenes, he complained, and far too many supporters still blinded by his "Arsenal thing". It was stirring stuff or it was until that sticky juncture when talk got round to the on-field torpor. "Okay," he grumbled, "the quality of the football has not been the best."

As it was, he chose to overlook the reasons behind their failure to win another away game in the Premiership all season or that, faced by one of the league's most porous defences, Rebrov's breakaway strike was their only effort on target and their first league goal for 7hr 42min.

So Tottenham's excruciating passage through the annals of sterility chugs along ad absurdum while City remain critical and stable. There is time to find an antidote but it will not have escaped the attention of their fatalistic fans that the bookmakers are taking bets on Manchester United winning the title and sending them down in the derby game on April 21.

Vernon Gomez, the old baseball player, used to say he would "rather be lucky than good" and Joe Royle would doubtless concur.

Having seen a perfectly good Danny Tiatto goal ruled out by a linesman at Middlesbrough a week earlier, City were on the wrong end of another grave miscarriage of justice here when the referee Steve Dunn inexplicably spotted something amiss as the Spurs goalkeeper Neil Sullivan collided with Sol Campbell while attempting to cut out a corner and Darren Huckerby hooked in the loose ball.

"The referee told me afterwards it was Shaun Goater on Sullivan," said Royle. "In that case I reckon I need to go for an eye test."

City had the pace to unnerve their guests but so little composure that they unnerved themselves. Egil Ostenstad flashed a header wide from three yards and, for all the chants of "Feed the Goat and he will score", Goater rarely threatened to oblige.

Then, lo and behold, Spurs scored.

Oyvind Leonhardsen set Rebrov free and the hitherto anonymous Ukrainian toe-poked under Nicky Weaver to send City's fans (including one misguided soul wearing a New York Yankees cap) scurrying en masse to the exits.

"I think I'll take the dogs for a walk to the beach," sighed Royle, and his affection for animals clearly extends to work. His menagerie on Moss Side now comprises a Goat, an Egil and at least half a dozen headless chickens.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Mary
fields.trailText: Check out the website www.mtsobek.com (US travel company that specializes in adventure travel). They have a good write up of what to do in Chile, Peru and Argentina.
fields.body:
Sue,

Am enjoying a glass of red wine, a pork chop and girl scout cookies - despite the fact the fortune teller in KL also told me to eat more veggies! Our fortunes were very similar. You made a good story out of yours.

Check out the website www.mtsobek.com (US travel company that specializes in adventure travel). They have a good write up of what to do in Chile, Peru and Argentina. You can easily do the Peru part without a tour group and save tons of money. They fly you from Lima to Cuzco. That was what I did; I then stayed in the hotel at Machu Picchu.

Mountain Sobek also has a good write up of Iguazu Falls, which you have to go and see. The falls are wider then Victoria and higher then Niagara - and some say more beautiful then both!

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Michelle
fields.trailText: For Sydney based activities... I recommend the zoo (not the best zoo ever but has a wonderful harbour back drop), the Centrepoint Tower and the Botanical Gardens for the best in free 'wow, isn't Sydney beautiful' moments.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

So jealous you're in Sydney, I absolutely love the place and will be moving there as soon as I finish wrestling with red tape. Anyway, I read that you're having probs getting a job so I thought I'd make a suggestion.

I don't know whether you're only looking at waitressing, but if not I know a dry cleaners (called Blue & White) on the North Shore (Crow's Nest to be precise) that are ALWAYS happy to give a skint backpacker a job. Now I know this probably sounds like your worst nightmare but it's not just any old cleaners... they operate a driveway service for Sydney's rich and famous. They drive up in their Porsches and drop off and pick up clothes without even getting out of the car. This is where the ever cheery backpacker comes in to it... OK, so it's really not glamorous at all and some people are very obnoxious, but it can be a good laugh. If you do get desperate enough, tell Jim Janakis Michelle sent you...

As for Sydney based activities... I recommend the zoo (not the best zoo ever but has a wonderful harbour back drop), the Centrepoint Tower and the Botanical Gardens for the best in free 'wow, isn't Sydney beautiful' moments.

Enjoy, you lucky person!!!

fields.headline: Napster loses appeal
fields.trailText: A US court has ordered Napster, the controversial online music exchange, to cease downloads of copyrighted digital music files, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A US court has ordered Napster, the controversial online music exchange, to cease downloads of copyrighted digital music files.

The long and complicated ruling, from the 9th circuit court of appeals in San Francisco, could spell the end of Napster. But experts warn the pioneering internet music outfit will not give up without a fight.

The federal appeals court said Napster must now prevent users from gaining access to copyrighted music, but stopped short of ordering an immediate shutdown.

It said the record companies' injunction against Napster was too broad and sent the case back to a federal district court for a rewrite of the order to create a more limited ruling focused on preventing copyright infringement of music.

However, the Recording Industry Association of America is already celebrating. "This is a clear victory," said RIAA president and chief executive Hilary Rosen. "The court of appeal found that the injunction is not only warranted, but required. And it ruled in our favour on every legal issue presented."

Napster will be allowed to stay in business until the "broad" injunction is tightened up and modified by a lower court.

Record companies have been up in arms about the free exchange of illegally copyrighted music files led by Napster.

Big music companies including Universal Music, Sony Music, Warner Music and EMI claim Napster is a haven for piracy and have demanded a legal precedent to stop it from operating. The appeals court ruling is a landmark decision in the ongoing digital music copyright battle between the music industry and advocates of free MP3 music file exchange.

Napster has a contingency plan up its sleeve, but has yet to detail what it is. It is thought Napster may petition the supreme court to stay in business and then do deals similar to the one it did with Bertelsmann last year with other record companies.

As soon as the 9th US circuit court of appeals published the ruling on its website at 6pm today, the site was immediately inaccessible due to server overload.

I'm pleased you are having a great time in Malaysia, especially KL. The land of my birth you know, before I baecame an anglophile, and decided to spend my life here in good ole Blighty.

fields.headline: Court rules against Napster
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Popular song-swap service Napster has been spared from an immediate shutdown today, although a US appeals court ruled in favour of the five recording companies who are suing the company for copyright infringement.
fields.body:
Popular song-swap service Napster has been spared from an immediate shutdown today, although a US appeals court ruled in favour of the five recording companies who are suing the company for copyright infringement.

The US ninth circuit court of appeals today upheld most parts of an injunction brought against Napster by BMG, EMI, Sony, Warner, and Universal to stop trading in advance of the trial.

The court ruled that Napster may have violated the law by allowing internet users to swap copyrighted music files, but stopped short of closing the site down.

In a 58-page opinion, the court ruled that Napster "knowingly encourages and assists its users to infringe the record companies' copyrights."

But the appeals court said the injunction was too broad and sent the case back to a federal district court to rewrite the order to a more limited ruling on preventing copyright infringement of music.

Napster must now prevent users from gaining access to copyrighted content through its lists of songs archived by the service's users, the ruling said.

The five music companies will now hope to continue their lawsuit without fear of losing money while downloads continue during what promises to be a lengthy trial.

webTitle: £28m cash boost for Northern Ireland's health and social services

fields.headline: £28m cash boost for Northern Ireland's health and social services
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland assembly today unveiled a £28m funding package aimed at reducing health service deficits of £38m and bridging the shortfall in expected European Union funding.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland assembly today unveiled a £28m funding package aimed at reducing health service deficits of £38m and bridging the shortfall in expected European Union funding.

The department of health, social services and public safety (DHSSPS) has been promised £18m from the cash windfall found from "routine savings".

Describing the move as "clear and decisive action" by the Northern Ireland executive, finance and personnel minister Mark Durkan also announced a joint review - to involve the DHSSPS, the department of finance and personnel, and the economic policy unit - into the causes and consequences of the deficits.

Northern Ireland and border counties of the Republic of Ireland have been promised £366m from the EU as part of Peace II grants, made following the April 1998 Good Friday agreement.

However, delays in accessing the EU cash was threatening job losses and bringing uncertainty to the voluntary and business sectors, ministers were told. The business sector also benefited from a 50% cut in a proposed rate rise to 3.3% - in line with inflation and those in England.

"The executive has recognised the problems that remain, given that it will be some time into 2000-01 before the allocations from Peace II become fully available," said Mr Durkan.

"The approach announced today should resolve the problem of gap funding which has been a difficult issue for the voluntary and community sectors over the last number of months and leave no remaining cause for uncertainty."

The package also includes:

 £3m for free travel for older people from October;

 £2m gap funding to be added to the social inclusion/community regeneration executive programme fund;

 £5m to compensate for a reduced non-domestic regional rate.

The assembly has also set aside a further £2m to provide a safety net.

"The executive has recognised the problems that remain, given that it will be some time into 2000-01 before the allocations from Peace II become fully available," said Mr Durkan. "The approach announced today should resolve the problem of gap funding which has been a difficult issue for the voluntary and community sectors over the last number of months and leave no remaining cause for uncertainty." The assembly has also set aside a further £2m to provide a safety net.

fields.headline: MP arrested at anti-nuclear demo
fields.standfirst: Two decades of protest at Faslane
fields.trailText: Labour MP George Galloway was today arrested during a protest at the home of Britain's Trident nuclear weapon submarines.
fields.body:
Labour MP George Galloway was today arrested during a protest at the home of Britain's Trident nuclear weapon submarines.

Mr Galloway, who represents Glasgow Kelvin, was among more than 200 people detained for public order offences during an attempted blockade at the Faslane naval base on the river Clyde, near Helensburgh.

Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan was also arrested, as hundreds gathered from 7am this morning at the site, where they formed a human chain to try to stop people going in through the main gates.

The demonstration was aimed at closing the base for the day. The organisers, anti-nuclear weapons group Trident Ploughshares and Scottish CND, claim the nuclear weapons breach international law because they cannot distinguish between civilian and military targets.

Protesters unfurled banners at the base, including a red flag and a depiction of a child maimed by nuclear weapons. Some demonstrators banged on drums, while others chanted slogans.

Police used power tools to cut through tubing which protesters had used to tie themselves together. They also had to dismantle the costume of a woman dressed as a silver nuclear missile before they could arrest her. People lay down in the road and brought traffic to a halt at a roundabout outside the base's north gate as a helicopter hovered overhead.

Strathclyde police dismissed claims by protest leaders that 1,000 people had taken part, saying a more realistic figure would be half that.

Before his arrest, Mr Galloway said: "We are worried about how to pay for care of the elderly and reducing class sizes in schools. "However, we are spending millions on weapons of mass destruction that will never be used."

Meanwhile a spokeswoman for Faslane said that staff were still managing to get into work despite the protest. She said: "We knew this was going to happen so we made sure we got people onto the site before it started.

"Non-essential staff have been advised to stay at home or work from home."

webTitle: Pires: Gunners must fire in France

fields.headline: Pires: Gunners must fire in France
fields.trailText: Robert Pires has warned his Arsenal team-mates they must get at least four points from their two Champions League games against Lyon to have any chance of progressing to the knock-out stages.
fields.body:
Robert Pires has warned his Arsenal team-mates they must get at least four points from their two Champions League games against Lyon to have any chance of progressing to the knock-out stages.

"I think we can win in Lyon - but it is more important that we don't lose," Pires told Guardian Unlimited. "A draw would be OK, provided we beat them at Highbury next week. Four points from our two games with Lyon would give us a great chance of qualifying."

The Gunners are the bookies' favourites to win tomorrow night. But Pires reckons Arsenal must be wary of underestimating Lyon, who are unbeaten since Christmas and possess a potent strike force in Sonny Anderson and Steve Marlet.

"Lyon will be tough opponents," Pires admitted. "They are fourth in the French league and have excellent strikers. We have to be careful. But over the two matches I remain confident."

And Pires is also confident that Arsenal are as good a side as Manchester United - despite trailing thirteen points behind them in the Premiership.

"Back in October I was sure we could challenge United for the Premiership," he admitted. "Then we had a very difficult November where we had lots of injuries and only won one match. But today I'm convinced we are now at the same level as Manchester."

The French international also revealed how much he is enjoying life in England after a difficult start.

"It was very hard when I arrived, especially that first game against Sunderland," he admitted. "It was very physical and were a lot of challenges - but now I am used to that. I realise that's how you've got to play. You have to compete for every ball.

"I am very happy in England now," he added. "I really appreciate the English game and the atmosphere in the stadiums is always fantastic. The only bad thing is the weather."

 Pires was talking to Sean Ingle at the launch of Umbro's new Pro-Training range. You can check it out at umbro.com.

Hi,

Enjoy! Selamat jalan.

webTitle: Leader: Peace deal in Irish mist

fields.headline: Peace deal in Irish mist
fields.standfirst: Conflicting signals offer hope and despair
fields.trailText: The great frustration for peacemakers is that, just when you think the two sides are closer than ever to agreement, the entire process can unravel. It happened in the Middle East and now threatens Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The great frustration for peacemakers is that, just when you think the two sides are closer than ever to agreement, the entire process can unravel. It happened in the Middle East and now threatens Northern Ireland. Before Christmas, the outgoing US president, Bill Clinton, was working feverishly behind the scenes to secure a deal which sought to put the Good Friday Agreement on a permanent footing. There was optimistic talk on both sides, with word of an IRA move on decommissioning so huge that even the most suspicious of Unionists would have to accept it. The republicans would concrete over arms dumps, while the British government would agree to demilitarise, by taking down the loathed army watchtowers that stir such resentment in nationalist areas like south Armagh.

According to the plan, the deal would first be agreed by London and Sinn Fein before being handed to the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble for his grateful acceptance. As one insider close to the talks put it, by the end of the process everyone would agree that "the Troubles are over".

That optimism has not entirely faded, but the dynamics have changed. Mr Clinton, who was doing so much behind the scenes, even until his last day in office on January 20, has gone. The disciplining effect of that deadline has been replaced with a new one: London officials have let the parties in Belfast know that Tony Blair will not spare much more of his precious time on their problems. He has an election to prepare for and has signalled that, after the next week or so, he will concentrate on that rather than them. The same goes for his chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, who has been the lead player in Northern Ireland policy, and the government's de facto chief negotiator, for some time. So Northern Ireland is on notice that a deal has to be done very soon.

Does that mean a deal is within reach, or about to disappear from view? The answer is confused. Mr Trimble himself has nodded in both directions. At the end of last month he gave an upbeat assessment of the chances of IRA disarmament; yet on Saturday he told his 110-strong party executive that he would maintain the sanctions he has imposed on Sinn Fein over the IRA's failure to disarm - and even increase them if necessary. So which is it: is there progress or isn't there?

One explanation may be that, while there has been definite movement in London's talks with republicans, the advances may not be enough. Unionists fear the British government may well agree to take down two watchtowers, for example, in return for an IRA promise merely to "re-engage" with John De Chastelain, the Canadian former general charged with overseeing the decommissioning process. "Two towers for a phonecall" would not be enough, says one Trimble aide; the UUP leader would still face a challenge from Unionist hardliners. For Sinn Fein the key obstacle remains police reform. The trouble here is that republican demands are not easy for London to meet: they would require unpicking an act of parliament that is just a few weeks old - and doing so only months before a general election.

So Northern Ireland finds itself in a strange kind of limbo, on the brink either of a deal or a collapse. With a rising wave of loyalist violence hanging over all the participants, they need all the creativity they are capable of, if they are to make Northern Ireland peace count as one of the achievements of Labour's first term - rather than as yet another item in the in-tray of the second.

webTitle: Scottish MP resigns as Liddell's PPS over Ahern row

fields.headline: Scottish MP resigns as Liddell's PPS over Ahern row
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Labour MP at the centre of a row over a visit to Scotland by the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, has resigned from his post as parliamentary private secretary to the Scottish secretary, Helen Liddell.
fields.body:
The Labour MP at the centre of a row over a visit to Scotland by the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, has resigned from his post as parliamentary private secretary to the Scottish secretary, Helen Liddell.

Frank Roy, the Motherwell and Wishaw MP, was widely criticised for warning Mr Ahern that his presence at a Catholic shrine in Mr Roy's constituency might inflame sectarian tensions after yesterday's Celtic-Rangers match.

Mr Ahern was to have unveiled a memorial to victims of the Irish famine at Carfin in Lanarkshire yesterday after attending the Old Firm match. He cancelled the private visit after Mr Roy's intervention.

Mr Roy has insisted that he had acted alone as a constituency MP, but it emerged at the weekend that he cited the names of Mrs Liddell and the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, in his letter to the Irish government voicing his concerns.

The letter does not say that the two ministers supported his efforts to have the visit cancelled or postponed, and both have denied involvement. However, the inclusion of their names is considered to have added weight to the letter. Mr Roy was previously a parliamentary private secretary to Dr Reid.

In his resignation letter to Mrs Liddell yesterday, Mr Roy said he regretted she and Dr Reid had been "falsely accused" of involvement in the affair. Mrs Liddell said: "I very much regret his resignation as my PPS. I tried to talk him out of it but the distress to his family .. has been so considerable that I feel I have no alternative but to respect his wishes."

The first minister, Henry McLeish, has issued a formal invitation to Mr Ahern to visit Scotland in April.

webTitle: Byers and Blunkett gear up for election

fields.headline: Byers and Blunkett gear up for election
fields.standfirst:
Government unveils policy on industrial strategy to narrow deficit in skills and innovation

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Government unveils policy on industrial strategy to narrow deficit in skills and innovation.
fields.body:
Measures to narrow Britain's deficit in skills, innovation and entrepreneurship will be announced by the government tomorrow as it lays out its industrial strategy for a second term in office.

In a white paper, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and David Blunkett, the employment and education secretary, are to highlight measures to tackle some of Britain's long-standing supply-side failings.

In the latest signal that Labour is gearing up for an election campaign, the white paper will stress the next steps required to improve economic performance and spread prosperity from the affluent south-east to the regions.

Although the government believes it has delivered economic stability since the 1997 election, important areas of weakness are identified in the DTI's competitiveness indicators published today. Sources said that the recommendations in the white paper would dovetail with tax changes announced by Gordon Brown in next month's Budget.

Mr Brown will warn his fellow EU finance ministers today that Europe must raise its game on research and development to improve its poor record on business innovation.

While the US and Japan spend 3% of national income in research, the figure for Europe is 2%. Treasury sources said the chancellor would call for a study into why Europe is lagging behind the world's two biggest economies and whether European rules banning subsidies to industry need to be changed so that tax incentives could be used to encourage firms to invest in R&D.

The competitiveness indicators report concludes that economic performance is being held back by poor basic skills and a shortage of intermediate-level vocational skills, where Britain's record compares unfavourably with countries such as Germany.

It adds that the UK's lowly position in the global productivity league table is the consequence of "decades of under-investment", and that the strength of the science base is not reflected in commercial spin-offs. Mr Byers said: "Firm economic foundations are now in place for us to build for the future. We have made a start but there is a lot more work to be done if we are to adapt to a constantly changing global economy.

"We need to remove obstacles to enterprise and entrepreneurship in all parts of the country to address the skills shortage in our workforce and to raise educational standards for all."

The DTI published its first set of competitiveness indicators in December 1999, and believes that there may have been some closing of the productivity gap in the meantime. The report admits, however, that it is "difficult to distinguish how much of this [improvement] is cyclical and how much a response to an improvement in the macro-economic environment".

The report says that Britain is receptive to new ideas and is effective at drawing on the "global knowledge pool". It stresses, though, that Britain "performs relatively poorly in terms of turning new ideas into commercial success."

webTitle: Two decades of protest at Faslane

fields.headline: Two decades of protest at Faslane
fields.trailText: More than 300 protesters, including George Galloway MP, were arrested during a demonstration at the home of Britain's Trident nuclear weapon submarines today.
fields.body:
More than 300 protesters, including George Galloway MP, were arrested during a demonstration at the home of Britain's Trident nuclear weapon submarines today.

It is not the first time that the Faslane naval base on the river Clyde in Scotland has been a target for anti-nuclear campaigners - it has been the subject of demonstrations for nearly two decades.

Their main targets are four Trident submarines that live at the base. Each has 16 missile tubes capable of firing Trident D5 missiles, which have a range of more than 4,000 nautical miles (more than 4,600 miles) and are accurate to within feet.

The anti-nuclear campaigners argue that such weapons of mass destruction are against international law because they cannot distinguish between civilian and military targets.

The Faslane peace camp was set up in 1982 to "non-violently oppose the presence of nuclear weapons at Faslane naval base", according to its website. A protest group called Trident Ploughshares began holding vigils, setting up blockades and breaking into the base in the late 1980s after the Trident subs arrived.

webTitle: Robin Cook to make speech on EU history

fields.headline: Cook looks to history over EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Robin Cook will today take the bold step of praising Labour's political adversaries for having the courage to create the European Union.
fields.body:
Robin Cook will today take the bold step of praising Labour's political adversaries for having the courage to create the European Union.

In a speech to a centre-left audience in Stockholm, the foreign secretary will say the EU may never have been built without the old Tory party.

"Historically, the right made a valuable contribution to the construction of Europe," Mr Cook will tell the Olof Palme international centre.

"Konrad Adenauer in Germany, Charles de Gaulle in France, and even Winston Churchill in Britain were major architects of the foundations of Europe and pioneered the historic rapprochements that made the Europe of today possible."

Mr Cook will use the memory of such historic figures of the right to show how the European right of today has lost touch with reality, handing the centre left a chance to become the natural parties of government.

Mr Cook will say that the right "as a force of opposition" embraces the likes of Jorg Haider in Austria and the Conservative party in Britain.

"It can be seen at its most extreme in the offensive hostility to foreigners of Jorg Haider, whose xenophobia is in flat opposition to the tolerance on which Europe is built. It can be seen at its most unreal in the British Conservative party, who talk openly about picking and choosing which European laws they would observe without recognising that without common laws there can be no single market."

Mr Cook, who takes over as president of the party of European Socialists in May, will say that the right's decline gives social democrats a unique chance to become "the natural force for government".

However, the foreign secretary will warn his political allies that they will succeed only if they constantly update their ideas.

webTitle: Tens of thousand access free genome data

fields.headline: Tens of thousand access free genome data
fields.trailText: Figures released from the Human Genome Project today show that scientists in more than 100 countries have searched the genetic data archives online as part of efforts to develop new medical treatments.
fields.body:
Figures released from the Human Genome Project today show that scientists in more than 100 countries have searched the genetic data archives online as part of efforts to develop new medical treatments.

The figures for the project funded by the Wellcome Trust and public organisations, which provide data free of charge, contrast with those for the rival commercial genome project, led by the US company Celera Genomics. It is estimated that the private database of Celera Genomics is used by less than 50 subscribing organisations.

"Every day, at least 10,000 organisations throughout the world are accessing the publicly available Human Genome Project data," according to Dr Graham Cameron, Director the European Bioinformatics Institute at the Wellcome Trust Genome Campus in Cambridgeshire.

The human genome - the entire 3bn-letter genetic code of a representative human - is revealed by the two competing projects in separate scientific journals today.

During the past two months, the public genome databases have been used by scientists in India (160,000 times), Mexico (61,000), China (50,000), and Brazil (50,000).

Dr Mike Dexter, Director of the Wellcome Trust, said: "It is a free gift to the world and many thousands of scientists access these data daily. It is essential to their research. Through making the data as widely available as possible - with no constraints - we allow hundreds of thousands of fine minds to harness the information to serve their own local communities.

"Had the sequence data only been available commercially, many individuals and scientific institutions in the developing world would not have had access to it."

Scientists in the developing world are working with the Human Genome Project data to examine the effects of genetic variation on people's susceptibility to tropical diseases such as tuberculosis, sleeping sickness, river blindness, malaria and HIV.

In a clear attack on the controversial plans by Dr Craig Ventor, the founder of Celera Genomics, to decode the human genome and sell the data to biotechnology businesses, Sir John Sulston, former Director of the Sanger Centre in Cambridgeshire, said: "Others want to charge the rest of the human race a fortune to read our own genetic code, but we're here to tell them that the human genome is not for sale."

The sequence data from the Human Genome Project is used regularly by about 50,000 individual scientists. The databases are provided by the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI) in Cambridgeshire, part of the European Molecular Biology Laboratory, Genbank at the National Centre for Biotechnology Information in Bethesda, Maryland in the US, and DNA Databank of Japan at the National Institute of Genetics in Mishima.

webTitle: Government to reveal schemes to bridge the innovation gap

fields.headline: Government to reveal schemes to bridge the innovation gap
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: The government is to unveil a series of schemes to nurture links between universities and businesses as part of a white paper on the knowledge-based economy.
fields.body:
The government is to unveil a series of schemes to nurture links between universities and businesses as part of a white paper on the knowledge-based economy.

Ministers hope that strengthening academic-industry links will produce the technical developments and skilled graduates needed to underpin a competitive high-tech economy.

Much has been done in recent years to improve the exploitation of research discoveries by universities, but UK industry, particularly small businesses, remain far less innovative than companies abroad.

The paper will confirm the creation of a Higher Education Innovation Fund - totalling £140m over three years Ü which will aim to address the innovation gap. This will incorporate the existing Higher Education Reach Out to Business and the Community fund, run by the Higher Education Council for England, and schemes currently administered by the Department for Education and Employment.

It is hoped that the innovation fund will develop into a permanent third stream of funding for universities. Although academic teaching and research budgets currently dwarf the funding business links.

The paper meanwhile will confirm the creation of a new Regional Innovation Fund of £50m a year for regional development agencies to support networks of scientists, entrepreneurs, and financiers.

The paper will also unveil details of the £1bn Science Research Investment Fund, £225m of which comes from the Wellcome Trust. The successor of the Joint Infrastructure Fund will again support university buildings and equipment across the sciences. But allocations this time will be distributed according to the level of government research grants already won by universities.

webTitle: Lib Dems unveil plans for higher education

fields.headline: Lib Dems unveil plans for higher education
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat party today accused the Labour government of not doing enough to solve the financial problems of universities and revealed their own plans for higher education.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat party today accused the Labour government of not doing enough to solve the financial problems of universities and revealed their own plans for higher education.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy said: "Tony Blair and David Blunkett are scratching at the surface of the problems faced in higher education. Liberal Democrats are committed to scrapping tuition fees which is what students want and what students need."

Only last Thursday, education secretary Mr Blunkett, for the first time, ruled out more fees if Labour wins the next general election. Currently, students are charged a maximum of £1050 a year.

Mr Kennedy's comments came as the Lib Dems unveiled their 'higher education package' at a conference at the University of London Union. The package is based on three principles: free education - through the abolition of tuition fees; better access for poor students through the restoration of maintenance grants and limited means tested benefits; and extra funding to improve lecturers' pay and conditions.

The Lib Dems higher education spokesperson, Dr Evan Harris, said: "Our carefully-costed commitments will allow us to restore the principle of higher education free at the point of access, open up our universities to students from poorer backgrounds, remove some of the burden of student debt, abolish the disgraceful pay gap that exists for female academics and tackle the recruitment and retention crisis affecting lecturers and researchers."

The Lib Dems say that they would pay for the higher education reforms by raising extra taxes. An extra penny in income tax would generate approximately £3.1bn in new income. The Lib Dems would channel £730m into universities, with the rest used for schools.

A spokesperson for the National Union of Students said that the NUS did not endorse the proposals, but welcomed the widening of the student funding debate.

The Liberal Democrats package includes the following proposals:

 The abolition of tuition fees
 The restoration of means-tested maintenance grants funded by the graduate endowment scheme that has proved both popular and effective in Scotland
 A net reduction in student debt for all students especially those from poorer backgrounds
 Access to income support and housing benefit in the summer vacation for those students unable to find work
 Full funding of the Bett Commission proposals to bridge the pay gap between male and female academics and reverse the casualisation of teaching posts
 Triple the premium paid to universities to fund increased applications from, and retention of, under-represented student groups
 Increase significantly the unit of funding per student to improve quality in higher education
 Concentrate expansion of student numbers on shortage areas such as health professionals, IT graduates and teachers
 Raise the income threshold at which students start to repay their loans to a rate higher than the average non-graduate starting salary

fields.headline: Door opens on deeper mysteries
fields.standfirst:
Unexpectedly small number of genes raises questions on humanity's controlling influences

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The human genetic code, a 3bn letter sequence of DNA to be published this week, shows that humans carry little more genetic information than mice, and barely twice as much as tiny fruit flies, raising questions on humanity's controlling influences
fields.body:
The human genetic code, a 3bn letter sequence of DNA to be published this week, shows that humans carry little more genetic information than mice, and barely twice as much as tiny fruit flies.

The two rival teams which deciphered the genome will publish separately. Their discovery promises new treatments for a whole range of diseases and deepens the mystery of life. It reveals that the genes - which hold the instructions for the proteins of which human tissue is made - occupy only about a hundredth of the length of the huge string of DNA, broken up into the 23 chromosomes in every cell.

Researchers had, when the project began, predicted there might be 70,000 to 140,000 genes. They believed that one gene contained the code for one protein which would have one function. Instead, the international consortium of scientists behind the publicly funded research into the human genome project say in Nature this week that they calculate that there could be as few as 30,000 genes in the human blueprint, and no more than 40,000.

Craig Venter, of the biotech firm Celera Genomics, whose rival team publishes its findings in Science this week, is in close agreement, putting the total at between 26,000 and 38,000.

"The small number of genes has tremendous implications, and you should be asking the question: why is the small number of genes surprising? I think it happened for several reasons. The fruit fly genome has 13,000 or so genes in it, and everybody was thinking we are so much bigger and smarter on average than fruit flies that we should have a lot more genes. Then look at our everyday language," said Dr Venter.

"People talk about you got the gene for this from your mother and the gene for that from your father, and so if you think that we are hard-wired and that everything is deterministic, there should be a lot of genes, because we have a lot of different traits. So I think a lot of people were expecting that to be the case."

But the vastly smaller number of genes means that biologists can no longer assume that one gene is a blueprint for one protein that has one function. Nature has found a way of making "executive" genes that do very sophisticated management work. Sir John Sulston, of the Sanger Centre at Cambridge, one of the leaders of the international effort, said that the similarity to other creatures provided confirmation, at the level of molecules, for Darwin's theory of evolution formulated 150 years ago. The same genes, with little adjustments, had been used throughout the 3.8bn year story of evolution.

"It is the unity of life, of nature being conservative, or the idea of the Blind Watchmaker - the notion of evolution as a constant reworking or random recombining of parts. You convert your Austin 7 into a Mercedes, but basically it is the same underneath," he said.

"We know that as we move up the ladder of complexity from the single cell creatures, through small animals like worms and flies, and up to us, what we are adding on is control genes," Sir John said. "What we are doing is to increase the variety and subtlety of genes that control other genes."

The completed map of the human genome has other surprises. The genes themselves - sequences of four chemical bases that spell out the instructions for making a protein - occupy only 1.1% of the chromosomes. The rest has in the past been dismissed as "junk," useful for identifying a genetic fingerprint, but no more. But both teams of scientists now believe that this junk DNA could form part of the great story of evolution.

"We have to look beyond the genes," said Richard Gallagher, biology editor of Nature. "We know what they are. We don't know what the rest of the stuff is that is sometimes called junk. It is that drawer you have got at home that is stuffed with memorabilia. Some things are essential, like your passport and birth certificate: they are your genes. But there is other stuff that gives insight into who you are and where you came from and why you do the things that you do."

The publicly funded scientists - backed by the US, Britain, France, Germany, China and Japan - also reveal that hundreds of genes appeared to have been transferred into the chromosomes by invading bacteria, effectively making humans, and all other vertebrates, genetically modified organisms. Comparison of the genomes of other creatures - scientists have published the DNA of many microbes, yeast, a nematode worm, a fruit fly, and a little weed called thalecress - could give clues to the 3.8bn year mystery of evolution.

But the same information rules out another habit of thinking called genetic determinism: the argument that humans might be little more than robots controlled by their genes. "Understanding the human genome will not take away the concept of free will," said Francis Collins, one of the US leaders of the international partnership. "Understanding the human genome will not help us very much to understand the spiritual side of human kind or to know who God is, or what love is."

The research also removes any grounds for racism. Researchers have so far collected almost a million tiny variations in the genetic code - single nucleotide polymorphisms, or SNPs - that might explain why humans differ from each other. The variation between any two individuals in the same population could be greater than that between two different groups. Nobody knows the identities of the people who donated their DNA for the publicly funded team, but Dr Venter deliberately selected DNA from five individuals, one Asian-American, one African-American, one Hispanic-American and two others and found no way of telling which was which.

"No serious scholar in this field considers race to be a scientific concept," he said. "We all evolved out of the same three or four groups in Africa, as black Africans. With migrations, different populations were fixed. But there is more diversity within Africans than there is between Africans and Caucasians. We are part of a continuum because we evolved from the same set of people over a very short period of time."

The research promises new treatments for a huge range of diseases, all of which must have some genetic component. It could, ultimately answer questions about the nature of life itself. It could also answer riddles about addictions such as gambling, or provide treatments for jet-lag, or sleep disorders, or mental illness. But the chiefs of both teams warn that there is a long way to go - even if there are only 26,000 genes to examine.

"It requires tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of good minds looking at it in an unfettered way, doing experiments, to really make the contribution that the human genome project information is capable of," Sir John said. "It is a very basic set of instructions and we have got to learn how our growing bodies interpret these instructions to make a human being."

Facts of life

What they discovered:

 Hundreds of genes have been smuggled into the human chromosomes by bacteria.

 Humans have only twice as many genes as a simple worm or a fly.

 There is no scientific basis for race. Humans the world over share more than 99.9% of their DNA.

 Most of human DNA seems like "junk" but it could contain clues to the history of life.

 Genes are more than just simple commands for making single proteins.

 Most mutations occur in males. And the male Y chromosome is very small.

 The 30,000 or so genes in 23 chromosomes could make 250,000 proteins available to the 100 million million cells in any adult human.

 The dog is 85% identical to a human in terms of genetic sequence and many of the 380 inherited diseases in dogs are very similar to human diseases. These include a type of blindness and liver failure.

 Scientists found that chickens barely have enough immune system genes to keep them alive. Humans have around 200 of these genes, chickens only 19.

What the genes promise:

 Up till now, pharmaceutical firms have known only 483 "targets" in the human body for drugs. The new research will deliver thousands more.

 There are more than a million genetic differences between humans found so far. These could open up a new era of personalised medicine.

 1,778 genes identified with disease have been found so far. They range from asthma to Alzheimer's.

 Genome scientists predict that by 2020, diseases will be diagnosed before symptoms appear.

But both teams of scientists now believe that this junk DNA could form part of the great story of evolution. "We have to look beyond the genes," said Richard Gallagher, biology editor of Nature. "We know what they are. We don't know what the rest of the stuff is that is sometimes called junk. It is that drawer you have got at home that is stuffed with memorabilia. Some things are essential, like your passport and birth certificate: they are your genes. But there is other stuff that gives insight into who you are and where you came from and why you do the things that you do." The publicly funded scientists - backed by the US, Britain, France, Germany, China and Japan - also reveal that hundreds of genes appeared to have been transferred into the chromosomes by invading bacteria, effectively making humans, and all other vertebrates, genetically modified organisms. Comparison of the genomes of other creatures - scientists have published the DNA of many microbes, yeast, a nematode worm, a fruit fly, and a little weed called thalecress - could give clues to the 3.8bn year mystery of evolution. But the same information rules out another habit of thinking called genetic determinism: the argument that humans might be little more than robots controlled by their genes. "Understanding the human genome will not take away the concept of free will," said Francis Collins, one of the US leaders of the international partnership. "Understanding the human genome will not help us very much to understand the spiritual side of human kind or to know who God is, or what love is." The research also removes any grounds for racism. Researchers have so far collected almost a million tiny variations in the genetic code - single nucleotide polymorphisms, or SNPs - that might explain why humans differ from each other. The variation between any two individuals in the same population could be greater than that between two different groups. Nobody knows the identities of the people who donated their DNA for the publicly funded team, but Dr Venter deliberately selected DNA from five individuals, one Asian-American, one African-American, one Hispanic-American and two others and found no way of telling which was which. "No serious scholar in this field considers race to be a scientific concept," he said. "We all evolved out of the same three or four groups in Africa, as black Africans. With migrations, different populations were fixed. But there is more diversity within Africans than there is between Africans and Caucasians. We are part of a continuum because we evolved from the same set of people over a very short period of time." The research promises new treatments for a huge range of diseases, all of which must have some genetic component. It could, ultimately answer questions about the nature of life itself. It could also answer riddles about addictions such as gambling, or provide treatments for jet-lag, or sleep disorders, or mental illness. But the chiefs of both teams warn that there is a long way to go - even if there are only 26,000 genes to examine. "It requires tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of good minds looking at it in an unfettered way, doing experiments, to really make the contribution that the human genome project information is capable of," Sir John said. "It is a very basic set of instructions and we have got to learn how our growing bodies interpret these instructions to make a human being." Facts of life What they discovered:  Hundreds of genes have been smuggled into the human chromosomes by bacteria.  Humans have only twice as many genes as a simple worm or a fly.  There is no scientific basis for race. Humans the world over share more than 99.9% of their DNA.  Most of human DNA seems like "junk" but it could contain clues to the history of life.  Genes are more than just simple commands for making single proteins.  Most mutations occur in males. And the male Y chromosome is very small.  The 30,000 or so genes in 23 chromosomes could make 250,000 proteins available to the 100 million million cells in any adult human.  The dog is 85% identical to a human in terms of genetic sequence and many of the 380 inherited diseases in dogs are very similar to human diseases. These include a type of blindness and liver failure.  Scientists found that chickens barely have enough immune system genes to keep them alive. Humans have around 200 of these genes, chickens only 19. What the genes promise:  Up till now, pharmaceutical firms have known only 483 "targets" in the human body for drugs. The new research will deliver thousands more.  There are more than a million genetic differences between humans found so far. These could open up a new era of personalised medicine.  1,778 genes identified with disease have been found so far. They range from asthma to Alzheimer's.  Genome scientists predict that by 2020, diseases will be diagnosed before symptoms appear. webTitle: Gene code opens new fields of medicine

fields.headline: Gene code opens new fields of medicine
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The "book of humankind" - the entire 3bn-letter genetic code of a representative human - is revealed by two competing journals today.
fields.body:
The "book of humankind" - the entire 3bn-letter genetic code of a representative human - is revealed by two competing journals today.

Although it could answer questions about human evolution and promise startling new cures for disease, paradoxically it has also deepened the mystery of life. The genome reveals that the human chromosome carries only about 30,000 genes, twice the number of a fruit fly, 10,000 more than a roundworm, and only a few hundred more than a mouse. Originally scientists expected as many as 140,000, which means the question of how genes actually work is now an even bigger mystery.

The genome also reveals that many human genes originate from microbes which over aeons smuggled their genetic material into human cells and stayed. This raises questions about human evolution.

Scientists who raced to complete a document so long that it may never be printed in full said the human genome could open an era of a new kind of medicine - one tailored to a patient's unique genetic makeup.

"It will be individualised medicine where we'll treat the individual person for the right disease, with the right medicine, at the right dose, at the right time," said Mike Dexter, director of the Wellcome Trust, the charity which launched the British research.

The effort, by an international consortium of scientists backed by taxpayers and charity, began almost 20 years ago with a search for the genetic cause of muscular dystrophy and other inherited diseases. It accelerated two years ago when a private group, Celera Genomics, joined the hunt for genes.

When the two groups made a truce and announced jointly last June that they had reached their target, the achievement was compared with the invention of the wheel - and one scientist spoke of an end to cancer in his lifetime. Since then, the two teams have fallen out and challenged each other's methods.

The Celera group claims its sequence is complete. The consortium claims it will have a "gold standard" genome in two years.

There is bitter disagreement about who should have access to the information. The public consortium argues that the information is so important it should be available to all, freely. But both concede the final publication has raised a new set of mysteries for science.

webTitle: Articles of faith lie at heart of genome feud

fields.headline: Articles of faith lie at heart of bitter feud
fields.standfirst:
Disputes over method dog research project
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Disputes over method dog research project.
fields.body:
The fragile peace between the two competing groups of scientists which decoded the human genome splintered yesterday in an explosion of acrimony.

Craig Venter, the US gene scientist who formed his own company, Celera Genomics, to decode the human genome and sell the data to biotechnology businesses, accused a group of publicly funded scientists of having wasted money on the project and produced uneven results.

Scientists from the public consortium, who published their discoveries on the internet every day, pronounced the Celera data unsatisfactory and accused Dr Venter of having based his results on their data.

The public scientists - led in Cambridge by Sir John Sulston of the Sanger Centre, backed by Mike Dexter of the world's biggest charity, the Wellcome Trust, and by several teams in the US - launched the human genome project more than a decade ago, and painstakingly assembled a "map" of the chromosomes before embarking on their sequencing method.

Two years ago, Dr Venter, the first scientist to decipher all the genes in a bacterium, launched Celera to sprint ahead for the big prize with a different method.

Sir John said yesterday: "Celera has repeatedly said we have wasted research money in doing what we have done with our American collaborators. We did it because we believed that probably the claim that the Celera method would work on its own was false. What we can say today is that we were right."

Both groups announced on June 26 last year that they had finished deciphering the human genome. They planned, originally, to publish their papers together. That plan collapsed when Celera scientists refused to make their data available without certain assurances. The public consortium's data has always been freely available to everybody.

So the two groups took their papers to different journals. The public consortium went to Nature, the British journal which publishes on Thursday. The second group went to the US journal Science, which publishes a day later. Even so, both groups planned to make simultaneous announcements on Monday.

But even this attempt at harmony collapsed after Dr Venter talked to the Observer yesterday, and revealed some of the first findings. At the heart of the row are conflicting philosophies of science - and faith in differing methods to read and search a code so huge that it would fill 750,000 pages of single-spaced typing.

"Our approach is like sending out 30,000 people across the world, each of whom is committed to mapping a little region," said Richard Durbin of the Sanger Centre. "The Celera approach is more like getting a satellite to take 40m pictures, throwing them all together and trying to build your map without knowing which part of the world each one comes from."

But the international group also argued that research would benefit everywhere if the results were immediately made available to all.

"There are certain forms of information that should be available to everyone, and available free of charge," said Dr Dexter. "Imagine the problems for chemistry if the periodic table was in a private databank and you were charged for access. That would be incredibly stupid."

Tim Hubbard, of the Sanger Centre, said Dr Venter had the advantage of seeing data from the international team, which claimed only to have completed the "first draft" of the genome. "Their genome is no longer than ours. We know that this is not 100% coverage. They should have made theirs longer. In fact it is slightly less and has more gaps in it, so the conclusion is that their method simply doesn't work."

But Dr Venter said "Everybody keeps wanting to turn this into a pissing contest of whose is bigger and whose is better, and that's never what it has been about in the first place. It is very important to them because we are the bad guys, we came along and just did the genome in nine months and frankly stole their thunder, but our goal was to get, as I said earlier, the highest quality product we can."

Even so, both groups concede that they have achieved substantially the same results, and that their findings broadly confirm each other. The race is on to use the information. It is expected to be the basis of a new kind of industry. A US government department is co-operating with Celera to build the world's most powerful computer to search for genes in the genome.

Dr Venter said: "Some feel that we have stolen their fame, and some people are going to be very unhappy that Celera exists, are successful and that I exist. I don't lose a lot of sleep over that."

webTitle: Blair outlines strategy for schools reform

fields.headline: Blair outlines strategy for schools reform
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: The prime minister announced today that "the day of the bog-standard comprehensive" was over and that diversity was the way forward for Britain's schools.
fields.body:
The prime minister announced today that "the day of the bog-standard comprehensive" was over and that diversity was the way forward for Britain's schools.

Preparing to launch this afternoon's green paper on schools, Mr Blair outlined four strategies for improving secondaries - allowing businesses and charities to take over failing schools; targeting pupil achievement in the first three years of secondary education; introducing vocational qualifications at an earlier age; and giving successful schools more autonomy.

"Our best schools have moved decisively to a post-comprehensive argument," said Mr Blair. "They take inclusion and equality of opportunity for granted but are highly flexible in the ways they meet them. They offer greater diversity and choice."

He added that he wanted to change the law to allow external sponsors - such as religious denominations, charities and corporations - to take control of schools. The private sector has already made inroads into state education, particularly in local education authorities deemed to be "failing" by the government.

The education secretary David Blunkett denied that specialist schools would lead to more selection. "Some of them - 7% - choose by aptitude, but that is where they are choosing for language and kids who have got a particular bent," he told the Today programme.

"I think the comprehensive ideal was equality of opportunity, the comprehensive ideal was inclusion, the comprehensive ideal was actually ensuring that you met the needs of the particular child rather than the child having to fit in with the particular needs of the school."

Other initiatives being announced this afternoon include Pupil Learning Credits, which will enable schools in deprived areas to benefit from free extra-curricular activities, remedial teaching for difficult 12-year-olds and a national academy for exceptionally gifted children - likely to be internet-based.

Mr Blair said that an unacceptably high number of pupils were leaving schools with few or no qualifications. "And every school should instil in its pupils a strong sense of independence and responsibility, to themselves and to the wider community. These demands are much greater than those made of secondary schools in the last generation and we must be explicit in recognising the overhaul of our comprehensive system needed to meet them."

fields.headline: £10,000 deal for new teachers
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: New teachers in shortage subjects in England are to have their student loans paid off as one of an array of financial incentives to encourage recruitment unveiled yesterday by the education secretary, David Blunkett.
fields.body:
New teachers in shortage subjects in England are to have their student loans paid off as one of an array of financial incentives to encourage recruitment unveiled yesterday by the education secretary, David Blunkett.

Graduates in English are to join those in other shortage subjects - maths, science, technology and modern languages - in becoming entitled to £4,000 "golden hellos" from the government when they take up teaching.

Those graduates will now also have their government student loan written off at 10% a year over 10 years - a deal worth about £10,000 for each graduate. The scheme will cost £25m in the first year.

Along with the £6,000 training salaries given to all postgraduate teachers, it means some staff will receive about £20,000 from the taxpayer for choosing teaching.

On the eve of the government's five-year plan for improving secondary education, unions said Mr Blunkett was finally acknowledging the recruitment "crisis". Though the number of trainee teachers is up, recruits for postgraduate teaching courses in English and maths have risen by just 2% and 1% respectively and the government is about 12,000 teachers short of its targets for key subjects.

Mr Blunkett also plans to offer three-month teacher training courses for undergraduates during summer holidays, with £2,000 grants. Undergraduates could also do training modules as part of their subject degree course, without the extra money.

These graduates would then go straight into the classroom, with top-up training, rather than complete a full postgraduate teaching qualification.

Mr Blunkett will today announce that he is looking at options of giving undergraduates on four-year B.Ed courses money in their final year. They could either receive the £6,000 training salary or go into full-time teaching backed by the £13,000 salary given to those who opt for the graduate teacher programme, which involves training "on the job".

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said the new scheme should be extended "so that any young graduate who wants to go into teaching can be free of student debt".

NASUWT general secretary Nigel de Gruchy said he welcomed the measure, but added: "It does smack of panic and it proves that NASUWT was right in describing the present situation over teacher recruitment as a crisis and not just a problem."

Today's green paper on secondary education will focus on diversity, raising standards and developing the talents of individual pupils.

With the number of subject-specialist schools set to expand to 1,500 by 2006 - 46% of all secondary schools in England - Mr Blunkett called for each school to develop its own distinctiveness. "We want diversity within a modernised comprehensive system. We want to ensure that we can play to the strengths of individual schools so that they can develop their own ethos," he said on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost.

A £35m "pupil learning credits" scheme will increase provision of cultural activities such as music, dance and art, often already available for middle-class children at home, for 60,000 youngsters over two years in inner cities.

fields.headline: McGuinness strives for top marks
fields.standfirst:
Scrapping 11 plus is key policy for education chief who failed test but has earned praise as minister

Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Scrapping 11 plus is key policy for education chief who failed test but has earned praise as minister.
fields.body:
Today is another red-letter day for the final year pupils at Hollybush primary school in Derry, and there have been plenty of them of late.

Last Wednesday, they sang in the school choir to welcome the Northern Ireland education minister, Martin McGuinnness, who came to open a new nursery class and computer suite. And when they arrive at school this morning, those primary seven children, like all their counterparts across Northern Ireland, will share their big news of the weekend, their 11-plus results, which arrived in the post on Saturday.

The school's results are even better than last year: 23 As, four B1s, two B2s, two C2s and four Ds. In Northern Ireland as a whole, only 25% of all pupils, including about 8,000 who did not take the test (among them three at Hollybush) got As. It is the same ratio every year: more a competition than a test.

Tomorrow and the day after their parents will file into school for meetings with Pat McLaughlin, the principal, for advice on which grammar schools they should apply for, or whether they should at all. Though the so-called transfer tests were taken back in November, this week is effectively the culmination of a whole school year. Across Ulster as a whole, only about 35% of students will win places at grammar school; at Hollybush it will be much higher. The A grade students are certain, and the B grades almost certain, of a grammar school place. The rest will have to sweat.

"We grind the children from Easter," Mr McLaughlin said. "Maths, English, science. We don't do art, we hardly say a prayer. Even during the summer holiday they work. Then they come back and they have six weeks until the test. And then it's two hours to decide their whole life."

Soon most of the choir that sang for Mr McGuinness will be scattered across the schools of Derry, to St Columb's, Lumen Christi, Foyle and Londonderry, or Thornhill grammar schools, or to Oakgrove, a religiously integrated comprehensive in the city, or to secondary school - St Brigid's, St Joseph's, St Celia's or St Mary's.

Unhappy experience

Thirty-nine years ago, as a pupil at another primary school in Derry, St Eugene's, Mr McGuinness took his 11-plus. "My experience with the 11-plus was a very unhappy one. I actually didn't do the 11-plus in the school that I was taught in. We were taken out of our school and brought several miles away to what was an alien place [Templemore school] and sat down in a room where I'd never been before," Mr McGuinness said.

"It is my opinion that no education system has the right to tell any child at the age of 10 and 11 that it's a failure ... I just find it totally abhorrent that a child at that age toddles down the stairs on a Saturday morning in spring, lifts up the envelope and has either success or failure staring them in the face." He ended up going to the Christian Brothers technical college, known as the Brow 0' The Hill, next to where Lumen Christi now stands.

"I enjoyed primary, I didn't enjoy secondary school," Mr McGuinness said. "The majority of the Christian brothers in the school I attended were good, decent people, very concerned about education. But there were a small minority who were not such good teachers and they played a very negative role in terms of my education."

This 11-plus failure is now in charge of Northern Ireland's schools. And though he is waiting for a report from an independent review of post-primary education, there is no doubt he intends to ensure this year's primary seven class is among the last to take the transfer test. More than a year on, it is still common to find people rubbing their eyes at the sight of Mr McGuinness, who left school at 15 and in time became IRA chief of staff, being put in charge of a budget of £1.33bn and the educational interests of 349,000 children. But he has been getting on with it, to some acclaim.

"Definitely more pluses than minuses," said Tom McKee, Northern Ireland officer of the NASUWT, the largest teaching union in Ulster. "His record as a minister inside the teaching profession is quite impressive. He can master a brief very quickly, he can make a decision, he's not tied to departmental advice."

It was a surprise, and to many a provocation, when Mr McGuinness took the education brief when the executive posts were shared out in December 1999. At Sinn Fein's office on the Falls Road in Belfast, he told the Guardian: "There were various opinions within the leadership of Sinn Fein which department I should choose, to such a point where Gerry Adams said to me, well, you make the choice. And I chose education because I thought education is a very, very crucial department. I think it does more to put you at the heart of government than most other departments and at that stage I hadn't considered the size of the budget."

There were protests in some unionist schools when Mr McGuinness became minister. Aside from an early visit to the Methodist college in Belfast, he has been to few mainly protestant schools.

Sinn Fein councillors continue to put pressure on Catholic head teachers not to invite the RUC in for talks on road safety and drugs. Sammy Wilson of the Democratic Unionist party, deputy chairman of the education committee, said: "I approach any view of McGuinness from the point of view of his background. I don't believe that it is right that someone who has been involved in terrorising this community for the last 30 years and still has the ability to do so - because, of course, his organisation is intact, the arms are still there - I don't believe someone like that should be rewarded by being given a ministerial position. More important than that I think he lacks the moral authority to be a minister."

And still, the wider process intrudes. In the car park at Hollybush, he is interviewed about comments made by Ulster Unionist minister Michael McGimpsey, suggesting police reform should be held up until the IRA decommission. That day he cancels lunch with the visiting head of Unesco to take part in telephone talks with the British and Irish governments.

But the other week, Downing Street called his office not over the process but to inquire about his sudden announcement that he was scrapping the publication of performance league tables. Though reforming post-primary education is a much bigger mountain to climb, Mr McGuinness is taking it in stages. Following the publication of a two-year research project on selective education, the minister appointed the former Northern Ireland ombudsman, Gerry Burns, to head the review. The review will report later this year. "We're into major change for our society here in Northern Ireland and the review body aspires to producing a report that can be an exemplar to any other country," said Mr Burns.

Passion and possibility

Inside and outside the 25 public meetings and 700 hundred submissions gathered by the review group, people in Northern Ireland are starting to talk about education with passion and sense of possibility. Principals such as William Raven, at St Patrick's college in Ballymena, a Catholic secondary school in a small town of 60,000, where four grammar schools take something like half the top 11-plus pupils, great efforts have to be made to rebuild pupils' self-esteem. At Mount Gilbert College, a secondary school in the loyalist Shankill in Belfast, the teachers face the same problems. "The people who want to put up an argument for keeping the 11-plus don't have to deal with the people who don't get it," said Philip Hutton, head of maths. In the Shankill, something like one in a hundred children pass the transfer test.

But the arguments for keeping the grammar school system are there, strong because Northern Ireland consistently produces better exam results than anywhere in Britain, has fewer students leaving school with no GCSEs, and more working-class students going to university. Strong too because of uncertainty about what to replace it with. Wilfred Mulryne, head of the Methodist college in Belfast, which only takes A-grade students as day pupils, warned that scrapping grammar schools would lead to "selection by postcode" as in England, hurting clever poor children. He is certain that the introduction of a fully comprehensive system would lead to some grammar schools going private.

"There is no evidence from anywhere that a reorganisation to all-ability comprehensive schools would actually improve outcomes," said Dr Mulryne. Better, says Sammy Wilson, selection by results than by interview. "A lot of this has been driven by the middle class lobby. Someone said to me that the one thing the middle class can't do is buy success in the transfer procedure." But Mr Burns is looking for consensus: "I genuinely would not wish to produce a report which would have any significant opposition from a grouping within the educational world. That would just in my view negative the whole thing that we're doing."

At times, talking about education if no other subject, Mr McGuinness sounds like a 1960s progressive teacher from England. "Yes the 3 Rs are important ... we also need the three Ens in education - we need encouragment, we need enjoyment, we need enlightenment. All of that is important and we want to put in place an education system which encourages our young people to see the merits of a good education, which encourages our teachers." Abolishing the league tables, Mr McGuinness said, did "more for the morale of schools and teachers than the threat of naming and shaming them that seems to be the approach in England".

It has also not passed anyone by that in the rest of Ireland, there are no league tables, and no selective system. "If for example you asked, as many people have asked previously, how this phenomenon of the Celtic tiger actually came about, nearly everybody would say it came about because of education," said Mr McGuinness. He went to court to prevent David Trimble, the first minister, banning him from attending ministerial meetings with his southern Irish counterpart, Michael Woods. He has made it easier for Irish-language and religiously-integrated schools to set up. Sammy Wilson has accused the minister of skewing the school-building programme to favour Catholic schools: he denies it. Sinn Fein's radicalism is imbedded with reassurance: trying to show the whole community the world won't fall in if they run departments.

His most waffley answer comes when he is asked what he wants pupils to be taught about the IRA. "I would like them to be taught that there was no IRA, there was no UDF, I'd like people to obviously look at it honestly at the history of where we've come from, to look at what has happened in Ireland over the last 800 years ..."

He said he has met teachers from state - that is, mainly protestant - schools in private many times, and that the meetings have been "absolutely brilliant". He thinks he will need assembly legislation to push through changes to secondary education.

That is as big an "if" as whether the assembly itself will still be there even to let him try. "If I were a betting person I would say he will find it very difficult to get it through," said Mr Wilson. But if he did, Mr McGuinness and his opponents are well aware what a milestone that would be.
