fields.headline: Mr Blunkett's three Rs
fields.standfirst:
Recruitment and retention need resources

Guardian Unlimited Education
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A 10-year education plan is unveiled today. But, true to this government's tradition of pre-publication leaks, we already know the main framework.
fields.body:
A 10-year education plan is unveiled today. But, true to this government's tradition of pre-publication leaks, we already know the main framework. On one important front, teacher recruitment, the government is still in trouble. Yet another bribe to attract recruits has been unveiled this week-end - paying off student loans over time to people who enter the profession.

Ministers have been ingenious in the use of such lures: first with £4,000 "golden hellos" in shortage subjects in 1999; then last year's £6,000 training salaries for all postgraduate training courses; now student loan paybacks. Ministers point to a dramatic rise in applications, but extra admissions have been much less spectacular. The "golden hellos" saw applications for maths courses rise by 460 in 1999 (a 48% increase on the previous year), but actual admissions went up by only 200, leaving total numbers still 23% below the target of 1,810 maths trainees. A similar pattern applied to science: applications up by 711, but admissions by only 84, although total science trainees only fell 3% below target.

Under the new plan, maths and science teachers would have their student loans written off over a 10-year period. Teaching union leaders welcomed the new initiative yesterday, but noted it needed to go beyond maths and science. This will make them even more unpopular with the education secretary, who was brutally scathing about their lack of leadership yesterday, but on this issue the unions are right. There are teacher recruitment shortages in all school subjects except PE and history. Recruits are in such short supply that physics or maths graduates who have barely qualified (a third class degree or lower) can still gain admission to postgraduate teaching courses. Entry levels on undergraduate education courses are even more dismal.

Ministers have been ingenious in distributing the funds they have received to maximum effect. Last week's 3.7% pay award had extra perks, which lifted the package to 4.2%. What was missing was sufficient funds to begin restoring the earlier status of teachers. A 4.2% pay award, in a year in which average earnings are increasing by 4.2%, leaves teachers on precisely the same lowly rung. A generation ago they got 37% above the white-collar average. Now they are barely above the average. What is needed is a five-year pay plan which will ensure they are pushed back up the ladder.

fields.headline: Making pupils behave
fields.standfirst:
Today's schools proposals will be scrutinised by demoralised secondary teachers who dread their classes

Education site
fields.trailText: Today's schools proposals will be scrutinised by demoralised secondary teachers who dread their classes.
fields.body:
This morning many teachers will go to school dreading the prospect of facing a particular class. It could be a class with which last week's lesson went particularly badly, a class where almost every lesson goes badly, or a group with one individual who cannot sit still or keep quiet for more than a few minutes at a time. Increasingly frequently, it could be a class not normally taken by the teacher, but where the regular, timetabled teacher is absent, or has left the school and cannot be replaced.

The crisis in teacher recruitment is affecting pupil behaviour. When children have five mathematics teachers in as many months, it is hardly surprising that they misbehave. And misbehaviour in one lesson can often lead to difficulties for the teacher who takes the children next.

Large classes for 11 to 14-year-olds have contributed to the difficulties that secondary schools face in educating this age group. While class sizes in primary schools have fallen in the last four years, average class size in secondary schools has continued to rise and, until more money goes into the core budgets of secondary schools, this will continue to have an adverse effect on behaviour of pupils. In the next financial year, early indications are that this situation is unlikely to improve.

For the first time this year, the chief inspector of schools, in a generally upbeat report on school performance, has drawn attention to growing behaviour problems in secondary schools. Although he reports behaviour as unsatisfactory in only 8% of secondary schools, he notes that this is a higher proportion than in previous years. In half of the schools making poor progress, bad behaviour is a "significant issue".

In the same paragraph, the chief inspector notes that there has been a further decrease in the number of pupils permanently excluded from school. The connection between behaviour patterns and the number of exclusions is clear. The year covered by this annual report saw the introduction of a new set of rules and procedures that made it considerably more difficult for schools to exclude disruptive pupils.

Children who used physical and verbal violence against teachers were sometimes returned to schools by appeals panels that gave little recognition to the position of the teachers or to the needs of the other 29 children in the class. The government has since revoked some of these regulations, but too many appeals panels are still reinstating pupils who have demonstrated, through their anti-social behaviour, that they cannot adapt to the needs of a stable school community. More alternative provision is being established, both within and outside schools, for disruptive pupils, but this programme needs to be speeded up. There is no doubt, though, that the regulations introduced in 1999 contributed to the situation described by the chief inspector.

The shift in the balance of rights and responsibilities between schools and parents has made it more difficult for schools to set and demand exacting standards of behaviour from children. The range of sanctions available to head teachers is much reduced and there have been cases of children calling their parents by mobile phone from school, resulting in a parent coming in to attack the head or the teacher. Parents who do not support the school's behaviour code undermine the education of more than their own children.

We must not get the situation out of proportion. In spite of the difficulties, behaviour in schools is largely very good. The chief inspector praises the behaviour in 11 out of 12 schools, many of which are havens of peace in the turbulent lives of their pupils. People in all jobs have problems and situations to face that they would rather avoid. Everyone has to deal with awkward people from time to time.

But, unless you have experienced it, it is difficult to imagine the feeling of walking into a classroom in which you know that you have to spend the next hour, on your own, trying to create the conditions in which 30 children can learn Shakespeare or simultaneous equations against a background of disruption by children who do not want to learn and do not value the qualification at the end of the long road you are travelling together.

Whatever support mechanisms schools put in place to cover these circumstances - and they range from detention for children to emergency bleepers for staff - the difficulty remains for individual teachers, who may question their own professional ability, and even ask themselves whether they should be in teaching at all. Many teachers have left the profession, or fled to less stressful schools.

Today's education green paper, Schools: Building on Success, will have little effect on raising standards unless it addresses the two issues of support for schools in promoting and insisting on good behaviour, and the recruitment and retention of an adequate number of well qualified teachers. It must outline a whole range of measures to make teaching an attractive, high-status profession.

 John Dunford is general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association.

fields.trailText: If you take a stroll around Santander, you'll still see people with T-shirts that have a huge green hand on the front. The wearers aren't members of some kind of bizarre Percy Thrower fan club, however. By each green finger is not a plant, but a name: there's Torre, Quique, Morino and Radchenko. The name of the Russian, once a regular at parties in the University's Economics department, appears twice.
fields.body:
If you take a stroll around Santander, you'll still see people with T-shirts that have a huge green hand on the front. The wearers aren't members of some kind of bizarre Percy Thrower fan club, however. By each green finger is not a plant, but a name: there's Torre, Quique, Morino and Radchenko. The name of the Russian, once a regular at parties in the University's Economics department, appears twice.

Who, then, are these mysterious characters? Read the rest of the shirt and all is revealed - they're heroes. Goalscorers. "5-0" it says above the hand and "11 febrero 1995" below it. February 11 1995 - the last time Racing de Santander beat the mighty Barcelona.

And here comes the really spooky part - exactly six years later, the Catalan giants were back in the Sardinero against bottom-placed Racing. Once again they were humiliated, even if the delirious Santander crowd didn't get the "cin-co, cin-co, cin-co" they were after. Still, 4-0's certainly not bad.

Winter signing Regeueiro set the home side on their way with an excellent first, and he was joined on the scoresheet by two more newcomers - Ramis and Mazzoni. Claudio Arzeno grabbed the other as Barcelona were simply torn apart.

While Lorenzo Serra Ferrer was furious, there were huge sighs of relief in Madrid, especially from Iker Casillas. The teenage keeper was the man at fault on Saturday night when Real Madrid (minus Luis Figo) lost for the first time in twelve games - 1-0 to an early Bittor Alkiza goal against Athletic Bilbao.

Madrid's players have insisted that there's no such thing as "Figodependencia", but the evidence for the prosecution was damning. The Man in the Moustache's team looked out of sorts against Txetxu Rojo's side, who were keen to regain some pride after the heaviest defeat in their history last week (7-0 against Barca). Without Figo, only Steve McManaman and Pedro Munitis offered any real attacking quality for Real.

Ironically, the defeat came in the same week that madridistas took to Marca's website to vote Real's current team better than "La Quinta del Buitre" - the side which, with Emilio Butragueño, Hugo Sánchez and co, won five consecutive championships from 85/86 to 89/90.

Fans also had the chance to select their "dream team", made up of the best eleven players from the two sides. Six players made it from "La Quinta", five from the current side - Iker Casillas, Roberto Carlos, Figo, Raúl and Steve McManaman, who edged out Martín Vázquez by just two percent. (By the way, I categorically deny vicious rumours going round that I voted twenty times.)

The vote was prompted by the announcement that club captain and the man who holds the all-time appearance record, Manolo Sanchís, will retire at the end of the season after eighteen years at the Bernabéu. Winner of twenty titles, it's a measure of Sanchís's stature at the club that alongside the European Cups and League championship trophies adorning the Real Madrid museum sit the knackered football boots he wore during his 500th game.

Deportivo and Valencia close the gap

Deportivo La Coruña and Valencia both took advantage of the big two's defeats, closing the gap with convincing victories.

Diego Tristán, sneakily recorded criticising coach Javier Irureta a few weeks back, must have finally got round to phoning the míster to grovel - he was back in the side and scored a brilliant hat-trick, as Depor beat Real Sociedad 4-1 at the Riazor. Irureta has probably forgiven him now, but John Benjamin was furious: "Some of our players took a while to enter the game", he moaned, "and some of the others never entered it at all".

No sign of prearranged 0-0 draws in Valencia (as if Manchester United would be so cynical erm ) where Héctor Cúper's men comfortably saw off Numancia 3-0. With Pablo Aimar still in the stands, Gaizka Mendieta lined up in an unfamiliar position behind the front two. It worked a treat, too - the captain inspired a great performance, rounded off by Diego Alonso's brilliant lob over Álvaro Nuñez.

The best of the rest

The much anticipated Collymore-Palermo dual was, inevitably, a bit of a let down, with Stan "El Hombre" only on as a sub and Martín Palermo officially not mad anymore. "I'm crazy about football and nothing else," he insisted in midweek, adjusting his bra and pantyhose. "The rest is rubbish. El Loco? I'm just Martín!" Just Martín scored his first goal for Villarreal with a close range volley as his new side beat Oviedo 3-1.

There was more dodgy foreigner fun in Spain this week. Brazillian Georlan Gomes Bastos revealed that he had joined Division B side Herculés in 1999 as Jucirlan Rodrigues Gil, a name which actually belonged to a dead compatriot with a Portugese passport. Although things didn't work out at Herculés, Georlan (or Jurcilan if you prefer) did end up playing for little Lorca down in Murcia, where club officials didn't notice that he was impersonating a dead man. So what? - Torben Piechnik did that at Anfield for years.

There were late goals this weekend for Rayo Vallecano, who beat Osasuna 2-1, and for Celta against Espanyol - Catanha got the only goal of a hideously dull match with a superb half-volley two minutes into injury time. It was 1-0, too, for Alavés against Zaragoza, Valladolid against Las Palmas, and Mallorca at Málaga - thanks to a dreadful cock-up by goalie Rafa (making his debut, too, the poor sod). Blinded by the sun, Málaga's keeper managed to put a harmless cross into his own net to hand Luis Aragonés's side all three points.

Madrid's little white book

A week ago, those miserable gits on the Real Madrid board tried to ruin all our fun with the announcement of the "Libro Blanco" (White Book) - a new code of conduct for the club which, among other things, bans players from saying anything remotely controversial in the press.

So, when Málaga's Uruguayan forward Dario Silva claimed this week that Guti was a "poof", you could be forgiven for thinking that, tragically, his jibes would go without comment. But where there's a will there's a way. "I'm not going to comment", said Guti, a copy of the Libro Blanco tucked under his arm. Oh go on, please. "But", he continued, "I do have a wife and a kid". Phew.

Besides, yesterday's comments by Roberto Carlos, who attacked referee Ansuategui Roca for not awarding a "blatant" penalty on Saturday, suggest that the Libro Blanco has been binned already. Just in time for the derbi, too - can't wait.

webTitle: A police van runs over a man late at night. Its siren is off. Why? Because people complain about the noise

fields.headline: John Sutherland
fields.standfirst: A police van runs over a man late at night. Its siren is off. Why? Because people complain about the noise
fields.trailText: A police van runs over a man late at night. Its siren is off. Why? Because people complain about the noise.
fields.body:
On the evening of Sunday 4 February, a 40-year-old man booked two private rooms in Chelsea's English Garden restaurant for his birthday party. Modest amounts of drink flowed. There was no rowdiness.

At midnight things broke up amiably. A knot of 17 party-goers left to catch a night bus, on the other side of the King's Road, near the junction with Lincoln Street. It is a long stretch of straight thoroughfare.

Having crossed over to the south side of the King's Road, one of the group, Mark (34), realised that he had dropped his scarf on the far pavement. He walked back to retrieve it.

As Mark returned, scarf in hand, a white van came down the King's Road, towards central London. "Over 30, under 50," is how Mark's friends estimated its speed. It hit Mark. He was bounced by the collision on to the van's windscreen (which smashed) and rebounded on to the island in the middle of the road.

Witnesses claim that the van did not apply its brakes until the moment of impact. A police investigation has been set up, as is usual in incidents like this. The police press release states that "it appears that the pedestrian stepped out into the road from behind a parked car". This is strongly disputed by Mark's friends.

The van, it emerged, was that of a police dog-handler. Such specialist officers routinely travel alone with their animals, it seems. As it came down the King's Road, the van was not (witnesses claim) doing "blues and twos". No blue light, no two-tone siren. From exchanges immediately after the accident, it was learned that the officer and his dog had been called to an emergency in Regent Street (this is confirmed by the police report).

When Mark's partner asked why there had been no audible warning signal when the police car was coming down the road, he was told: "We get complaints from the public when we sound our sirens at one o'clock in the morning." Before getting out of his van, he sent out a Polac (police accident) bulletin on his radio. All witnesses agree that the police driver's behaviour after the accident was exemplary. It was he, presumably, who provided a blanket and first-aid kit for the injured man. He was, it is conceded, subjected to bitter remarks.

Within 10 minutes, there were a dozen area and panda cars around Mark's body and the damaged van. About 10 minutes later an ambulance arrived from Chelsea and Westminster Hospital.

By the time the ambulance arrived, the King's Road had been sealed off in both directions ("like an IRA bomb incident"). Mark, meanwhile, was bleeding profusely and screaming incoherently.

When the ambulance took off for the hospital, Mark's (distraught) partner was informed he could not accompany him because (he claims to have been told): "You're bleeding pissed." He insists vehemently he was not. Instead, two police officers accompanied the injured man in the ambulance.

Mark had suffered six broken ribs, a broken arm, a broken ankle and a 20cm-long wound to his skull. His spleen was removed by operation. He will be on antibiotics for the rest of his life. He has been in intensive care and comatose for a week.

Most of the score or so officers milling around were, it is agreed, civil and stoical in the face of the high indignation of Mark's friends. But one officer - witnesses claim - deliberately taunted them.

Since the bad publicity of the Sheena McDonald case, the metropolitan police seem to be hyper-defensive in any Polac episode. British motorists are currently being barraged with a publicity campaign whose stark message is: "Speed Kills." It is being backed up by the installation of robot cameras virtually behind every traffic sign.

In articles Sheena McDonald wrote, after she recovered from her injuries, she vigorously contradicted the police defence suggestion that she may have had too much to drink when she was hit by a police car.

One of the witnesses to the King's Road accident lives in Los Angeles. In that city, he told me, the LAPD can only speed in specified emergencies: "officer down", or "crime in progress", notably. And they must sound a siren: even in Beverly Hills at one o'clock in the morning. Are British police regulations as strict?

webTitle: In brief: Connery turned down £10m to return as James Bond

fields.headline: Connery turned down £10m to return as James Bond
fields.standfirst: Plus: Zellwegger and Pfeiffer keep it in the family; Eminem to make screen debut as a bad boy; Tom Hanks admits he's a football fan; two Mummies are enough for Rachel Weisz
fields.trailText: Plus: Zellwegger and Pfeiffer keep it in the family; Eminem to make screen debut as a bad boy; Tom Hanks admits he's a football fan; two Mummies are enough for Rachel Weisz
fields.body:
 Sean Connery has revealed that he turned down more than £10m to return to the role of James Bond after his last 007 film, Never Say Never Again, although the offer would have made Connery the highest paid actor in the world. The veteran Oscar winner told reporters: "They were talking wild sums back then to get me into another Bond. Much as I enjoyed the Bond films back in the 60s, I needed a fresh challenge. A new direction. I could have just stayed where I was and made an incredible amount of money. Others would have done so. But not me. That isn't arrogance or me saying how wealthy I am. Far from it. I think I am being honest and putting people who say I watch the pennies in their place."

 Golden Globe winner Renee Zellweger is in talks to play Michelle Pfeiffer's daughter in White Oleander, according to the Hollywood Reporter. Despite competition from Susan Sarandon and American Beauty star Mena Suvari, Pfeiffer and Zellweger are the main contenders to appear in the adaptation of Jane Finch's novel about a fraught relationship between a mother and daughter.

 Controversial rapper Eminem who has just finished a series of concerts in Britain is set to make his film debut playing a villain, according to an interview with Radio One today. The 28-year-old rapper, real name Marshall Mathers, said he had finally been sent a script that appealed to him. "It is an action movie," he told the station. "That is all I can say. I would be the villain. This is the first offer I have got that actually sounded appealing to me."

 Double Oscar winner Tom Hanks is apparently a fan of British football and a dedicated supporter of Aston Villa. It is unclear whether the Cast Away star has ever seen the team play, but the club are reportedly so pleased that they have offered him a personalised shirt and invitation to watch a game.

 Rachel Weisz has announced that she will not be appearing in Mummy III even before the second film in the series has been released, although the British actress, who stars in the sequel alongside Bedazzled star Brendan Fraser, says that making the follow-up was a lot of fun. "If there is another one it will be without me," she said. "I loved doing The Mummy Returns because it was like a wonderful family reunion. And my character has really evolved, so it was also quite challenging. But twice is definitely enough!"

fields.headline: Genome project dispute escalates
fields.standfirst: Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The two teams of scientists leading research on the human genetic code, or genome, have today abandoned any hope of cooperation as they argued over methodology and how their data should be made available to other researchers.
fields.body:
The two teams of scientists leading research on the human genetic code, or genome, have today abandoned any hope of cooperation as they argued over methodology and how their data should be made available to other researchers.

An earlier truce dissolved as the publicly funded Human Genome Project launched a blistering attack on its privately owned US rival Celera Genomics.

Last June the two sides agreed to declare the race to work out all the molecular sequences in human DNA a draw. Both announced they had simultaneously achieved the goal of working out a 94% complete first draft of the genome.

But today the international public consortium accused Celera, headed by controversial gene pioneer, Dr Craig Venter, of producing an inferior product, failing in its key objects, and holding back science by imposing commercial restrictions on its data.

HGP said that Celera's gene map, though a little larger, is less ordered than the consortium's version and riddled with gaps. It also relied heavily on publicly available HGP data, it was claimed - so much so that without it Celera's "Book of Life" could not have been written at all.

Dr Venter has in the past been scathing about the publicly funded project, claiming his "shotgun" method of genome sequencing was faster and cheaper, and accusing the consortium of wasting research money.

Dr Mike Dexter, the director of the Wellcome Trust and a member of HGP, said today that his consortium's work is "a gift to the world." He said that if scientists charged for the information, researchers in areas like India and China would not be able to conduct important studies due to lack of funds.

"We find it remarkable that scientists from developing nations have accessed this data over 300,000 times," he said. "It is important that the data is not available on a commercial licence."

The attack on Celera came as HGP published a new series of papers on the genome in the journal, Nature, including a 30,000-word definitive analysis of the draft sequence.

Both employ a system of chopping up the genome randomly into bits and seeing where the pieces fit. But whereas the HGP method sequences small sections of DNA separately before putting the pieces of the jigsaw together, Celera's technique attempts to assemble the entire genome in one go.

Sir John Sulston, former director of the Sanger Centre in Cambridgeshire, which sequenced a third of the genome for the consortium, said today: "Celera has repeatedly said we have wasted research money in doing what we have done with our American collaborators. We did it because we believed that probably the claim that the Celera method would work on its own was false.

"What we can say today is that we were right. They failed by their own standards. The pure whole 'shotgun' technology did not work," he added.

Dr Venter today denied that he was limiting scientists' access to the genome data produced by his company, saying that the data is freely available to scientists as long as there is no attempt at a commercial gain from Celera data.

He also rejected suggestions that Celera's data was of a lower quality than that produced by publicly funded scientists, saying: "Our data will clearly stand the test of time. Most reputable scientists dealing with both data sets know that our data is clearly superior."

fields.headline: Cook Report team sue NoW
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Nine members of the Cook Report production team have issued writs against the News of the World for libel, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nine members of the Cook Report production team - including Roger Cook and former series producer Mike Morley - have issued writs against the News of the World for libel.

Last year, the newspaper published allegations of fakery, alleging interviews with people presented by the programme as criminals were staged.

David Price, the lawyer who successfully sued the Mirror over allegations his client Debbie Price had knowingly booked fake guests for BBC1's Vanessa show, said the stories had caused "massive damage and hurt to all my clients".

"Accusing a broadcast journalist of regularly deceiving viewers with faked television is a serious attack on professional integrity," Mr Price added.

"The News of the World was prepared to condemn my clients on the basis of wholly unreliable sources."

The News of The World was not available for comment.

webTitle: 'Livingstone u-turn does not go far enough'

fields.headline: 'Livingstone u-turn does not go far enough'
fields.trailText: London boroughs are today complaining that mayor Ken Livingstone's climbdown on his weighty budget proposals does not go far enough.
fields.body:
London boroughs are today complaining that mayor Ken Livingstone's climbdown on his weighty budget proposals does not go far enough.

With the London assembly threatening to slash millions from his first budget, Mr Livingstone has suggested scaling back the proposed increase to the average band D council tax from £38 to £28 per year. The whole of the remaining increase will go to the Metropolitan police.

Mr Livingstone said he had "gone the extra mile to listen and seek compromise and agreement" with the assembly in his final draft budget.

But Sir Robin Wales, chairman of the Association of London Government (ALG), said: "Any savings for Londoners are to be welcomed, but we'd like the mayor to consider additional cuts." ALG leaders will enter talks with Mr Livingstone this afternoon aimed at resolving their disagreements.

They are worried about the effect the mayor's precept will have on council tax. Under Mr Livingstone's original budget proposals, band D bills would have shot up by around 5% before councils added in their own increases to fund frontline services.

He has now conceded almost all the assembly's proposed cuts, including £9.3m in efficiency savings from the metropolitan police budget. But Mr Livingstone has remained defiant on the transport budget.

The assembly had called on the mayor to cut the entire £23.6m increase for Transport for London (TfL) which was destined to form the organisation's reserves. The mayor now wants an increase of just over £10m. Said Mr Livingstone: "The transport budget I am proposing is the absolute minimum needed to ensure London gets the full programme of planned transport improvement and to safeguard the financial position of TfL. I still believe my original plans were a better and more secure option - delivering the programme will now need especially careful management but I have put the objective of achieving consensus first." Assembly budget committee chairwoman Baroness Sally Hamwee said both the Met and TfL budgets could be "clearer and tighter".

Last week Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens and transport commissioner Bob Kiley pleaded with the assembly not to force them into a financial juggling act by calling for swingeing cuts.

Mr Livingstone has also accepted a proposed £2.318 million cut to money earmarked for core GLA services such as cultural initiatives and health monitoring. He intends to manage these cuts by keeping a tight control of staffing and closely timing the introduction of new initiatives.

The mayor presents his final draft budget to the assembly on Thursday and will have to give reasons if any amendments previously made by them are not included.

The assembly may amend this final budget only by a two-thirds majority.

fields.headline: Putin dodges Ukraine scandal
fields.standfirst: The case of a murdered journalist is causing political ripples in Russia, reports Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: The case of a murdered journalist is causing political ripples in Russia, reports Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
Russian president Vladimir Putin's assessment of the angry mood in Ukraine on the eve of his summit with his beleaguered counterpart Leonid Kuchma was carefully worded with exquisite tact.

As thousands of protesters marched through the streets of the capital Kiev - brandishing banners accusing the president of the murder of an opposition journalist and baying for his resignation - Mr Putin chose to play down the crisis.

Acknowledging that he was aware of the "acute political problems" troubling the government, Mr Putin argued that the furious uprising was merely a sign of healthy democratic society in action.

"There is nothing special in the fact that an internal political struggle is underway," he said, as crowds chanting 'Ukraine without Kuchma!' gathered in the city centre. "I think this is a sign of a normal democratic society."

Mr Putin has contrived to avoid coming face to face with these manifestations of democracy in his meetings in Ukraine today. Instead of convening in Kiev, the two leaders met in the smaller, quieter city Dnipropetrovsk, a safe 300 miles south of the capital.

Anxious to prevent opposition activists sabotaging the meeting, security officials emptied the streets, prompting locals to complain that they had not witnessed such feverish police-orchestrated document checks since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

Mr Putin's visit to Ukraine comes as an unprecedented political crisis unfolds for the country's political leadership. The question of whether the "Kuchmagate" cassette scandal fits into Mr Putin's vision of a "normal democratic society" in operation remains a moot point.

Over the past few weeks, left and right wing opposition groups have come together to call on the president to quit. Mr Kuchma's political future has been under threat since late November when a lurid scandal erupted involving a series of foul-mouthed secretly taped conversations and the discovery of the corpse of missing journalist Georgy Gongadze.

Recordings made by a presidential bodyguard (who placed a dictatophone under the president's sofa) were released to the press. They revealed a sequence of highly damaging conversations in which the president apparently ordered his senior officials to "dispense with" Mr Gongadze - the editor of a Ukrainian internet newspaper focusing on political and financial corruption.

A headless and gruesomely disfigured corpse was discovered in a shallow grave in the woods near Kiev last November, and was later identified by the journalist's family as Mr Gongadze.

Last week, the prosecutor general confirmed that the voices on the tapes are genuine, but the Ukrainian president continues to insist that he was framed and has accused journalists of spreading "fairy tales" about him.

On Saturday, Mr Kuchma sacked Leonid Derkach, the head of the Ukrainian secret police, who was also implicated in the Gongadze affair, in an attempt to placate his critics.

Opposition activists welcomed the decision, but insisted Mr Kuchma himself must be the next to go. The newly-established Forum of National Salvation is calling for Mr Kuchma's impeachment and is working simultaneously to "put an end to the criminal regime, establish truth and law, and direct Ukraine to a European path of development."

Officially, today's the bilateral talks between the two presidents steered clear of the scandal, although aides indicated that the subject was discussed at an informal supper late on Sunday night.

Instead, the two men were set to sign a series of agreements on energy, space and economic relations. Mr Putin said that his trip was a reflection of Russia's desire to maintain close relations and indicated that, in spite of political crisis, Moscow would not "pause in its cooperation with Ukraine".

There was speculation, however, in the Moscow press over how much longer Russia's cooperation with Ukraine will be done through the intermediary of Mr Kuchma, with several commentators suggesting that Kremlin officials were already starting to build covert relations with possible successors to the Ukrainian president.

"Ukrainian experts unanimously state that, in such a situation, Russia should not be betting on Leonid Kuchma alone. They believe that the Kremlin will soon be developing contacts with his possible successors in the event of an impeachment," the liberal daily newspaper Sevodnya declared.

Some analysts have argued that Mr Putin's visit represented a show of support for his Ukrainian counterpart, but political commentator Alexander Dergachev argued: "Moscow is interested in preserving control in Ukraine -with or without the help of Kuchma.

"Moscow will be looking for a replacement." Possible successors to the president include, he said, the leader of Workers' Ukraine, Sergei Tigipko, or the current prime minister Viktor Yushchenko.

webTitle: Brown rebuffs EC attack on spending plans

fields.headline: Brown rebuffs EC attack on spending plans
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today stage a showdown with Brussels when he attacks a European commission report which criticises his pre-election spending plans.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today stage a showdown with Brussels when he attacks a European commission report which criticises his pre-election spending plans.

In a sign of the chancellor's increasingly wary approach to Europe, Mr Brown will dismiss claims that Britain has broken EU financial discipline rules.

At a meeting of EU finance ministers in Brussels, Ecofin, Mr Brown will call for a more "intelligent" approach after a European commission report claimed that his spending plans will create a deficit in three years' time.

Independent estimates say that if Britain were a member of the single European currency, the chancellor would be forced to take draconian action to comply with EU rules. These could involve increasing the basic rate of income tax by 2p or cutting investment by £12bn.

Government sources last night laughed off the EC report, which was compiled using figures supplied by the Treasury. Britain has to submit a mini pre-budget report to the EC every year under the "convergence programme". The report says that the chancellor's spending plans are inconsistent with the European stability pact which should be close to balance or in surplus.

One government source said last night that the chancellor would tell the commission to lay off Britain because he was abiding by his "golden rule" which allows the Treasury to borrow for investment.

"If our fiscal position is sound, our debt level is low and there is a need for investment in infrastructure then we should not be criticised for borrowing for investment," the source said. "We will express a concern that interpreting the stability pact too rigidly would force member states to do something that is not in their national interest."

Sources close to Mr Brown insisted last night that his tough message in Brussels today would not amount to a "sixth test" on whether Britain was ready to join the euro. Pro-European ministers were disturbed recently when it was reported that the chancellor be lieved that the government should tighten the criteria for British membership.

Some pro-European ministers will see the chancellor's move today as another sign of his guarded approach to economic and monetary union, not least because his office briefed the Eurosceptic Times newspaper about his showdown in Brussels.

Tony Blair caused surprise last week when he said the government would carry out an assessment of the Treasury's five economic tests for membership of the euro within two years of the election. Mr Brown's tough stance today may be seen as an attempt to show who is running the government's euro policy.

The Tories will seize on to day's meeting in Brussels to attack the government on two fronts. They will say that the EC report is an example of how Europe would play a far greater role in British affairs if the country joined the euro. The Tories will also say that the report shows that the chancellor is spending more than Britain can afford.

The Ecofin conference will also see the chancellor criticise European investment into research and development. Mr Brown will invite fellow finance ministers to support a study on R&D shortcomings.

He will remind colleagues that the average R&D spend among European nations is around 2% of national income, compared with 3% in the United States and Japan.

webTitle: Blair promises better deal for self-employed

fields.headline: Blair promises better deal for self-employed
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's support for business was extended last week when Tony Blair said ministers needed to devise policies to back the self-employed.
fields.body:
The government's support for business was extended last week when Tony Blair said ministers needed to devise policies to back the self-employed.

The prime minister said the government had to listen to the concerns of the self-employed, who were a vital part of the economy and needed to increase in number.

Many self-employed groups, such as computer contractors, have complained that they are treated with suspicion by government departments including the Department of Trade and Industry and the Inland Revenue.

The dispute over the tax rule IR35, which restricts the ability of contractors to be directors of their own limited companies and pay themselves in dividends, proved to many that Labour ministers failed to understand the nature of their business and the minefield of tax rules they faced.

Self-employed workers have complained they are neglected by their trade bodies, associations and unions. These bodies are accused of focusing on the needs of larger businesses.

A small number of new online communities claim to represent the self-employed and provide them with specialist services.

This week Mongrel Worlds, a venture capital-backed start-up, added to the list with a "21st century guild" targeted at self-employed professionals under the banner name, Alodis. It plans to step in where it believes the Confederation of British Industry, the Institute of Directors and the Federation of Small Businesses have failed.

Alodis chief executive, Julia Hutchinson, said self-employed professionals needed a voice in government and she would take up issues on their behalf. Sole traders in fields such as marketing, the media, and accountancy will be targeted rather than computer specialists and trades people such as plumbers.

"Self-employed professionals are becoming an increasingly important part of general corporate life and we hope to raise their profile. We plan to work with other stakeholders like the CBI and IoD when we take up their cause, but three quarters of self-employed professionals believe they don't get any support from their trade bodies."

Ministers needed to move quickly after a study funded by the firm showed that the number of professionals working for themselves was set to double to 3.2m over the next 10 years, she added.

The firm has a marketing budget of £4m and plans to sell a mix of services and products including a magazine and tax software by September.

Its main rival is Elancentric. Chief executive Helen Wilkinson, a founder of the think-tank Demos, said the company had £500,000 of venture capital money to develop a service for the self-employed.

The operation has more than 900 pages of content. Unlike Alodis, which charges for each service, Elancentric's users pay a £50 membership fee, though 5,000 free memberships are available while the website is in launch phase.

The firm takes a broader look at the estimated 3m self-employed market. It hopes to provide a service to professionals but also targets people working in traditional trades, who will require its services as they turn to the internet more and more to generate business .

webTitle: Government unveils policy on industry strategy

fields.headline: Byers and Blunkett gear up for election
fields.standfirst:
Government unveils policy on industrial strategy to narrow deficit in skills and innovation

Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Government unveils policy on industrial strategy to narrow deficit in skills and innovation.
fields.body:
Measures to narrow Britain's deficit in skills, innovation and entrepreneurship will be announced by the government tomorrow as it lays out its industrial strategy for a second term in office.

In a white paper, Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and David Blunkett, the employment and education secretary, are to highlight measures to tackle some of Britain's long-standing supply-side failings.

In the latest signal that Labour is gearing up for an election campaign, the white paper will stress the next steps required to improve economic performance and spread prosperity from the affluent south-east to the regions.

Although the government believes it has delivered economic stability since the 1997 election, important areas of weakness are identified in the DTI's competitiveness indicators published today. Sources said that the recommendations in the white paper would dovetail with tax changes announced by Gordon Brown in next month's Budget.

Mr Brown will warn his fellow EU finance ministers today that Europe must raise its game on research and development to improve its poor record on business innovation.

While the US and Japan spend 3% of national income in research, the figure for Europe is 2%. Treasury sources said the chancellor would call for a study into why Europe is lagging behind the world's two biggest economies and whether European rules banning subsidies to industry need to be changed so that tax incentives could be used to encourage firms to invest in R&D.

The competitiveness indicators report concludes that economic performance is being held back by poor basic skills and a shortage of intermediate-level vocational skills, where Britain's record compares unfavourably with countries such as Germany.

It adds that the UK's lowly position in the global productivity league table is the consequence of "decades of under-investment", and that the strength of the science base is not reflected in commercial spin-offs. Mr Byers said: "Firm economic foundations are now in place for us to build for the future. We have made a start but there is a lot more work to be done if we are to adapt to a constantly changing global economy.

"We need to remove obstacles to enterprise and entrepreneurship in all parts of the country to address the skills shortage in our workforce and to raise educational standards for all."

The DTI published its first set of competitiveness indicators in December 1999, and believes that there may have been some closing of the productivity gap in the meantime. The report admits, however, that it is "difficult to distinguish how much of this [improvement] is cyclical and how much a response to an improvement in the macro-economic environment".

The report says that Britain is receptive to new ideas and is effective at drawing on the "global knowledge pool". It stresses, though, that Britain "performs relatively poorly in terms of turning new ideas into commercial success."

The competitiveness indicators report concludes that economic performance is being held back by poor basic skills and a shortage of intermediate-level vocational skills, where Britain's record compares unfavourably with countries such as Germany. It adds that the UK's lowly position in the global productivity league table is the consequence of "decades of under-investment", and that the strength of the science base is not reflected in commercial spin-offs. Mr Byers said: "Firm economic foundations are now in place for us to build for the future. We have made a start but there is a lot more work to be done if we are to adapt to a constantly changing global economy. "We need to remove obstacles to enterprise and entrepreneurship in all parts of the country to address the skills shortage in our workforce and to raise educational standards for all." The DTI published its first set of competitiveness indicators in December 1999, and believes that there may have been some closing of the productivity gap in the meantime. The report admits, however, that it is "difficult to distinguish how much of this [improvement] is cyclical and how much a response to an improvement in the macro-economic environment". The report says that Britain is receptive to new ideas and is effective at drawing on the "global knowledge pool". It stresses, though, that Britain "performs relatively poorly in terms of turning new ideas into commercial success."

webTitle: Minister steps in over 'failing' council services

fields.headline: Minister steps in over 'failing' council services
fields.trailText: Health minister John Hutton has taken radical action to turn around children's services in Merton by placing the London borough on special measures.
fields.body:
Health minister John Hutton has taken radical action to turn around children's services in Merton by placing the London borough on special measures.

The move comes in the wake of a social services inspectorate (SSI) report, which raised serious concerns, particularly about the council's duty service. An SSI inspection last November found that "a lack of vision, strategy and management" had led to inadequate planning and protection for children at risk.

The SSI pointed to a number of areas requiring urgent management and council attention including:

 Insufficient safeguards for looked-after children and those on the child protection register. These include a failure to review the majority of looked-after children and some children on the child protection register in accordance with regulations;
 Insufficient attention to the individual needs siblings who are looked-after or on the child protection register;
 Poor care planning for looked-after children;
 Inconsistent assessments which failed to consider all risks to children;
 Poor practice within the duty service leading to an unsafe service;
 Inadequate responses to complaints from children and families;
 A lack of compliance with fostering regulations when approving, reviewing and monitoring of foster carers;
 No council "ownership" of corporate parenting responsibilities;
 Councillors not properly scrutinising the performance of children's services.

Mr Hutton said: "This report highlights a catalogue of failings which cannot be allowed to continue. It is unacceptable that the children in this borough are not safeguarded adequately. Councils must ensure that there are effective systems in place at all times to make sure children are kept safe."

A council is added to the special measures list when there are serious concerns about the quality of its social services. The council must then develop an action plan and submit monthly monitoring information to the SSI.

There are currently 15 councils subject to special measures.

fields.headline: Wenger defends Bergkamp axe decision
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger has defended his decision to stop Dennis Bergkamp from travelling to Lyon for Arsenal's Champions League tie tomorrow.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger has defended his decision to stop Dennis Bergkamp from travelling to Lyon for Arsenal's Champions League tie tomorrow.

"I just didn't feel it was the right preparation for him with all the fixtures we face now, including the FA Cup tie against Chelsea next Sunday," he said.

"Dennis wanted to go and he has made trips like this before when we have needed him - but playing two matches in four days plus all the travelling is not the best thing." Thierry Henry also remains a doubt for the Gunners. "His ankle is still not 100% and I will have to see how he is," Wenger said.

fields.headline: Napster
fields.standfirst: US judges are about to decide whether to kill off the free music download service. Here's our guide to the best links on the controversial swap shop
fields.trailText: 1. The cult internet song-swap service, Napster, may be forced to shut up shop today if judges in the US uphold an injunction against the company.
fields.body:
1. The cult internet song-swap service, Napster, may be forced to shut up shop today if judges in the US uphold an injunction against the company.

2. Right now, those users share music as digital MP3 files, with each user allowing others access to their personal collection. The result is the world's largest collection of free music.

3. Users can download the music on to their computers or specialised portable MP3 players.

4. The world's biggest record companies filed suit against Napster last year for failing to pay up for the music downloaded by its users.

5. Sony, Warner Music, EMI and Universal say Napster violated copyright law, and they want the site shut down.

6. A fifth company, BMG, is continuing with its lawsuit despite its parent company, Bertelsmann, doing a deal with Napster. The two are to jointly develop a subscription service that will pay copyright owners while still giving Napster's 5m users the ability to swap music. Music companies want to see all free sites replaced by paying services.

7. If the judges' decision today goes the wrong way for Napster, there's no guarantee that its users won't defect to other song swap sites, such as iMesh or Scour.com, if they're charged for songs.

8. Musicians such as Metallica have complained that free music sites are doing little more than stealing the product of their creativity.

9. But British band Chumbawamba released an internet-only single, entitled Pass it Along (MP3 Mix), to attack anti-Napster musicians for their alleged greed.

10. Either way, the future of Napster founder Shawn Fanning seems assured. After the legal fees are sorted out, Silicon Valley is sure to embrace him as the most inspired entrepreneur of his generation.

fields.headline: From diatribe to dialogue
fields.standfirst: Businesses are still grappling with the challenge of effective corporate social responsibility, reports Manny Amadi
fields.trailText: Businesses are still grappling with the challenge of effective corporate social responsibility, reports Manny Amadi
fields.body:
Many of the dot.coms that dominated discussions at last year's World Economic Forum summit in Davos, Switzerland, are now dot.gones. "Globalization backlash" was front of mind at this year's summit, as business executives, political leaders and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) gathered to discuss the pressing need to "sustain growth and bridge the divides". This theme was front of mind, too, for the hundreds of demonstrators gathered outside.

The "battle of Seattle" and subsequent globalisation backlash demonstrations seem to have concentrated minds in many multinationals - and it showed in Davos. While the possible fallout from the current downturn in the US economy was a constant subject for discussion, the urgent agenda for the future was the need for real and effective engagement between businesses, governments and NGOs to tackle social issues.

This was debated in robust fashion at a special summit session, aptly titled Dialogue or Diatribe: When Business and NGOs Meet.

Jack Greenberg, chairman of McDonald's Corporation, and Hendrik Verfaille, president of Monsanto, joined NGO leaders Thilo Bode, executive director of Greenpeace International, Pierre Sané, secretary general of Amnesty International and Burkhard Gnarig, chief executive officer of the International Save the Children Alliance, in a debate which put most of the issues on the table but brought little agreement on concrete action.

The participants' honesty was refreshing and was itself an indicator of how much the dialogue between businesses and NGOs is improving, but the NGOs present were clear that diatribe is still needed to push many multinational corporations to take action on social issues. Hendrik Verfaillie didn't shirk the issue and was upfront that Monsanto had learnt some tough lessons. "There are commercial benefits to being a good corporate citizen and to engaging and communicating with NGOs and communities," he said. He acknowledged that Monsanto had miscalculated initially by not engaging with NGOs and consumer groups. Monsanto was forced to review its approach. It now has a programme of active dialogue with NGOs and other groups. What this is achieving wasn't made particularly clear.

Mr Greenberg proposed four key principles for dialogue between businesses and NGOs - to communicate openly, listen for understanding, assume innocence in others and treat each other with respect. He recognised the huge influence and power for change held by businesses and acknowledged the need for that influence to be used positively. McDonald's, he said, was doing its very best but remains, in his view, a victim of NGO misunderstanding and sometimes disinformation.

Thilo Bode observed that dialogue between companies and NGOs was nothing new. Companies still take the credit on occasions when, in fact, an NGO like Greenpeace has pushed them into action. This point was well-illustrated the previous night, when I heard a senior Coca-Cola executive praise the company's social responsibility programmes and achievements to the heavens, without mention of any external pressures that might have concentrated executives' minds and contributed to change.

Mr Bode questioned whether companies really understand NGOs and expressed concern that most chief executive officers present were more concerned about the cooling of the US economy than the warming of our planet. Mr Sané argued that unless the social movement gets stronger, the 21st century could be worse than the 20th in terms of human rights abuses.

The International Save the Children Alliance's Burkhard Gnarig went further, insisting that there are times when NGOs have to mobilise the public to reverse a corporate policy. "We can't give up diatribe," he said.

So, will talk turn to action as a result of the summit? The World Economic Forum plays a key role in bringing leading players from the business, political and NGO arenas together in creative, open and constructive dialogue. It is no accident that more NGOs were present this year than ever before. As Claude Smadja, managing director of the World Economic Forum, said: "Amid all the uncertainties about globalisation and the IT revolution, NGOs have emerged as spokespersons for people concerned about what is happening to the quality of life and social mores. The political world has been unable to assert its role, while business is seen to be arrogant. NGOs have moved into this vacuum and become more assertive."

My overall impression at Davos was that many companies are still stuck in a time warp, believing that corporate philanthropy - donating to charity - is enough. This can be likened to outsourcing the business conscience. However, many of the younger business people and social entrepreneurs who attended the forum - and the leaders of a few established companies who are staying ahead of the competition - are clear that we have to find really practical ways to fully integrate social, environmental and economic benefits in global business strategies if we are all to win. Companies have to become accountable in these three areas and they are increasingly being held to account by NGOs and others. Corporate performance must now be driven by strategies that deliver measurable positive benefits for people and the planet, as well as profits.

Consensus on specific actions at Davos was relatively thin on the ground, with some notable, and highly commendable, exceptions. An estimated 250m children under the age of 15 are working in developing countries and almost 900m adults throughout the world are illiterate. A special taskforce, asked to identify practical initiatives with which to tackle the issue of child labour and education, set the United Nations' special September session on children as a deadline for agreeing concrete action at a global level. This is one example of dialogue which will evolve into a specific drive for action but it will take much more real and concerted action by businesses and NGOs if we are to "bridge the divides".

As Kofi Annan, secretary-general of the United Nations, warned at Davos: "If we cannot make globalisation work for all, in the end, it will work for none. The unequal distribution of benefits and the imbalances in global rule-making, which characterize globalisation today, will inevitable produce backlash and protectionism. Companies are learning that, as markets have gone global, so must the concept and practice of corporate social responsibility."

 Manny Amadi is chief executive officer of Cause & Effect Marketing

webTitle: Cream magazine forced to change name

fields.headline: Cream magazine forced to change name
fields.trailText: 2pm: A magazine has had to rename just weeks before launch after legal threats from a nightclub with the same name, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A high-profile magazine has had to be renamed just weeks before launch after legal threats from a nightclub with the same name.

The magazine formerly known as Cream has been forced to dump the name in favour of the new title Ampersand, after receiving "aggressive legal threats" from Cream nightclub in Liverpool.

Publisher Jonathan Kern said: "Although we feel we would have been victorious in any sort of legal dispute with Cream nightclub, commercially we did not want to become entangled in a lengthy legal wrangle that would prevent us from hitting the newsstands."

A spokeswoman said Ampersand was still on course for a March 7 launch.

The title is being billed as offering an alternative to the obsession with sex and celebrity in mainstream magazines.

The launch issue will feature contributions from former Pink Floyd band member Nick Mason and independent MP Martin Bell.

webTitle: Weather eye makes Ellen simply the best

fields.headline: Weather eye makes Ellen simply the best
fields.standfirst: Map of Ellen MacArthur's route
fields.trailText: Quite simply, Ellen MacArthur is the best oceangoing sailor Britain has ever produced. She may have been beaten to the line by Michel Desjoyeaux, but that should not detract from the scale of her achievement.
fields.body:
Quite simply, Ellen MacArthur is the best oceangoing sailor Britain has ever produced. She may have been beaten to the line by Michel Desjoyeaux, but that should not detract from the scale of her achievement.

The Vendée Globe is the toughest race in the sailing world. To finish it in a little over 94 days, 12 days faster than the previous record, is testament to a huge talent. At the age of 24, a decade after she came to the sport, this was a milestone performance.

For the past three months, MacArthur has been on her own, skippering a 60ft yacht, that would ordinarily be crewed by 11 people, in the foulest conditions.

To achieve this calls for remarkable mental and physical strength. To do so at the speed MacArthur has demands an even more astonishing level of skill, courage and belief.

It is the ability to read the weather that marks out the exceptional sailor, and MacArthur is blessed with a particular skill. Her superior interpretation of the same meterological information that every sailor in the race had was one of the keys to her success.

Once they have digested all the data that appears on their computer screens, great sailors will study the clouds and make their decisions about what the wind will do. Her knack at predicting accurately where the wind will be strongest and in the right direction, is uncanny.

It is this skill that enabled her to track down Desjoyeaux as they sailed up the east coast of South America. About 1,000 miles off Rio de Janeiro, she detected that a high pressure system had moved further west than normal and was heading for where she thought the strongest winds would be. She was right, and made up 600 miles in three or four days.

Her other great skill is as an engineer. This includes dealing with the boat's sophisticated electronics as well as repairing sails and rigging.

Race winner Desjoyeaux appeared baffled by what MacArthur had achieved. "Ellen is a great mystery to me," he said. "She is 10 years younger than me and she could have beaten me."

"She's achieved the unachievable," said Sir Peter Blake, who has won the Whitbread round-the-world race and the America's Cup. "For someone of her age to do this gives a huge direction to other young people."

With the world at her feet, MacArthur will today announce her forthcoming plans. They are likely to include the French 60ft trimaran offshore circuit.

We may not know a huge amount about that particular series in Britain, but if MacArthur has her way - and she usually does - we soon will.

Birth of obsession

1977 MacArthur is born to teacher parents in landlocked Derbyshire

1985 Aged eight, MacArthur goes sailing while holidaying on the east coast with her aunt and an obsession is born

1990 Buys her first boat, an 8ft dinghy, after saving up her school dinner money for three years

1995 Circumnavigates the UK single-handed, becomes the youngest person to pass the Yachtmaster Offshore Qualification and is named British Yachtsman of the Year and sailing's young hope in France

1997 Takes one-way ticket to Brest where she buys and refits a 21ft yacht, Le Poisson, living underneath it to save money. Competes in the Mini Transat transatlantic race

1999 Wins her class in the Route de Rhum, another transatlantic event, and sponsors begin to take notice

2000 Secures £2m sponsorship from Kingfisher group and planning begins for Vendée Globe. Race begins on November 5

fields.headline: Hero's welcome as history is made
fields.standfirst:
Thousands greet lone British sailor Ellen MacArthur at end of magnificent round the world adventure

Map of Ellen MacArthur's route
fields.trailText: Thousands greet lone British sailor Ellen MacArthur at end of magnificent round the world adventure.
fields.byline: Paul Weaver  in Les Sables d'Olonne and  Paul Kelso
fields.body:
The legend of Ellen MacArthur emerged from the darkness of the Atlantic last night and received a welcome that would have drowned out the storms of the southern ocean.

Fireworks, floodlights and flares shone upon this little piece of the Bay of Biscay as MacArthur brought her magnificent Vendée Globe adventure to an end and confirmed second place in the toughest boat race of them all.

An ecstatic crowd of more than 200,000 - significantly more that welcomed Saturday's winner, Frenchman Michel Desjoyeaux - greeted the youngest (24) and smallest (5ft 2in) competitor in the fleet, their beloved jeune espoire de la voile (sailing's young hope). Some banners bore her favourite message, Ellen - A Donf (go for it).

Hundreds of journalists and an assortment of TV crews battled with the crowds for the best vantage point. A flotilla of boats awaited and helicopters circled for a view of this self-confessed "geek" and solo sailor from the land-locked county of Derbyshire.

As the gun fired to mark the end of MacArthur's race, she jumped up and down, pumping the air with her fists in pure joy. She was immediately joined by her jubilant family together with Mark Turner, her project manager.

After docking, MacArthur poured champagne over her 60ft yacht, Kingfisher, and kissed it before bursting into tears and making a reluctant departure.

She said: "The boat did it. I was just the pilot. This is all too much. I didn't expect anything like this. I can't explain how I feel because I don't know myself. But I do know I'm happy to finish today.

"I'm so happy to see my friends but at the same time I really don't feel like a party tonight. I think I have learned a lot about myself and the boat. She admitted she would find it difficult to leave the boat with which she has shared one of the greatest achievements in British sailing history. "The last couple of weeks have been very emotional. It's been tough to see Kingfisher unable to realise her full potential." Apart from some damage, the yacht was in "great shape, amazing after 24,000 miles. I've been cleaning her so she would look beautiful".

Her parents, Ken and Avril, who once worried about the little girl who put her bed in the garage and slept in a bag to make more room for her maps and charts, went out to meet her. She had to climb down the mast and she had gone over the edge in terms of her strength and endurance.

MacArthur's feat in becoming the youngest woman to circumnavigate the globe singlehanded has ensured huge interest from publishers. A book based on her email diary could attract offers of around £100,000.

webTitle: Ellen MacArthur to set sail again

fields.headline: Ellen MacArthur to set sail again
fields.trailText: Record-breaking single-handed yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur today announced her plans to take part in another race later this year - less than 24 hours after reaching dry land at the end of the Vendée Globe round-the-world race.
fields.body:
Record-breaking single-handed yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur today announced her plans to take part in another race later this year - less than 24 hours after reaching dry land at the end of the Vendée Globe round-the-world race.

The 24-year-old British yachtswoman, who crossed the finishing line for the Globe race last night, said she would compete in the Atlantic challenge race in July. She will use her yacht Kingfisher - but this time with a crew, she told a news conference in Les Sables d'Olonne, France.

Competitors in the race have to sail from Europe to the United States and take part in several legs off the American continent before returning to Europe.

Ms MacArthur looked less exhausted than when she finished second in the Vendée Globe, setting records as the fastest woman and youngest person to circumnavigate the Earth in a single-handed race.

She said she could face another Vendée Globe race, despite the dramas and dangers of the past three months, and spoke with great affection of her New Zealand built 60-foot yacht, Kingfisher. "In the past 12 months I have spent six months at sea with Kingfisher, mostly alone," she said. She wept as she paid tribute to Mark Turner, her business partner and project manager, saying: "There is no doubt about it - I could not be sitting here without him."

Ms MacArthur, who is from Derbyshire, added: "I do not see myself as being famous, but it's an immense pleasure to see hundreds and thousands of people to come from all over Europe to see me come home."

She said she had received an email from someone that summed up what it was like to survive and complete one of the world's toughest races, adding: "Courage is not having the energy to go on; it's going on when you do not have the energy. That's true."
