webTitle: How to compile the perfect charity report

fields.headline: How to compile the perfect charity report
fields.standfirst: Effective communication with the public is central to the success of a charity. At a recent  conference, charity commissioner David Taylor spoke on the elements that must be considered and included to produce the very best public reports.
fields.trailText: Effective communication with the public is central to the success of a charity. Charity commissioner David Taylor discussed the elements that must be included to produce the very best public reports at a recent conference.
fields.body:
Charity commissioner David Taylor's speech
Clear communication: changing the focus of the annual report

Introduction

I am very pleased to be here, not only as an ex-chair of CFDG but especially to welcome the joint initiative of ACEVO, CFDG and ICFM. And, of course, as a charity commissioner, it gives me the opportunity to support this gathering in its efforts to promote and improve the effectiveness of the annual report as a communications instrument in support of charities. A reminder that the commission's main aim is to give the public confidence in the integrity of charity. What better starting point for me today?

My words and thoughts embrace both the annual report and the financial statements.

Public perceptions

Some believe that the public sees charities as fundraisers for relief of poverty, and action in support of overseas aid, animals, children and health.

The public largely has contact with charities not as a beneficiary but as a potential source of funds.

Assessing the value of the annual report as a trusted means of communication, our opinion surveys have consistently shown that a charity's annual report and accounts are just about the only element of a charity's information about itself that people actually trust. MORI research in 1999 showed that people appear to trust this information as much as they trust information about charities that they get from regulatory bodies like ourselves. Conversely, and perhaps predictably, there is distrust of information given out by charities in the course of their fundraising.

You don't really need me to highlight the importance of the reputational risk to charities.

Influence of the press

Leaving aside charities where there may be serious mismanagement or fraudulent practices, some stories damage the whole sector. This may be where the charity has failed to communicate clearly why it is doing what it is doing or fails to appreciate how all its information, both narrative and numbers, will be interpreted. How many stories of good practice get into the news, except perhaps when there is a disaster or when a skillfully managed telethon captures the passions and imagination of viewers?

It is relevant to quote a press cutting in my in-tray. Its a quote from Andrew Watt, ICFM's head policy officer, reported in the Cardiff Western Mail: "The fact that critics had jumped on the NSPCC's statement revealed a problem of communication rather than finance. It was important for charities to make people aware how they were spending the money because the givers were now more interested in exactly where their money went. Each individual organisation needs to be honest and open about what they are doing and why they are doing it".

The Financial Times followed this with: "The NSPCC should have explained better the rationale behind its spending on marketing," and criticised the charity's communications policy.

I use these quotes not to single out the NSPCC's activities, nor in any way to criticise its policies, but simply to highlight the media minefield. It highlights how the press doing its job and how the public can so easily make assumptions and influence perceptions contrary to those you would wish.

How can we change some of these perceptions?

Clearer communication is the key.

So, explain what you do, what has gone well, what has gone badly, what work needs to be done, the impact the charity has had in the year. Show that you appreciate any concerns of your potential audience. Donors need to understand not only that their money is well used but also that it is well protected and not wasted.

How many times have we seen bland trustees' reports written, dare I say it here, often by accountants - who are not renowned for their flair in capturing the publics' imagination. Yet the same charity will issue a glossy brochure - the annual review - which tells the charity's story, sometimes without the numbers to explain and back up those stories, and is too late to influence potential supporters.

There is a major communications risk with fundraising material, especially mailshots. There is a risk that trust in what charities say will be reduced.

The commission's statement of recommended practice (Sorp)

The new title, "Accounting and reporting by charities" was no accident.

The commission has produced the revised Sorp, with much help from the sector itself (indeed, some of the culprits are here today) in support of clear communication. The recommended minimum requirements can be used as a very effective tool to get key messages across. However, even with the reduced "checklist" in the narrative section, it still remains with the authors to understand their audiences concerns, to understand the key messages that the charity wishes to convey. You must provide the balance that gives confidence and comforts readers that the charity is acting responsibly, is accountable for its actions, and is carrying out work that has a significant impact. But please don't just observe minimum requirements.

The information needed to discharge your duty of public accountability and stewardship can be supported by imaginative and innovative design, clarity and good presentation. All are important alongside technical compliance and financial accuracy.

The stories you need to tell

It is not possible to tell good stories in your report unless there are actually good stories to tell. If I were sitting on the trustees' or executive officers' side of the fence today, I would probably be thinking: "What story do I want to tell in my 2002 report?" and "What steps do I need to make to be able to tell that story?". In other words, if the charity has good planning processes, policies and organisational structures, all of which are clearly understood, then the chances of achieving your objectives are significantly increased.

Do remember that your report is not just a financial one. Non-financial performance indicators may be vitally important and interesting.

Rationale for requiring statements in trustees' report

 The report is where trustees focus on developments and achievements of the past year and explain future plans - it should reflect joined-up thinking and action;
 The report is a narrative to be seen as a cohesive part of the "report and accounts" package; not a series of unrelated statements;
 Demonstrate how policies fit in with organisation and how they impact upon performance;
 The story told by the Sorp, balance sheet and notes (not forgetting the accounting policies) should have a seemless link with the trustees' report.

For example, if we in monitoring can see that your trading subsidiary is in deep trouble, so can others. Explain it in the report.

If reserves are spilling over - or appear to be - and you don't think so, the communications remedy is obvious.

Accountability

Accountability is perhaps the most important buzzword, alongside transparency. Demonstrate responsibility and accountability by showing:
 That your charity is properly governed and managed with clear organisational structures. This can go much further than a list of people, by explaining what people do;
 That charity trustees understand their responsibilities to use monies raised effectively and efficiently for the beneficiary groups;
 That the charity has a clear focus on the work that needs to be done, a clear strategy for doing it, and understands the risks attached;
 Openness about the principal policies.

Following these precepts should at worst deflect criticism and at best help inspire public confidence.

What does the charity do?

In the past, we have all come across charity reports that fail to state what the charity does. I believe you should:
 Clearly set out who you have helped, what help you have given and then translate this into the numbers;
 Without some interpretation or measure of effectiveness it is very difficult for the reader to understand the potential impact;
 Explain what the actual activities were and why they are necessary;
 Explain who else you work with and why this is necessary;
 Explain why it is important to have services that support the charity's work (eg head office costs) and what these contribute;
 Be open about fundraising efforts, their effectiveness and the costs attached - remember the new requirements deal with this;
 Explain how volunteers are used and, if appropriate, estimate their contribution.

Explaining the future

 What still needs to be done;
 What are the strategies and plans for the forthcoming year;
 What are the key risks and how will these be managed;
 What are reserves going to be used for.

About your audiences

Remember in communicating your messages:
 Who needs to and who will see the report - is it just the trustees and the commission, or is it all key stakeholders? You know the list: employees, fundraisers, volunteers, donors, grant-makers and regulators;
 What about other local community groups or even the local or national press
 Decide how to get these parties to read them. Do you need to do something that focuses the stakeholder so they will open up the report and accounts and have a read;
 Decide how the messages can be got across in all contacts with the public.

What will the commission look for?

The revised Sorp pays more attention to and encourages a more intelligent trustees' report. We inspect both this report and the accounts report, but accounts and numbers are easier to produce than narrative.

My additional interest, which I hope you all share, is in improving annual reports. Monitoring may raise issues such as:
 Accuracy of charity details (address, objects, list of trustees, bankers, auditors, etc);
 Inappropriate level of reserves or inadequate explanation of policy;
 Major causes of concern;
 Trustee benefits;
 Related-party transactions;
 Problems within trading subsidiaries;
 Non-charitable trading.

Note that we have over 700k hits to our website each month, of which half are searches for information on charities. With electronic submission and availability of your information online by 2005 - this will include reports and accounts - just think how many people around the world will easily and quickly be able to get the wrong end of the stick!

Some conclusions

The revisions to the annual report and accounts in the proposed Sorp are all about transparency and the link between them. The legal reporting and accounting framework provides the right balance between prescriptiveness and opportunity and, when well written, will provide balance on accountability and achievements. Remember:
 A spirit of openness on governance, policies and performance will inspire confidence;
 The charity should be planning what story it wants to tell;
 The authors, not just accountants, and especially the trustees, need to know the audience;
 Many stakeholders find it difficult to interpret accounts, anticipate their questions or where their understanding may be lacking;
 You need to be able to persuade the public that the good you do is solid, visible and value for money;
 The more charities can shift the debate away from the size of their overheads and on the value of their achievements, the better.

A "down to earth" check-list:

A colleague has generously provided me with the following:

 What picture of the charity does your report paint?
 Have you put in the necessary legal details?
 Have you included any pictures - if you can afford them?
 Have you boasted enough about what you are doing?
 Have you confessed what you are not doing?
 Do you need to appeal for funds and if so do you say what funds would be spent on?
 Are you giving money away? If so:
     have you said how you are spending it
     how does this relate to your objectives?
     would an applicant know what they would get money for
     how do you make decisions about what to support?
 Have you too little/too much reserves?
     Can you justify this?
     How are you going to correct over/under reserves?
 Is there anyone who you need to praise, thank, beg from, butter up?
 Does the report show how trustees are managing?
 Have you told any stories about what you are doing?
 Have you told any lies?
 Have you any problems to report - especially ones you have overcome?
 Can you give any statistics about how good you have been?
 Have you said what the charity is doing?

 David Taylor gave this speech at a joint conference by the association of chief executives of voluntary organisations (ACEVO), the charity finance directors' group (CFDG) and the institute of charity fundraising managers (ICFM), which took place on January 18, 2001

Note that we have over 700k hits to our website each month, of which half are searches for information on charities. With electronic submission and availability of your information online by 2005 - this will include reports and accounts - just think how many people around the world will easily and quickly be able to get the wrong end of the stick! Some conclusions The revisions to the annual report and accounts in the proposed Sorp are all about transparency and the link between them. The legal reporting and accounting framework provides the right balance between prescriptiveness and opportunity and, when well written, will provide balance on accountability and achievements. Remember:  A spirit of openness on governance, policies and performance will inspire confidence;  The charity should be planning what story it wants to tell;  The authors, not just accountants, and especially the trustees, need to know the audience;  Many stakeholders find it difficult to interpret accounts, anticipate their questions or where their understanding may be lacking;  You need to be able to persuade the public that the good you do is solid, visible and value for money;  The more charities can shift the debate away from the size of their overheads and on the value of their achievements, the better. A "down to earth" check-list: A colleague has generously provided me with the following:  What picture of the charity does your report paint?  Have you put in the necessary legal details?  Have you included any pictures - if you can afford them?  Have you boasted enough about what you are doing?  Have you confessed what you are not doing?  Do you need to appeal for funds and if so do you say what funds would be spent on?  Are you giving money away? If so:  have you said how you are spending it  how does this relate to your objectives?  would an applicant know what they would get money for  how do you make decisions about what to support?  Have you too little/too much reserves?  Can you justify this?  How are you going to correct over/under reserves?  Is there anyone who you need to praise, thank, beg from, butter up?  Does the report show how trustees are managing?  Have you told any stories about what you are doing?  Have you told any lies?  Have you any problems to report - especially ones you have overcome?  Can you give any statistics about how good you have been?  Have you said what the charity is doing?  David Taylor gave this speech at a joint conference by the association of chief executives of voluntary organisations (ACEVO), the charity finance directors' group (CFDG) and the institute of charity fundraising managers (ICFM), which took place on January 18, 2001

fields.headline: Love in a Cold Climate fails to warm viewers
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: It was cold comfort for BBC1's Love In A Cold Climate last night when it lost out to Sunday nostalgia viewing, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
It was cold comfort for BBC1's Love In A Cold Climate last night when it lost out in the pitched battle that was Sunday nostalgia viewing.

According to unofficial overnight figures, the second and concluding part of the 1930s drama, adapted from the Nancy Mitford novels, managed a lukewarm 4.8m viewers, or 18% share of the audience from 8pm.

Love in a Cold Climate was up against a 13.2m audience for ITV's 1960s-based series Heartbeat, which held 49% of viewers.

Viewers on the whole did not want to watch BBC1's You Don't Want to Do That, a humorous look at the public information films of the 1950s and 1960s fronted by Jeremy Clarkson. The show pulled in just 4.3m viewers from 9.20pm.

Instead, 9.7m preferred London's Burning, which captured 39% of the audience on ITV between 9 and 10pm.

The B& H Masters snooker championship final on BBC2 overran by two hours to 12.40am, but kept viewers hooked as Paul Hunter pulled off his final frame victory over Feargal O'Brien.

The audience for BBC2's snooker coverage peaked between 12.15-12.30am, with 4.4m and a 60% share.

fields.headline: Gameplay clinches interactive TV deals
fields.trailText: 4pm: Online gaming company Gameplay has signed a series of interactive television deals, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online gaming company Gameplay has moved to clear up doubts over its strategic direction by signing a series of interactive TV deals.

It has joined up with pan-European player UPCtv in Holland, Viasat in Sweden, TDC Kabel in Germany and Dutch companies Mediakabel and Casema to launch interactive games for TV viewers.

"Gameplay now has agreements with more operators in Europe than our competitors, and our games and other services can be accessed through more than 7.5m set-top boxes," said Mark Bernstein, chief executive of Gameplay.

The company's shares plunged to a record low of 96p this month after it was forced to shut its eight high-street shops in the UK and cut 270 jobs from its workforce.

Gameplay also said it would sell its computer games software business in an attempt to reach profitability and restore fragile market confidence, which had caused Gameplay's shares to plummet from a high of 1080p.

"It is pleasing to be able to demonstrate the strength of our technology base with the deals announced today," added Mr Bernstein.

The Kabel TV deal facilitates the interactive TV debut of Gameplay's Jive platform, which links a player's set-top box to websites and mobile phones.

Gameplay sells computer games over the web, allowing players to buy or rent the software.

fields.headline: BBC2 wins battle of the archive shows
fields.trailText: TV overnights 12.45pm: BBC2's I Love 1983 pulled in more than double the audience of Channel 4's Top Ten Heartbreakers, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC2 is winning the Saturday-night battle of the archive shows, with I Love 1983 pulling in more than double the audience of Channel 4's Top Ten Heartbreakers.

I Love 1983 featured such pop-cultural delights as Roland Rat, Wham!'s Club Tropicana, hit movie Flashdance and Michael Jackson's Thriller video.

The archive programme had 4m viewers and a 17% share between 9.05pm and 10.35pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Despite the presence of Isaac Hayes as host, Channel 4's Top Ten Heartbreakers could muster only 1.6m viewers and a 7% share from 9.05pm to 10.40pm.

I Love 1983 also beat ailing BBC1 sitcom Beast between 9.55pm and 10.25pm.

The last in the series of the Simon Nye-scripted vet comedy gained just 3.5m viewers.

ITV scored with the gyrating hips of Latin heartthrob Ricky Martin earlier on Saturday night.

An Audience with Ricky Martin pulled in 8.6m and a 39% share from 6.30pm-7.30pm.

It comfortably beat Jim Davidson's Generation Game on BBC1, which gained 6.2m.

Popstars followed ITV's Ricky Martin special but, not surprisingly, could not maintain the giddy ratings heights reached last Saturday when the identities of the band were revealed.

But the hit reality show still had an impressive 9.7m and 40% share between 7.30pm and 8.15pm.

On Friday night, BBC1's 9pm-10pm comedy line-up of Office Gossip and Adrian Mole: the Cappuccino Years lost ground in its second week.

Office Gossip, the sitcom featuring Pauline Quirke, had 5.1m, after opening with 6.3m viewers last Friday.

Adrian Mole fell from 6m to 4.7m on its second outing.

fields.headline: Thumbs up for Lastminute despite losses
fields.trailText:
2.15pm update: Lastminute.com has been given the thumbs up by the stock market, despite steep losses, reports Dan Milmo.
Feb 12: Lastminute losses overshadow Thomas Cook deal
fields.body:
Lastminute.com has been given the thumbs up by the stock market, despite reporting steep losses in its latest results.

The first-quarter figures were closely watched, reflecting the status of the online booking agency as a bellweather for internet retailing in the UK.

Lastminute's £15.3m losses were more than double the figure for the last three months of 1999.

However, they were ignored in favour of confirmation of a joint venture with offline competitor Thomas Cook.

Lastminute's shares rose 3 per cent to 70.5p by mid-afternoon, although they remain far below their year high of 555p.

"Lastminute needs to move its supplier base to more traditional companies such as Thomas Cook," said Nick Jones, senior analyst at global internet research firm Jupiter MMXI.

"It is well established among affluent, young city dwellers but it needs to widen its appeal."

The Thomas Cook deal will enable the travel agency's website to offer last minute deals.

The companies will team up to offer a service for customers who want to book a holiday six weeks in advance.

The acquisition of French online travel firm Degriftour in October last year is now seen as a shrewd move, which boosted the company's reach in time for the vital Christmas-shopping period.

"The Degriftour deal was a sensible acquisition because the weeks before and after Christmas are prime holiday-buying periods.

"The French connection has worked well," added Mr Jones.

However, Lastminute.com has several doubters within the City, who pointed to the flat growth in subscribers and the increased operating losses.

These increased from £10m in the three months to September last year to £16.3m.

Although quarter-on-quarter turnover nearly doubled from £1.48m to £2.9m, some analysts said they expected a bigger boost from the Degriftour deal.

"I would have expected a rather higher increase in revenue," said one analyst.

"It might be that all that growth came from Degriftour, which would tell you something about the underlying business.

"And the amount of money they are spending to generate £2.9m in revenue is worrying."

Lastminute still has the envious asset of a healthy cash balance, thanks to a successful flotation in March last year.

The £70m it has in the bank is expected to see it through to profitability in 2002, while other online retailers fall by the wayside.

fields.headline: Government to investigate BBC
fields.trailText: 9am: Culture secretary Chris Smith has ordered three investigations into abuse of the BBC's public service position, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith has ordered three new investigations looking at whether the BBC is abusing its public service position.

One inquiry will look into whether the BBC is using the licence fee to subsidise its commercial activities. The other two reviews will focus on BBC Online and rolling news service News 24.

Mr Smith has appointed Law professor Richard Whish to lead the review of the BBC's commercial policies and fair trading rules.

He will look in particular at whether there is enough separation between the BBC's public service operations and commercial arm BBC Worldwide.

Mr Smith told the Financial Times: "There must be a firm wall between licence fee-funded activity - which must be part of the public service responsibilities for a domestic audience - and commercial activities which must be funded commercially and make a commercial return."

The other two reviews will take place after the general election, which is expected to be called for early May.

The review of BBC Online follows complaints from commercial broadcasters and internet publishers that the corporation is competing unfairly.

BSkyB has long argued that News 24, which the BBC gives away to pay-TV operators for free, provides unfair competition for its own news channel Sky News.

News of the new government reviews of the BBC comes on the day of the deadline for submissions about the communications white paper.

The BBC said it had no comment to make immediately.

fields.headline: The euro
fields.standfirst:
The question of whether Britain could join the European single currency is causing disagreement again. Charlotte Denny explains

Special report: Economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The question of whether Britain could join the European single currency is causing disagreement again. We explain.
fields.body:
Could Britain join the euro?
Probably, yes, since it has met all the rules laid down in the Maastricht treaty for EMU entrants, except one. Several of the other countries that joined the euro when it was launched two years ago failed one or more of the criteria.

What are the rules?
Governments aren't allowed to borrow more than 3% of national income and they must reduce the ratio of debt to income to below 60%. Britain meets these rules comfortably, but, at the time they joined EMU, Belgium and Italy broke both. Inflation has to be 1.5 percentage points of the EU's three lowest inflation countries while long term borrowing costs have to be within two percentage points. Britain has the lowest inflation rate of any EU country, and its long term borrowing rates are well within the rules. Finally, EMU entrants have to have an independent central bank - which Britain has - and its currency has to be stable against the currencies of other EMU entrants. This is the big stumbling block for British entry.

Why?
The pound's value against the currencies of other EU members has gyrated wildly since it crashed out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism on in 1992, falling to as low as DM2.20 in 1995 and then rising to almost DM3.40 last year. Even though currencies have been allowed more latitude to fluctuate within the ERM since 1992, there is no way that the pound meets the stability rule. Britain argues that, as the ERM effectively had to be recreated after the 1992 debacle - the Italian lira and the Finnish markka were both ejected along with the pound, and the other currencies were allowed to move around by as much as 15% - the condition no longer applies. However, other countries insist that Britain must rejoin the ERM prior to joining EMU. Both Italy and Finland rejoined the ERM prior to the launch of the single currency.

Is the ERM the only obstacle?
No, in addition to the Maastricht criteria, the government has spelt out its own economic tests which must be met before Britain could join. The five tests are:
Business and economic cycles must be compatible so that Britain could live with European interest rates
There must be sufficient flexibility to deal with problems
Joining the euro must create better conditions for firms investing in Britain
The City must not be disadvantaged
Joining the euro must promote higher growth, stability and job creation

Have the government's tests been met?
Some of the tests are so woolly that they could be answered either way. The first test is probably the most important. Essentially, it asks whether Britain could live with a one-size-fits-all monetary policy-making regime. The IMF said recently that, if British interest rates had been as low as European ones over the last seven years, the government would have been forced to raise taxes or cut spending in order to curb inflation. The fund doubts whether UK and European business cycles will converge naturally in the short term. However, the National Institute for Economic and Social Research, probably the most respected independent thinktank, believes that Britain is converging with Europe. Interest rates in Britain are now just a percentage point higher than European rates and most people expect them to fall further.

So who's right?
Pays your money and you takes your pick. The treasury will formally examine the tests after the next election - providing of course, Labour is reelected. However, some commentators think that the tests have been designed to be deliberately vague on purpose so that the government can call it either way. Which way they jump will probably depend on the sixth and most important test: whether Labour thinks it can win a referendum on entering the euro. At the moment, the answer is clearly no.

fields.headline: AD78 faces financial crisis
fields.trailText: 3pm: Controversial ad agency AD78 has convened a meeting of its creditors, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
AD78, the advertising agency that caused an outcry last month by inviting job applicants to send in topless photos, is now facing financial crisis.

The Newcastle-based agency has called in accountancy firm RMT and convened a meeting of creditors for February 22.

Liquidators may be appointed at the meeting.

There is also believed to be another company ready to take over the ailing agency.

No-one at the agency was available for comment but a spokesman for RMT confirmed the crisis meeting was taking place.

Last year AD78 restructured and moved to bigger offices.

However, in December managing director Alex Giles quit along with creative director Dean Rutter and two other staff.

The breakaway group has now set up a rival agency called Lateral Advertising.

AD78 shot to fame last month when it placed a job ad for an account handler and asked applicants to send in a topless photo along with their CVs.

The story was covered in several national newspapers.

In the face of criticism from the TUC, which said the ad potentially breached sexual discrimination law, agency chairman David Buckle said: "We asked for a topless photo just to see how far people were prepared to go.

"We want people who are prepared to go the extra yard and we thought this would be a challenge."

AD78 takes its name from the year it was formed - 1978.

It has a turnover of around £300,000 and clients include the GMB trade union, for which it recently ran a campaign to raise awareness of new workers rights.

fields.headline: Anti-gun poster campaign abandoned
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Government-backed anti-violence ads in London have been taken down after they were vandalised, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The government-backed anti-violence "young, gifted and dead" campaign has been taken down after scores of the posters were vandalised and families of shooting victims complained.

The hard-hitting posters form part of the "not another drop" anti-gun campaign, run by the Metropolitan police and Brent council and backed by the Home Office.

It was launched less than two weeks ago in Brent, north-west London.

Brent has one of the highest rates of shootings in Britain.

The shocking image on the posters shows a man lying in a pool of blood under the words "Young, gifted and dead".

Up to 60 of the posters have been covered in super-adhesive white paint.

A Brent Council spokesman said all the posters have been removed following the vandalism and after families of a number of shooting victims made complaints.

He added the campaign against gun crime would continue and was being backed by the Home Office and senior police.

When the campaign launched it was greeted with dismay by some community groups.

Friends of the Family, a Christian evangelical group, said the campaign would distress victims' families.

Commander Mike Fuller, who heads the Met's Operation Trident - which tackles gun violence in London - also expressed reservations about the posters, saying they could heighten the fear of crime in the community.

The police took the radical step of advertising the campaign on pirate radio in an attempt to reach the target audience.

webTitle: 'The political leaders are on different wavelengths'

fields.headline: 'The political leaders are on different wavelengths'
fields.standfirst:
As a loyalist feud continues to rumble on, the listing Northern Ireland process may be in need of reappraisal, says Derek Brown

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: As a loyalist feud continues to rumble on, the listing Northern Ireland process may be in need of reappraisal, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The discovery of a bomb factory in a strongly loyalist area of north Belfast has underlined the growing tensions in Northern Ireland as the peace process drifts.

Pipe bombs have been used in more than 50 sectarian attacks on Roman Catholic homes in the province this year alone.

They are thoroughly nasty devices, in which pieces of scrap metal are packed with blasting powder extracted from fireworks or shotgun cartridges, then welded up to contain and therefore maximise the blast.

At least three pipe bomb attacks have been reported in the past 24 hours, in Belfast and County Antrim. There was also an overnight shotgun attack on a house in Belfast.

webTitle: Sky News boss clashes with BBC's Hall

fields.headline: Sky News boss clashes with BBC's Hall
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Sky News's Adam Boulton has becomed embroiled in a bitter war of words with the BBC's head of news and current affairs. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sky News's political editor, Adam Boulton, has becomed embroiled in a bitter war of words with the BBC's head of news and current affairs.

He described Tony Hall as being "stupid" for writing to Tony Blair's press spokesman Alastair Campbell to push for televised lobby briefings.

Mr Boulton said Mr Hall's approaches to Mr Campbell and the lobby were merely about "being a pawn of the chattering classes".

"Lobby briefings are now on the record. Why go to the bother of creating a system that just makes something more opaque?" he asked.

And he accused Mr Hall of "putting his interests before those of broadcast news and democracy". Mr Boulton believes that by putting Mr Campbell on screen, the BBC will be encouraging the government to give the media less access to ministers.

Mr Boulton's remarks provide confirmation that Mr Hall is writing to Tony Blair's press spokesman Alastair Campbell to ask about the possibility of televising lobby briefings.

The outgoing head of BBC news, who is joining the Royal Opera House, has already approached rivals ITN and Sky to ask them to join the BBC to push for an overhaul of the antiquated lobby system.

Meanwhile, in this week's New Statesman, Mr Hall calls for the abolition of a lobby system which he sees as arcane and secretive.

"I'm now trying to get Sky and ITN and ourselves to put lobby briefings on camera," Mr Hall says in an interview with Mary Riddell.

"The lesson I have learned is that if we, as broadcasters, get together and say 'These are the terms,' we stand the best chance."

Mr Hall admits in the interview that he is still smarting after the collapse of the planned televised election debates, which foundered on the lack of commitment from the Labour party.

He says in the interview: "I am really upset that we couldn't get the leaders' debate to happen".

"Shouldn't you and I, as citizens, be able to hear and see what is going on? The answer is yes."

A BBC spokesman confirmed that a letter had been sent to Mr Campbell, and that an approach had been made to the chairman of the lobby, Catherine McLeod.

The move follows growing criticism of Mr Campbell, who has been accused of briefing against ministers.

In the House of Lords last week, Lord Renton of Mount Harry said Mr Campbell was guilty of "airbrushing another reluctant minister out of history".

webTitle: Virgin in crunch talks with agency

fields.headline: Virgin in crunch talks with agency
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Wieden & Kennedy is understood to be in talks with Virgin Interactive Entertainment over unpaid fees, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Wieden & Kennedy is understood to be in crunch talks with its client Virgin Interactive Entertainment this week over unpaid fees.

It emerged last week the relationship was on rocky ground but Virgin refused to confirm or deny rumours of a split.

A spokesman described it as "unofficial".

Senior executives from client and agency are believed to be meeting in London this week in an attempt to resolve the conflict, which is thought to derive from several months of unpaid fees by Virgin.

"We have not lost the account as rumoured, but there are some very serious issues to sort out," said a spokeswoman for Wieden & Kennedy.

The agency won Virgin Interactive Entertainment's £2.5m ad account early last year in a pitch against Court Burkitt & Company.

It was subsequently tasked with launching Virgin games brands across Europe by making each launch a big event.

webTitle: Angulo: United match was not fixed

fields.headline: Angulo: United match was not fixed
fields.trailText: Valencia midfielder Miguel Angel Angulo has categorically denied that comments he made at a press conference last week were meant to infer that his side had "agreed" to draw last season's Champions League match with Manchester United.
fields.body:
Valencia midfielder Miguel Angel Angulo has categorically denied that comments he made at a press conference last week were meant to infer that his side had "agreed" to draw last season's Champions League match with Manchester United.

"A part of what I said last Friday has been taken completely out of context," Angulo said today. "Perhaps I was mistaken in the wording of what I said, but what I meant to say was that in the last game between Valencia and Manchester United there was not the same intensity as there is likely to be on Wednesday.

"The last time the two teams met a draw was enough and so without being conscious of the fact neither side was prepared to take risks in the game.

"But I have to reiterate that there was absolutely no form of agreement between the two sides to draw the game as has been suggested in the press in Spain, France and England this weekend," he added.

Uefa had already said that they had no plans to launch an investigation into the matter. Mike Lee, Uefa's communications director, said the reaction by the English press had been "way over the top".

Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson has made it clear he had no knowledge of the claims.

fields.headline: BBC welcomes government inquiries
fields.trailText:
2.30pm update: The BBC has welcomed three inquiries into the relationship between its commercial and public activities. By Jason Deans.
9am: Government to investigate BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has welcomed three government inquiries due to examine the relationship between its commercial and public service activities.

The corporation was responding to a newspaper interview with Chris Smith.

The culture secretary talked about a review into whether the BBC is using licence-fee money to subsidise its commercial activities plus separate inquires into BBC Online and News 24.

Mr Smith has appointed law professor Richard Whish to lead the review of the BBC's commercial policies and fair trading rules.

Mr Whish will look in particular at whether there is enough separation between the BBC's public service operations and commercial arm BBC Worldwide.

Commenting on the inquiry into the separation of its public service and commercial activity, a BBC spokesman said: "This independent review has been expected since the recommendations of the Davies report in 1999 and the secretary of state's comments following the licence fee settlement last year.

"We welcome it.

"The BBC has worked hard to stay at the leading edge of best practice in our fair trading arrangements," the spokesman added.

"We look forward to working with professor Whish and benefiting from his expertise in this field."

Mr Smith told the Financial Times: "There must be a firm wall between licence fee-funded activity - which must be part of the public service responsibilities for a domestic audience - and commercial activities, which must be funded commercially and make a commercial return."

The other two reviews will take place after the general election, which is expected to take place in early May.

The review of BBC Online follows complaints from commercial broadcasters and internet publishers that the corporation is competing unfairly.

BSkyB has long argued that News 24, which the BBC gives away to pay-TV operators for free, provides unfair competition for its own news channel Sky News.

News of the new government reviews of the BBC comes on the day of the deadline for submissions about the communications white paper.

webTitle: Housing associations in the firing line

fields.headline: Housing associations in the firing line
fields.standfirst: Successive governments have made increasing demands on housing associations but have failed to secure adequate resources to support them
fields.trailText: Successive governments have made increasing demands on housing associations but have failed to secure adequate resources to support them.
fields.body:
It must be a dream situation for a New Labour strategist - pile the responsibility for social housing onto arms' length organisations and then, as soon as the financial storm clouds start to gather, just walk away like it's none of your business.

From the reports that have been reaching me from our members, that is exactly what's going on at the moment in a significant number of housing associations. As one activist from a major inner London association pointed out, they have been caught by an old-fashioned double whammy - major increases in demand, particularly for short-term accommodation, just at the point when housing benefit services have been plunged into chaos.

The major problem in housing benefit is bound up from head to toe with the drive to privatise, externalise and outsource, or whatever the current trendy word for profiteering from the public services is today. While the private companies sit on piles of applications, the income stream to the housing associations is cut off at source. The problem is compounded in a borough like Hackney, where crisis management and sheer political incompetence have left the housing associations chasing millions of pounds of debt with the serious risk of default on a massive scale.

The difficulties are most acute for those associations specialising in short-term accommodation and for those finding housing for refugees and asylum seekers. Not only are they caught in the web of political point-scoring and tabloid hostility, but it is notoriously hard to secure income streams on a short-term basis. If benefit systems hit meltdown, it's the specialist short-term associations that get hit hardest and quickest.

Against this background, it's no surprise that housing associations are finding it increasingly difficult to recruit and retain staff. Those left trying to hold the organisations together are carrying massive workloads on low wages with the constant risk of personal burn out. Our reps tell me that staff turnover rates in housing associations are on the rise and that vacancies are being covered by employees who can barely cope with their own responsibilities.

Like much of the voluntary sector, housing associations are still blighted by an outdated attitude to what it is that they are all about and the government must take its share of responsibility for changing attitudes. While the growth of housing associations into massive organisations with multimillion pound budgets has been phenomenal, the public perception of associations harbouring a bunch of old hippy dropouts is still deeply ingrained.

For too long successive governments have had an easy ride on the backs of the housing associations, but its time ministers started taking a bit of responsibility and offered some real stability in what are difficult times. This means underwriting budgets so that staff can get on with their jobs rather than looking over their shoulders for the insolvency practitioners. With the new legal right to trade union representation, housing association staff now know that they call in a union steward when things start to get tough. Unison has developed specialist support services for housing association employees in recent years and that work will continue.

The Tories were the first to realise that they could dump responsibility onto housing associations and use them as a buffer zone to deflect attention from their own failings. Needless to say, New Labour have embraced this approach with vigour and have even knocked it on a few notches.

Maybe some housing associations embraced the new "business" ethos a bit too readily, without getting long-term assurances properly bolted down. Maybe some grew too quickly and lost sight of what they were really there for. It could be that they are paying a heavy price today for trusting what the politicians told them yesterday. Then again, politicians' memories aren't what they used to be.

 Geoff Martin is the secretary of Unison's London voluntary and independent sector branch.

fields.headline: Red Romans enjoying prospering project
fields.trailText: Who says kidnap threats don't work? Last week Roma fans, worried that coach Fabio Capello was being seduced by Europe's top clubs - including Barcelona and Manchester United - chanted "Let's kidnap Capello!" during their side's 2-1 win at Parma.
fields.body:
Who says kidnap threats don't work? Last week Roma fans, worried that coach Fabio Capello was being seduced by Europe's top clubs - including Barcelona and Manchester United - chanted "Let's kidnap Capello!" during their side's 2-1 win at Parma.

Maybe those jovial threats played on Capello's mind. Or perhaps it was the offer of a two-year contract worth an Italian record-busting £2.5m a season as well as a plush villa in the Aventine hills. Whatever: Capello has finally agreed to stay, and red Romans everywhere are happy.

But while the Giallorossi fans spent the weekend celebrating, Capello spent his time insisting that money had absolutely nothing to do with his decision. "I know how far we can make it, in this season and the ones to come," he explained. "Between me and Roma there was never a problem of money. The issue centred on belief in our project."

And the "project" continues to prosper. This weekend Roma, without the injured Francesco Totti, Aldair and Cristiano Zanetti, faced a tricky looking trip to Bologna. But once again they made it look easy.

Neither side was helped by the funeral-like atmosphere in the Stadio Renalto Dall'Ara, caused by the death of Bologna's 17-year-old defender Niccolo Galli in a moped accident on Friday. But Roma responded best, going ahead through a Gabriel Batistuta penalty after 11 minutes and doubling their lead when £12m summer signing Emerson - no, not that one, Boro fans - made it 2-0 after 35 minutes.

Bologna, who were reduced to ten men when Jonatan Binotto was sent off midway through the first half, clawed one back six minutes after the break through Emanuele Brioschi. Even so, Roma were always in control and missed further chances - including another Batistuta penalty - to increase their lead. After a blip in early January, Capello's side remain six points clear and odds on for their first Scudetto since 1983.

Juve and Lazio keep up the pressure

"We live in a free-market society," Juventus manager Carlo Ancellotti probably reasoned to himself on hearing about Capello's rise over the weekend. "And if he's getting a salary increase, then why can't I?"

But if Ancellotti did harbour such thoughts, they were soon beaten up and sent to a dark corner by Juventus's honourary president Umberto Agnelli. "Nowadays, coaches push themselves well beyond any acceptable and justified economic level," he whined. "That's a pity. We will never follow such a trend." Ancelotti's response was curt. "I'm not asking for too much at all," he insisted.

Such hostilities clearly didn't hurt Juve's performance on the pitch, however, as they recovered from last week's defeat at Atalanta to destroy Napoli 3-0, thanks to goals from Darko Kovacevic, Filippo Inzaghi and substitute Alessandro Del Piero.

"It was a good match and we showed a lot of spirit," said Ancellotti afterwards. "After the defeat in Bergamo seven days ago my players responded the way I wanted them to."

Lazio manager Dino Zoff was also in upbeat mood, despite seeing his side stutter to a 0-0 draw at home to Atalanta. "You can't always win," said the pragmatic Zoff afterwards. "We knew how difficult it would be to play Atalanta. They closed us down well on the wings and we were unlucky as well.

"During the second half, my players were too hurried because they were scared of not winning," he added. "And when you are in hurry, you don't win at all. That's what happened today."

Misery in Milan

How much does George Weah hate AC Milan coach Alberto Zaccheroni? Well, on a Spinal Tap hate-scale of 1 to 10, Zaccheroni would score at least eleven.

"Zaccheroni is not only a nasty piece of work, he is also a liar," ranted Weah yesterday morning. "He almost ruined my career. On top of that, he makes out he is a great coach, which he isn't. He beefed himself up with the Scudetto win two years ago, but it was the players who won that title. He had nothing to do with it, I can assure you.

"Anyway, his time is almost up he's done so much harm he'll end up having to pay for it."

Zaccheroni could end paying sooner rather than later. Yesterday, Milan were beaten 2-0 by relegation-threatened Vicenza, leaving them 15 points behind Roma and facing a Champions League-or-bust scenario.

After the game, Zaccheroni didn't blame his long injury list - Gattuso, Ambrosini, Albertini, Maldini, Costacurta, Chamot, Redondo, and Boban - for the defeat. He blamed himself.

"We have to rediscover our concentration, our spirit, again," he said. "Obviously we are changing the team and our way of playing every day because of the injuries. It is a bad way to prepare for the next match. But matches like the Vicenza one have no explanation, and there are no excuses. I'm guilty." Words, no doubt, that Weah would agree with.

And it was a bad day all round for Milan clubs as Internazionale could only manage a fortuitous 1-1 draw at home to Reggina. Davide Dionigi gave the visitors the lead on 22 minutes, and only a dubious penalty from Christian Vieri just before half-time earned them a point.

Understandably, Inter coach Marco Tardelli was furious afterwards. "Have we taken a step back? I would say 20 steps back," he fumed.

"I do not want my players to talk. That way it's better for everybody. On Monday they will have to explain to me why they played in such a shameful way.

"This was the worst performance since I arrived at Inter. We had a bad approach to the match. We were too much confident and, as usual, we never reached the heights we are capable of." Words that could easily be applied to Inter sides throughout the last ten years, in fact.

Lazio manager Dino Zoff was also in upbeat mood, despite seeing his side stutter to a 0-0 draw at home to Atalanta. "You can't always win," said the pragmatic Zoff afterwards. "We knew how difficult it would be to play Atalanta. They closed us down well on the wings and we were unlucky as well. "During the second half, my players were too hurried because they were scared of not winning," he added. "And when you are in hurry, you don't win at all. That's what happened today." Misery in Milan How much does George Weah hate AC Milan coach Alberto Zaccheroni? Well, on a Spinal Tap hate-scale of 1 to 10, Zaccheroni would score at least eleven. "Zaccheroni is not only a nasty piece of work, he is also a liar," ranted Weah yesterday morning. "He almost ruined my career. On top of that, he makes out he is a great coach, which he isn't. He beefed himself up with the Scudetto win two years ago, but it was the players who won that title. He had nothing to do with it, I can assure you. "Anyway, his time is almost up he's done so much harm he'll end up having to pay for it." Zaccheroni could end paying sooner rather than later. Yesterday, Milan were beaten 2-0 by relegation-threatened Vicenza, leaving them 15 points behind Roma and facing a Champions League-or-bust scenario. After the game, Zaccheroni didn't blame his long injury list - Gattuso, Ambrosini, Albertini, Maldini, Costacurta, Chamot, Redondo, and Boban - for the defeat. He blamed himself. "We have to rediscover our concentration, our spirit, again," he said. "Obviously we are changing the team and our way of playing every day because of the injuries. It is a bad way to prepare for the next match. But matches like the Vicenza one have no explanation, and there are no excuses. I'm guilty." Words, no doubt, that Weah would agree with. And it was a bad day all round for Milan clubs as Internazionale could only manage a fortuitous 1-1 draw at home to Reggina. Davide Dionigi gave the visitors the lead on 22 minutes, and only a dubious penalty from Christian Vieri just before half-time earned them a point. Understandably, Inter coach Marco Tardelli was furious afterwards. "Have we taken a step back? I would say 20 steps back," he fumed. "I do not want my players to talk. That way it's better for everybody. On Monday they will have to explain to me why they played in such a shameful way. "This was the worst performance since I arrived at Inter. We had a bad approach to the match. We were too much confident and, as usual, we never reached the heights we are capable of." Words that could easily be applied to Inter sides throughout the last ten years, in fact.

webTitle: BBC Radio 5 Live secures F1 contract

fields.headline: BBC Radio 5 Live secures F1 contract
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: BBC Radio 5 Live has secured the exclusive UK radio rights to formula one for the next four years, reports Guy Adams.
fields.body:
BBC Radio 5 Live is to step up its coverage of formula one motor racing after winning a four-year extension to its current Grand Prix contract.

The deal, worth an undisclosed sum, gives 5 Live exclusive UK radio rights to formula one from 2002-2005.

It was secured in the face of a rival bids, said a 5 Live spokesman. Yet a spokesman from commercial station Talk Sport, which is owned by Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, said the station did not make a bid.

As well as live race coverage, 5 Live will launch a preview show, fronted by motor racing correspondent Jonathan Legard.

Jonathan Legard's World of Formula One will air on the night before each Grand Prix.

"The show will be along similar lines to Jonathan Agnew's World of Cricket and Jeremy Guscott's World of Rugby, in which seasoned commentators are bought together on location in the run-up to big events," said a 5 Live spokesman.

Bob Shennan, 5 Live controller, added: "Jonathan and the 5 Live approach to formula one has spawned a strong following among fans.

"We're delighted to recieve this vote of confidence in the way we cover the sport."

Bernie Ecclestone, managing director of motor racing rights owner Formula One Management, said: "The massive radio following for formula one has been very well served by BBC Radio 5 Live in the UK.

"When something works that well, it's best left in place."

The BBC has hung on the the radio rights to formula one, despite losing the TV rights to ITV in 1997.

webTitle: Online media buyers set to merge

fields.headline: Online media buyers set to merge
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Consolidation has reached online planning and buying with the merger of Optimad.com and iMediapoint.com, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Consolidation has reached the online planning and buying market with the merger of Optimad.com and iMediapoint.com, two of the largest internet-based media buying platforms in Europe.

The combined entity, Optimad-iMediapoint, will have a market leading position ahead of the growing crowd of online media trading platforms in the UK and Germany.

The move will enable Optimad-iMediapoint to put up a stronger fight against competitor Adazzle, a trading platform that is growing in strength because of ties with ad groups such as Tempus.

MediaTel's MediaTrader, another online media trading platform, is believed to be scaling back its business and development.

Optimad-iMediapoint will be run in the UK by iMediapoint founder, Jean-Louis Velaise, and its managing director, Andy Troullides.

They will report to Hans-Hendrik Puvogel, the chief executive of Optimad's holding company.

The merged company's German operations are unaffected by the deal.

Optimad-iMediapoint will now concentrate on expanding its business and as a result has no plans to make any redundancies from its combined 40-strong staff.

Optimad and iMediapoint have, in the past, focused on building up a portfolio of media owners for whom they sold excess inventory.

Isaac Levy, UK managing director of Optimad, said the two companies had now had something of a strategy shift and were increasingly focused on tools and services for the media planning and buying community and media owners.

"We bring together strengths in national press, online and ambient, which allows us to cover most of those markets," Mr Levy said.

"But it's no longer just about signing up media owners, we're now developing products to appeal to media agencies and owners."

webTitle: Hannibal takes record bite from US box office

fields.headline: Hannibal takes record bite from US box office
fields.trailText: The much-hyped sequel to The Silence of the Lambs, which opens in the UK this Friday, has already broken several records in the US
fields.body:
Hannibal, the long-awaited sequel to 1991's Oscar-winning Silence of the Lambs, devoured all competition at the US box office, taking a whopping $58m (£40.02m) in its opening weekend. If the figures add up, it will confirm Ridley Scott's psycho-thriller as the third most successful debut in US cinema history.

Starring Anthony Hopkins as refined serial killer Hannibal "the Cannibal" Lecter and Julianne Moore as the FBI agent on his trail, Hannibal opened across 4,900 US screens to mammoth hype, patchy reviews and harsh criticism of its grisly tone. Defending the picture at the Berlin Film Festival, Hopkins conceded that: "If people are repulsed and terrified, so be it. I understand that as well. It's not to everyone's taste - if you'll excuse the pun." The Welsh-born actor also confessed that he was looking forward to another stint in what looks set to remain his most memorable role. "I would like to do one more, a sequel, which is being discussed," Hopkins said. "Hopefully that will be fairly soon, maybe next year."

In the meantime Hannibal's early success has already ratcheted up a number of records. The film is already confirmed as the biggest R-rated opening, the biggest February debut and the biggest opening ever for backers MGM. Its three-day tally of $58m (£40.02m) pushes it ahead of Mission: Impossible 2's first weekend figure of $57.9m (£39.95m), but leaves it lagging in third place behind The Lost World: Jurassic Park's total of $72m (£49.68m) and The Phantom Menace's $65m (£44.85m).

"I must confess I expected it to be big, but not this big," admitted dazzled producer Dino De Laurentiis. A moment later, however, he had recovered his trusty mogul manner. Hannibal, Dino told reporters: "Is a picture on its own. It's a picture that will be remembered forever." The film opens in the UK on Friday.

webTitle: Forgan to hand out lottery cash

fields.headline: Forgan to hand out lottery cash
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Former BBC radio director Liz Forgan is to head a government body that allocates lottery funding to heritage projects, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Former BBC director of radio Liz Forgan has been appointed chairwoman of a government body that allocates National Lottery funding to heritage projects.

Ms Forgan will take over as part-time chairwoman of the National Heritage Memorial Fund from April 1, for a three-year term.

As well as allocating money from the Heritage Lottery Fund, the NHMF provides grants for buying land, buildings, objects and collections deemed important to the national heritage and under threat.

The appointment was made by culture secretary Chris Smith.

The job comes with a salary of £31,190 a year for what is expected to be two or three days work a week.

Ms Forgan will take over from Dr Eric Anderson.

Her appointment coincides with the development of a strategic plan to look at the way in which money from the Heritage Lottery Fund is allocated.

Once considered as a potential director-general of the BBC, Ms Forgan was at the forefront of the campaign to keep BBC Radio journalists at Broadcasting House rather than moving to White City.

webTitle: Jewell sacked as manager of Wednesday

fields.headline: Jewell sacked as manager of Wednesday
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell has been sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday after just eight months in charge at the club.
fields.body:
Paul Jewell has been sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday after just eight months in charge at the club.

In another day of turmoil at Wednesday, Howard Culley has also stood down as chairman of the First Division side almost a year to the day since taking over, although he has been persuaded to remain on the board.

Peter Shreeves has again been handed the managerial reins on a caretaker basis, while 70-year-old director Geoff Hulley becomes Wednesday's third chairman in a year.

Jewell, however, has admitted he has "no regrets" about joining Wednesday, despite the perilous state of the club when he was appointed in June last year.

"Clearly, I'm bitterly disappointed," he said. "I think any manager near the bottom of any league of any country is going to be under pressure given the club's current position.

"But I have to say I didn't see this coming. Of course I'm aware we're bottom of the league, but we're all grown men here. I was preparing for tomorrow's home game with Tranmere and working on bringing in a loan player from Southampton [Trond Egil Soltvedt].

"Obviously, it is not nice getting sacked, but I don't think I have been given enough time. But people have to make decisions and the board believe what they have done is in the best interests of Sheffield Wednesday.

"You don't need too much common sense, though, to realise that to stay in this league when I first took over was going to be an achievement in itself.

"And I've no need to make excuses because the facts speak for themselves. Simon Donnelly and Phil O'Donnell have hardly kicked a ball this season and Wim Jonk the same, along with Andy Hinchcliffe, while Gilles de Bilde has not pulled his weight.

"Look at the players I was forced to let go in the summer. The likes of Niclas Alexandersson, Peter Atherton, Ian Nolan, Wim Jonk, Pavel Srnicek and Richard Cresswell, Danny Sonner and others.

"In contrast, I've barely been given a penny to spend. My biggest money buy was Steve Harkness for £200,000, while I've had to play a load of kids from the reserve and youth teams who in normal circumstances would not be ready for first-team football.

"But a decision has been made because the board felt a change was needed. Let me just say the supporters have been fantastic and the staff have been great, although they are in a state of shock like me.

"I'm feeling pretty low right now, but you have to learn never to feel sorry for yourself because being sacked happens to the best.

"I have no regrets joining Sheffield Wednesday, but I am confident I will be stronger for this because I have learnt a lot in the last seven months. I'm still only 36 and there's still plenty of time on my side."

fields.headline: Coke drops divorcee Barbara Becker
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Coca-Cola has axed Barbara Becker from its ads following her divorce from tennis star Boris, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has axed Barbara Becker from its advertising following her messy divorce from her former tennis ace husband.

Ms Becker was to appear in a German TV commercial for Coca-Cola Caffeine Free.

However, the advert has been pulled because Coke believes her appearance would "distract viewers from the brand message".

Ms Becker - who has custody of the couple's two children and has started a new relationship - is thought to no longer fit Coke's desired "family image".

Coke's German agency Springer & Jacoby said it had replaced the commercial filmed with Ms Becker with new adverts featuring "everyday families".

The Beckers recently divorced in a settlement reportedly worth £15m.

The split followed a multi-million-pound paternity suit, filed against Mr Becker by Russian-born model Angela Ermakova.

Ermakova claimed she became pregnant after a one-off tryst with Mr Becker in the broom cupboard of upmarket London restaurant Nobu.

Mr Becker has his own advertising contracts with AOL Germany and Mercedes Benz.

The tagline he made famous for AOL - "I am in" - is now, combined with his domestic situation, the subject of jokes in Germany.

fields.headline: Media Monkey's diary
fields.trailText: A selection of headlines purporting to be from last year's Melbourne Herald Sun has reached Monkey's desk. There are 25 in total, but here's a handful. At number five we have: "Something Went Wrong In Jet Crash, Experts Say"; at four: "If Strike Isn't Settled Quickly, It May Last A While"; in at three: "War Dims Hope For Peace"; at two: "Panda Mating Fails; Veterinarian Takes Over"; but the absolute winner has to be: "Prostitutes Appeal to Pope".
fields.body:
A selection of headlines purporting to be from last year's Melbourne Herald Sun has reached Monkey's desk. There are 25 in total, but here's a handful. At number five we have: "Something Went Wrong In Jet Crash, Experts Say"; at four: "If Strike Isn't Settled Quickly, It May Last A While"; in at three: "War Dims Hope For Peace"; at two: "Panda Mating Fails; Veterinarian Takes Over"; but the absolute winner has to be: "Prostitutes Appeal to Pope".

Monkey's favourite newsman, Jon Snow, recalls a lucrative wager during the 1997 General Election campaign: "I was following the Conservative campaign during the final days, and you could tell that they were headed for the most cataclysmic result. Anyway, we were travelling back to London one night when I found a leaflet in my pocket from some spread-betting firm, which was offering very generous odds on the election. I had never had a spread bet before, but was straight on my mobile to open an account. I backed Labour to win by more than 175, and offset that with a bet on the Lib Dems to pick up more than 40 seats. My stake was just £25, and it won me more than £600. A memorable night all round."

Richard Lambert, photogenic editor of the Financial Times, famous within his paper for charming the US TV networks during its recent push overseas, has been rumoured for some time to be contemplating a change. Media Monkey now hears he has been discreetly sounding-out senior business figures for a bit of career advice as to quite what an ex-Fleet Street editor is best suited for. Jeff Randall, starting next month at the BBC, provides one role model, but Monkey hears that professor of journalism is a better tip.

The final interviews, or "boards" as they still quaintly call them at the BBC, are taking place for a replacement for Tony Hall, the director of news who leaves in April. The smart money is still on his deputy Richard Sambrook, but hanging around outside the interview room, Monkey heard that the BBC is prepared to head-off Government concerns about its public service role by returning Panorama to a prime time weekday slot from its Sunday exile.

Well, now we know what Greg Dyke gets up to in bed, and on holiday. The BBC director general told an audience at the LSE last week that "there are days when I go home and think: Am I doing it right? I've turned into a sad human being, lying in bed at night reading the History of the BBC, 1965-1980."

He also asked staff to email him all the worst excesses of the internal market, which he then took to Barbados: "I lay on the beach and laughed all week. There were things like: 'Can I use your Sellotape?' Reply: 'What's your [account] number?' "

It's been a busy week for Greg. In the august surroundings of the media select committee, an on-message Dyke dismissed suggestions that the BBC board of governors are a bunch of compliant pushovers. Quite the opposite, he insisted. It was just a pity that when a short-sighted DG attempted to read a crucial figure from his notes, the image was shattered when he was forced to turn to Sir Christopher Bland for help. "I would be able to tell you the figure," he sheepishly told the committee, "if the chairman would pass me my glasses first."

Further grist for Sky News's bid to colonise ITV. The latest BSkyB results published last week show that it is running Sky News on a budget of £34m a year, up on last year's £28m, but comfortably below the £45m paid by the ITV network for its tailored service. Meanwhile Sky's highest profile presenter, Bob Friend, 63, running up to retirement, has decided to pack in his 10pm slot for an easier morning routine. Perhaps he can't take the competition.

Last word (promise) on the PCC party. According to the guest list, the organisers' claims that there would be as many "real" complainants as Coronation Street stars whose privacy has been invaded by their kiss-and-tell lover might have been a bit ambitious. Number of guests? 640. Number of guests identified as (non-celeb) "complainant"? Four. Most interesting reason for attendance? "Amanda Donohoe's father."

Oh alright then, but only five more potentially made up headlines claiming to be from the Melbourne Herald Sun. "Plane Too Close To Ground, Crash Probe Told"; "Iraqi Head Seeks Arms"; "Include Your Children When Baking Cookies"; "Typhoon Rips Through Cemetery; Hundreds Dead" and last, but still the Monkey's favourite: "Stolen Painting Found by Tree".

At number five we have: "Something Went Wrong In Jet Crash, Experts Say"; at four: "If Strike Isn't Settled Quickly, It May Last A While"; in at three: "War Dims Hope For Peace"; at two: "Panda Mating Fails; Veterinarian Takes Over"; but the absolute winner has to be: "Prostitutes Appeal to Pope". Monkey's favourite newsman, Jon Snow, recalls a lucrative wager during the 1997 General Election campaign: "I was following the Conservative campaign during the final days, and you could tell that they were headed for the most cataclysmic result. Anyway, we were travelling back to London one night when I found a leaflet in my pocket from some spread-betting firm, which was offering very generous odds on the election. I had never had a spread bet before, but was straight on my mobile to open an account. I backed Labour to win by more than 175, and offset that with a bet on the Lib Dems to pick up more than 40 seats. My stake was just £25, and it won me more than £600. A memorable night all round." Richard Lambert, photogenic editor of the Financial Times, famous within his paper for charming the US TV networks during its recent push overseas, has been rumoured for some time to be contemplating a change. Media Monkey now hears he has been discreetly sounding-out senior business figures for a bit of career advice as to quite what an ex-Fleet Street editor is best suited for. Jeff Randall, starting next month at the BBC, provides one role model, but Monkey hears that professor of journalism is a better tip. The final interviews, or "boards" as they still quaintly call them at the BBC, are taking place for a replacement for Tony Hall, the director of news who leaves in April. The smart money is still on his deputy Richard Sambrook, but hanging around outside the interview room, Monkey heard that the BBC is prepared to head-off Government concerns about its public service role by returning Panorama to a prime time weekday slot from its Sunday exile. Well, now we know what Greg Dyke gets up to in bed, and on holiday. The BBC director general told an audience at the LSE last week that "there are days when I go home and think: Am I doing it right? I've turned into a sad human being, lying in bed at night reading the History of the BBC, 1965-1980." He also asked staff to email him all the worst excesses of the internal market, which he then took to Barbados: "I lay on the beach and laughed all week. There were things like: 'Can I use your Sellotape?' Reply: 'What's your [account] number?' " It's been a busy week for Greg. In the august surroundings of the media select committee, an on-message Dyke dismissed suggestions that the BBC board of governors are a bunch of compliant pushovers. Quite the opposite, he insisted. It was just a pity that when a short-sighted DG attempted to read a crucial figure from his notes, the image was shattered when he was forced to turn to Sir Christopher Bland for help. "I would be able to tell you the figure," he sheepishly told the committee, "if the chairman would pass me my glasses first." Further grist for Sky News's bid to colonise ITV. The latest BSkyB results published last week show that it is running Sky News on a budget of £34m a year, up on last year's £28m, but comfortably below the £45m paid by the ITV network for its tailored service. Meanwhile Sky's highest profile presenter, Bob Friend, 63, running up to retirement, has decided to pack in his 10pm slot for an easier morning routine. Perhaps he can't take the competition. Last word (promise) on the PCC party. According to the guest list, the organisers' claims that there would be as many "real" complainants as Coronation Street stars whose privacy has been invaded by their kiss-and-tell lover might have been a bit ambitious. Number of guests? 640. Number of guests identified as (non-celeb) "complainant"? Four. Most interesting reason for attendance? "Amanda Donohoe's father." Oh alright then, but only five more potentially made up headlines claiming to be from the Melbourne Herald Sun. "Plane Too Close To Ground, Crash Probe Told"; "Iraqi Head Seeks Arms"; "Include Your Children When Baking Cookies"; "Typhoon Rips Through Cemetery; Hundreds Dead" and last, but still the Monkey's favourite: "Stolen Painting Found by Tree".

webTitle: Councils in the south-east prepare for climate change

fields.headline: Councils in the south-east prepare for climate change
fields.trailText: Local authorities are developing strategies to deal with the health and planning problems posed by major climate change.
fields.body:
Local authorities are developing strategies to deal with the health and planning problems posed by major climate change.

Surrey, Kent, West Sussex and Hampshire county councils have already drawn up a planning agenda to deal with risks such as flooding and storm damage.

A recent report, Rising to the challenge: Impacts of climate change in the south-east in the 21st century, warns that rising sea levels will pose serious challenges to their coastal and floodplain defences, water supplies and countryside.

It recommends improved monitoring of climate change, improved flood forecasting and warning systems, and revised approaches to land use. Water treatment may have to be improved to ensure the quality of drinking water.

The study, part of the UK climate impacts programme, noted the south-east's climate is already changing. Average temperatures have risen by 0.5 degrees celsius and summer rainfall has decreased. In the future it will be warmer all year round, with much wetter winters and drier summers.

The report warned that the south-east had potentially more to lose from climate change than any other region of the UK. Increasingly frequent droughts could challenge the area's traditional self-sufficiency in terms of natural resources, such as water for domestic and industrial uses.

The study was supported by the Wildlife Trusts, the National Trust, the World Wildlife Fund, the government office for the south-east, the Environment Agency and Thames Water.

fields.headline: New Media Age
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 8
fields.trailText: February 8: The Free Internet Group is taking legal action against 12 of its members who it believes have been using its service for commercial activities.
fields.body:
The Free Internet Group is seeking to have a legal precedent established by taking action against 12 of its members who, it believes, have been using its service for commercial activities. It intends to seek financial compensation from members that have been logging on constantly during peak periods.

The creative industry is bracing itself for dire results from Razorfish following its announcement of 400 redundancies on Monday.

Sky has staked its claim as the leading interactive TV bookmaker, having signed up 10,000 text betting accounts since its launch last December.

TheMutual.net has ditched its consumer operations and repositioned itself as an email marketing company. It plans to use the purchase of thestreet.co.uk's database in December to kickstart its business.

Grey Interactive has become the latest agency to unveil a dedicated wireless division, Gi Wireless.

Capital Interactive has scaled back on its plans to launch 35 niche online radio stations, blaming the dot.com downturn. Instead of 35, it will now launch 15, at a rate of one per month.

Financial advice website Motley Fool has secured £20m in funding to boost operations. No mention of the lay-off of 115 staff though.

Website of the week is NewScientistJobs.com, which scored 84 out of 100.
