fields.headline: Guinea refugees wait for 'safe corridor'
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of refugees from Sierra Leone and Liberia were facing another day of uncertainty today as the UN refugee chief tried to find a political solution to ensure their safe passage from the fighting in the dense rainforests of Guinea.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of refugees from Sierra Leone and Liberia were facing another day of uncertainty today as the UN refugee chief tried to find a political solution to ensure their safe passage from the fighting in the dense rainforests of Guinea.

The UN high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, has appealed for a "safe corridor" to enable the refugees, who had fled to Guinea to escape conflict in their own countries, to escape the deteriorating security situation along Guinea's southern borders with Liberia and Sierra Leone.

Mr Lubbers arrived in Guinea on Saturday at the start of a nine-day west African tour and visited two camps near the southwestern town of Kissidougou, where the refugees from Sierra Leone and Liberia have sought shelter. Many more refugees remain trapped in camps where relief workers have been unable to reach them since September.

"I call here on the government of Guinea to give us assistance to provide for the security of the refugees who are fleeing," Mr Lubbers said yesterday at the Massakoundou camp, just outside Kissidougou. "We need a corridor of security and safety for refugees and humanitarian workers."

One of the world's poorest nations, Guinea has one of Africa's largest refugee populations, including 122,000 Liberians who fled their country's seven-year civil war which ended in 1996, and 330,000 Sierra Leoneans who have fled almost ten years of fighting by rebels of the Revolutionary United Front.

Since September, 200,000 of the refugees have been on the move inside Guinea's forests after fighting broke out on the borders with Liberia and Sierra Leone. About 22,000 Sierra Leoneans have returned home, often to equally perilous conditions.

On Tuesday, the UNHCR began relocating refugees from the border areas to a new camp at Albadaria, 110 miles to the north. But UNHCR officials say they are hampered by security concerns, insufficient trucks and the difficult terrain. Many refugees have fled on foot behind a UNHCR convoy.

By Saturday, some 20,000 of them had sought refuge at Katkama, a former camp looted and partially destroyed during fighting in December. Exhausted families sat surrounded by bundles of possessions as Lubbers, a former Dutch prime minister who was appointed to his UN post last month, toured the camp yesterday.

A few makeshift shelters made of branches and plastic sheeting had been erected, but many people were sleeping in the open as they waited for UN trucks to take them further away from the border.

"They are too slow," complained Kamoba Daramy, a 42-year-old Sierra Leonean who has fled two refugee camps nearer the border in the past three days. "We want (the UNHCR) to hurry up because all around here is a rebel zone."

Guinean officials fear rebel fighters could be concealed among the refugees and want a slow relocation so they can conduct roadside searches. Refugees complain these searches often turn into violent shakedowns and many lose what few possessions they have left.

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 12
fields.trailText: February 12: Harpers & Queen is to boost its fashion coverage in an attempt to entice premium designer-label advertisers away from Vogue.
fields.body:
Harpers & Queen is to boost its fashion coverage in an attempt to entice premium designer-label advertisers away from Vogue.

Optimad and iMediapoint have merged in a move that marks a major consolidation in the online media-trading market.

To combat the publicity surrounding the launches of InStyle and Glamour, Vogue is to break its first ever branding campaign on February 12.

Manning Gottlieb Media has promoted its brands communications director Alison Wright to the position of deputy managing director.

Richard Bogie has taken up a new position with Scotsman Publications as assistant managing director and group advertisement director.

Car manufacturers are missing a trick by not targeting young people with their advertising, according to new research from Channel 4.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-four, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-four, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Two winners for Blue Square expert Patrick Murray this week. But is he happy? No: all he wants is some sleep and some cheese
fields.trailText: Two winners for Blue Square expert Patrick Murray this week. But is he happy? No: all he wants is some sleep and some cheese.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £190.67
Sean Ingle = £47.40
Paul MacInnes = £39.39
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £29.12

Scott Murray: Celtic v Rangers - 0 or 1 goals scored - £5 @ 3/1
Bet won

This time last week I was lauding young Mr Murray for taking the aggressive route and backing no goalscorer rather than 0 or 1 goals, despite the fact that this cost him a win. This week I'm going to laud him for doing exactly the opposite. Right little teacher's pet, isn't he?

But before you put me down as some sort of medieval pope, abusing my almost limitless power to dispense favour to my namesakes while ignoring the legitimate claims of Scott's esteemed, but suspiciously unMurrayesque, colleagues, I have one word to say to you, and it's a word I may have used once or twice before: namely, 'value', the God of all things punter.

In last week's match, 0 or 1 goals was just 13/8 with no goalscorer 8/1. This week, 0 or 1 goals was a far more attractive 3/1 yet no goalscorer was still 8/1. So whereas last week you were paying a big premium for getting the 1-0 and 0-1 results on your side, this week you're paying very little; whereas last week the implied odds for 1-0 to either side were 11/4, this week they are more like 7/1 which is actually longer than the price on Celtic to win 1-0 alone. (Indeed, add together the individual prices on 0-0, 1-0 and 0-1 and it comes to considerably less than 2-1, let alone 3-1).

The fact is that correct score prices are pretty much fixed, derived from age-old charts that relate to the relative prices of the sides involved with little, or rather no, thought given to the goalscoring prowess of the teams involved or to the history of the fixture. The number of goals market, on the other hand, is far more fluid and open to the interpretation of the odds compiler. Clearly in this case, the odds compiler foresaw another high-scoring match, then factored in the propensity of punters to back goal-fests in live matches, and came up with 3/1 for 0 or 1 goals.

Scott clearly believed the odds compiler had over-reacted and his bankroll is looking the healthier for it. This is not to say the odds compiler was wrong; perhaps Scott got lucky and the value lay in backing high-score combinations from the correct score market. Who knows? But the important thing to learn from this is the advantages to be gained by spreading your net as widely as possible in your search for value, checking out all the markets, particularly related ones, and looking for contradictions within matches that can be targeted. Hope all that's clear.

Sean Ingle: Chelsea to beat Manchester United - £8 @ 7/4

Mr I's bumper book of ancient Chinese proverbs received yet another airing this week as he continued his journey through the brave new world of multiple-free punting. "With time and patience the mulberry leaf becomes a silk gown," he wrote. Or, to put it another way, it's a marathon not a sprint. Wise words indeed.

As for his bet, it has all the hallmarks of a value single in my admittedly extremely tired eyes. With United umpteen points clear in the League and facing a massive Champions League match in Valencia in midweek, it was hard to see them killing themselves to win this match. Chelsea, meanwhile, are playing like a team possessed at home, such that they would probably be value to beat Brazil at 7/4 let alone United.

There may well have been a case for backing Chelsea on the Asian handicap given the fact that United have lost only once away all season and drawn four times (five now). But I can't blame Mr I for going all out for the win. Maybe next week. Maybe the week after. Patience is the key, it is only February and I still believe the silk gown will be ready by the end of the season.

Paul MacInnes: Chelsea to draw with Man Utd - £5 @ 9/4
Bet won

An example of that rare beast, so rare in fact that many thought it extinct, the MacInnes Winner (Randomus Puntus) was discovered alive and well in London this week. It is hoped this may be one half of a breeding pair but experts remain doubtful. Okay, so there's no need to be facetious, but its been a busy weekend and one has to relax somehow.

Mr M's success, long overdue and all the more welcome for it, has at least given him a bit more ammunition for future weeks, but I hope he won't be investing it in this sort of bet again next week. As regular readers will know, I am rather dubious about the wisdom of backing draws in general - it all seems a little too random to me.

Opposing overvalued favourites and backing undervalued outsiders seems a far more reliable source of income, as Scott's healthy bankroll testifies, and with the MacInnes millions reaching the dizzy heights of £40 once more, Paul still has every chance of ending up in profit if he follows the example of his illustrious colleague.

Mitch Pryce of the Guardian Unlimited Punters' Collective: £5 treble - Chesterfield to beat Cheltenham @ 1/2, Forest to draw with Blackburn @ 11/5, Port Vale to draw with Bournemouth @ 11/5
Bet lost

This is one way to try to get the GUPC bankroll out of trouble and back into profit but believe me it's the wrong way. What can I say about this bet that I haven't said a thousand times before? Nothing, so I'll say the things I've said a thousand times before. Look for value not winners. Bet in singles not multiples. Don't back draws (in general). And, of course, the old favourite, the one that underpins the rest: it's a marathon not a sprint.

Funds may be low in the GUPC, but the immensely cliched fat lady has not even arrived at the opera house as yet. Punting is for life, not just for Christmas, and the only way to win at the game is to take the long-term view which paradoxically means treating every week on its individual merits.

How much you are up or down should never be a factor in choosing a bet or the stake to be placed on that bet. The only determinants should be: (a) how much value the bet represents (the major determinant in deciding whether to do the bet); (b) the likelihood of the bet winning, and; (c) the size of your bankroll. The bigger (a), (b) and (c) are the bigger your stake should be.

It's hard not to set yourself short-term targets, to push that little bit extra to break level over a given period, but this will only cost you money in the long term. And we wouldn't want that. But enough preaching, I must away to find some cheese. Until next week, happy punting.

webTitle: PlayStation games to appear on mobile phones

fields.headline: PlayStation games to appear on mobile phones
fields.trailText: 1pm: Sony has teamed up with Vodafone to develop PlayStation games for mobile phones, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Sony has teamed up with Vodafone to develop PlayStation games for mobile phones.

The partners have agreed to share technical research, development and marketing expertise to produce products and services with the aim of extending the PlayStation experience to Vodafone mobiles.

As the relationship evolves, the focus will broaden to include the development of game environments and software applications.

Services being developed include allowing Vodafone customers to connect their mobile phone to their PlayStation 1 console or PlayStation 2 computer entertainment system.

A web-based PlayStation hints and tips services via text messaging, WAP and other internet enabled services is also being developed.

The joint research will initially take place in the UK.

The intention is to extend the available services to other Vodafone and PlayStation customers across Europe and then globally.

"This is the first building block in establishing an exciting, long-term partnership," said Vodafone UK managing director Paul Donovan.

"PlayStation is synonymous with gaming and home computer entertainment.

"Focussing on our gaming and entertainment portfolio, Sony Computer Entertainment Europe is a key partner that we believe will help develop our wireless gaming strategy," he said.

Donovan added: "The potential of enhancing the entertainment experience by connecting mobile devices with the world of PlayStation is enormous and something our customers want.

"We will create a whole new market for games, entertainment and information services."

Sony Computer Entertainment Europe president Chris Deering said: "Mobile phone and PlayStation users in Europe have a lot in common in terms of lifestyle, attitudes and their enthusiasm for connected entertainment, "

"We are very excited about what this could mean for participative gaming and information services as bandwidth expands on the cellular front," he added. Vodafone Multimedia is part of Vodafone UK, which has 11.66m customers.

The company has 78.7m customers worldwide.

Sony Computer Entertainment Europe is responsible for the sales, marketing and distribution of PlayStation, PlayStation 1 and PlayStation software and hardware.
fields.bodyText: Sony has teamed up with Vodafone to develop PlayStation games for mobile phones. The partners have agreed to share technical research, development and marketing expertise to produce products and services with the aim of extending the PlayStation experience to Vodafone mobiles. As the relationship evolves, the focus will broaden to include the development of game environments and software applications. Services being developed include allowing Vodafone customers to connect their mobile phone to their PlayStation 1 console or PlayStation 2 computer entertainment system. A web-based PlayStation hints and tips services via text messaging, WAP and other internet enabled services is also being developed. The joint research will initially take place in the UK. The intention is to extend the available services to other Vodafone and PlayStation customers across Europe and then globally. "This is the first building block in establishing an exciting, long-term partnership," said Vodafone UK managing director Paul Donovan. "PlayStation is synonymous with gaming and home computer entertainment. "Focussing on our gaming and entertainment portfolio, Sony Computer Entertainment Europe is a key partner that we believe will help develop our wireless gaming strategy," he said. Donovan added: "The potential of enhancing the entertainment experience by connecting mobile devices with the world of PlayStation is enormous and something our customers want. "We will create a whole new market for games, entertainment and information services." Sony Computer Entertainment Europe president Chris Deering said: "Mobile phone and PlayStation users in Europe have a lot in common in terms of lifestyle, attitudes and their enthusiasm for connected entertainment, " "We are very excited about what this could mean for participative gaming and information services as bandwidth expands on the cellular front," he added. fields.headline: Livingstone in London budget u-turn
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone has backed down on his weighty budget demands in the face of opposition from the capital's councils and assembly.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone has backed down on his weighty budget demands in the face of opposition from the capital's councils and assembly.

With the London assembly threatening to slash millions from his first budget, Mr Livingstone has suggested scaling back the proposed increase to the average band D council tax from £38 to £28 per year.

The move will be welcomed by London's boroughs, which were anxious that the original precept proposals would force band D council tax up by around 5% - on top of which councils would have to add increases to pay for frontline services.

Mr Livingstone said he had "gone the extra mile to listen and seek compromise and agreement" with the assembly in his final draft budget.

He has now conceded to almost all the assembly's proposed cuts, including £9.3m in efficiency savings from the metropolitan police budget. But Mr Livingstone has remained defiant on the transport budget.

The assembly had called on the mayor to cut the entire £23.6m increase for Transport for London (TfL) which was destined to form the organisation's reserves. Mr Livingstone now wants an increase of just over £10m.

He said: "The transport budget I am proposing is the absolute minimum needed to ensure London gets the full programme of planned transport improvement and to safeguard the financial position of TfL. I still believe my original plans were a better and more secure option - delivering the programme will now need especially careful management but I have put the objective of achieving consensus first."

Assembly budget committee chairwoman Baroness Sally Hamwee said the met and TfL budgets could be "clearer and tighter".

Last week metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens and transport commissioner Bob Kiley pleaded with the assembly not to force them into a financial juggling act by calling for swinging cuts.

Mr Livingstone has also accepted a proposed £2.318m cut to money earmarked for core Greater London authority services such as cultural initiatives and health monitoring. He intends to manage these cuts by keeping a tight control of staffing and closely timing the introduction of new initiatives.

The mayor presents his final draft budget to the assembly on February 15 and will have to give reasons if he has not included amendments it previously suggested. The assembly may amend this final budget only by a two-thirds majority.

webTitle: Tarnished Jewell set for the sack

fields.headline: Tarnished Jewell set for the sack
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell is set to be sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday this afternoon.
fields.body:
Paul Jewell is set to be sacked as manager of Sheffield Wednesday this afternoon.

The Owls have called a press conference for 1pm at which they are expected to announce the dismissal of Jewell, who took over at Hillsborough last summer following Wednesday's relegation from the Premiership.

Jewell has been unable to turn around the club's fortunes amid tight financial constraints and Saturday's 4-1 defeat at Wimbledon left them rock bottom of Division One.

Jewell succeeded Chris Kamara as Bradford boss in 1998 and guided the Bantams to promotion into the Premiership, but quit after keeping them up on the last day of last season.

webTitle: Lastminute losses overshadow Thomas Cook deal

fields.headline: Lastminute losses overshadow Thomas Cook deal
fields.standfirst: By Dan Milmo
fields.trailText: 9.45am:Lastminute.com's doubled losses have overshadowed its deal with Thomas Cook, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online booking firm lastminute.com has more than doubled its losses, overshadowing a deal with offline rival Thomas Cook.

The UK's most famous dot.com said it lost £15.3m between October and December last year, up from £6m for the same period in 1999.

Subscriber figures were also flat, rising by just 10,000 from the 2.85m reported at the end of September last year.

The Thomas Cook deal will see lastminute linking up with the travel agent's website, offering theatre tickets and restaurant bookings to holiday buyers. Lastminute will also set up a joint site for customers who wish to book a holiday more than six weeks in advance, as it tries to bring a wider range of consumers to the site.

Despite the widened losses, lastminute's much-maligned shares rose 6% to 74.75p in early trading as the market focused on a rise in sales from £0.4m to £2.9m. The shares remain far behind their year high of 555p, which was achieved just after lastminute's flotation in March last year.

Lastminute chairman Allan Leighton, the former chief executive of supermarket giant Asda, said the October acquisition of French rival Degriftour had given the company a vital boost.

"As we have said before, there is a lot to do. However, our strong brand, our widening offer, the successful integration of Degriftour, our new technology platform and our cash position continue to provide us with confidence as we build the cash towards profitability," Mr Leighton said.

webTitle: Two deaths in West Bank shootings

fields.headline: Two deaths in West Bank shootings
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Two Palestinians have been killed and two seriously wounded by Israeli army fire in two separate incidents in the West Bank, a day after an Israeli motorist was gunned down by Palestinians near Jerusalem.
fields.body:
Two Palestinians have been killed and two seriously wounded by Israeli army fire in two separate incidents in the West Bank, a day after an Israeli motorist was gunned down by Palestinians near Jerusalem.

In both West Bank shootings, Palestinian witnesses said Israeli soldiers fired at Palestinian vehicles without provocation.

The fresh round of violence came as prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon intensified efforts to bring predecessor Ehud Barak and his moderate Labour party into the new government. Outgoing communications minister Binyamin Ben-Eliezer announced today that he would seek the leadership of the Labour party.

Mr Ben-Eliezer, an ex-general who represents the more hawkish wing of the centre-left party, is one of the most outspoken advocates of joining Mr Sharon's government.

Meanwhile the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, is keeping a close eye on the Israelis' negotiations after he held talks with Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak in Cairo today, urging a united Arab front in the face of hardliner Mr Sharon's victory.

The first West Bank shooting occurred this morning near the village of Al Khader when a bus carrying Palestinian labourers drove along a back road to avoid Israeli checkpoints enforcing a blockade of West Bank communities.

The bus encountered an Israeli army bulldozer, and soldiers ordered the driver to turn back, said one of the passengers, Zidan Ahmed. The witness said that after the bus had already turned around, soldiers fired at the vehicle.

The back window of the bus was shattered by the bullets, killing one passenger and seriously wounding another. The army said that at the time of the shooting, Palestinians in Al Khader were throwing stones at troops.

In the West Bank village of Rafat, Palestinians and Israeli troops engaged in a firefight for several hours this morning. When a car drove from the village toward an army roadblock, soldiers opened fire, killing one of the passengers, the army said. Palestinian witnesses said a second passenger was seriously wounded. They said the van was driving fast, but that soldiers shot without provocation.

On Sunday night, an Israeli motorist was killed by Palestinian gunmen on a main West Bank road leading to Jerusalem. Palestinians also fired from the West Bank town of Beit Jalla at Gilo, a Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem built on land Israel captured in the 1967 war and claimed by the Palestinians for a future state.

The latest fighting brought to 389 the number of people killed in Israeli-Palestinian violence in the past five months. Of those, some 340 were Arabs and nearly 50 were Jews.

Moshe Arens, a senior Likud lawmaker, said the new government would retaliate more harshly for Palestinian attacks than Barak has done. "They should know that we have means that we still haven't used," Arens told Israel radio.

The renewed West Bank violence came less than a week after Sharon was elected by a landslide on a pledge to end the Israeli-Palestinian fighting. Teams representing Labour and Sharon's Likud are due to meet later today to negotiate the terms of joint government.

A major sticking point is Labour's insistence that Likud agree in writing to dismantle some Jewish settlements as part of any deal with the Palestinians.

webTitle: Two Way TV links up with Infogrames

fields.headline: Two Way TV links up with Infogrames
fields.trailText: 12.45: Interactive TV games company Two Way TV has signed up its first external games developer, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Interactive TV games company Two Way TV has signed up its first external games developer.

The company is gearing up to launch a fully fledged interactive TV channel on ONdigital in the next two months.

Two Way TV has joined forces with leading games developer Infogrames to co-produce games for the ONdigital Two Way TV channel.

Infogrames already makes games for Warner Bros and Paramount and has recently bought Hasbro Interactive.

The purchase allows it to produce digital versions of Hasbro board games, such as Monopoly, Scrabble and Risk.

The deal with Two Way TV will enable Infogrames develop a number of puzzle-based games for the channel.

It is expected to lead to the development of interactive board games for Two Way TV.

It is also thought the tie-up with Infogrames will lead to further games partnerships with Two Way TV on other platforms.

Gilles Lioret, head of the I.Lights department at Infogrames, said: "Working with Two Way TV will bring our games to a new audience and will strengthen our brand within the digital entertainment market."

In a bid to build its profile, Infogrames has recently started adding its brand name to ads for its games.

Last month, Two Way TV underwent a cost-cutting exercise in which 30 jobs were axed.

A further 12 staff are in the process of negotiating "sabbaticals" or part-time contracts.

webTitle: Foster replacement Ullmann signals more Eurocentric Cannes

fields.headline: Foster replacement Ullmann signals more Eurocentric Cannes
fields.trailText: The choice of Liv Ullmann to replace Jodie Foster as jury head at the Cannes Film Festival is believed to mark a political decision to favour European cinema over Hollywood product
fields.body:
Liv Ullmann has been confirmed as the jury head at this year's Cannes Film Festival. The Norwegian actress-director replaces original choice Jodie Foster who pulled out a fortnight ago due to filming commitments on the David Fincher thriller Panic Room.

"I am honoured and deeply appreciative," said Ullmann in a statement released by Cannes president Gilles Jacob. The Cannes post, she added, would provide her with the opportunity: "To do what I enjoy most - watching movies." The announcement is evidence of a further upswing in Ullmann's public profile. Having made her name as Ingmar Bergman's star of choice in the late 60s and early 70s, Ullmann moved behind the camera. Her latest film Faithless, based on an old Bergman script, played at last year's Cannes and was released to rave reviews in the UK last week.

Inevitably, however, Ullmann's selection will be picked over for its political message. It was widely believed that the initial choice of Foster was part of a concerted attempt by the Cannes organisers to make peace with Hollywood - all too often a sworn enemy of the French film industry.

But with the selection of Ullmann the pendulum appears to have suddenly swung back again. The 62-year-old actress is a revered emblem of European art-house cinema. More crucially, in a recent Guardian interview at the NFT, Ullmann admitted that she was no fan of modern American cinema: "80% of the films we see are Hollywood movies, and the more people see these movies the harder it is to get them into other movies It is tough for film-makers if they want to make a serious film. But most of all I am worried for the young people because they cannot go to the cinema and experience the wonder when the curtain goes up and something is happening there." One can only hope that the Farrelly Brothers are not one of Cannes' featured attractions this year: Ullmann is no fan of their last film, Me, Myself and Irene: "They were raping a chicken! It's not even fun!"

fields.headline: Shepperton sold to Pinewood for £35m
fields.standfirst: Takeover by studio famous for James Bond seen as a boon for British film industry which has struggled to compete
fields.trailText: Takeover by studio famous for James Bond seen as a boon for British film industry which has struggled to compete.
fields.body:
Shepperton, the west London film studio behind favourites such as Top Gun and Blade Runner, has been sold to its arch rival Pinewood for £35m, it was revealed yesterday.

The merger of the two famous British studios has been largely welcomed by the industry which sees it as a chance to attract more major film-makers.

British studios have suffered in recent years as Hollywood producers have found complexes in mainland Europe, especially eastern Europe, Canada and Australia cheaper and more flexible.

It is hoped that the merger will redress the balance. One drawback is that the spaces are so far apart, which could cause logistical difficulties.

The former Channel 4 chief executive Michael Grade became chairman of Pinewood Studios, best known as the home of the James Bond series, last February after his bidding group bought the business from Rank for £62m.

Since 1995 Shepperton had been owned by a consortium, including Ridley Scott, director of Gladiator, his brother Tony and the private equity company Candover.

There were suggestions that Candover had been pushing for the sale of Shepperton to realise the return on its investment and it was thought that the Scott brothers were preparing to take the business public.

But then it became clear that Mr Grade was keen to merge the two studios.

Details of the deal remain sketchy but it is thought that the Scott brothers will continue to play key roles, perhaps as senior managers. Their presence will boost the artistic integrity of the new operation. It is also thought that senior industry figures such as Lord Attenborough and Lord Puttnam have been sounded out about the plans.

The merger comes at a good time for the British industry. Though it has struggled to compete over recent years, the next 12 months - with the possibility of an actors' and writers' strike in Hollywood looming - could put film-making here back on the map.

Because of the possible strike, coupled with competitive exchange rates and the Americans' love affair with British talent, a number of high-profile companies, including Disney and Paramount, are to make films in Britain. Warner Brothers is currently shooting the Harry Potter film at Leavesden Studios in Hertfordshire.

The merger is being part-financed by the venture capital firm 3i.

Marek Gumienny, managing director of Candover, said: "The deal revolutionises Europe's positioning in the global film production arena, bringing it head to head with its Hollywood counterparts."

Dan Adler, investment manager at 3i, said the deal would not lead to any job cuts on either side. Shepperton employs around 120 people, while Pinewood, which is based in Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, has about 140 on its books.

The film critic Barry Norman, who has discussed the plans with Ridley Scott, yesterday welcomed the news. He said: "It seems a good idea. My only worry is that the two studios are not very close together. I suppose ideally you would have one huge space, rather than two smaller ones."

fields.headline: Channel East blames staff for production cuts
fields.trailText: The satellite channel has blamed "lax" staff after it slashed 100 of its 126-strong workforce, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
In an extraordinary outburst, an Asian cable and satellite channel has blamed "lax" TV production staff, who "want to work for a quick buck", after it slashed 100 of its 126-strong workforce.

Channel East, which was set up early last year, has scaled back programme production from 25 programmes to around seven.

Channel East's boss Pom Bhabra said he cut the channel's staff rosters from 120 to 26 over a period of about nine months because most production staff "simply weren't performing".

webTitle: Express sales have slipped below 1m. Last time they were so low, Lord Beaverbrook was in charge

fields.headline: Express sales have slipped below 1m. Last time they were so low, Lord Beaverbrook was in charge
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade on historic times at the Express (again) and those 'spectacularly unhelpful' bulk sales.
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on historic times at the Express (again) and those 'spectacularly unhelpful' bulk sales.
fields.body:
Before I intrude on Mr Richard Desmond's grief, a word about the new circulation chart, which is making its second appearance. To recap, the first three columns reflect a truer picture of newspaper sales by omitting bulks - the papers sold at a fraction of their cover price to hotels, fast food outlets, betting shops and airlines, which are then distributed free to customers.

I was uncertain whether the change was such a good idea until an editor told me that one of his senior managers had called the exercise "spectacularly unhelpful". In other words, the chart was exposing a practice that management would rather remain concealed.

An independent critic pointed out that some papers that are less reliant on bulks use other sleight-of-hand measures, such as discounting and cheap pre-paid subscriptions. True, but I believe the conscious act of purchase makes it more likely that the buyer will read the paper.

I also happily admit that most people handed a free copy when getting on a plane will probably read it in some depth, but these are one-off, casual readers. To equate them with six-times-a-week, home-delivered buyers is nonsense. Nor can we be sure of the level of interest of readership among hotel guests or punters.

Anyway, the die is cast. The main chart comparisons, contrasting year-on-year sales, continue in their unbulked format. The fourth column shows the figures with bulks, as does the six-monthly averages. This allows everyone to get as clear a picture as possible.

Nothing springs so obviously to the eye this month as the figures for the two Express titles. The Daily Express's fall below 1m sets all sorts of records. I believe it to be the paper's lowest sale since June 1924, a period in which Beaverbrook was forced to discourage sales from rising because publishing more was costing him too much money.

The same cannot be said now. Indeed, let us not forget that the new owner, Richard Desmond, promised to increase distribution. My inquiries suggest that he never even attempted to fulfil that pledge. Returns have been running at higher levels than his circulation department has known since one of Desmond's foolish predecessors, Lord Stevens, decided to merge the Daily Star and Sunday Sport in 1987.

That analogy is apt. The Star's readers and advertisers deserted in their thousands because Stevens's joint deal with the pornographer David Sullivan resulted in tasteless content, and the paper's already shaky editorial credibility nose-dived.

This time, there can only be one reason for the desertion: a combination of general publicity about Desmond's pornographic businesses and the specific targeting of Express buyers by the Daily Mail, asking whether they are happy buying a pornographer's paper.

Although the Express has been on the slide for months, edging ever closer to the million, the sudden plunge cannot be anything to do with the paper itself. It was adequate enough in Rosie Boycott's last two months and the new editor, Chris Williams, has done a good job since he took over a couple of weeks ago.

It is noticeable that the great beneficiary of the Express's fall has been the Mail, which sold over 5% more copies in January than in the same month a year ago. The Express was down by more than 6%.

Failure to promote the paper in January was another crucial error and illustrates an unpalatable truth about the new owner's lack of knowledge. Forget Desmond's other activities for a moment and ask the basic newspaper industry questions the rest of Fleet Street is asking: does he know what he is doing? Has he any idea what he has got himself into? Has he got a strategy for recovery?

Time isn't on his side. Both circu lation and advertising revenue, already low, will fall dramatically as sales decline in the coming months.

Of course, he can cut costs. He can swing the axe, sacking journalists by the dozen. He can save on paper clips. None of that, no matter how skilful Williams turns out to be, will stop the circulation rot.

What the paper requires is commitment, investment and, most of all, understanding. On the evidence of his first 10 weeks as proprietor, Desmond is the wrong owner. In selling to him, Clive Hollick has done a disservice to the newspaper industry and he should wipe the smirk off his face at having pulled off a financial coup.

His lack of involvement during his tenure is more to blame for the paper's falling sales than Desmond's. Perhaps his greatest contribution to its decline was the clumsy merging of the Daily with the Sunday Express.

That kind of union manifestly failed to work at the two Telegraphs, yet Hollick encouraged a former Telegraph executive who had witnessed the failure - Stephen Grabiner - to oversee a similar merger at the Express. Was any paper ever subjected to such ruthless cynicism?

Look at the result: the resources-starved Sunday Express is selling 926,000, down more than 9% on a year ago. It is a paper without soul, without stories, without reason. I do not doubt that its journalists exert themselves and I do not criticise them. But they are going through the motions. No editor, not even the very best, can do the job unless the owner cares.

It would be churlish though not to point to one remarkable success within Ludgate House: the continuing sales success of the Daily Star. Editor Peter Hill and his deputy, Hugh Whittow, have managed to increase circulation by almost 8% in the past year. The volume is small, but to arrest decline in this market is some feat, especially since its use of bulks is negligible.

The problem for Williams and his journalists is that Desmond may read too much into the Star's ability to retain a British sale of 540,000 with a tiny staff. Express readers demand greater authority and a wider news agenda than the Star's audience. If he cuts the Express editorial team down to the Star's level, prepare for meltdown.

As for the rest of the figures in the monthly chart, note the Sun's continued improvement and the Mirror's failure to compete. Observe also the Sunday Telegraph's disturbing down-turn and its daily stablemate's failure to stay above 1m. The Express is not the only paper facing a difficult time in the months ahead.

fields.headline: Jungle death throes
fields.standfirst: Granada says high costs and a change in viewers' tastes mean that Survival must adapt or die. But it could be that dead animals don't attract advertisers, says  Thomas Penny
fields.trailText: Granada says high costs and a change in viewers' tastes mean that Survival must adapt or die. But it could be that dead animals don't attract advertisers, says Thomas Penny
fields.body:
It should be a time of celebration at Survival, the wildlife film-making arm of Anglia Television. This month marks its 40th anniversary and, 850 films down the line, it still has a worldwide reputation for making quality programmes.

But changes in the market for wildlife films, coupled with the second corporate takeover of its parent company in six years, mean that redundancy notices are being prepared and Survival has become the latest target for 'rationalisation'.

There was much speculation about what would happen to Survival when Granada took over United News and Media's television interests last year. It was felt that there would not be room for both Survival and Partridge Films, the two wings of United Wildlife, in Granada's factual portfolio, and most hoped for some sort of amalgamation. But now the axe is swinging and, save for a handful of producers, most of the staff from both outfits will be dispatched to the freelance jungle.

Those who remain will be moved to Bristol, the self-styled Hollywood of wildlife film-making and home to the BBC's Natural History Unit. Here, the area's substantial pool of freelance writers, editors and cameramen will be used to make programmes under the Survival brand alongside hired hands doing the same for Partridge.

There is bitterness and anger among Survival's 40-plus employees, who feel that after years of bringing in healthy profits to the company they are being cast aside as a result of one bad year. As one put it: "Over the past four years Survival made £10m, £8m, £8m, and then lost £1.3m. Now the bean-counters have come in, and with no apparent thought for what might change in the future, have decided we have to go."

A statement from Granada makes its reasons clear: broadcasters want to buy cheaper programmes that are turned around quickly, such as those made by Partridge and fronted by Steve Irwin and Nigel Marven. "The restructuring of the wildlife business has come in response to the changing demands of UK and international broadcasters," said the statement. "Markets are now hungry for popular documentary techniques, the use of presenters and the inclusion of more science - approaches that have already been embraced in Bristol."

Survival's reputation has been built on blue-chip films, made with big budgets and no presenters, the polar opposite of the "popular documentary techniques" referred to in the Granada statement. It made a stab at the presenter-led market with a series on predators fronted by Gaby Roslin, but hasn't repeated the format.

What mystifies staff at Survival is why there is a perceived lack of demand for high-end wildlife when the BBC continues to pull in millions of viewers for films made with high production values and big budgets.

Part of the answer could be seen at last year's Wildscreen Festival, the industry's biennial bunfight in Bristol, at which commissioning executives were frank about the changing tastes of their viewers. In a seminar in which they were pitched ideas for programmes and gave their responses, the ideas that were best received were a fly-on-the-wall documentary about chimpanzees and a presenter-led series following international animal welfare workers, a kind of Animal Hospital on the road. Proposals about the need to cull feral cats and the contribution of hunters to conservation didn't get past the starting gate.

The problem with serious wildlife programmes is that they don't always have happy endings and channels which rely on advertisers are reluctant to risk the consequences. One executive from a commercial TV company spelt out the problem: "We don't want to make programmes that send people to bed feeling depressed," she said. Given the current state of the environment, that makes serious wildlife film-making difficult.

In contrast, the BBC can afford to be more robust, as Keith Scholey, the head of the corporation's Natural History Unit, made clear: "On the BBC we show a lot of things being killed, including people. That's what we're about," he said.

Blue-chip is also expensive. Each hour-long Survival costs between £350,000 and £450,000 to make, representing a substantial financial risk. Survival sells well overseas - it even has a Queen's award for export - but without a solid source of income from a terrestrial channel, it is difficult for the board to justify big budgets.

It was a proud boast of Survival that its programmes have been shown "in every country in the world with a TV transmitter". Because they didn't have presenters, the scripts could be redubbed into any language. At one stage in Hong Kong, the Chinese script was read live as the pictures were broadcast. But that flexibility has also contributed to Survival's downfall. Film-makers in Germany, Japan and Scandinavia have been making films that can be redubbed into English to take advantage of the American market.

Another problem for Survival is that new films are competing against its own back catalogue, which is still sold around the world and, because there are no presenters, is largely immune to changing fashions. "We recently sold a lot to Discovery Channel's Animal Planet and we went through them, cleaned them up and updated them and they have really stood the test of time," says Mike Linley, a producer at Survival. "As long as there aren't too many people in flares or old Ford Cortinas, the films are fine - the wildlife behaved the same way 30 years ago as it does today and did 30,000 years ago."

Survival is in the middle of a month long "consultation" period before the redundancies are handed out, and most staff are expected to leave by the summer, when they have finished their current projects.

Linley, who will stay in Norwich and freelance rather than applying for one of the few jobs in Bristol and uprooting his family to the west, said: "We hoped for the best and feared the worst and the worst was a move to Bristol. We didn't anticipate the cuts which accompany that move. There are a lot of people who are very upset, hurt and angry."

webTitle: Sore thumbs? I know what you've been doing

fields.headline: Sore thumbs? I know what you've been doing
fields.trailText: My name is Amy and I'm a text message junkie. I've known about this addiction for quite some time, but it's only now that I'm aware of it dominating my life - if I don't notch up my quota of 20 a day then I'm in the cold turkey zone.
fields.body:
My name is Amy and I'm a text message junkie. I've known about this addiction for quite some time, but it's only now that I'm aware of it dominating my life - if I don't notch up my quota of 20 a day then I'm in the cold turkey zone.

Thankfully, I'm not alone. Around 30m others in the UK send text messages, but the phenomenon has really hit home with young people, especially teenagers.

Forget microscooters, cowboy hats, and even PDAs, text messaging is the new craze sweeping the nation at breakneck speed. It's reached fantastical proportions: more than 1m messages an hour were sent during December and we're close to hitting 1bn messages a month (in the UK alone). It seems there is no stopping this one.

If you're not already sick and tired of reading about text messaging, then be warned, you will be. Just like the media hype that surrounded the internet boom last year and the attention given to Wap when it first emerged, text messaging; the text generation; thumb culture, call it what you will, is the new cool thing to write about.

Marketers are falling over themselves to do deals with mobile operators to cut revenue share deals for SMS (the official term, meaning short message service). But not surprisingly, mobile operators are being difficult because they rather greedily want to keep all the millions they make from SMS for themselves. Operators in Asia are more flexible and pressure from overseas should see the landscape change for SMS revenue cuts over here.

The word going round marketing circles at the moment is that if you're not yet thinking of running a campaign that uses SMS, then you should be - and soon. Broadcasters, newspapers and radio stations have been quick to catch on, with many dabbling with SMS for feedback or competitions based around shows and events. The results have blown them away. The Sun, for example, recently ran an SMS competition called Ringo Bingo, which prompted more than 80,000 responses via text message.

Of course there are a few services that haven't quite had the desired effect. The jury is still out on SMS chat, and services such as Talkcast's Texer.com have been lambasted for seemingly spamming users, and then charging them 12p for the privilege of each received message.

Start-ups that a year ago were basing their business models around exponential Wap growth are now primarily focused on SMS strategies. Some have even ditched their Wap services altogether and relaunched themselves as SMS pure-players. Once the mobile operators agree to fully fledged revenue share deals - where marketers can take up to 50% of the money generated by SMS - this area of marketing is going to go ballistic.

Another side of SMS set to be massive is shopping. Anyone who hasn't yet come across Scan, an SMS-only shopping service for CDs, DVDs, books and games, should try it out. To the uninitiated, shopping by SMS must seem like an odd activity, especially now that there are so many different ways in which consumers can shop. I have to admit I'm hooked. It seems I'm not the only one.

Like the growth of SMS itself, the service has spread like wildfire. Scan's own research shows that more than 70% of customers go on to recommend the service to friends, proving that word of mouth rather than multimillion-pound advertising campaigns can be the best driver of new customers. Scan now has more than half a million customers' mobile numbers on its database and, tellingly, it hasn't done any mainstream marketing.

So where does SMS go from here? The cost of sending messages is likely to come down. Last week One 2 One announced plans to launch Talk & Text, a plan that includes 50 text messages and 500 minutes of off-peak calls for £15 a month. Other operators are certain to follow suit.

More and more cross-media promotions will use SMS as the primary feedback function; and inevitably it will move away from just being a young persons' pastime to something that the older generations use.

And, of course, there will be thousands of relationships conducted and broken via text message. With Valentine's Day just two days away, operators are already bracing themselves for more than 30m messages winging back and forth. If anything, text messaging should do for uptight Brits what the pill did for the sexual revolution in the 1960s. We seldom say what we think, but the beauty of text messaging is that it's private, instant and encourages flirtation. What did we ever do without it? More importantly, pity the poor Americans who, for once, are so far behind the UK that they don't even have the facilities for text messaging. Shucks. But that will change, and soon we'll be text messaging friends in the US for 10p a pop.

I'm managing my addiction well - I've only sent and received five messages while writing this piece. I realise it's not such a bad addiction after all, but it is playing havoc with my increasingly RSI-ridden thumbs.

fields.headline: Britvic boosts 'new age' brands
fields.trailText: 11.45pm: Britvic is to spend £4m on raising the profiles of Purdey's, Aqua Libra and Ame, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Britvic is putting a £4m marketing spend behind its "new age" adult drinks Purdey's, Aqua Libra and Ame in a bid to raise their profiles.

The soft drinks giant acquired the three Orchid Drinks brands last July, adding to a portfolio that includes Pepsi, Tango, Robinsons and R Whites. Britvic wants to double the combined value of the Orchid brands to £32m within five years.

It hopes to increase awareness of the brands among consumers and develop distribution.

To date, the brands have not been supported by a significant media spend.

An advertising and promotional campaign for Ame will kick off in May.

The campaign will include press and poster ads and a national sampling programme.

The brand will also be promoted to the on-trade, as the drink can be used as a non-alcoholic alternative to wine.

Purdey's will launch an advertising campaign from May and a sampling programme will run in cities across the country.

The brand is well known in London and the south-east but Britvic wants to extend its reach.

Aqua Libra will have new packaging from August supported by a PR campaign.

The company wants to broaden the appeal of the drink to a wider range of health-conscious consumers.

Creative work will be handled by Barrett Cernis with media planning and buying by MindShare.

Sampling will be undertaken by Triangle.

"Adults make up 70 per cent of the population and currently consume almost half of all soft drinks," says Britvic category director Andrew Marsden.

"Per capita consumption is growing and, most importantly, adults control 80 per cent of spending.

"We regard adults as a key sector to grow the whole soft drinks category."

fields.headline: The empire strikes back
fields.standfirst: Rupert Murdoch was knocked off his stride by the internet but he has returned to form, says Emily Bell - and this time it's global
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch was knocked off his stride by the internet but he has returned to form, writes Emily Bell.
fields.body:
For those who regard Rupert Murdoch as the media strategy equivalent of Old Mother Shipton, the past few years have proved rather troubling. For the man who kicked off the 80s by reshaping Fleet Street and started the 90s by revolutionising the TV industry, the new millennium has so far been decidedly quiet. Perhaps, like Old Mother S, Mr Murdoch expected the world to have come to an end by now.

Knocked off his stride by the puzzling new paradigms of the internet economy, and dogged by the expense of turning his analogue satellite system into a digital platform, the last time Murdoch completed a major acquisition was with the purchase of Star TV in August 1993. But now he's back, and this time it's global. The mooted $70bn merger between Sky and DirecTV has been on the brink of completion for some time. Both sides are able to say that talks are ongoing, neither is able to say when they might conclude. But what is clear is that Rupert Murdoch really, really wants this deal.

DirecTV has a relatively small - for the US - satellite customer base of 10m, but its attraction is that it puts the final piece in a global pay-TV jigsaw for Murdoch. With Sky TV in Britain and Star TV in the far east, DirecTV is an ambitious but logical target for Murdoch. Whilst the numbers involved are not inconsiderable, the dull business of Scart socket compatibility and the ultimate achievement of having matching set-top boxes in three major markets seems to have the "Murdoch effect" of shaking an industry to its very core.

But in many ways the DirecTV deal does represent a very significant milestone. It is Murdoch nail ing his colours, not to the swaying mast of HMS Internet, but to the tug-boat of interactive TV. He is making a play that goes directly against where other global players are putting their money. Vivendi is betting on the mobile internet being the key to content in the future, whilst AOL-Time Warner is similarly committed to broadband internet access via cable.

It is not surprising that Murdoch and his sleeping partner Bill Gates, who is putting $5bn behind the bar for the DirecTV deal, have looked for an alternative to the internet. Both men very much lost their bearings when confronted with the anarchic state of cyberspace. Bill G underestimated its effect and wound up being pummelled by the anti-trust police having tried to corral the internet onto his browser. For Murdoch it has been an even more worrying experience. To call News Corp's new media adventures a dog's breakfast would be to invite a lawsuit from the manufacturers of Pedigree Chum. For a man who is renowned for his evasion of regulation, Murdoch's businesses actually thrive by using rules to their advantage. Encouraged by his children and his new wife, Murdoch started to believe some of the hype rather than sticking to his own original and entirely correct analysis: the internet companies were, by and large, hideously over-valued.

He declared his love for Soft Bank, the Japanese internet investor, which turned into one of the biggest dot.com casualties. So to find Murdoch retreating to TV is hardly a surprise. But it is a risk. BSkyB needs to up its income-per-digital-subscriber from £286 to £400 for 2005. Star TV's losses have been substantially cut, but the ink is still red. For interactive TV to provide the kind of fatted calf News Corp thinks it ought to, consumers will have to get used to using their TVs to spend money. In BSkyB's results last week interactivity provided £37m of revenue - of which £33m was from betting. A fascinating number, but Rupert Murdoch is no more a bookmaker than he is a shopkeeper.

If Murdoch closes the deal, it will be the biggest of his career. And probably his last. What will he do then? Does he want to be the Starbucks of pay-TV? In which case will he ditch Sky as a brand in favour of Fox? Will he take on the cabled-up leviathans of North America with a supercharged, cheaper customer service? And if he doesn't close the deal then it's not the end of the world. Except of course for Old Mother Shipton.

fields.headline: Dove va il calcio?
fields.standfirst: Italy's football federation is clamping down on a worrying increase in football violence and racism by introducing tougher rules for clubs. Use of videocameras and a heavy police presence doesn't seem to work - so what, asks Mariacarla Pavoni, do young football fans think is the answer?
fields.trailText: Italy's football federation is clamping down on a worrying increase in football violence and racism by introducing tougher rules for clubs. Use of videocameras and a heavy police presence doesn't seem to work - so what, asks Mariacarla Pavoni, do young football fans think is the answer?
fields.body:
Il campionato di calcio fa parlare di sé non solo per le partite giocate ma anche per gli episodi di teppismo sulle gradinate. Non bastano poliziotti e telecamere a frenare violenza e razzismo. Frange di tifoserie "malate" si esibiscono in duri attacchi personali, lanci di razzi e seggiolini o in cori di fischi e "buuu" diretti ai giocatori di colore. Le stesse società calcistiche non riescono sempre a contrastare questi atteggiamenti. Sono emblematiche le parole del presidente del Verona calcio, che ha recentemente dichiarato, durante un'intervista televisiva, di non poter acquistare un giocatore di colore perché "i tifosi mi metterebbero sulla graticola".

La Federcalcio ha ora stabilito sanzioni pesantissime: multe, squalifica del campo e addirittura partite giocate a porte chiuse. Riporteranno la serenità?

Che tipo di tifoso sei?

Marco, Presidente Torino Club di Alpignano - Sono tifoso del Toro per cultura familiare e per amore del calcio. Mi piace parlare della squadra con i soci del club e andare allo stadio. Vivo la partita con allegria in uno dei settori "freddi" della curva, con amici che la pensano come me.

Emanuel, socio Juventus Club di Rivoli - Noi siamo tifosi organizzati ma tranquilli, la violenza non ci tocca proprio, però lo stadio è un ambiente dove ci si può scaldare, anche trasformare. Siamo un club, occupiamo un settore di curva preciso, abbiamo i nostri striscioni. Andare allo stadio per noi è un obbligo, una fede!

Ilaria, studentessa - Tifo Milan perlopiù alla televisione insieme agli amici. Se vado allo stadio sto alla larga dalle zone "calde".

Fabio, studente - Sono un abbonato del Torino calcio. Mi entusiasma stare in curva, nelle zone centrali "calde" dove già andava mia madre da ragazza. Sto in mezzo agli ultras, ma non appartengo a nessun club.

Come giudichi i recenti episodi di violenza e razzismo?

Marco - Gli stadi riflettono la realtà sociale. Gli esagitati sono gli stessi che si scatenano a scuola, per strada o in birreria. Sono fortunatamente una minoranza. Purtroppo allo stadio, dove si è gomito a gomito possono contagiare gli altri. Ma il calcio non può essere screditato da questi episodi.

Emanuel - I giornalisti spesso esagerano. Parlano delle cose negative e mai delle amicizie fra tifoserie, ad esempio. Non credo che gli sfottò verso alcuni giocatori siano razzismo.

Ilaria - Odio vedere la guerriglia da stadio o leggere scritte razziste. Forse stiamo tutti diventando violenti e intolleranti. Basta assistere alle liti fra giornalisti sportivi in televisione!

Fabio - Le tifoserie del Toro non sono razziste. Chi ci prova viene zittito. Io sono assolutamente contro la violenza, ma devo ammettere che allo stadio esiste. Molti tafferugli nascono dalla stupidità di un singolo che scatena la reazione di molti.

Di chi pensi sia la responsabilità?

Marco - Si può risalire a situazioni familiari o educative ma anche alla scarsa repressione. Gli scalmanati sono spesso gli stessi e non dovrebbero entrare negli stadi. A volte le società, per non scontrarsi con questi pseudo-tifosi, chiudono un occhio.

Emanuel - Le responsabilità sono singole, ma anche del poco rispetto delle regole da parte di chi controlla.

Fabio - Paradossalmente a volte la presenza dei cordoni di poliziotti accende gli animi invece di calmarli. Molti tifosi li considerano una provocazione più che una difesa.

Quali misure bisognerebbe adottare?

Marco - Non sono d'accordo con l'idea delle partite a porte chiuse. Non si farebbe altro che "punire" i tifosi veri. Penso invece che le società non dovrebbero sponsorizzare le trasferte degli ultras coinvolti in episodi di violenza o razzismo.

Emanuel - Bisogna far rispettare le regole esistenti. Ad esempio, non fare entrare nello stadio persone già diffidate. È presto per giudicare le nuove regole, bisognerà vedere se saranno effettivamente applicate.

Ilaria - Le misure annunciate sono severe, ma forse serviranno. E spero che, se necessario, vengano adottate. È inutile limitarsi a fare la voce grossa!

Fabio - Penso si debbano usare soprattutto i filmati delle videocamere per isolare i tifosi violenti, farli uscire dagli stadi e mai più rientrare.

la curva the stand behind the goal

far parlare di sé to get oneself talked about

fare la voce grossa to speak threateningly

gomito a gomito side by side

non mi tocca proprio doesn't concern me in the least

non si farebbe altro che that would only mean

pensarla come to have the same opinion

lo sfottò (coll) teasing

stare alla larga to keep away

lo striscione banner

la tifoseria (coll) group of supporters

il tifoso supporter

gli ultras organised groups of supporters who always follow their team

Ilaria, studentessa - Tifo Milan perlopiù alla televisione insieme agli amici. Se vado allo stadio sto alla larga dalle zone "calde". Fabio, studente - Sono un abbonato del Torino calcio. Mi entusiasma stare in curva, nelle zone centrali "calde" dove già andava mia madre da ragazza. Sto in mezzo agli ultras, ma non appartengo a nessun club. Come giudichi i recenti episodi di violenza e razzismo? Marco - Gli stadi riflettono la realtà sociale. Gli esagitati sono gli stessi che si scatenano a scuola, per strada o in birreria. Sono fortunatamente una minoranza. Purtroppo allo stadio, dove si è gomito a gomito possono contagiare gli altri. Ma il calcio non può essere screditato da questi episodi. Emanuel - I giornalisti spesso esagerano. Parlano delle cose negative e mai delle amicizie fra tifoserie, ad esempio. Non credo che gli sfottò verso alcuni giocatori siano razzismo. Ilaria - Odio vedere la guerriglia da stadio o leggere scritte razziste. Forse stiamo tutti diventando violenti e intolleranti. Basta assistere alle liti fra giornalisti sportivi in televisione! Fabio - Le tifoserie del Toro non sono razziste. Chi ci prova viene zittito. Io sono assolutamente contro la violenza, ma devo ammettere che allo stadio esiste. Molti tafferugli nascono dalla stupidità di un singolo che scatena la reazione di molti. Di chi pensi sia la responsabilità? Marco - Si può risalire a situazioni familiari o educative ma anche alla scarsa repressione. Gli scalmanati sono spesso gli stessi e non dovrebbero entrare negli stadi. A volte le società, per non scontrarsi con questi pseudo-tifosi, chiudono un occhio. Emanuel - Le responsabilità sono singole, ma anche del poco rispetto delle regole da parte di chi controlla. Fabio - Paradossalmente a volte la presenza dei cordoni di poliziotti accende gli animi invece di calmarli. Molti tifosi li considerano una provocazione più che una difesa. Ilaria - Le misure annunciate sono severe, ma forse serviranno. E spero che, se necessario, vengano adottate. È inutile limitarsi a fare la voce grossa! fields.headline: Afghanistan's cruel winter
fields.standfirst: Terrible drought, a particularly bitter winter and merciless UN sanctions have driven more than half a million Afghans to flee their homes this year, says Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Terrible drought, a particularly bitter winter and merciless UN sanctions have driven more than half a million Afghans to flee their homes this year, says Luke Harding.
fields.body:
At night in the Afghan city of Herat it is cold. Not just a little cold, but cruelly, mortally cold. On one night last month the temperature plunged to -25°C, climbing later to a mere -16°C.

By the time dawn broke over the six makeshift UN camps outside the city, the bitter snap had killed 500 refugees, most of them children. The camps are now home to 80,000 people, with three families sharing each flimsy tent.

At night glowing embers of charcoal provide the only source of heat. The refugees have trudged for days to the camps out of sheer desperation, victims of Afghanistan's worst drought in 30 years.

They have been forced to abandon their homes in remote rural provinces like Ghor and Badghis to the east because there is simply no water. In many places there has been no rain for three years. Animals have died, crops have perished and there is nothing left to eat.

The international community has so far chosen largely to ignore this enormous and growing humanitarian disaster, and is instead merely obsessed with trying to persuade the Taliban, Afghanistan's fundamentalist rulers, to give up the Saudi militant Osama bin Laden. Under US pressure, the UN has recently imposed a fresh round of sanctions on the Taliban. The movement's office in New York - its only window to the outside world - faces closure.

The sanctions have also stopped Afghanistan's airline Ariana, one of the few institutions to survive 21 years of war, from flying to Pakistan for crucial servicing.

Over the weekend, some western aid did reach the camps, where residents continue to shiver in what is proving to be an exceptionally cold winter, even by Afghan standards. On Saturday an American plane landed at Herat's airport on the outskirts of town carrying thousands of blankets, tents and water cans.

At the same time the first trucks of an 11-vehicle convoy arrived from the Afghan capital Kabul with 10,000 quilts purchased from another aid project that has been training women to earn a living.

But these small symbolic gestures will do little to help ordinary Afghans who have been impoverished by the long years of war and Soviet occupation - and now find themselves residents, thanks to western sanctions, of the world's last great pariah state.

Top-ranking UN officials recognise privately that the situation in Afghanistan has become so grave that sanctions are completely inappropriate. "I think they are a bad idea.

"They are a blunt instrument. But in the end the UN Security Council is the boss, and we don't query its judgement, even if it has a negative impact," one extremely senior UN executive told the Guardian last week.

Meanwhile, in Afghanistan, those who are in any position to leave the country are doing so. More than half a million Afghans have fled their homes this year - some internally but most to Pakistan - in one of the largest exoduses in South Asia's recent turbulent history.

Food supplies in Herat itself are likely to run out within a month. "The important thing is not exactly how many people died," Hans-Christian Poulsen, co-ordinator of the UN's humanitarian programme in the region said yesterday, over conflicting accounts of the death toll.

"The important thing is the conditions that 80,000 people are living under and that the number will be going past 100,000," he said. One man at Shadaie camp, which houses 20,000 people, yesterday explained how he had lost an infant son to the cold, one of eight people to die in the cluster of shelters in his section of the camp.

The refugee, Mazallah, shares his mud house with 12 other people. Until western policy-makers wake up to the awful human crisis in Afghanistan, Mazallah's tragedy will be followed by many others.

fields.headline: Marx lives
fields.standfirst: A year ago the libertarian magazine Living Marxism was bankrupted by a libel trial.   Now it is to be resurrected online. Mark Tran looks at its chances of survival
fields.trailText: A year ago the libertarian magazine Living Marxism was bankrupted by a libel trial. Now it is to be resurrected online. Mark Tran looks at its chances of survival
fields.body:
It hardly seems the best of times to start a news website when media behemoths such as News International and CNN are curtailing their internet operations. It seems positively foolhardy in the extreme when your last venture was bankrupted after a blazing libel trial. Last March, LM, the magazine formerly known as Living Marxism, closed after losing a libel action brought by ITN over an article in which the publication accused the broadcaster of misrepresenting one of the most harrowing images of the Bosnian war.

The photo, published in papers around the world, including the Guardian, showed an emaciated Muslim, Fikret Alic, enclosed behind barbed wire at the Trnopolje camp in northern Bosnia. In fact, the wire had surrounded the ITN crew. Nevertheless, the jury accepted that the camp was - contrary to what LM suggested - a prison, and therefore the ITN pictures had not distorted the truth. The jury awarded £375,000 in damages to ITN and reporters Penny Marshall and Ian Williams.

Mick Hume, LM editor, and Helene Guldberg, its publisher, were personally liable for the damages and the legal costs of £500,000. They have been living under the spectre of bankruptcy for the past three years. But some time this month - the date is deliberately vague - Hume and Guldberg are making a comeback online. Spiked-online.com will be LM and more.

Hume and Guldberg have seized on the demise of LM as an opportunity to recreate in cyberspace what was a libertarian voice in print. Guldberg says LM supporters urged her and Hume to try to find a way of carrying on somehow. At the time, when internet mania was at its height, going online must have seemed the obvious answer. Now things are bleak, but nevertheless, Spiked, based in the new media enclave of Farringdon Road, will be going online 'for those who want to see some change in the real world as well as the virtual one'.

Hume, 41, who is also a columnist for the Times, says the audience for Spiked will be the "intelligent, maverick type" and believes that there will be a market for the online magazine in Europe and the US. For Hume and his team of four journalists, Spiked will be a bigger and better LM, untrammelled by the distribution problems that can hamper a controversial magazine. Hume is particularly optimistic about winning eyeballs in the US, despite the online presence of established niche players such as Mother Jones, the Nation and Salon.

LM made a name for itself by offering views not normally associated with the left. It pushed the line that society is too squeamish about scientific research and that concern over GM foods and biotechnology, for example, bordered on hysteria. LM also pooh-poohed the political preoccupation with child-rearing, crime and health.

A piece on child safety by Guldberg, Spiked's managing editor, typifies the site's contrarian-libertarian take on the world. She rubbishes the obsession with child safety. Despite a Guardian/ICM poll released last August showing that 79% of parents believe the world is more dangerous for children, she argues that children in fact are healthier, wealthier, safer and better educated than ever. In obsessing about the need to keep children safe, 'we risk denying them the freedom they need to develop, to grow up. And this has its own, very real dangers', she writes.

LM sank because it pushed the boat out too far on the Bosnian war, so will Spiked be more cautious? Hume says he always hesitates before running really contentious stuff anywhere and after three years with the LM case has "no wish to waste another moment of my life with libel lawyers. But I hope that, if we believe that something is true and important, we will still publish it."

Interestingly, Hume says the problem with the article about the Bosnian war photo was not that it was wrong per se, but in how it was presented: "I am sure I could edit that same article today in such a way that even Mr Justice Morland could not object to it."

For Hume and Goldberg, Spiked took their minds off the threat of bankruptcy that has dogged them ever since the start of the ITN libel case almost four years ago. They started to put it together at the beginning of last year, relying on the network that sustained LM. It took the relatively small amount of £100,000 to cobble together the venture, thanks to the brains and sweat of volunteers. Hume is cagey about the identity of investors, saying only that it came from people who made money early on in the internet boom.

In the long term, Spiked will count on advertising, but also on sponsorship for seminars and conferences that also ran alongside LM. They will need a fair amount of money as they plan audio and video streaming for the site, functions that will not come cheap. But then LM's survival always seemed puzzling from a financial point of view, so Hume and Guldberg may be able to pull off the same trick online. None of their assets is in Spiked so the venture is out of reach of any bankruptcy proceedings. Now all they have to do is stay out of the libel courts. Although LM lost the ITN case, Hume clearly believes he and his colleagues were the moral victors.

"The case taught me that if you are prepared to take a stand for the principle of free speech," he says, "you can win a lot of support. That is the only reason why Spiked has been able to rise from the ashes."

www.spiked-online.com

fields.headline: London mayor seeks marketing supremo
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Ken Livingstone's GLA is on the hunt for a marketing chief to help roll out a new 'brand' for London, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's Greater London Authority is on the hunt for a marketing chief to help roll out a new "brand" for London.

The newly created position of head of marketing has been created to control all aspects of the GLA's marketing, advertising and paid publicity.

This will include publications, exhibitions and direct mail campaigns.

The marketing chief will plan and implement marketing and events strategies for the GLA.

He or she will explore new media initiatives such as using the GLA website for consultation and marketing.

One of the key tasks facing the new recruit will be helping the communications team roll out a "brand" for London.

Mr Livingstone wants London to have a catchy slogan to rival the Big Apple's "I love New York".

Ad agency Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper won the GLA's £10m advertising account last year.

Identity specialist Appetite has developed a corporate identity for the GLA.

The new brand will first be used by bodies such as Transport for London and the Metropolitan Police.

It will gradually extend across all London's services.

The head of marketing will report to GLA executive communications director Charlotte Rowe, who joined from the London Tourist Board in December.

Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper's first poster and radio campaign for the GLA will ask Londoners to submit their views on the mayor's plans for the capital's transport system.
