webTitle: Private lives pulped as PCC earns praise

fields.headline: Private lives pulped as PCC earns praise
fields.trailText: Private lives pulped as PCC earns praise, writes Hugh Stephenson.
fields.body:
There was a triumphalist tone to the trumpet Lord Wakeham was blowing this week as chairman of the Press Complaints Commission. His smart bash at Somerset House to celebrate the PCC's tenth birthday was a huge public relations success.

Even though the coverage of the event was less about the PCC and press self-regulation and more about the soap opera involving Prince Charles, Prince William and Camilla Parker Bowles, that one glamourous event must have done more to raise public awareness of the PCC than its entire promotion budget for the past decade.

Wakeham, it has to be said, has a lot to be triumphant about. The old Press Council, from which the PCC sprang in 1991, had lost all credibility with politicians and the public. It had been destroyed by the press itself. When the old Press Council reprimanded John Junor, then editor of the Sunday Express, for a racial slur in his personal column, he repeated the offending words in print and called the Council 'po-faced, pompous, humourless twits'. Margaret Thatcher knighted him two years later for his services to journalism.

When the old Press Council investigated the orgy of chequebook journalism that built up around Sonia Sutcliffe, wife of the Yorkshire Ripper, it found that David English, then editor of the Daily Mail, and others of Fleet Street's finest evaded, lied and failed to cooperate. English refused to attend an oral hearing. When he and his paper were found guilty of gross misconduct, Sir David (for he had been knighted by Thatcher while the inquiry was in progress) wrote an article in which he described the findings as 'short-term, short-sighted and smug', proving 'yet again that the Press Council still does not understand the concept of a free press'.

Looking back over the PCC's first decade, Wakeham deserves congratulation for rescuing it from a shaky start. Sir David Calcutt's 1993 review of its first two years concluded that it had failed and should be replaced by a statutory body. Also that year, a Commons Select Committee came out in favour of privacy legislation, and the erratic behaviour of its first chairman, Lord McGregor, over a case involving clandestine photographs of Princess Diana in a leotard, caused the Mirror Group to pull out of the PCC for several days.

So to arrive at glittering Somerset House from the dark days of 1993 has been a real achievement. With the Prime Minister, Culture Secretary Chris Smith and Tory leader William Hague all declaring that freedom of the press is central to democracy and the PCC its handmaiden, Wakeham can say: 'There are no serious commentators now who believe that statutory controls are either desirable or practical.' Indeed, compared with the self-regulated complaints machinery operated by lawyers or doctors or bankers, the PCC is now pretty good.

Wakeham's next claim, though, goes too far. He asserts: 'The PCC - with the absolute commitment of editors themselves and their publishers - has changed the entire culture of British newspapers.'

The wily old ex-chief whip has successfully fixed the politics of self-regulation for the time being. The close personal relationship between the PCC's director, Guy Black, and his predecessor, Mark Bolland, who is now private secretary to Prince Charles, effectively covers the exposed royal family flank.

But he deludes himself if he thinks he has led a cultural revolution. For the PCC is in the business of broking between individuals with a complaint and the publications that ran their stories.

It is not in the business of ethics. Unlike its counterpart, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, it does not research public attitudes to media issues, and it declines to take complaints from 'third parties'.

So, if a person who feels abused by the press does not personally complain, the PCC system remains silent.

If you put all this together with falling newspaper circulations and today's much greater media focus on personalities and private lives, my guess is that there is more invasion of privacy by the press than there was 10 years ago.

What is more, broadsheet editors have realised that their readers are every bit as interested as tabloid readers are in the private lives of the well-known.

A reporter from a broadsheet, not a tabloid, was clearly mystified a month ago when I said that I would not confirm gossip about someone I know on the grounds that it was an entirely private matter.

Of course, the PCC's code has a 'public interest' clause. It is the duty of the press to expose crime, malpractice and hypocrisy in high places. But, as evidence that there has been no change in the past decade in the culture of British newspapers over the right of the individual to be let alone, I offer at random the following (half from broadsheets, half from tabloids):

« Details of the private life of banker Amschel Rothschild, who committed suicide in Paris in 1996.
« The revelation the same year that Joan Bakewell and Harold Pinter had been lovers.
Details of Glenn Hoddle's marriage breakdown in 1997.
Disclosures about the sex life of Anthea Turner in 1998.
The revelation the same year that Des Lynam had an affair while covering the World Cup.
The disclosure, also in 1998, that the retired and widowed Admiral Sir James Eberle had had a relationship with a prostitute.

All of these stories will have interested the public, but which of them actually involved 'the public interest'? Answers on a postcard to the PCC, please.
Hugh Stephenson is Professor of Journalism at City University, London.

So to arrive at glittering Somerset House from the dark days of 1993 has been a real achievement. With the Prime Minister, Culture Secretary Chris Smith and Tory leader William Hague all declaring that freedom of the press is central to democracy and the PCC its handmaiden, Wakeham can say: 'There are no serious commentators now who believe that statutory controls are either desirable or practical.' Indeed, compared with the self-regulated complaints machinery operated by lawyers or doctors or bankers, the PCC is now pretty good. Wakeham's next claim, though, goes too far. He asserts: 'The PCC - with the absolute commitment of editors themselves and their publishers - has changed the entire culture of British newspapers.' The wily old ex-chief whip has successfully fixed the politics of self-regulation for the time being. The close personal relationship between the PCC's director, Guy Black, and his predecessor, Mark Bolland, who is now private secretary to Prince Charles, effectively covers the exposed royal family flank. But he deludes himself if he thinks he has led a cultural revolution. For the PCC is in the business of broking between individuals with a complaint and the publications that ran their stories. It is not in the business of ethics. Unlike its counterpart, the Broadcasting Standards Commission, it does not research public attitudes to media issues, and it declines to take complaints from 'third parties'. So, if a person who feels abused by the press does not personally complain, the PCC system remains silent. If you put all this together with falling newspaper circulations and today's much greater media focus on personalities and private lives, my guess is that there is more invasion of privacy by the press than there was 10 years ago. What is more, broadsheet editors have realised that their readers are every bit as interested as tabloid readers are in the private lives of the well-known. A reporter from a broadsheet, not a tabloid, was clearly mystified a month ago when I said that I would not confirm gossip about someone I know on the grounds that it was an entirely private matter. Of course, the PCC's code has a 'public interest' clause. It is the duty of the press to expose crime, malpractice and hypocrisy in high places. But, as evidence that there has been no change in the past decade in the culture of British newspapers over the right of the individual to be let alone, I offer at random the following (half from broadsheets, half from tabloids): « Details of the private life of banker Amschel Rothschild, who committed suicide in Paris in 1996. « The revelation the same year that Joan Bakewell and Harold Pinter had been lovers. Details of Glenn Hoddle's marriage breakdown in 1997. Disclosures about the sex life of Anthea Turner in 1998. The revelation the same year that Des Lynam had an affair while covering the World Cup. The disclosure, also in 1998, that the retired and widowed Admiral Sir James Eberle had had a relationship with a prostitute. All of these stories will have interested the public, but which of them actually involved 'the public interest'? Answers on a postcard to the PCC, please. Hugh Stephenson is Professor of Journalism at City University, London.

webTitle: Puffy courts excess with hip hop glitz

fields.headline: Puffy courts excess with hip hop glitz
fields.trailText: Sean "Puffy" Combs is surely a man with a lot on his mind. He is at the centre of the most talked about trial of the moment, facing charges of possessing a gun and bribing his chauffeur to take the blame. If convicted he faces up to 15 years in jail.
fields.body:
Sean "Puffy" Combs is surely a man with a lot on his mind. He is at the centre of the most talked about trial of the moment, facing charges of possessing a gun and bribing his chauffeur to take the blame. If convicted he faces up to 15 years in jail.

So one might have expected the catwalk show for his latest collection of Sean John menswear to be a downbeat affair. But Puff Daddy is not the type to keep a low profile, and Saturday night's hottest ticket was a showbiz extravaganza, a defiantly glitzy and upbeat display of confidence.

This was no ordinary New York Fashion Week show. The cashmere clad Park Avenue princesses - New York's equivalent to London's so-called 'it girls' - were nowhere to be seen. The unofficial front row dress code was white fur and diamonds, and that was just for the men. Hip hop and rap stars Busta Rhymes, Faith Evans, Destiny's Child and Bobby Brown sat alongside Tommy Hilfiger, Combs' lawyer Johnnie Cochran, Anna Wintour, editor of American Vogue, and Jamie Oliver, Britain's "Naked Chef", currently the chic guest on the New York scene. Heavily armed police looked after the crowds outside desperate to gain admission despite the show being screened live. Clearly this millionaire rap mogul's popularity has not evaporated.

The show opened with some words from the designer. "People always ask me why I started designing clothes. I like looking in the mirror, I want my pants to drape perfectly over my combat boots," Combs explained to whoops from the crowd. This is a man who understands that fashion shows are about more than tailoring skills; to a cinema screen backdrop of civil rights footage, a white model emerged wearing just a pair of shearling trousers, with the words Black Power written across his chest.

Combs later explained that his multi-racial models reflected "an integrated cast - black, beautiful, strong men, Latinos". At the show's end the rap soundtrack was swapped for the song I'm Still Standing.

The clothes themselves were staggering. This is an aesthetic of conspicuous consumption marrying excess with street style: there were bleached denim jackets trimmed with fox fur, parka jackets with hoods lined with Persian lamb, crocodile skin suits and a black fur coat with a full-length train. There were also sharply tailored suits with French cuffed shirts and pocket 'kerchiefs - perfect for making a good impression in the courtroom.

When Combs took a standing ovation on the catwalk, it was his mother and two young sons he embraced. Jennifer Lopez, his erstwhile girlfriend, was busy presenting Saturday Night Live. But Combs seemed keen to quash rumours of a split, screening footage from her latest video at the show, and dedicating the collection jointly to Lopez and to the late Gianni Versace.

After the show Combs told reporters: "What I'm going through is nothing compared to what Malcolm X went through, or Mohammed Ali."

fields.headline: View from the pack
fields.trailText: The big names in TV and publishing give their thoughts on how the upcoming general election will be covered.
fields.body:
Jon Snow, Channel 4

Once the campaign kicks off, it becomes a different way of life: getting up earlier, travelling miles across the country. At election time everyone makes an effort to get out from under the metropolitan cloud. The problem will be trying to stoke viewer and voter enthusiasm. If it becomes boring, Channel 4 will find something else to fill the bulletins. We're not in the business of making elections interesting - that's the politicians' job.

Adam Boulton, Sky News

We've done two elections as the only 24-hour news network, but now BBC News 24 and the ITN News Channel are there and it could get competitive. We are committing over 50% of our UK news-gathering capacity to the election. The big change is the technology. Press conferences are routinely televised, and digital viewers should be able to choose which ones they watch.

John Sergeant, ITV

The last general election campaign was described as the longest in history, but this one could be even longer. As each year passes, the public's bullshit threshold decreases: people accept less of the windy rhetoric that politicians used to spout and look for an attractive individual. The big targets for party leaders have become less political: shows such as Woman's Hour and GMTV, which could make the Leo factor very important.

Elinor Goodman, Channel 4

It's hard to get excited when one party is so far ahead. The temptation for journalists is to seize one rogue poll and declare an open race, but it would be dishonest to say this is going to be close without strong evidence. Getting politicians off their soundbites is harder at election time. I suppose TV has contributed to this problem: we're always chasing short, lucid clips and politicians are giving us what we want.

Piers Morgan, the Mirror

Since Thatcher, middle England has voted with whichever front bench holds the greatest personal appeal. Policies come into play only when they're attached to a story. At the last election the Sun stole the agenda by coming down for Labour. This time they will probably flirt with the Tories before going for Blair again, but it won't have the same impact. People know the Mirror as the natural paper of Labour and I've told Blair we're behind his party. Short of them being busted in a cocaine ring, that's how it will stay.

Jackie Ashley, the New Statesman

The New Statesman comes from a different angle from most papers or broadcasters - I don't need a big story to hang my coverage on. I did the last election for ITN, and it was a bit of a nightmare: parties would call morning press conferences, realise newsdesks weren't interested in what they'd concentrated on, and call a rebuttal conference. The Tories have hinted that they'll do away with daily conferences. For journalists, that's no bad thing.

George Jones, the Daily Telegraph

One complete waste of time is the tradition of travelling around in leaders' buses. It costs about £8,000 and generates little in the way of hard news. I think stories could instead start coming from party websites and we will keep a close eye on them throughout. When I started, the trend was for constituency profiles. Now there's more emphasis on getting a newspaper's big names - sketchwriters or whatever - out and about to provide the colour.

Patrick Wintour, the Guardian

This election will be much more diffuse. The increasing number of outlets is making it harder for politicians to set the agenda. Papers also want to set their own distinct agenda to influence the election. At by-elections, hacks used to get a conference with candidates each morning and turn them to mincemeat. Parties have learnt that regular scrutiny does them no good and stopped daily conferences. The same could happen at a national level.

Andrew Marr, BBC

The 1997 election saw an awesome Labour machine that swept all before it. This time it is far less awe-inspiring and there is a huge unknown about voter turnout. Hague is a good cam paigner, with two or three big issues that will resonate, so it could be close. That's exciting. The 10pm slot will also see a battle between us and ITN. That's good for both channels, although the success or failure of our coverage will end at my door, so I'd like to think that we will beat them journalistically.

Martha Kearney, Newsnight

We plan to spend as much time away from London as possible and will almost certainly do a big outside broadcast from a Salford estate. We'll also get some big US correspondents to file reports: last time Gore Vidal did one. It injects variety into the coverage.

webTitle: In brief: Kidman in shock after Cruise's divorce decision

fields.headline: Kidman in shock after Cruise's divorce decision
fields.standfirst: Plus: American Pie sequel starts shooting on Valentine's Day; Premiere magazine defends article which fingers Arnie
fields.trailText: Plus: American Pie sequel starts shooting on Valentine's Day; Premiere magazine defends article which fingers Arnie
fields.body:
 The mystery surrounding the Cruise-Kidman break-up took another twist yesterday with the news that Nicole was as much in the dark as the rest of us right up until the moment the axe came down. "The divorce was not her decision, "Kidman's representatives said in a statement. "Tom made the move. Nicole is in a state of shock." Meanwhile the Mail on Sunday yesterday quoted a friend of the actress as claiming that: "Nicole was totally flabbergasted. She has spent the last few days crying. She knew there were problems, but she didn't realise he was about to call it quits."

 Lusty teens across the globe will have the chance of a fresh piece of pie when the sequel to 1999's cherry-popping comedy American Pie finally begins filming - fittingly enough - on Valentine's Day. Having opted out of the sequel, original director Paul Weitz has been replaced by the virginal JB Rogers, who will make his directing debut after serving as first assistant director on the 1999 movie. Hollywood.com reports, however, that the original cast will all return to the fold: Jason Biggs, Mena Suvari, Chris Klein and Shannon Elizabeth. "Everyone's back, as far as I know," said Biggs.

 Arnold Schwarzenegger could be contacting his lawyers over an article in March's edition of Premiere magazine written by journalist John Connolly (see earlier story). Entitled Arnold the Barbarian and set to hit newsstands on February 14, the piece investigates persistent rumours about both Arnie's private life and health and supposedly reveals the truth behind: "An incident of an intimate nature". Defending the story, a spokesman for the film publication claimed that: "Connolly's story was well researched and well vetted by not only our researchers but our legal department as well."

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours have gone out and bought their own yacht
fields.trailText: Chelsea have found an ideal replacement for Dennis Wise, according to the Daily Star, and he's Spanish. The paper reports that the Blues have already contacted Espanyol about their 24-year-old midfielder Sergio Gonzalez, who is expected to gain his first international cap against England this month.
fields.body:
Chelsea have found an ideal replacement for Dennis Wise, according to the Daily Star, and he's Spanish. The paper reports that the Blues have already contacted Espanyol about their 24-year-old midfielder Sergio Gonzalez, who is expected to gain his first international cap against England this month.

Chelsea have taken 19-year-old Argentine midfielder Elias Bazzi on trial for two weeks.

Planetfootball suggest that Arsenal are also looking towards Catalonia to expand their squad. The website claims the Gunners, who have already scouted Espanyol's Romanian midfielder Constantin Galca, are now looking at his team-mate Roger. The former Barcelona player could be available for less than £4m, but Roma are also interested.

Peter Taylor wants to spend again, according to the Sun, this time on Leeds defender Danny Mills. The 23-year-old is still on the fringes of the first team at Elland Road and may take the opportunity to join Taylor's Leicester. Leeds, who don't want to sell the former England under-21 player, will however accept a bid of £4m.

Both Manchester United and Liverpool are interested in AEK Athens midfielder Akis Zikos. According to reports in the Greek press, both clubs will send representatives to watch the player in Athens' Uefa Cup tie with Barcelona on Thursday.

fields.headline: Dirty tricks belittle online rival
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Dirty tricks campaigns seem to be disappointingly commonplace. They range from the relatively innocuous dismissing of a competitor in a sales meeting to more conspicuous displays of public battles, such as that which occurred between Sir Richard Branson's Virgin and Lord King's British Airways.
fields.body:
Dirty tricks campaigns seem to be disappointingly commonplace. They range from the relatively innocuous dismissing of a competitor in a sales meeting to more conspicuous displays of public battles, such as that which occurred between Sir Richard Branson's Virgin and Lord King's British Airways.

Rools seems the subject of a dirty tricks campaign at the moment. We think another company is waging a campaign to undermine our business. It emerged when one of our partner retailers called up saying that a sales representative from a competitor's business had, in a recent sales call, mentioned that we had gone out of business.

This competitor was only too happy to sign our retail partner up to their own payment network. Our friendly retailer was not taken in. In fact he actually thought it was a pretty pathetic and shabby way to try to attract business.

Later, we were interviewed by a new financial services publication. The journalist let on that a manager from the same competing company had also told him we had gone out of business - a fact he could see to be untrue.

This time we were more surprised: although both situations are unacceptable, it is one thing for junior sales staff to say almost anything to close a deal with a retailer in the heat of the moment, but we were gobsmacked to learn that a senior manager might rubbish us.

It leaves a nasty taste when you find out that people are bad-mouthing what you have worked hard to create. We can't stop them - but it seems their efforts have hurt their business more than ours. Apparently this competitor has turned at least one retailer and one member of the press off their business.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of rools.com, a system that enables teenagers to shop online

webTitle: Napster awaits ruling on internet downloads

fields.headline: Napster awaits ruling on internet downloads
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Thousands of fans of the music-sharing service, Napster, were logging on over the week-end in anticipation of a judgment which could go against the firm in court this morning. A ruling in the appeal court in San Francisco today could effectively close down the service - although Napster said last night that they were optimistic of success.
fields.body:
Thousands of fans of the music-sharing service, Napster, were logging on over the week-end in anticipation of a judgment which could go against the firm in court this morning. A ruling in the appeal court in San Francisco today could effectively close down the service - although Napster said last night that they were optimistic of success.

According to the web site, 10,000 users logged on to just one of Napster's more than 100 computer servers sharing nearly 2m free song files. Last July saw 7,300 users sharing 800,000 files.

In San Francisco today, the court is due to deliver its ruling on a lower court's injunction against the Redwood City-based company.

The case arises out of the decision by the recording industry to sue Napster for breach of copyright. The music industry argued that artists were being deprived of revenue by Napster because people are able to download the music without paying any royalties.

In a packed court hearing last July, attended by many Napster fans, it was decided that Napster had infringed copyright regulations but the appeal court stayed the injunction which could have closed the service. Napster - started by teenage programmer Shawn Fanning - was allowed to remain online and fans celebrated by logging on in record numbers.

Napster, which has made much of its youthful image and has presented itself as an online David against a music industry Goliath, remains bullish that they can win the latest legal round. "We have confidence in our legal position," said a statement on their web site.

Despite its image, Napster looks set to join the music industry. Last year media group Bertlesmann took a stake, saying it would start charging for downloads.

fields.headline: My new media
fields.trailText: Gareth Hunt, director of www.e-media-c.net
fields.body:
Favourite websites? I'd say amazon.com. I'm not a great techno person, but I saw that the internet could make the entertainment industry more accessible. It's like a supermarket and that's what fascinates me about it. It saves a lot of time, answers a lot of questions and gives people a wider scope to find actors and locations.

Last online purchase? A Dell computer for my son. I did though discover the downside of buying on the net when trying to buy half a salmon from Scotland. The alarm bells went off in the search area when I typed in my credit card details. Someone had obtained my card number and was using it in Spain.

Most recent technological faux pas?

I was putting together a search idea for finding models, photographers, locations, actors and anything that relates to the industry as a whole. Worked all day on it, pressed two buttons, and it all disappeared. Eventually we got it back, but I was laughed at in the office because I just look at a computer, and it all goes wrong. I'm really more of an ideas man.

Main news source on the web?

BBC online - it's easy and looks good.

Most persistent spam emailer?

I would say www.info.day.com.

Time spent on the web?

I'm mostly on about four hours a day.

Next boo.com? Well somebody in the office said fashionfile.com. would be the next one to go. The problem is it takes a lot longer to build up something than people think. I use Microsoft's fish in the office and have my son's name Jason on the screen at home.

fields.headline: Working with dinosaurs
fields.standfirst: As the BBC's first director of new media, Ashley Highfield must marry broadcasting and the internet. If successful, his post will be a thing of the past, he tells David Teather
fields.trailText: The BBC's first director of new media must marry broadcasting and the internet, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Ashley Highfield shakes his head in despair that the BBC was beaten to Big Brother. The landmark marriage of broadcasting and the internet, he says, was exactly the kind of thing on which the corporation should have led the way.

As the BBC's first director of new media, it is Highfield's job to make sure the corporation doesn't get caught out again. One of director- general Greg Dyke's key appointments, he has been brought in to deliver a wake-up call. And it is clear that in the four months since taking the job, he has not been idle.

Within half an hour of our meeting, he has detailed a long list of changes - many of which will raise the hackles of the commercial sector and BBC critics. BBC Online is to be rebranded, a licence fee-funded mobile phone service is to be launched, its interactive service will be available on Sky Digital for the first time, and a number of existing services face the axe. The list goes on.

Highfield is also at the sharp end of the debate on the creeping commercialisation at the BBC. He is the person who will oversee the launch of BBC.com, the international version of the corporation's online news service, which will, controversially, accept advertising. He is also exploring ways of adding commercial elements to some existing websites.

Highfield is one of Dyke's growing band of appointments from outside the corridors of the BBC. He joined the corporation from cable company Telewest and, as the Guardian photographer sets up, Highfield hurriedly switches off Sky News on one of the bank of TV sets behind him, before confessing to being an avid viewer.

His appointment means that, for the first time, new media is represented at the main, 18-strong board level. His remit brings together existing online licence fee-funded news and sport services, interactive services across all the digital platforms, including satellite, cable and mobile, and what he describes as "imagineering" - fresh ways of merging new and old media in projects like Big Brother.

The overarching strategy is to change the mindset of the BBC. One of his first jobs has been to appoint a dozen heads of new media attached to all the main BBC departments, with the aim of their being there at the outset of programme commissioning. Better access, will, Highfield hopes, avoid the Walking with Dinosaurs scenario, which he holds up as an example of how not to run a new media strategy. "Getting near the end of a four-year production and then, two months before finishing, asking the new media people to do a website is not how you do it," he says.

This time around, the wire frames used in the production were passed straight to the new media creatives so that they could build 3D images that would allow website users to travel under the legs of the tyrannosaurus, or fly the pterodactyl, with the same realism shown on the broadcast. "That is staggering. People can take those tools and create their own episode," says Highfield.

He is passionate that new media is a vital tool for bringing people back to the BBC. He found it bizarre, he says, that the corporation's interactive text service was absent from Sky Digital. "The marketing line will be to create the UK's number one digital destination and that implies we have to be ubiquitous - we have to be everywhere. I want consumers to know that they can switch on a TV, mobile phone or PC and know they are going to get a comprehensive range of quality-trusted BBC content."

With hindsight, he says, the existing commercial-only deals to supply content over wireless internet may have been a mistake. "I don't think you can look at mobile and say that it is somehow a uniquely different platform from narrowband internet or digital television.

"We've got to get out there into the platforms like satellite, like Sega Dreamcast consoles, like mobile phones, where people are light BBC consumers, to reach people for whom the BBC means less and less. That means having quite imaginative relationships with the evil empires of this world, like Sky. It also means doing a whole load of distribution deals on the net."

This year's Wimbledon tennis on Sky Digital will have an interactive service, including the choice of six different courts plus news, match reports and results. Similar services will also be offered for the Open golf, and the text service on Sky Digital will be up later this year.

The wider spread of services has also highlighted the "mess" of brands used by the corporation in new media - which Highfield plans to change by rebranding BBC Online, BBC Text and the cable services under a single, as yet undecided, name.

"Online is too parochial to the internet and it doesn't work on TV or on mobile, and the word 'text' is rather, well . . . Actually I don't like the name 'new media' as a division. It's pejorative. It implies there is old media. One of the things we'll be doing is creating a really simple, single brand for all our services."

Funding of the growing number of services, though, is clearly an issue. Dyke's cuts in croissants and taxis, as well as back office job losses, are on the way to producing the kind of savings promised when the BBC won its licence fee increase, but the demands on cash, particularly with the launch of new digital TV channels, are only increasing.

Highfield's budget last year was £70m. An increase has been agreed for this year, but he declines to say how much. There are about 1,000 staff working for the division, representing about 5% of the BBC workforce.

Many of the costs of new media leverage existing resources - the cameras are already at the courtside at Wimbledon, for example - but still the issue of generating commercial revenues, particularly online, refuses to go away.

Highfield says the internal argument for an international online service carrying advertising has already been won. "The government is quite clearly telling us we have to find ways of making money from our international traffic on the co.uk service. We are currently providing a service to people who don't pay the licence fee and therefore we have to explore ways of doing that."

He is adamant, however, that the licence fee-funded news and sport services are sacred cows. "We have no plans to accept advertising on public services. Apart from anything else, I would not want to jeopardise the sum we get from the licence fee. It would be mad. The budget we get from the licence fee would dwarf any commercial revenues we could hope to gain."

The mobile phone service, he adds, falls into the broader debate in the BBC about the boundaries between publicly funded and commercial services. "We haven't got any further than saying that we have to revisit the current status quo. But for the Radio 1 site, for instance, not to be able to send text messages - when that's almost exclusively how teens communicate with each other - is a major gap in our communications portfolio. We know we have to offer short message services as well as Wap."

Existing websites are one area where he does see potential for adding commercial elements. The site for the Proms, for example, doesn't even sell tickets at the moment. "The rules are probably too prescriptive, but I think it's also the case that no one has really looked at them in too much detail. We don't have the answers yet."

He is also keen to develop further transparent links to commercial services from BBC-branded sites. Other sites may be under threat. If a website is not number one or two in its market, or if it doesn't serve the interests of a market ignored by the commercial sector, then it will be closed as part of a root-and-branch review of the services on offer.

His plans for the online news and sports services include an overhaul of the sites' architecture to make them more easily relevant to individual users, and ramping up the interactive content. "I want to introduce large amounts of chat, discussion rooms, forums, alerts, voting - you can take it so far forward. BBC Online has been brilliant at 'broadcasting at', but actually quite poor at 'engaging with' users."

As for the next Big Brother, Highfield suggests there is some programming on the way that will make up for lost ground - although he is reluctant to be specific. He will know he has done his job when there is no longer the need for a director of new media. "We will have been successful when new media is so a part of everyday life around the BBC that no one would dream of commissisoning A History of Britain, say, without an interactive element not just stuck on afterwards but integrated right up front when it was commissioned."

fields.headline: Napster copyright ruling imminent
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Today may be the last day to download music for free from embattled song-swap service Napster, as a US court prepares to rule on whether the site has violated copyright law by allowing users to download music without providing payment to artists and record companies.
fields.body:
Today may be the last day to download music for free from embattled song-swap service Napster, as a US court prepares to rule on whether the site has violated copyright law by allowing users to download music without providing payment to artists and record companies.

This weekend tens of thousands of Napster's 50m users flooded the company's servers for last minute downloads in advance of the ruling, expected at 6pm GMT today.

The five largest record labels - Sony, Warner, BMG, EMI and Universal - sued as soon as Redwood City-based Napster took off, saying it could rob them of billions of dollars in profits.

The issue before the US 9th Circuit court of appeals today is whether to uphold a US District court judge's injunction ordering Napster to shut down pending a trial on the music industry lawsuit. The injunction was put on hold pending the 9th Circuit review.

But the three-judge panel also could rule more broadly, describing how copyright law should apply to emerging technologies that make it ever more difficult to control and profit from the distribution of music, software, books, movies and other creative content.

In May 1999, Napster founder Shawn Fanning released software that made it easy for personal computer users to locate and trade songs they had stored as computer files in the MP3 format, which crunches digital recordings down to manageable lengths without sacrificing quality.

The concept of "peer-to-peer", song trading quickly proved too popular to contain. As Napster users grew by the millions, other file-sharing programs also popped up, such as Gnutella and Freenet. Record labels themselves are looking to use the same technology, only with paying subscribers and secure digital formats that prevent copying.

Major record labels hope today's ruling will force millions of computer users to pay for music the online music swapping service has allowed them to get for free.

If Napster wins however, the ruling could give new life to other business ventures that have been waiting for guidance on whether a "personal use" exception to copyright law allows or prohibits trading copyrighted material over the Internet.

Since the appeal court judges began deliberating in October, Napster has made agreements with former business foes like Bertelsmann AG, the parent company of the BMG music unit. The German media giant has promised much-needed capital if Napster switches to a subscription-based service that pays artists' royalties. The other four major labels are holding out for Napster's demise.

fields.headline: Branson's principle
fields.standfirst: The lottery loser is threatening charities
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson is in danger of giving business an even blacker name than it has already in the charity world. As the annual conference of voluntary organisations heard last week, only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income comes from the business sector.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is in danger of giving business an even blacker name than it has already in the charity world. As the annual conference of voluntary organisations heard last week, only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income comes from the business sector. Worse still, just 400 companies account for 97% of this modest contribution - the remainder of the 3.7m businesses in the country donating a mere £10m to charity between them. American companies are five times as generous. Now Sir Richard, who launched his People's Lottery on the prospectus that all profits would go to good causes, will be lodging a compensation claim this week over its unsuccessful bid for the national lottery.

Sir Richard is believed to have spent £30m on his bid - including £8m since August last year, when rival Camelot was initially excluded by the lottery commission from the bidding process, only to be restored by the high court. He feels he was misled by the commission and unfairly denied the contract. The commission says that if any compensation is paid, it would reduce the amount for good causes. Sir Richard has good grounds for feeling aggrieved by the five-member commission, which, having signalled its intent to award the contract to the People's Lottery, swung back to Camelot following a change of chairman. But he has no grounds for compensation. The bidding process was clear from the start: winner takes all, losers pay their own costs. It is absurd for Sir Richard to suggest compensation could come out of taxes raised by the lottery - wrongly implying there was a state responsibility for the bidding process, while ignoring the harm a reduction in taxes would inflict on good causes. Sir Richard is a billionaire. His consortium includes Bill Gates, the richest man in the world, plus major international computer and consultancy firms. The bidding costs to them are peanuts - but if awarded would be a major loss to charities.

webTitle: Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed'

fields.headline: Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed'
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson was at the centre of fresh controversy yesterday when it emerged he was demanding compensation for his failed bid to run the national lottery.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson was at the centre of fresh controversy yesterday when it emerged he was demanding compensation for his failed bid to run the national lottery.

But the lottery commission said it was unlikely that Sir Richard's consortium, the People's Lottery, would receive compensation - and if it did, the money would have to come from funds for good causes.

Sir Richard's consortium believes it should be recompensed for its expenditure on the bid since last August, at least, when the commission initially indicated that the consortium's bid was the one it wanted to see developed. Camelot went on to clinch a new seven-year franchise.

The People's Lottery confirmed it would be lodging a request with the commission this week but dismissed as speculation reports that it was seeking an £8m payoff and that a deal had already been done behind closed doors.

In a statement, Sir Richard said: "We will be lodging a claim. However, we would not expect any funds to be paid to come out of the good causes fund." He said the money ought to come from payment which the government will take from Camelot in tax.

A commission spokesman said that it would examine any representations lodged by the People's Lottery, but added that he doubted whether the consortium had a strong case.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said it would be "outrageous" if money which should have gone to good causes was paid to the consortium. "The public would not forgive them for such a shameful abuse of lottery money."

fields.headline: Never say Tina again
fields.standfirst: Commentary: Hilary Wainwright
fields.trailText: The ghost of Tina - There Is No Alternative - still haunts our cobweb-infested political mansion. The government we chose hoping for alternative policies is instead acquiescing to worldwide agreements which deregulate and privatise on an international scale, ruling out new economic directions for all of us.
fields.body:
The ghost of Tina - There Is No Alternative - still haunts our cobweb-infested political mansion. The government we chose hoping for alternative policies is instead acquiescing to worldwide agreements which deregulate and privatise on an international scale, ruling out new economic directions for all of us.

It is appropriate that an antidote to Tina should come from international sources. While the elite of the deregulated economy met in Davos last month for the World Economic Forum, in southern Brazil social movements and municipalities gathered in the city of Porto Alegre for the World Social Forum. As the title implies, the purpose was to develop alternatives that make economics the servant of social objectives.

The 10,000-strong World Social Forum marked a new phase in a movement that has already had a global impact. "Seattle was not enough; we need to show the world our alternatives," was the recurring explanation delegates gave for their trip to Brazil.

They had come to a city which enabled them immediately to point to an alternative that works. For the last 12 years the radical Brazilian Workers' Party has governed Porto Alegre, an industrial city with a population of 1m, on the basis of principles that run consciously counter to neo-liberal orthodoxy. Each time the party goes to the electorate it wins a greater popular mandate - it has several times won the UN Habitat prize for good governerment. Porto Alegre has provided a model of public administration now followed or aspired to by several states and many city governments across Brazil.

The crucial achievement of Porto Alegre is that it has relegitimised the state as an institution to be trusted to meet the needs of the majority of people. It has won trust because people are able not only to call the city government to account through the normal electoral process, but they have control over the budget - or that part of it not laid down by federal law - through a transparent process of direct popular participation.

The "participatory budget" (PB) as it is known, is an annual cycle of neighbourhood meetings where people identify their priority needs for new investment - whether pavements, schools, health provision, drainage, cooperative industries - and then elect delegates to meetings for wider districts. These delegates apply criteria and rules, developed in previous years, which give the priorities different weights. They then elect a budget council which represents every part of the city.

Through an open process of negotiation and reporting back, the overall budget is drawn up to be put to the mayor and municipal council for final agreement. The same bodies of direct democracy monitor its implementation. Officials have to report back to citizens' meetings on the progress of the projects agreed through the participatory cycle. After 12 years, direct participation has spread to every area of the city council's work.

The most celebrated result is an end to the corruption that was rife in this and most other Brazilian cities.

Neo-liberal orthodoxy has been able to run riot world-wide, partly because the social-democratic state lost its legitimacy. Monetarism led to cuts that made the state appear tatty and inefficient. But social democracy also had a false optimism that parliamentary representation was enough, that it was able to represent and know people's needs in with a multi-faceted and powerful state apparatus. When parliamentary control failed, the selling off of the state apparatus was presented as the only alternative.

The experiences of Brazil do not provide a simple transferable alternative. But the weaknesses of Brazilian parliamentary institutions have led to the invention of principles of democratic public control over the state and private vested interests from which we could learn. Our government has not provided the alternative we hoped for. Our best chance now of ousting Tina is not keeping quiet for fear of something worse, but using the election period to speak out about international alternatives which others have shown can work.

Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball couldn't help putting the boot in to his terrestrial brethren at the company's first half results presentation last week. ITV's exile from Sky Digital shows no sign of ending. Ball explained that Sky Digital's much-hyped interactive service is described as iTV by industry specialists, adding: "That's the only way you'll hear the letters ITV at this company over the next few years." Meow. But, oh how the audience laughed.
fields.body:
BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball couldn't help putting the boot in to his terrestrial brethren at the company's first half results presentation last week. ITV's exile from Sky Digital shows no sign of ending. Ball explained that Sky Digital's much-hyped interactive service is described as iTV by industry specialists, adding: "That's the only way you'll hear the letters ITV at this company over the next few years." Meow. But, oh how the audience laughed.

Ten points for the boys over at Firebox for initiative. An order comes through the website for a few thousand pounds; the delivery address? A country manor in Essex. The boys duly call to check whether it's kosher, and what transpires is that Firebox has now signed up a country lord, the Honourable Mark J Petre, to write regular dispatches. Yes, aristocrats online, or "cybercrats" as Mark prefers, are the new, as yet untapped, demographic. Even, rumour has it, Tom Parker Bowles, reformed PR monster, is trying to get a dot.com for toffs off the ground. In Mark's latest column he talks of how he kitted out his north-wing corridor with optics and a dartboard - for the time when one has to give the driver the night off. It's all highly entertaining stuff.

The cream of Westminster new media was out in force for an e-communications conference thrown by the government last week. The new e-envoy Andrew Pinder was paraded around for all the civil servant IT bods to clock, and the talk was about how the government was forging ahead with its online plans. Yes, we know - we've been told often enough. But most curious was the overemphasis on Chatham House rules (off the record, for us laypersons) when, oddly enough, there was absolutely nothing at all juicy to come out of the event. The sole interesting point came out in a phone call with a local government official, who revealed how unimpressed councils are with the initiatives. It appears that the moves to put all local authority services online by 2005 are way behind schedule. Needless to say, they are not very impressed with the hyperbole.

And so it came to pass that T-Motion, Deutsche Telekom's all-singing, all-dancing Wap service was switched on for us lucky One 2 One subscribers last week. Intrigued by the countless text messages that One 2 One spammed me about it, I dialled up. Was it as "fast, exciting and fun" as it was billed? Well, it was quick, confusing and irritating. I got lost in the chat rooms, and got annoyed because after all the research about Wap, no operator has yet developed a generic "back" button to escape the mesh of links. Worst of all, for the first two days after launch, all I got was the message that news only worked on One 2 One Wap-enabled handsets. Wonder what they thought I was using?

Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: Brand aid: Interflora
fields.trailText: The flower delivery service is updating its image, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
What is it?

The grandaddy of all florists everywhere. Interflora has been getting forgetful Brits out of a tight spot for decades with its handy last-minute delivery service.

So what's the problem?

The company's over-enthusiastic use of carnations and chrysanthemums has unfortunately given Interflora a rather mumsy image. Trendy rivals with a more creative approach to flower- arranging have been stealing away business, and now Interflora is determined to woo back young consumers. "When people started calling us 'Aunty Flora', we knew that something had to be done," said a company spokeswoman.

And what are they doing about it?

Interflora's marketing bods have come up with a raunchy new Valentine's Day advertising campaign. A series of print ads show naked men and women with red roses in place of their rude bits. One, aimed at the gay press, shows a rose looking like an erect penis below the words, "floral sex".

Interflora has also gone online with a Valentine's Day website with a "find your date" computer game and an electronic diary to remind you of those special days.

Blimey. So how has all that gone down?

It's caused a few shock waves in the world of flower arranging, I can tell you. Even the Sun - which has never been noted for its PC attitude to these things - took such offence at an ad that used the strapline "tit-elation" that it refused to run it. Private Eye also said no.

Brand history

Interflora began life in 1935 as the International Florists' Association, a global trade body. Later it became Interflora and adopted Mercury, the messenger of the gods, as its logo. Today the Interflora network consists of 60,000 florists in about 165 countries.

The future

If Interflora bosses have their way, the organisation will become the "Nike of the flower world". Which rather begs the question of what it is now - Reebok, perhaps?

fields.headline: Don't be a dobber
fields.standfirst: After a spate of recent allegations, bullying in Australian has become more apparent than ever. And with a macho culture in equally rude health, the victims aren't exactly encouraged to come forward, reports Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: After a spate of recent allegations, bullying in Australian has become more apparent than ever. And with a macho culture in equally rude health, the victims aren't exactly encouraged to come forward, reports Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
Australians are renowned for their plain speaking. Former prime minister Paul Keating won a place in many hearts for his vituperative dismissal of political foes as, among other things, "scumbags", "stupid foul-mouthed grubs", "intellectual hoboes", "dummies", "dimwits" and "desperadoes".

But after a week in which bullying - commonly called "bastardisation" - has seldom been out of the headlines, the country is facing up to accusations that outbreaks of verbal and physical violence in its top institutions have been suppressed by an unwritten code of silence.

A week ago, all 50,000 of Australia's defence force were made to sit down and watch a video lesson, aimed at eradicating bullying in the military. It followed the charging in a military court of eleven soldiers for "acts of brutality".

The defence force will be further embarrassed in two weeks' time, when a TV documentary is set to reveal the "traditions" of its training academy, where female cadets are stripped naked and abandoned outside the base, while other trainees suffer "turkey slapping" - being hit on the head with male genitals.

Meanwhile, in a bar in the capital, Canberra, two Labour MPs were recently accused of intimidating a Liberal MP, Christopher Pyne. He told parliament that one of the MPs "threatened and intimidated me... [with] a string of vulgar four-letter words too foul to repeat here". During Mr Pyne's speech, another Labour MP was ejected from parliament for calling Mr Pyne a "ponce".

But the most serious story has been the exposure of bullying at Sydney's august private school, Trinity Grammar, where two boys last week pleaded guilty to six charges of aggravated indecent assault. A third pleaded guilty to intimidation and a fourth will be charged shortly.

The case came to light after two students, aged 14 and 16, confessed to school counsellors that they were repeatedly assaulted by in the school's boarding house by bullies brandishing handmade dildos. One was so large that boys called it the "anaconda". The bullying went on for six months. Police evidence later revealed a teacher had confiscated and destroyed several of the weapons without reporting the matter.

At a children's court last week, the defence and prosecution struck a deal in which two of the bullies pleaded guilty in return for the dropping of more serious sexual charges. Some parents then claimed there had been no sexual assaults, just bullying, while one of the bullies' parents dismissed the outrage expressed at the abuse as mere "political correctness".

Assisted by a vigorous media manager attempting to limit the damaging publicity for the prestigious 88-year-old school, Trinity Grammar's headmaster professed helplessness. "We're not there with surveillance cameras. We don't run a prison - we run a boarding house," Milton Cujes said. "The boys [who were victims of the attacks] did not confide in the staff; the boys did not confide in their parents."

Mr Cujes also denied there was a culture of bullying at the school, telling parents in an open letter: "We believe these were isolated incidents by some individuals and not part of any 'culture'."

Yet the bullies claimed in court that they were subject to similar abuse when they were younger. And the police evidence referred to a "culture of rumbling and general bastardisation at Trinity boarding school even prior to last year's reported attacks."

The 16-year-old victim told the Sun-Herald newspaper: "I was accused of being a dobber. The code of silence is really strong. The worst thing is to be seen as a dobber. I couldn't tell a teacher as I was too embarrassed to tell anyone."

He still hasn't talked directly to his parents about the attacks. They learned about the details from the agreed statements of facts given to the children's court judge.

One mother of a teenage student who withdrew her son from the school said: "There's not only a culture of bullying, there's a culture of being men, being macho, not talking about your feelings."

The victims of abuse can only hope that the recent rash of publicity about bastardisation encourages individuals and institutions in Australia to ditch the verbal violence in favour of real plain speaking.

webTitle: Big Bad World gets bad, bad ratings

fields.headline: Big Bad World gets bad, bad ratings
fields.standfirst: Jason Deans
fields.trailText: 10.30am: ITV has pulled comedy drama Big Bad World from the schedule due to poor ratings. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV has pulled comedy drama Big Bad World from its Friday night schedule after only four episodes due to the show's poor ratings.

The Carlton show, which was being beaten in the ratings by BBC1's Clive Anderson Now and Channel 4's So Graham Norton, is to be replaced this Friday at 10.30pm by ITV regional programming.

Big Bad World, which is a Cold Feet-esque thirtysomething comedy drama starring Ardal O'Hanlon and Beth Goddard, has averaged just 3.1m and an 18% share since debuting on Friday night on January 19.

The second series of the show started out at 10pm, before being moved back to 10.30pm in its second week.

"This is a commercial channel," said an ITV spokeswoman. "There's still a lot of trial and experiment with the new schedule. Big Bad World wasn't doing as well as it could have done."

The spokeswoman added that the remaining six episodes of the comedy drama will be broadcast, though they have not yet been rescheduled.

fields.headline: Bubbling over
fields.standfirst: Crossroads is back, EastEnders is getting another episode a week - television is awash with soaps. Maggie Brown wonders if we can take any more.
fields.trailText: Television is awash with soaps: Maggie Brown wonders if we can take any more.
fields.body:
By autumn the main five television channels will be offering viewers 15 and a half hours of home-grown soap opera a week, compared with 11 and a half now. Quite a jump. This growth stems from the BBC's planned fourth weekly episode of EastEnders, the impact of ITV's Trafalgar Road (casting now) and Crossroads (starting next month). It is driven by twin pressures: the intensifying competition for audiences, and a quest for value-for-money drama that can deliver huge numbers for a low budget. But it leaves big questions unanswered: can we take any more? Should diversity be sacrificed on the soap altar?

Greg Dyke, who overthrew John Birt's blanket refusal to back a fourth EastEnders, raised the whole issue last week when he was lightly grilled on his first year in office by Loyd Grossman at the LSE. The answer to the first question, at least, is simple. If you are an EastEnders fan, a fourth episode probably can't come soon enough. Emmerdale, stripped nightly since Christmas, is garnering average audiences of 10.5m.

In fact these figures for soap overload understate the impact, by excluding weekend omnibuses and daily repeats. Nor does the total include the rise of new dramas that may become fully fledged soaps shortly. These are the BBC's acclaimed daytime drama, Doctors and Channel 4's experimental pop- video-meets-teen-drama, E4's As If, which is being sized up as Channel 4's third soap alongside Brookside and Hollyoaks. It also ignores popular imports such as Neighbours, and ITV's The Bill, which has the year-round quality of a soap and is becoming increasingly soap-like by focusing more on characters' private lives.

At BSkyB, director of broadcasting Mark Sharman plans an overhaul (yet again) of Sky One. He may throw resources into Dream Team, the football drama series (which plunders Sky's real football footage), converting it to a full-blown soap. Two new soaps are also under consideration, a reversal of last year's decision to back costly drama specials. For Sharman, a soap costing £65,000 an episode (compared with £600,000 and upwards for an hour of filmed drama with stars), which can be endlessly repeated, supplies exactly what he knows fickle satellite viewers want: consistency and familiarity.

Quizzed on the issue, Dyke said ITV's four soaps were a sign, perhaps, that it is beginning to feel the strain of an advertising slow-down, and is opting for cheaper soaps at the expense of its prestige drama. (In fairness, Crossroads is replacing the imported Home & Away, snatched by Channel 5, with UK programming). He thinks a fifth episode of Coronation Street is inevitable.

Should the BBC be going down the same road? Some executives even say its duty is to devise a fresh second soap, rather than more EastEnders, but as Dyke observes pragmatically that is a hard thing to do - Eldorado haunts the BBC. Channel 5's daily soap Family Affairs is still struggling to make a mark. Mal Young, BBC's controller of continuing drama series, says: "Popular is not a dirty word". EastEnders will go through a careful expansion, he promises. "It has a 10m base audience. They're addicts. If it's good, audiences will watch more; if it's crap, they stop. In the last six months EastEnders' quality has been up there with the greats. We've got to keep that standard of writing. I think EastEnders can be as good as Play for Today."

Do soaps appeal ever more strongly? Kay Patrick, the experienced producer of Crossroads ("All the sets are all pretty solid"), says they are becoming dominant because "people love being told stories. In the old days it was sagas, story telling around the fire. Soaps heighten stories in the way the old sagas do. Dickens understood it too. Passion, fear, hate, envy - it's all there."

She adds quickly, though, that it's not going to be all gloom and doom at her four star hotel, now set on the edge of a market town. "Soap is life in primary colours. Escapism, so people can live vicariously. There will be humour, we'll be showing the games people play." Her Crossroads has a gym, jacuzzi, and little sense of being in the Midlands.

Richard Handford, the executive producer of The Bill, points out that the soap rise is also accompanied by longer runs of popular drama. ITV screens nearly 100 hours a year of The Bill annually, while 40 episodes of Casualty and Holby City have been ordered by BBC1, and 38 of Peak Practice by ITV. "I think people are more conservative in their tastes, and less prepared to welcome the new. They are working harder. They come home and ask themselves, why should I commit time to the new?"

But, like many others involved at the sharp end of production, he is sure that there is still a distance to go before soap saturation is reached. ITV and BBC1 are still very careful not to run Coronation Street and EastEnders head-to-head, while Emmerdale at 7 pm is unchallenged. All - bar Brookside - generally enjoy a clear run in the period before the real 8-10 pm battleground.

Handford says: "I don't have the time to watch them, I leave work at 8.15 pm. Neither do my crews watch: they work 50-hour weeks." His theory is that people at work in their 20s are largely a lost cause to the early evening soaps because they have long working hours and are more likely to be in the pub after work than heading home for Emmerdale.

Carson Black, the producer of Doctors, which returns in March stripped across BBC1 weekdays, says: "I personally don't understand it - people's appetites for soaps seem insatiable, voracious. fields.headline: The profits that kill
fields.standfirst:
Intellectual property agreements are making too much money for the west
Special report: Aids
Special report: World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: Intellectual property agreements are making too much money for the west.
fields.body:
One of the most grotesque and least well known achievements of the British in India was the great salt hedge. Roy Moxham's book, The Great Hedge of India, is testimony to a personal obsession to track this great monument to British imperial exploitation: 2,300 miles of thorny cacti, 10ft high, 14ft wide and guarded by 14,000 troops.

Its purpose was to prevent salt smuggling into British-controlled India, where the British collected an exorbitant salt tax - it was the equivalent of two months' salary of an Indian peasant. The burden of this colonial crime is self-evident: the first health tip for anyone who gets sick in a hot country is to keep up the salt level. But not once under the British Raj was this salt tax relaxed, not even during famines. Salt became the symbol of imperial exploitation for Mahatma Gandhi's independence movement and the civil disobedience campaigns begun with the salt march of 1930.

We complacently assume that such colonial atrocities are a thing of the past, and that in a much more enlightened 21st century, we wouldn't tolerate such a blatant disregard to human well being. But the unpalatable truth is that all that has changed is the form - colonialism has disappeared to be replaced by an alliance of corporate self-interest and governments eager to promote global capitalism. The salt hedge offers a neat analogy for Trips (the trade related intellectual property agreement) under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation - the purpose of which is every bit as exploitative and exclusive, and its consequences will be every bit as pernicious.

Of all the acronyms that multilateralism seems to spew out (WTO, Gats and so on), the fiercest battles will be over Trips. Intellectual property has not been much of a rallying cry at the barricades before, but it will be. Why? The most dramatic reason is Aids, which is exposing the whole international patent system on drugs as solely in the interests of the handful of multinational drug companies which make huge profits from their 20-year patents. Copies - generic drugs - are being made at a fraction of the cost, but millions will die because the multinationals invoke Trips to protect their patents, as an Oxfam campaign launched today will make clear.

Put baldly, patents are killing people. But that's not all. Intellectual property protection has become a tool to make permanent the growing inequality of the global economy: the rich get richer and the poor get poorer. Drugs are only the most blatant example of how, through Trips, the developed countries have stacked the odds in their favour. They have set the ground rules for the knowledge economy so they can extract a constant flow of income from less developed countries. Those countries will never be able to close the technology gap. This is the same principle as the salt hedge - ensure a steady flow of revenue and eliminate competition. It is also, to use another metaphor, kicking away the ladder which you have just climbed up - and it has never happened before in the history of industrial development.

What the rich countries chose to overlook is that their own economic development involved blatant abuse of patent law. The growth of the US textiles industry in the early 19th century was all based on ripping off the inventions being pioneered in the Lancashire mill towns. The Japanese did much the same later in the century with their textile industry, and in the early 20th century, they copied from the US and German steel industries. Post-war, Japan's economic miracle was based on innovative copying - with scant regard for patents.

Most developed countries have had domestic patent regimes to reward invention, but have always ripped off each other's ideas. There were attempts to achieve some kind of international patent protection, but they had no power of enforcement until the WTO negotiated Trips. If a country breaches Trips, it faces the threat of trade sanctions. Suddenly the whole game changes dramatically. Trade sanctions by a major trading partner on a vulnerable economy is so serious that in most cases it guarantees compliance.

The impetus for an international system of intellectual property protection was the rise of the knowledge economy. Countries such as the US wanted to maximise their returns on knowledge through licences on their patents across the globe. Seventy per cent of US export earnings are now linked to intellectual property - on everything from Aids drugs to brands such as Disney, McDonald's and Microsoft. The US needed an international regulatory regime to reap the benefits of its economic and cultural hegemony, and it is working: between 1991 and 1997, the value of royalties to the US doubled to more than $33bn a year. Naomi Klein addresses this in her book No Logo, as she charts the shift of production of trainers and jeans to Asian free trade zones where it represents a tiny cost compared to the value generated by the knowledge element - the brand management, advertising and design.

Real money in the global economy is no longer made from the production of commodities (for example, the price of coffee has plunged) nor even from labour-intensive manufacturing; it is made from knowledge-intensive technology and services. Since 1980, the share of global trade represented by commodities has halved to 13% while that of hi-tech goods has doubled. It becomes harder and harder for developing countries to catch up. They can't copy - they have to import the technology and pay royalties on the licences. The flow of revenue is one way, from poor to rich.

The stakes are so high in the knowledge economy that it is triggering a frenzied rush for patents. Applications for patents in the US have gone up from an annual 150,000 a year in the late 80s to 275,000 today. One of the most shocking examples is gene patenting. In October last year, there were patent applications on 126,672 human gene sequences. By this month that figure had gone up a staggering 38% to 175,624. Patents are now being used not just to protect an invention but as a strategy to scare off the competition by staking out an area of research. Of course, this rush to privatise knowledge only tilts the playing field more firmly against the developing world. In 1997, 26,000 patent applications were filed to the African intellectual property organisation. Only 31 came from resident Africans.

The analogy of the salt hedge would not be lost in India where the implementation of Trips into domestic legislation is proving bitterly controversial. One of post-colonial India's great achievements, argues the activist Vandana Shiva, was to frame a patent law in 1970, which recognised that there were issues of human welfare and development that must take precedence over profit, particularly in the areas of food and health.

This boosted a huge generic drugs industry which provides drugs which are much cheaper than over the border in Pakistan, and which have been exported all over the developing world. All that is now jeopardised.

One of the shabbiest sections of the government's white paper published at the end of last year (Eliminating world poverty: making globalisation work for the poor) was that on intellectual property; it praised Trips, but acknowledged the difficulties for many developing countries. It proposed the time-honoured British solution of setting up a commission to look into the issue. Two months on, no commission has yet been appointed; a senior official from the Department of International Development, after endorsing Trips, admits that neither at home or internationally has much thought been given to "what kind of intellectual property regime best serves poorer countries". It's about time it was.

fields.headline: Not the US elections
fields.standfirst: Come the big night, there's no danger of Cornwall being too close to call. ITN's  Richard Tait  on the lessons of Florida
fields.trailText: Come the big night, there's no danger of Cornwall being too close to call. ITN's Richard Tait on the lessons of Florida.
fields.body:
Last week's report by three US academics into CNN's coverage of the night of the US presidential election should send a cold shiver down the spine of every television news editor in Britain. They chronicled how in a few mad hours of wrong polls and over-hasty forecasting, CNN, ABC, CBS and NBC did terrible damage to their well-earned reputations as among the most trusted sources of information in the US. Dan Rather of CBS shared his own anger with the viewers: "If you're disgusted with us," he said on air, "I don't blame you".

Here in Britain, television news also enjoys the confidence of its viewers - opinion surveys during the last two general elections found that people trusted ITN and the BBC as the best sources of impartial information - a long way ahead of newspapers and political parties. So we have taken very careful note of what happened that night in November. ITN, ITV and Mori have reviewed how we will conduct our exit poll for ITV's election night programme, what margins of error we will build in, how we will ensure that the forecast is an accurate reflection of the poll data.

We will certainly not be setting up a joint polling operation with other broadcasters as the US networks did - the US report makes clear this was a cost-cutting measure too far.

Under the British system, of course, there is no danger of the polls misleading voters. The US networks called Florida twice. First they said Gore had won, then they called it for Bush while the result was still too close to call and many polling stations around the country were still open. The independent report concluded that "television interfered with the election process and the election result". British television news organisations operate a convention that we do not report any polls or any campaigning while voting is taking place.

The one US experience we would have liked to reproduce in the forthcoming UK election was the leaders' debates. They once again provided a mass television audience with one of the few focal points of the campaign and attracted viewers who were not watching very much other election coverage.

Ironically, I suspect the experience of the US debates did not encourage the prime minister's advisers. I remember a senior Labour strategist after the last election saying he was opposed to Tony Blair ever debating with William Hague because although he was sure that Blair would win, Hague as the underdog could only come out of the debate with his reputation enhanced. This is precisely what happened to George W Bush in the US debates. When it became clear that Gore, the man with the election to lose, had suffered from the debates, I thought our slim chance of success had become distinctly slimmer - as, sadly, it proved to be.

What we certainly will see imported across the Atlantic will be the latest spinning techniques, from individually targeted campaigning to online electioneering. And like the first swallows ahead of spring there are the first slightly random shots from the spin doctors across the broadcasters' bows.

Nothing so far can match the glorious ridiculousness of a solemn letter I received from a very experienced Labour spin doctor ahead of the last election. His complaint was that in a report we had allowed our cameras to dwell for too long on the Conservative poster of Tony Blair with "demon eyes". I checked how we had covered the last Labour poster which the Conservatives hadn't liked - and found that we had given it the same number of seconds of coverage as the Blair poster. I wrote back rejecting the complaint. It did occur to me at the time that two adults should really be able to find better uses for their time than wrangling over eight seconds of videotape - but that's politics.

L ooking ahead to the election I am struck by how wrong the gloomier prognostications over the last few years about the future of television news in Britain have been. Our main commercial customers, ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5, share ITN's belief that commercial television viewers have as much right to high quality news as those who tune in to the BBC. In the US, we perhaps now can begin to see the consequences of allowing market forces an excessively free hand. The American network news programmes are losing audience and research shows a growing number of those people who are still interested in news are migrating to news channels or news websites. In the UK, the great success of ITV's new schedule has actually increased the number of people watching television news in Britain on BBC1 and ITV for the first time for a number of years.

Our relations with BBC News are a unique mixture of pragmatic cooperation and ferocious competition. We all worked together for a joint proposal for the leaders' debates because we thought the programmes would have been so much in the public interest. Behind the scenes, we work very closely together in areas like the reform of electoral law and regulation. But in the field, and in the newsrooms, it's business as usual - a battle to be best which mirrors the political contest which is about to start.
