fields.headline: Stanley Harrison
fields.standfirst: Journalist and campaigner
fields.trailText: The second world war took Stanley Harrison, who has died aged 87, from Caversham to Cairo; the cold war took him to a job with a communist press agency in Prague, and to the forests of Bohemia.
fields.body:
The second world war took Stanley Harrison, who has died aged 87, from Caversham to Cairo; the cold war took him to a job with a communist press agency in Prague, and to the forests of Bohemia. From 1966 to 1979, as the Morning Star's chief sub editor, he helped to train a generation of radical journalists - who scattered far beyond the communist daily - and in 1974 as an author, he wrote Poor Men's Guardians, on the struggle for a democratic newspaper press from 1763-1973.

Harrison was the antithesis of the apparatchik. A working-class Yorkshireman, he won a scholarship to Jesus College, Oxford, where he read history and modern languages, of which Spanish was his preferred tongue. As a labour of love he translated Lope de Vega's play Fuenteovejuna, and it was performed at London's left-wing Unity Theatre.

During the war he worked at the government's Caversham monitoring service before the Cairo posting, where he listened to broadcasts from the Balkans. There he met his wife, Gina, a fiery and beautiful Croat.

It was the Communist party which sent Harrison to Prague, and Telepress agency, where one day, he recalled, men in mackintoshes arrived and closed it down. The Harrisons were exiled for six months to the Bohemian forests - he learned a lot about gathering and cooking mushrooms.

Eventually Harrison and Gina returned to England, where he became a sub editor on the Daily Worker - the Morning Star's predecessor - and Gina worked at Collet's, the left-wing bookshop in Charing Cross Road. Harrison worked with Allen Hutt, the legendary chief sub, who repeatedly won the Worker the annual newspaper design award - usually with pages Harrison had conceived. Gina left the CP over the 1956 Soviet intervention in Hungary but Harrison laboured on. In 1966 he succeeded Hutt as chief sub. Post-retirement he was for a time London correspondent of an Athens socialist newspaper.

In retirement, the couple left Highbury in north London (where Harrison used to go swimming with Jack Straw in the open-air pool) and settled in Brighton. Gina became a star of the local Labour Party and Harrison edited the Brighton and Hove Democratic Left's bulletin. They raised money, and consciousness, for the people of Bosnia as their beloved Yugoslavia went up in flames.

Harrison became an open-air speaker in his 70s to oppose the Falklands adventure and the gulf war. Their home meanwhile was an ecumenical - and gastronomic - meeting place for their broad family of friends. Gina died in 1998. Harrison is survived by a daughter, Susan, two granddaughters and two great grandchildren.

Stanley Harrison, journalist, born August 1, 1913; died December 26, 2000

fields.headline: Maxwell scandal reignites
fields.standfirst:
DTI report into former MGN owner will unsettle top City and political figures

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: DTI report into former MGN owner will unsettle top City and political figures.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry's potentially explosive report into the collapse of Robert Maxwell's business empire will be published by the end of next month, reopening the controversy sparked by the sudden death of the former owner of the Mirror newspaper.

Almost a decade after Mr Maxwell disappeared off his yacht, the inspectors recruited by the DTI to examine his complicated web of companies are finalising their detailed inquiry, which many figures in the City and in politics would probably prefer to keep away from the printing presses.

The inspectors, according to a report this weekend, highlight the iron fist with which Robert Maxwell controlled his business empire, looting money from the Mirror Group Newspaper's pension fund soon after taking over the paper in 1984. It outlines the role played by the then investment bank Samuel Montagu, which floated MGN on the stock market in 1991, and Coopers & Lybrand, which acted as accountants to the Maxwell empire.

While the inspectors conclude that some of the firms involved could have blown the whistle on Maxwell, they also argue that he was often the only person who really knew what was going on inside his sprawling business empire. The report is said to give details of money channelled from MGN and private Maxwell companies. It is also said to show deals Robert Maxwell conducted by using the assets of the Mirror's pension funds to trade in shares and channel the profits into his own company.

This weekend the DTI could not confirm the authenticity of the report, saying it had not yet received the inspectors' final draft. However, a DTI spokesman said the inspectors were "nearing completion of the report".

There was no official DTI confirmation on the publication date, but other sources said it should come out in "the next two months".

The DTI inspectors' investigation is edging closer to publication after being derailed by a number of lengthy court cases, including the unsuccessful fraud charges brought against Robert's sons Kevin and Ian, whose trial took 121 days and remains the most expensive criminal fraud case to ever take place. Along with financier Larry Trachtenberg, the brothers were acquitted and remaining charges dropped.

Kevin's role again comes under scrutiny by the DTI inspectors. The report is said to find that he knew more about the movements of cash between Mirror Group and Maxwell's private companies than any person apart from his father.

The investigators are reported to have concluded that companies and executives dealing with Robert Maxwell, who was also investigated by the DTI 30 years ago, should have treated him with caution. He is also said to have courted politicians in a bid to boost his credibility.

Leading investment bank Goldman Sachs is said by the report to have played a crucial part in ensuring that the flotation of one of Maxwell's other companies was a success. Coopers & Lybrand, now part of PricewaterhouseCoopers, has already been fined by the accountancy profession's policing body for its role in the Maxwell affair.

Goldman Sachs was unavailable for comment while HSBC, now owner of the former Samuel Montagu, was unable to comment. PricewaterhouseCoopers also declined to say anything.

webTitle: Report raises concerns over compulsory mental health admissions

fields.headline: Report raises concerns over compulsory mental health admissions
fields.trailText: A new report from the social services inspectorate (SSI) reports a worrying lack of information surrounding compulsory mental health admissions, a lack of interpreting services and a lack of alternatives to hospital admission for black people.
fields.body:
A new report from the social services inspectorate (SSI) reports a worrying lack of information surrounding compulsory mental health admissions, a lack of interpreting services and a lack of alternatives to hospital admission for black people.

The report, Detained: SSI Inspection of Compulsory Mental Health Admissions, found that management supervision of services and staff varied considerably from one local authority to another. Case recording was often poor, links between local authority mental health and children's services were tenuous, and social care input to written plans was underdeveloped, it said.

Published after the inspection of 10 local authorities, the report reveals a mixed picture of the effectiveness of assessment processes and social care services for people detained in psychiatric hospitals.

It found that approved social workers (ASWs) were highly valued and joint working between agencies was generally good. However, inspectors highlighted major areas of concern, including:
 the over-representation of people from minority ethnic groups in mental health assessments
 users' negative experiences of hospital treatment
 shortages of professional staff, including ASWs, sharing similar racial and cultural backgrounds as patients
 patchy equal opportunities practices
 poor information and recording systems, in some places
 unambitious social care input to care plans, in some areas
 inappropriate hospital admission for black people, where alternatives could have been provided
 problems in contacting doctors with specialist knowledge of mental illness.

Concerns were also raised about the use of ASWs. "Most councils had sufficient numbers of ASWs and some paid a premium, in the form of additional increments of pay, to retain experienced staff," says the report. "However, staffing figures were misleading because they included ASWs who had very limited operational involvement, because they were managers or worked in settings where statutory activity was low - learning disability services or services for older people."

Denise Platt, chief inspector of the SSI, said: "This report will help councillors and senior officers review how decisions are made about compulsory admissions under the Mental Health Act and whether an appropriate range of services is currently provided. It will enable them, in some cases, through the provision of good quality mental health services, to avoid the need for compulsory admission by finding alternatives to hospitalisation."

Carers of people with mental health problems were generally not included in discussions about care planning, the inspectors found.

A spokesperson for the Carers National Association said professionals often used "the excuse of confidentiality not to involve the carer".

The report comes as the recent mental health white paper proposes diluting the social work role in mental health sections. Currently, all decisions to "section" people under the Mental Health Act 1983 must involve an ASW as well as two doctors. The white paper says the ASW role in compulsory detention could be undertaken by "another approved mental health professional".

The Association of Directors of Social Services is pushing for ASWs to continue to have a statutory role in sectioning assessments. David Joannides, chairman of the ADSS mental health strategy group and Dorset director, said the shortage of appropriately experienced ASWs was countrywide. The authority of Rochdale, for example, - one of the 10 inspected - is raising the grade of ASWs to deal with a local shortfall.

"Given the shortage in some areas, it's not surprising that we are also finding there's a lack of ASWs with the knowledge and experience to deal with black and ethnic minority communities," he said. "That's something that local authorities are having to give much more regard to.

"The lack of children's services is one that we have all got to work hard at remedying, in particular the assessment of integrated services between health and social care. There's a real risk we could take our eye off the ball of the increased importance between mental health and children's services."

The campaigning charity Mind welcomed the report's focus on poor service provision for minority ethnic communities. "They are often the victims of assessments [which aren't really followed] through with appropriate care and treatment," said policy director Melba Wilson. "We need to have multi-disciplinary assessments that take into account every aspect of a mental health service user's life, and shouldn't be rushed."

Proper assessments were often not taking place because of a lack of time and resources, she said.

Inspections took place in Barking and Dagenham, Bolton, Cambridgeshire, Derby, Hackney, Nottingham, Rochdale, Southwark, Walsall, and Warwickshire.

 Detained: SSI Inspection of Compulsory Mental Health Admissions is available from the NHS responseline on 0541 555 455 or from DH Publications, PO Box 777 London SE1 6XH

webTitle: Unilever hints at cuts if UK says no to euro

fields.headline: Unilever hints at cuts if UK says no to euro
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Unilever's co-chairman, Niall FitzGerald, has warned that the Anglo-Dutch food conglomerate could scale back its investment in Britain if the public says "no" to joining the euro.
fields.body:
Unilever's co-chairman, Niall FitzGerald, has warned that the Anglo-Dutch food conglomerate could scale back its investment in Britain if the public says "no" to joining the euro.

A well-known enthusiast for the single currency, Mr FitzGerald has welcomed the government's promise of a referendum on the issue in the first two years of the next parliament.

He told a Sunday newspaper that if the result favours keeping sterling, the firm would "go back and re-examine the assumptions we have made about investment".

A Unilever spokesman yesterday said most large companies had based their recent investment decisions on the basis that Britain would join the euro within five years. In this respect, he said, Unilever was no different from Ford and Vauxhall, which have recently moved production away from Britain, partly because of the strong pound.

Unilever's brands include Lipton tea, Vaseline and Magnum ice creams. The group employs more than 17,000 people in Britain - its big factories include a Fabergé site in Leeds and a Lever soap facility at Port Sunlight, Merseyside. The group recently pledged to create 400 new jobs by consolidating its information technology operations at a site in north Wales.

Mr FitzGerald was quoted as saying that he was "hugely passionate about joining the euro". He expressed confidence that the public would eventually agree with him: "I have little doubt that once there is an open fact-based debate, then the answer will be clear."

 Irish finance minister Charlie McCreevy will go head to head with his fellow eurozone finance ministers today over demands from the European Commission for Dublin to rein in the booming Irish economy to restrain inflation. Ireland has the highest inflation rate in the single currency zone at 6%.

webTitle: Internet to show probe on asteroid

fields.headline: Internet to show probe on asteroid
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A spacecraft is due to land on an asteroid tomorrow in an operation that will mark the furthest distance from Earth that a landing has been made.
fields.body:
A spacecraft is due to land on an asteroid tomorrow in an operation that will mark the furthest distance from Earth that a landing has been made.

The Nasa spacecraft should land on an asteroid named Eros and then start sending photographs to a website.

The attempt marks the end of a year-long orbital mission of Eros, the first part of Nasa's Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous (Near) programme. The aim has been to establish the asteroid's mineralogical make-up and its relationship to comets, meteorites and the origin of the solar system.

"We fulfilled our primary science goals of the mission and wanted to find some way to end our mission on a high note," said Near mission director Robert Farquhar of Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, which built the solar-powered craft. "This also gave us the opportunity to do some bonus science and things with a spacecraft that had never been done before."

Nasa hopes that the internet could help to stimulate public interest in its work. The site, http://near.jhuapl.edu, will show how the investigation develops almost in real time. This marks the first time that an asteroid will have been seen so closely.

The spacecraft will remain on Eros after the completion of its work because it will not have enough fuel to return to Earth.

The kidney bean-shaped Eros was chosen because of its accessibility and size. It is the second-largest of the near-Earth asteroids whose orbits take them between Earth and Mars.

fields.headline: Pierre Leyris
fields.standfirst: Translator of great literature
fields.trailText: Translator of great literature
fields.body:
Pierre Leyris, who has died aged 93, was the leading translator into French of a staggering number of British and American writers. But it is not only the quantity that is remarkable. It is the quality of the writers concerned and the fact that they often presented difficulties of understanding and interpreting. Thus we find, alongside Dickens, such names as Herman Melville, William Blake, TS Eliot and Gerald Manley Hopkins. In 1985 Leyris was awarded the Grand Prix National de la traduction.

Leyris was involved in vast projects, such as the translation of the complete works of Shakespeare, and Gallimard's anthology of American Poetry. All his work was an invaluable contribution to literature.

Most of all, Leyris believed that only after patient effort would the right words be found, but he thought that when that word came it was like a sudden grace. He was always ready to admit to mistakes. In a letter to the Times Literary Supplement in October 1993, he wrote that in his translation of a line in TS Eliot's Little Gidding he ought to have used the words "a été " rather than the past historic tense, " fut". French, he once said, had lost much of its briskness during the latinising vogue of the Renaissance, and was therefore left with very formal-sounding words for everyday use. He warned English visitors to France that they must not think that French hotel keepers were highly educated because they used words such as " Monsieur est matinal ".

Pierre Leyris was born at Ermont in the Seine-et-Oise department and educated at the Lycée Jeanson-De-Sailly where he was influenced by his fellow lycéens, especially the future author Pierre Klossowski and his brother, the painter Balthus.

Attracted to literature and art, Leyris became part of para-surrealist groups, like the Simpliste and Le Grand Jeu and met novelists such as George Bataille and Roger Vailland. Two further friendships assisted his development: one with Pierre John Jouve led him towards poetry; the other, with Brice Parain, brought him towards the study of language.

Through Parain, he also began to work with the Nouvelle Revue Française. While his published work with this important publication was small and consisted mainly of book reviewing, his first contribution dates from 1932 and his collaboration continued until December 1939. It was Parain, the philosopher of language and the believer in the autonomy of language, who caused Leyris to turn towards translation as a form of literary expression.

At the Nouvelle Revue Française, Andre Gide was constantly demanding that works in English should be translated into French, complaining in 1930, for example, that he could not fully understand Siegfried Sassoon's Memoirs of an Infantry Officer. Meanwhile his co-founder of the review, Jean Schlumberger, was one of the earliest translators of Walt Whitman.

Thus Leyris began his long career with translations of Herman Melville, recalled with praise by David Gascoyne in the Times Literary Supplement, when Gallimard published an edition of Melville's war poetry in 1992. Leyris accompanied his translations with brief but useful notes. He never attempted to impose French cultural assumptions on the English texts.

Throughout his career he received considerable help from his English wife; they had three children. He served as secretary to the catholic review Dieu Vivant (edited by Louis Massignon) after 1945. He donated his body to scientific research.

 Pierre Leyris, literary translator, born July 16 1907; died January 4 2001

But it is not only the quantity that is remarkable. It is the quality of the writers concerned and the fact that they often presented difficulties of understanding and interpreting. Thus we find, alongside Dickens, such names as Herman Melville, William Blake, TS Eliot and Gerald Manley Hopkins. In 1985 Leyris was awarded the Grand Prix National de la traduction. Leyris was involved in vast projects, such as the translation of the complete works of Shakespeare, and Gallimard's anthology of American Poetry. All his work was an invaluable contribution to literature. Most of all, Leyris believed that only after patient effort would the right words be found, but he thought that when that word came it was like a sudden grace. He was always ready to admit to mistakes. In a letter to the Times Literary Supplement in October 1993, he wrote that in his translation of a line in TS Eliot's Little Gidding he ought to have used the words "a été " rather than the past historic tense, " fut". French, he once said, had lost much of its briskness during the latinising vogue of the Renaissance, and was therefore left with very formal-sounding words for everyday use. He warned English visitors to France that they must not think that French hotel keepers were highly educated because they used words such as " Monsieur est matinal ". Pierre Leyris was born at Ermont in the Seine-et-Oise department and educated at the Lycée Jeanson-De-Sailly where he was influenced by his fellow lycéens, especially the future author Pierre Klossowski and his brother, the painter Balthus. Attracted to literature and art, Leyris became part of para-surrealist groups, like the Simpliste and Le Grand Jeu and met novelists such as George Bataille and Roger Vailland. Two further friendships assisted his development: one with Pierre John Jouve led him towards poetry; the other, with Brice Parain, brought him towards the study of language. Through Parain, he also began to work with the Nouvelle Revue Française. While his published work with this important publication was small and consisted mainly of book reviewing, his first contribution dates from 1932 and his collaboration continued until December 1939. It was Parain, the philosopher of language and the believer in the autonomy of language, who caused Leyris to turn towards translation as a form of literary expression. At the Nouvelle Revue Française, Andre Gide was constantly demanding that works in English should be translated into French, complaining in 1930, for example, that he could not fully understand Siegfried Sassoon's Memoirs of an Infantry Officer. Meanwhile his co-founder of the review, Jean Schlumberger, was one of the earliest translators of Walt Whitman. Thus Leyris began his long career with translations of Herman Melville, recalled with praise by David Gascoyne in the Times Literary Supplement, when Gallimard published an edition of Melville's war poetry in 1992. Leyris accompanied his translations with brief but useful notes. He never attempted to impose French cultural assumptions on the English texts. Throughout his career he received considerable help from his English wife; they had three children. He served as secretary to the catholic review Dieu Vivant (edited by Louis Massignon) after 1945. He donated his body to scientific research.  Pierre Leyris, literary translator, born July 16 1907; died January 4 2001

webTitle: A green housing estate that could revolutionise suburbia

fields.headline: What, no conservatory?
fields.standfirst: A new green housing estate in the heart of commuterland could revolutionise suburbia.  Jonathan Glancey  reports
fields.trailText: A new green housing estate in the heart of commuterland could revolutionise suburbia. Jonathan Glancey reports.
fields.body:
It really is a breath of fresh air. Rising from the site of a former sewage treatment plant, the 82-home BedZed scheme in Sutton, Surrey, is the first real attempt by architects and developers to build a "green" housing estate in Britain - though there are many examples of one-off eco-friendly homes.

BedZed is the brainchild of architect Bill Dunster (who lives in his own eco-friendly house nearby), the affordable housing agency the Peabody Trust and the environmental charity BioRegional. Some way from completion, the scheme has already attracted more than 1,000 potential house buyers, although a third of the 82 live-work terrace homes have been set aside as low-rent social housing. The fact that so many people have expressed an interest in this quietly revolutionary housing estate is encouraging not only to the architects and their clients, but to anyone concerned about the future of housing. Ever-expanding suburbia has gobbled up and often ruined much of Britain, notably the south-east. Sutton is at the heart of this greedy suburban sprawl.

It's not as if the suburbs are all they are cracked up to be. Those hoping to find a bit of rural peace and quiet away from city centres often find themselves in houses that waste land and greedily consume energy. They are also often completely dependent on cars - living in a petrol-driven subtopia rather than a William Morris-style rural utopia. One of the greatest problems facing the experts brought in to help London mayor Ken Livingstone formulate a rational transport policy for Greater London is the huge increase in suburban traffic.

"What we need to learn," suggests Bill Dunster, "is to live more closely together and, where possible, to live and work without having to commute. This means the creation of more densely packed homes in suburbia, homes with built-in workspaces. Of course, this arrangement won't appeal to everyone, but the fact that so many people have expressed interest in living at BedZed is some sort of proof that we're working along the right lines." One of the clever things about the Dunster-designed houses is that they are a soft Modern architecture; with their gently curved roofs and construction of brick and timber, they clearly appeal to those for whom a mock Tudor or neo-Georgian house would be the normal choice, the ideal home. Arranged in elegant terraces of six three-storey homes, the houses are a contem porary take on traditional Georgian row housing. They occupy the least possible acreage, but even so they have balconies and roof gardens as well as conventional back gardens - and the bonus of office-workshops.

In town planning terms, the BedZed development shows how suburbia can become more responsible than it has been to date, how it can organise itself more efficiently, use considerably less energy and, as far as possible, shed its reliance on the car. Built into the estate is an all-electric car pool; this makes it possible for future residents to forgo car ownership and to make short trips to shops, schools and station by quiet cars that use little energy. Of course they have to get power from somewhere, so the estate incorporates a combined heat and power plant that uses tree waste as fuel. This will produce all the energy needed to power the estate and its pool of electric cars. Dunster's environmental consultants tell him that houses on the estate will expend 90 per cent less energy than an average British family home. There will be, as far as technologically possible, no emission of carbon-laced exhaust gases.

As for the energy needed to build the estate, this has been kept to a minimum by sourcing all necessary materials within three miles of the site. Wherever possible, materials are recycled. "There is nothing new in the structure of the houses," says Dunster, "but we've tried to ensure that their initial environmental cost is low and that they will be cheap to run and maintain."

By shaping houses that might appeal to anyone and not just those (by far the minority in Britain) in search of a modern, architect-designed home, Richard McCarthy, chief executive of the Peabody Trust and chairman of the National Housing Federation, hopes to create a demand for low-energy homes. To get people to give up the dream of a mock-Tudor pile will take some doing by the likes of the forward-looking McCarthy. Yet if he can woo house-hunters into living and working in a suburban update of the urban Georgian terrace, then suburbia may yet be green.

Ken Livingstone's environment commission, set up last year to advise the mayor on the "greening" of London, commended the scheme last week as a model that all other house builders and developers might follow. The commission calls for, among other things, a halt to the loss of open spaces and playing fields in Greater London as well as a London-wide programme of tree-planting. This is encouraging. Yet the battle over the future of suburbia has really only just begun.

webTitle: Covenants put paid to new lease of life for gems of cinema architecture

fields.headline: Covenants put paid to new lease of life for gems of cinema architecture
fields.trailText: Bristol's first purpose-built cinema, a rare listed survivor from the glory days of cinema architecture, looks doomed to become a leisure centre, after being sold by the ABC-Odeon chain with a covenant which ensures that the building can never be used as a cinema again.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Bristol's first purpose-built cinema, a rare listed survivor from the glory days of cinema architecture, looks doomed to become a leisure centre, after being sold by the ABC-Odeon chain with a covenant which ensures that the building can never be used as a cinema again.

It will share the fate of hundreds of former palatial movie theatres, once sumptuous buildings open to anyone for the price of a cinema ticket.

In the 1920s, operators vied to outdo one another in splendour, with glittering bars and tearooms, auditoriums equipped with spectacular lighting effects and vast electric organs that sank into a pit when the show began. The buildings may survive, but have been converted into pubs, churches, carpet storerooms and office equipment stores. The communities they once served are left with no alternative to a long trek to an out of town multiplex.

In Bristol the news that their cherished cinema will never show films again has dismayed local campaigners who fought to save the ABC cinema on Whiteladies Road. It is still open, but is due to close at the end of the year. Locals, convinced it is still viable, had hoped to see it taken over by an independent operator.

"This is an interesting, much loved building, still being used for the purpose it was designed for when it opened in 1921, and heavily used by local people," said Hattie Appleby, one of the campaigners who have launched a Keep Cinema Local campaign to alert other communities to the threat. "To discover that it has been sold with this covenant is just a tragedy."

The ABC was listed by English Heritage two years ago to save it from the threat of demolition, but there is no statutory power to preserve it in cinema use - unlike theatres, which can have change of use only after a public inquiry.

The Bristol cinema was listed as English Heritage launched a national survey to find the remaining gems.

Many cinemas which were saved by conversion into bingo halls are now in danger again as the game becomes less popular. Ironically, the new threat to local cinemas comes from the renewed popularity of cinemagoing. The fate of the Bristol cinema seems to have been sealed by last year's merger between the ABC and Odeon chains. The group does not see the future in small local cinemas, on tight inner city sites, which cannot be expanded into multi-screen complexes and often have little or no parking.

It has emerged that restrictive covenants such as the Bristol one, intended to protect the chains from potential local competition, have become standard in disposing of local cinemas.

Although the Odeon group, which since last year's merger now includes ABC, refused to discuss such contracts, the developer who has bought the Bristol site has already bought eight other former cinemas from the group, all with restrictive covenants.

Richard Gray, chairman of the Cinema Theatres Association, which campaigns nationally for the preservation of both the buildings and their cinema use, is alarmed at the trend.

"The right of the chains to impose such a covenant has never been challenged in law, and we would welcome a test case," Mr Gray said.

The listed former ABC cinema at Walthamstow, east London, and another at Gravesend have been sold to an Asian businessman with a covenant barring him from showing anything except Asian films.

These cinemas have been enthusiastically supported, but report that their audiences would also like to see a wider range of films. Film societies have approached them to show other films, but the covenant forbids it.

webTitle: Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed'

fields.headline: Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson was at the centre of fresh controversy yesterday when it emerged he was demanding compensation for his failed bid to run the national lottery.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson was at the centre of fresh controversy yesterday when it emerged he was demanding compensation for his failed bid to run the national lottery.

But the lottery commission said it was unlikely that Sir Richard's consortium, the People's Lottery, would receive compensation - and if it did, the money would have to come from funds for good causes.

Sir Richard's consortium believes it should be recompensed for its expenditure on the bid since last August, at least, when the commission initially indicated that the consortium's bid was the one it wanted to see developed. Camelot went on to clinch a new seven-year franchise.

The People's Lottery confirmed it would be lodging a request with the commission this week but dismissed as speculation reports that it was seeking an £8m payoff and that a deal had already been done behind closed doors.

In a statement, Sir Richard said: "We will be lodging a claim. However, we would not expect any funds to be paid to come out of the good causes fund." He said the money ought to come from payment which the government will take from Camelot in tax.

A commission spokesman said that it would examine any representations lodged by the People's Lottery, but added that he doubted whether the consortium had a strong case.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said it would be "outrageous" if money which should have gone to good causes was paid to the consortium. "The public would not forgive them for such a shameful abuse of lottery money."

 There were no winners in Saturday's national lottery draw. Numbers were 7, 9, 12, 17, 20 and 32, the bonus 30. No one won the extra draw; numbers were 9, 10, 12, 14, 36 and 39. But two tickets picked up £250,000 in the thunderball, matching the numbers 4, 9, 12, 14, 24, and thunderball 12.

webTitle: Downing Street calls truce with Mandelson

fields.headline: Downing Street calls truce with Mandelson
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street agreed an informal truce with Peter Mandelson yesterday after his campaign to clear his name over the Hinduja affair spun out of control last week.
fields.body:
Downing Street agreed an informal truce with Peter Mandelson yesterday after his campaign to clear his name over the Hinduja affair spun out of control last week.

Amid fears that Labour's general election campaign was in danger of being derailed, Tony Blair authorised a statement offering qualified support for his former confidant. "We quite understand why Peter feels he has to clear his name," a Downing Street aide said.

It is understood that the statement was designed to offer support to Mr Mandelson when he appears this week before Sir Anthony Hammond, who is chairing the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair.

Mr Blair's support does not extend to Mr Mandelson's decision last week to tour newspaper offices to put his side of the story. The prime minister is said to be still seething after Mr Mandelson overshadowed his key speech on education by telling the Daily Telegraph that he would like to deploy his reforming skills in Europe.

Yesterday Lord Sawyer, Labour's general secretary during the last election, said he hoped Mr Mandelson would play a role in the future.

Describing him as irreplaceable, Lord Sawyer told BBC1's On the Record: "Give him any portfolio, give him any case to make, and Peter... will make it in a manner which is hard to equal in the parliamentary Labour party now. In Labour party politics this is a big asset, and it's too big to squander."

However, he admitted that Mr Mandelson would struggle to make a comeback if he had intentionally deceived people over the Hinduja passports.

Phil Woolas, parliamentary private secretary to the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, said: "It's possible [the inquiry] will exonerate Peter Mandelson. If that is the case, I can't see any reason why after the general election, sometime in the future, he couldn't play a role in government."

However, another Labour MP underlined deep unease among backbenchers over his conduct. Gordon Prentice, a former ministerial aide, said Labour MPs would not "swallow" a Mandelson comeback.

Mr Mandelson, meanwhile, was preparing his defence to present to Sir Anthony. He believes he was unfairly removed from office by a Downing Street "hanging bench" after the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, compiled a partial account of his role in the Hindujas' passport applications.

Mr Mandelson believes that Sir Richard relied too heavily on the Home Office account of the affair, which claims that he spoke on the phone to the former immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, about the applications. Mr Mandelson will point to a memo prepared by officials which said Mr O'Brien could not recall how they had been in touch on the issue.

However, Sir Anthony may not provide solace for Mr Mandelson because even he admits that he cannot provide a cast-iron guarantee that he did not speak to Mr O'Brien.

Yesterday Andrew Lansley, shadow cabinet office minister, said the affair had created a backdrop against which people "think increasingly ill of this government, where they don't trust what they say, where they feel that they came into office claiming they'd uphold the highest standards in public life, and they have completely failed to deliver on that".

Sinn Fein's education minister, Martin McGuinness, described Mr Mandelson as "out of his depth" and said he had made "a mess" of legislation to reform the RUC.

webTitle: Briton was 'physically maltreated' in Israeli jail

fields.headline: Briton was 'physically maltreated' in Israeli jail
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A British man has suffered "physical maltreatment" in an Israeli prison where he is being held on terrorism charges, the Foreign Office confirmed yesterday.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem and  Jeevan Vasagar
fields.body:
A British man has suffered "physical maltreatment" in an Israeli prison where he is being held on terrorism charges, the Foreign Office confirmed yesterday.

Jehard Shuman, 32, was arrested by Israeli security forces on January 5, on suspicion of being sent by the Lebanese guerrilla group Hizbollah to carry out an attack in the Jewish state.

The Israeli government partially lifted a five-week-old gagging order on the case yesterday, though Mr Shuman, who is described as a naturalised British citizen, has not been formally charged. He has been held at Jerusalem's Russian compound prison on a series of administrative detention orders.

Mr Shuman's lawyer, Leah Tsemel, said that he had "severe complaints" about his treatment, and that he has received medical attention. A Canadian doctor is believed to have visited him in the past few days, a senior Israeli police official said.

Mr Shuman appeared in court yesterday where his detention was extended until Sunday. The doctor has said his condition is consistent with suffering physical mistreatment.

The Foreign Office, which was notified of Mr Shuman's arrest on January 8, yesterday released a complaint that Mr Shuman had been maltreated. The Israeli ambassador in London has been called in to see Foreign Office minister Baroness Scotland. "We have been unable ... to satisfy ourselves that the physical maltreatment has stopped," she said.

She made no comment on the accusations levelled against him, but said he should be charged or released.

There were few details available about Mr Shuman's origins, or the accusations against him, because of Israeli censorship. He is believed to have been on a visit to Israel when he was arrested in Jerusalem, and the Israeli prime minister's office said he was suspected of having been sent on a mission from Hizbollah to carry out an attack inside Israel.

"Shuman is being investigated regarding his recruitment in Lebanon and being sent to carry out a mission inside Israel; his investigation is continuing," the prime minister's office said in a statement.

"He is not cooperating in the investigation much," the Israeli police official said. He said police were continuing to explore the possibility that Mr Shuman may not have been acting alone.

Ms Tsemel said her client denied the charges, and that security forces had not discovered any weapons at the time of Mr Shuman's arrest.

There were few details available on Mr Shuman's condition. fields.headline: Deal 'this week' on dome sale
fields.standfirst:
Duke of Westminster's stake viewed as clincher

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Duke of Westminster's stake viewed as clincher.
fields.body:
Legacy, the group seeking to buy the Millennium Dome, expects its bid to be accepted by the government this week, after inviting the Duke of Westminster to join the consortium.

The group, fronted by Labour donor Robert Bourne and dominated by Irish-based Treasury Holdings, said last night it was confident of securing ministerial approval to take over the project.

Legacy's prospects of clinching a deal to turn the site into a hi-tech business park surrounded by houses, pubs, and shops rose last week after it bowed to pressure and agreed to seek new partners.

Talks were continuing last night with the duke's privately owned Grosvenor Estates and property firm Quintain, plus another unnamed British firm.

The consortium declined to disclose whether Grosvenor, Quintain or the other British firm was likely to take a stake in the venture, as a Grosvenor source confirmed that discussions were underway.

But Legacy predicted that its offer would be approved in principle on Thursday by a cabinet committee led by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the dome minister, Lord Falconer.

The Duke of Westminster is the country's richest aristocrat, worth an estimated £3.75bn, and owner of 300 acres in Mayfair and Belgravia, and is reported to be considering a 25% stake.

His involvement risks fuelling public criticism that a landmark building and 63 acres of land, into which have been pumped more than £800m of public money, is to be sold for around £125m.

Unless the Legacy bid collapses in the next few days, ministers are expected to extend Wednesday's deadline by up to a month to complete the transfer after Tony Blair made clear he wants to be rid of the dome before the election.

Mr Bourne, due to meet the government's competition advisers on Wednesday, is also expected to disclose that the building giant, Sir Robert McAlpine, has agreed to join Legacy, after declining a stake last month.

Four months of negotiations since Legacy was nominated "preferred bidder" last November, when the Japanese bank Nomura pulled out, have been dogged by rows. The government has insisted on clawback clauses to share in future profits if the site is sold on. It feared it was vulnerable to Tory attacks over Legacy unless the make-up of the consortium was broadened.

Mr Bourne has donated £100,000 to Labour, handing over the last tranche of the cash after expressing an interest in the dome, and has also supported the culture secretary, Chris Smith's Islington South constituency. Treasury Holdings has been involved in political and business dealings in Ireland.

Mr Prescott is believed to have asked architect Lord Rogers of Riverside to head a committee to advise the government on how the rest of the Greenwich peninsula should be developed.

Ministers must also decide on Thursday whether a four-day auction of the dome's contents, intended to raise up to £4m, opens as planned on February 27.

The sale will be postponed if the Legacy deal collapses, as the government has promised to keep the dome as an entertainment venue until its future is decided.

fields.headline: Submarine 'did little to aid' Japanese trawler it sank
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President Bush and other senior members of the US government have apologised and are considering compensation for the families of those who died when a Japanese trawler was sunk accidentally by a US submarine about nine miles from Honolulu's Pearl Harbour.
fields.byline: Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo and Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles
fields.body:
President Bush and other senior members of the US government have apologised and are considering compensation for the families of those who died when a Japanese trawler was sunk accidentally by a US submarine about nine miles from Honolulu's Pearl Harbour.

The submarine's commander has been removed from his post pending a full inquiry into the tragedy on Saturday in which nine people on board the Japanese ship are feared to have drowned.

"We're doing everything humanly possible to find the remaining participants on that ship," the US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said yesterday.

It now appears that the accident happened as the submarine was testing an emergency manoeuvre. The regulations stipulate that checks should be made that there are no vessels in the vicinity before such an operation is carried out.

The US national transportation safety board, an independent government body, yesterday sent five investigators to Hawaii to look into whether the submarine followed safety procedures when it carried out what is believed to have been a mock emergency routine in which it would have dived to considerable depths and then surged to the surface.

The captain of the Ehime Maru, Hisao Onishi, said the submarine had done "little to help" after the collision. For an hour afterwards, he said, the only assistance offered by the USS Greeneville was to lower a rope ladder to survivors. "We had to wait for the coast guard," Capt Onishi said.

The Japanese media have criticised the submarine's crew, with speculation focusing on whether the emergency surfacing operation was conducted to show off to a group of corporate executives on board the vessel.

"It is a matter of course for a submarine to use sonar and its periscope to check for nearby vessels before surfacing. If the US submarine neglected to do this, it is an incredibly basic mistake," said an editorial in the daily Asahi Shimbun.

While Mr Rumsfeld said there was as yet no way of knowing why the accident happened, he said the US government would be considering compensation for families of those who died as soon as the facts were known.

"It clearly was just a terrible tragedy and most unfortunate," Mr Rumsfeld said.

Mr Bush and the secretary of state, Colin Powell, have added their personal condolences.

The submarine's commanding officer, Commander Scott Waddle, of Austin, Texas, was reassigned on Saturday pending the outcome of an investigation.

"While it's not yet clear how the accident occurred, it is both tragic and regrettable," said Admiral Thomas Fargo, commander in chief of the US Pacific Fleet. "I want to express my apologies to those involved in the incident, their families and the government of Japan."

The submarine USS Greeneville remained at the scene as Japan demanded yesterday that the US raise the Ehime Maru. The US navy and coast guard broadened their search in waters close to Hawaii for the nine missing persons, including four school students and two teachers who were on a study trip. It is feared the missing were trapped inside the Ehime Maru as it went down within minutes of being hit by the 6,900-tonne nuclear-powered submarine.

"The rescue of the nine missing people should be considered first," said the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori. "If they have not been discovered through searches on the surface of the sea, everybody would like to know about the inside."

The accident threatens to damage relations between Japan and the US military, which were strained last week when the top US marine in Japan was forced to apologise after calling officials in Okinawa "a bunch of wimps".

The Ehime Maru was carrying 17-year-old students from Uwajima Marine and Fisheries High School on a study tour. Twenty six of the 35 people on board were rescued. Parents and students held a vigil at the school yesterday as the list of missing persons was broadcast on television.

"Our [search] plan is for at least another 48 hours. We will search as long as we think there is a bit of hope," coast guard Lieutenant Commander Jack Laufer said late yesterday.

webTitle: Tories plan tax breaks for over-75s

fields.headline: Tories plan to take 400,000 over-75s out of tax bracket
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday stepped up his courting of the "grey vote" when he guaranteed that 400,000 pensioners over 75 would not have to pay tax under a Tory government.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday stepped up his courting of the "grey vote" when he guaranteed that 400,000 pensioners over 75 would not have to pay tax under a Tory government.

The shadow chancellor pledged to increase the personal allowance for anyone aged over 75 by £2,000, automatically taking 400,000 people out of the tax bracket.

Mr Portillo yesterday told Sky News: "We want a different sort of society in which people are encouraged to save, take more responsibility for themselves, can face their future with greater confidence, and can have more choice." Under his plans, the personal allowance for pensioners over 75 will be raised from £6,050 to £8,050, which will ensure that 400,000 pensionners will not have to pay any tax.

The change will cost £350m, which will be paid from the £8bn the Tories are planning to slash from the government's overall spending plans.

In his first initiative, outlined last week, Mr Portillo promised to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters. Under the £3bn plan, only higher rate taxpayers - with incomes above £32,785 - will pay income tax on savings.

Labour claimed last night that the Tories' pensions policy was in disarray, not least because Mr Hague would struggle to find the savings needed to fund the latest tax cut.

 One in five old people in care in Scotland are suffering from malnutrition, according to a three-year study for the Scottish executive, writes Kirsty Scott. The study concluded pensioners in professional care were more likely to suffer malnourishment than those in their own homes.

 Charles Kennedy, Liberal Democrat leader, pledged yesterday to raise an extra £8.5bn in taxes to fund increased spending on health and education.

fields.headline: £1bn space lab opens for business
fields.standfirst:
Nasa has spent a fortune but firms balk at the cost of experiments

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: It may go down in history as the beginning of industrial exploitation of space. It is likely to be the most expensive white elephant ever built. But at last, the laboratory Nasa calls its "crown jewel" is in orbit and open for business.
fields.body:
It may go down in history as the beginning of industrial exploitation of space. It is likely to be the most expensive white elephant ever built. But at last, the laboratory Nasa calls its "crown jewel" is in orbit and open for business.

Yesterday, astronauts for the first time opened the hatch between the lab, Destiny, and the rest of the International Space Station. In doing so, the ISS residents, two Russians and an American, had the size of their living area increased by 40%. Never before have humans had so much space in space.

"The lab looks, feels and smells great. It looks like all the hard work has really paid off," Kenneth Cockrell, commander of the space shuttle which delivered Destiny, said after entering the lab.

The £1bn laboratory will be the station's first centre for large-scale scientific experiments. Whether supporters of the ISS are proved right depends on Destiny's performance. Critics of the ISS say there is no laboratory science to be done on a manned space station which could not be done more easily on earth, or on unmanned craft.

The arrival of Destiny also marks the end of an era for Russia. The module carries the equipment to enable ISS mission control to switch from Russia to the US. When Moscow ditches Mir in the Pacific later this year, Russia's role as a junior partner in the settlement of space will be confirmed.

With Destiny attached, the ISS becomes the biggest space station ever, dwarfing Mir and the US Skylab. With its solar panels outstretched, it is 72 metres wide. It is more than 50 metres in length, and on Earth would weigh 112 tonnes.

The ISS was already one of the brightest objects in the sky. With the added reflectivity of the lab's aluminium cover, it will shine still more brightly as it crosses the night horizon.

More modules, including a laboratory from the European Space Agency, are due to be added to the ISS in the run-up to completion in 2006, giving it an area equivalent to 14 tennis courts and a pressurised living space as big as two jumbo jet passenger compartments.

Experiments will be ferried up to the ISS by shuttle in pre-packed, fridge-sized units - the first will be delivered in March - which will be slotted on to 13 racks inside Destiny.

The theoretical advantage of carrying out experiments in space is that the processes that lie behind plant growth - cell division and the synthesis of complex molecules such as enzymes and combustion - will be easier to understand without the distortions of gravity.

Some scientists believe that it may be possible to make new materials or even medicines in space which could not be made on Earth. The problem is that such experiments have been carried out in orbit since the 1970s and none has provoked a rush of interest.

The successful connection of Destiny to the skeleton ISS over the weekend was a huge relief to Nasa. The agency did not have the money to pay Boeing to build another one.

In one of the most high-pressure assignments of her 11-year career flying space missions, 49-year-old Marsha Ivins, sitting inside the shuttle Atlantis, manoeuvred the robot arm that lifted Destiny out of the shuttle's cargo bay.

The laboratory, 8.4 metres by 4.2 metres, fitted in the bay with only five centimetres to spare. With two spacewalking colleagues, Thomas Jones and Robert Curbeam, acting as her eyes, she plucked the lab out and married it to the rest of the ISS.

During the long and troubled gestation of the ISS - at one point Congress came within a single vote of cancelling the project - Nasa pointed out that the station would be available for commercial research.

But electronics and bio- tech firms have shown little interest, partly because of the expense of taking material into orbit and back.

US scientists resent the huge cost of the ISS over its surprisingly short lifetime - just 10 years. It may end up consuming£70bn when the cost of shuttle flights to maintain it and rotate crews are included.

One prominent member of the US physics community, Dr Robert Park, said before the first part of the ISS was launched that there was no justification for a permanently manned station in Earth orbit.

"The International Space Station is yesterday's technology and its objectives are yesterday's science," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man killed by police car | Weather sends rats indoors | Inuit saluted for anorak | Madonna finds her ideal home | C4 rapped over wrestling
fields.body:
Man killed by police car
A 40-year-old man died after being struck from behind by an unmarked police car yesterday in Kenilworth, Warwickshire, police said. The car had not been involved in any pursuit. An inquiry is under way.

Weather sends rats indoors

Cold weather and flooding have brought a big rise in people reporting problems with rats, whose numbers have swollen due to some mild winters. Heavy rain has driven them from sewers into gardens, sheds and houses, said the National Pest Technicians Association. Calls to pest controllers rose by 18% last year and are this year likely to be up by a further 20%.

Inuit saluted for anorak

An exhibition at the British Museum, opening on Thursday, features the anorak as an example of Inuit technology in the Canadian Arctic. The museum describes it as a simple design of great effectiveness. In the Inuit language annuraaq means a piece of clothing.

Madonna finds her ideal home

Madonna, recently married to film director Guy Ritchie, has bought a £5.7m four-storey Georgian terrace house in the West End of London after three years of house hunting.

C4 rapped over wrestling

The independent television commission criticised Channel 4 for allowing violent scenes to be transmitted in an American wrestling programme last October at a time when many children were viewing. In one sequence a wrestler threatened an opponent's aide with a sledgehammer.

webTitle: US missile shield 'would cost UK billions'

fields.headline: Missile shield 'would cost UK billions'
fields.trailText: British participation in the planned US missile defence shield - dubbed "son of star wars" - would be extremely expensive, Sir Charles Guthrie, the chief of defence staff, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
British participation in the planned US missile defence shield - dubbed "son of star wars" - would be extremely expensive, Sir Charles Guthrie, the chief of defence staff, warned yesterday.

He said the proposed US national missile defence system was regarded in Washington as a "moral issue", a matter of defending the American people against so called "rogue nations". Sir Charles is known to be concerned that the system threatens Nato solidarity and in particular the traditional concept that all allies must share equal risks.

"What I think we have to do is talk to the Americans, the rest of Europe has to talk to America, and make quite sure that the balance of destruction in the world is not made worse by this - I don't see why it should be."

Sir Charles also insisted that EU plans for joint European peacekeeping operations must not be allowed to divide Nato.

webTitle: Downing tells of pressure to admit killing

fields.headline: Downing tells of pressure to admit killing
fields.trailText: Stephen Downing, released after 27 years behind bars for a murder he says he did not commit, spoke yesterday of the pressure he faced to admit his "guilt" while in prison.
fields.body:
Stephen Downing, released after 27 years behind bars for a murder he says he did not commit, spoke yesterday of the pressure he faced to admit his "guilt" while in prison.

Downing, 44, was granted bail last Wednesday pending an appeal hearing that is likely to quash his conviction for the murder of the typist Wendy Sewell, 32, in 1973.

He could have walked free 10 years ago - the judge at his trial had set a 17-year tariff - but he persisted in claiming innocence. The Home Office classified him as an IDOM, a prisoner "in denial of murder", and he could not be released.

Downing claimed yesterday that he was at one time offered a move to a more amenable prison if he admitted the crime: "They told me I could go to a nice warm prison if only I would admit to murder, that I should stop causing trouble for them and myself.

"They denied me my right to have a parole hearing because they said I was 'in denial'.

"During my whole 27 years in prison, the staff would try to persuade me to confess. It seems as if they were having some sort of competition to see who could be the one that made me finally admit it.

"It was always pressure, pressure, pressure. But I was optimistic that we would win in the end. It was hard work, but I believed in my cause. I believed in myself. I wanted to clear my name."

Downing was convicted of Mrs Sewell's murder at Nottingham crown court after her body was found beaten in the cemetery in Bakewell, Derbyshire, where he worked as a groundsman.

Following his release from prison he is adjusting to the world outside prison. A world he has not seen for more than a quarter of a century. He just wants to live as normal a life as possible.

He told a Sunday newspaper that he planned to find work, get his own house, pass his driving test and perhaps get married and settle in Bakewell.

"I'm aware there are people in Bakewell who will always believe I am guilty. If they want to have a go, then fine. I will have endured a lot worse in prison.

"I have nothing but contempt for the people who killed Wendy. They are the lowest of the low. They are scum.

"They not only killed Mrs Sewell, they robbed me of what should have been the best years of my life."

Urging local people with information about the crime to come forward, he added: "There has been a killer walking around Bakewell for 27 years, and he got away scot free.

"It is not too late for them to be punished for what happened that day."

Derbyshire police, who have said they would not consider reopening the murder case until the outcome of the appeal, refused to comment on claims by the Mail on Sunday that detectives had identified four suspects in a new, unofficial investigation.

The paper claimed that two suspects' passports had been confiscated while two others were under surveillance.

webTitle: Croats turn on leaders for hunting 'war criminals'

fields.headline: Croats turn on leaders for hunting 'war criminals'
fields.trailText: Croatia's year-old democracy was confronting its biggest challenge last night when around 100,000 nationalists took to the streets of the Adriatic port of Split in protest at government attempts to bring alleged war criminals to book.
fields.body:
Croatia's year-old democracy was confronting its biggest challenge last night when around 100,000 nationalists took to the streets of the Adriatic port of Split in protest at government attempts to bring alleged war criminals to book.

The scale of the weekend's protests, after four days of smaller actions and the erection of roadblocks across the country, stunned President Stipe Mesic and the centre-left government of Ivica Racan, the prime minister.

Mr Racan pledged to stand firm behind the rule of law, but the eruption orchestrated by hardline heirs of the late authoritarian president, Franjo Tudjman, suggested a rightwing attempt to topple the government elected a year ago.

"It would be exaggerated to speak of an attempted coup d'etat," Mr Mesic said, [but] "what is happening is organised destruction, a premeditated scenario. Only naive people could think this was happening spontaneously."

The protests highlighted the potency of the war crimes issue as a political rallying point and its capacity to make or break governments, not only in Croatia but across the former Yugoslavia. Senior officials in Belgrade yesterday stressed again that they would not extradite Slobodan Milosevic, the deposed Yugoslav president and indicted war criminal, to the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

The Split rally was triggered by a manhunt for a Croatian general who is suspected of being involved in the murder of dozens of Serb civilians in the 1991 war of independence.

Retired general Mirko Norac, the wartime commander of Croatian forces in Gospic, south-west of Zagreb, went missing on Thursday after prosecutors said they wanted to question him about the abduction and murder of some 40 Serb civilians in the region in October 1991.

To nationalists, Gen Norac is a war hero who helped defend Croatia against Serb rebels and the Yugoslav army in 1991.

Six men have been in detention since last year in connection with the murders. Gen Norac's deputy was arrested last week, and some witnesses have testified that Gen Norac chaired a "death meeting" in 1991 at which he ordered the execution of the abducted Serbs. He is also said to have taken part in the killings. Some of the dead were exhumed from a mass grave in the area in December.

A decade of virulently nationalist leadership in Croatia imploded last year with the death of Tudjman and the disintegration of his Democratic Union, or HDZ. The new government of social democrats and liberals and the new president shifted their sights towards the west.They won plaudits for liberal reforms on free media, human rights, for curbing the corruption of the Tudjman era, and for cooperating with the Hague tribunal.

The nationalists, accusing the government of treason, are seeking to turn the war crimes issue into their ticket back to power. Their case is helped by the fact that Serbia has yet to turn any indicted war criminals over to the Hague.

Tudjman's HDZ followers organised yesterday's Split rally, bussing thousands of people in from the Dalmatian hinterland across the border in Bosnia-Herzegovina, the heartland of Croatian nationalists. "Mirko Norac is a hero," said Ivo Sanader, the HDZ leader. "I don't know of another case in which a state is ashamed of its generals."

fields.headline: Freed man's father aided Democrats
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Former president Bill Clinton was yesterday involved in fresh controversy over his last-minute granting of pardons and commutations of sentences, when it emerged that the father of a freed cocaine dealer had contributed heavily to the Democratic party after his son's conviction.
fields.body:
Former president Bill Clinton was yesterday involved in fresh controversy over his last-minute granting of pardons and commutations of sentences, when it emerged that the father of a freed cocaine dealer had contributed heavily to the Democratic party after his son's conviction.

The revelation will increase the growing scepticism about the motives for the pardons, which were granted in the dying hours of the Clinton administration last month.

Carlos Vignali, 30, who served six years of a 15-year sentence for federal narcotics violations, was freed following the commutation by Mr Clinton. He was convicted in 1994 for being part of a ring that transported 800lb of cocaine from California to Minnesota to convert into crack.

The decision to release a major drug dealer raised eyebrows, although attention has earlier focussed on other controversial pardons, such as that of the financier Marc Rich, and of Mr Clinton's brother who had been convicted on a cocaine charge.

It has emerged that Carlos Vignali's father, Horacio, a Los Angeles entrepreneur, became a major political donor in the years after his son's arrest, giving more than $160,000 to state and federal officeholders, including the current Democratic governor of California, Gray Davis, who is a likely contender for the party's 2004 presidential nomination.

Mr Vignali's father told the Los Angeles Times that the freeing of his son was "a miracle". He had not written to the president to ask for his help, "but I thank God, and I thank the president every day". Others were more sceptical.

"It's not plausible, it makes no sense at all," said Margaret Love, the lawyer who oversaw all justice department reviews of presidential clemency applications from 1990 to 1997. "Somebody had to help him. There is no way that case could have possibly succeeded in the department of justice."

Craig Cascarano, a lawyer for one of Mr Vignali's 30 co-defendants, many of them poor and black, said: "How is it that Carlos Vignali is out eating a nice dinner while my client is still in prison eating bologna sandwiches?"

A federal prosecutor who had urged the justice department to reject clemency for Mr Vignali demanded an explanation. The judge who sentenced him was also furious.

It has emerged that after Mr Vignali was convicted in Minnesota, the authorities there were contacted by people active in politics in California to urge clemency. His father has said that he does not know who made the calls.

webTitle: Labour reels as coalition talks split Israeli left

fields.headline: Labour reels as coalition talks split Israeli left
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Labour party, the erstwhile bastion of the Israeli establishment, appeared to be heading towards collective suicide yesterday with deep splits opening over the prospect of an alliance with the hardline prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
The Labour party, the erstwhile bastion of the Israeli establishment, appeared to be heading towards collective suicide yesterday with deep splits opening over the prospect of an alliance with the hardline prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon.

As Shimon Peres, Labour's elder statesman, declared yesterday his willingness to serve Mr Sharon as foreign minister in a national unity coalition, several figures in the party, including its leading dove, Yossi Beilin, were poised to make their exit.

"We have in the Labour party a leadership crisis," Eli Goldschmidt said.

Mr Goldschmidt resigned from parliament in spectacular fashion last week, saying the party was a "den of backstabbers", who put personal ambitions before the interests of the party and the country.

Another Labour leader, Uzi Baram, also announced his resignation yesterday after nearly 25 years in parliament, saying the party needed to rebuild after the devastating defeat of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, in last week's elections.

"I believe there is a real need for a change of generations," Mr Baram said. "The party has to set a new platform and work towards reviving itself after the blow we received."

It may have to do so without Mr Beilin, who began discussions yesterday for the formation of a new social democratic force with the leftwing Meretz party.

Never a cohesive force, Labour's divisions became starkly apparent during the election campaign, with key figures - including Mr Peres - working behind the scenes to bring down Mr Barak.

"I am sure that more than one or two members of the [Labour] leadership were happier than Ariel Sharon himself with the election results," Mr Goldschmidt, in charge of publicity for Mr Barak's campaign, said.

With negotiations underway for a unity government, those ugly rivalries have been exposed to full public view. But many argue that a coalition with Mr Sharon could prove even more damaging, by robbing Labour of its one selling point: its willingness to make the painful compromises needed for a peace deal with the Palestinians.

"If there is a national unity government, it will be evident that the differences between Labour as the main branch of the left and the Likud as the main branch of the right are not that big," Mr Goldschmidt said.

Mr Barak, who led a second session of coalition talks with Mr Sharon yesterday, thinks otherwise. Yesterday, he led the Israeli cabinet in disowning the compromises offered to the Palestinians at last month's talks in the Egyptian Red Sea resort of Taba.

Mr Peres also supports the Likud stand against picking up negotiations where they left off, as the Palestinians demand.

"It is important for the country and for the nation to have peace," Mr Peres told Israel Radio yesterday. "Labour has to follow the needs of the country."

But that stand has infuriated the stalwarts of the left in Labour, including Mr Beilin, the foreign minister Shlomo Ben Ami, and the peace activist Yael Dayan.

At a recent party meeting, Mr Beilin rounded on Mr Peres, screaming: "You are a man of peace, a man of truth. Don't give him [Sharon] legitimacy around the world."

Israeli commentators now predict that a unity coalition, which looked like a very real possibility yesterday, could kill off Labour entirely. "The birth of such a government could well signal the death of the Labour party," the Ha'aretz columnist Akiva Eldar said.

Mr Sharon is desperate to form a national unity government to achieve some measure of stability.

His Likud party has just 19 seats in the badly fractured 120-seat parliament that he inherited from Mr Barak.

However, Mr Sharon faces pressure from Labour to moderate his hardline stance by agreeing to a freeze on Jewish settlements in Palestinian areas. He is also being asked to spell out his policies for negotiations with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

"We want to see if Mr Sharon really has a policy of pursuing peace," Ophir Pines-Paz, a Labour representative in the coalition negotiations, said.

fields.headline: Tidy the house, or I'll see you in court
fields.trailText: Failure to dust and tidy gives husbands grounds to divorce wives, Italy's highest court ruled at the weekend. A messy home was judged akin to a messy life and therefore a violation of the duties of cohabitation.
fields.body:
Failure to dust and tidy gives husbands grounds to divorce wives, Italy's highest court ruled at the weekend. A messy home was judged akin to a messy life and therefore a violation of the duties of cohabitation.

A pensioner from the southern port of Bari was declared solely responsible for the break-up of her 50-year marriage after photographs of domestic disorder were produced in court. Named only as Maria Cristina V, she was accused of betraying her husband and four adult children by disdaining housework.

"The lack of interest of the wife who neglected the cleaning and order of the house confirmed total lack of interest for the rules of civil life," said the panel of judges. Her husband, Vincenzo C, was awarded sole possession of the family home and a cut in maintenance payments.

Feminists have been infuriated by judgments by the supreme court which appear at odds with progressive legislation intended to roll back macho culture. Governments have refrained from challenging the judiciary's autonomy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Armenian visit fuels row
The first state visit to France by an Armenian president starts today amid high and rising tension between France and Turkey. In January the French parliament decided to recognise as genocide the mass killing of Armenians in eastern Turkey in 1915.
fields.body:
Armenian visit fuels row
The first state visit to France by an Armenian president starts today amid high and rising tension between France and Turkey. In January the French parliament decided to recognise as genocide the mass killing of Armenians in eastern Turkey in 1915.

The vote, opposed by France's president, prime minister and most of the business community, prompted Turkey to recall its ambassador to Paris, cancel dozens of deals with French companies and ban them from tendering for Turkish contracts.

One Nation tips the balance
The Australian Labor party won a three-seat majority in Western Australia's state election yesterday, after the ruling conservative coalition lost votes to the controversial One Nation party, led by Pauline Hanson.

One Nation, which runs on an anti-immigration platform, won more than 9% of the vote, and its strategy of instructing supporters to put sitting MPs last on the preferential ballot papers helped unseat at least 12 coalition members.

McVeigh wants TV execution
Timothy McVeigh, convicted of the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995 which killed 168 people, wants his execution by lethal injection to be shown on public television.

McVeigh said in a letter published yesterday in the newspaper The Oklahoman that he did not object to a closed-circuit broadcast of his execution on May 16, but questioned how such a telecast could allow equal access to the 250 people who have expressed an interest in watching.

webTitle: Railtrack seeks new chairman as criticism grows

fields.headline: Railtrack seeks new chairman as criticism grows
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Paddington train crash
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack has bowed to increasing pressure from the government and is expected to appoint a new chairman before the election in an attempt to head off mounting criticism of the company.
fields.body:
Railtrack has bowed to increasing pressure from the government and is expected to appoint a new chairman before the election in an attempt to head off mounting criticism of the company.

The company announced yesterday that it hoped to have the new appointment in place "within weeks".

Railtrack's present chairman, Sir Philip Beck, is not due to finish until July but would be willing to stand down earlier when a suitable successor is found.

Sir Philip has led an intensive search to find a candidate willing to take on one of the most difficult jobs in British industry.

Several names have been mentioned, including Bill Cockburn, number three at British Telecom and a former chief executive at the Post Office, and David Jones, the chief executive of the National Grid who is to leave the energy company in March.

Reports over the weekend suggest that Ross Sayers of Innogy now heads the list - but Railtrack dismissed his prospects. The prime minister's own favourite is David James, who is in charge of selling off the Dome.

Senior Railtrack executives are angry at the level of political interference in the internal affairs of a quoted company.

But they recognise that the appointment of a new chairman would enable the company to assuage public criticism.

Insiders acknowledge that the swift appointment of a new chairman is vital to allow the company to move on after the disastrous Hatfield rail crash last October. Privately, RaIltrack managers fear the worst from the forthcoming report by Lord Cullen into the Paddington rail crash in October 1999.

The new chairman is likely to cut a swathe through senior Railtrack management and is likely to overshadow Stephen Marshall, Railtrack's new chief executive.

Railtrack's continuing problems will be underlined later this week by revelations that it has fallen well behind in maintaining the network after Hatfield. More than 100 sites of rail cracking still have to be repaired.
