webTitle: Black Americans step up fight for slavery redress

fields.headline: Black Americans step up fight for slavery redress
fields.standfirst: Top lawyers join wide-ranging action to force US government to pay compensation at home and abroad for damage done by oppression
fields.trailText: Top lawyers join wide-ranging action to force US government to pay compensation at home and abroad for damage done by oppression.
fields.body:
A lawsuit against the US government by some of the country's top attorneys and a daily mass lobby of Congress are two of the strategies now being planned in the long-running battle for reparations to black Americans for centuries of slavery.

Johnnie Cochrane, who defended OJ Simpson and is currently defending the rapper and music producer Sean "Puff Daddy" Combs on a firearms charge in New York, is a member of the legal team which is examining the possibility of making the US government compensate the descendants of slaves.

The issue of reparations has been the subject of intermittent debate in the US for nearly 150 years. But now proponents of the compensation scheme say there is sufficient public support for action that would get the government to acknowledge that much of the wealth of the country, and some of its most admired educational institutions, were built on the back of slavery.

A spokesman for Trans-Africa, the organisation which has spearheaded a movement to influence US policies towards Africa and the Caribbean, said yesterday that a number of new initiatives were "in the works". Among them are the legal action in which Mr Cochrane and other leading attorneys, such as Charles Ogeltree and Alexander Pires, are working. Mr Pires won a $1bn settlement in a class discrimination action on behalf of black farmers.

Randall Robinson, author of The Debt - What America Owes to Blacks, gave details of the planned lawsuit. "Our government has been complicit in the longest running crime against humanity in the world over the last 500 years - 246 years of slavery and a century of de jure discrimination based on race that followed it," he said.

Mr Robinson, president and founder of Trans-Africa, said the result of slavery was a gap which existed to this day between blacks and whites "in income, in financial assets - in almost every social category, blacks still lag the American mainstream. Whenever a government does something like this, it is commonplace now in the world that the government is obliged to make the victims whole. Under international law and precepts of common decency, we are going to pursue this gap that separates blacks and whites."

Mr Robinson argues that even such hallowed American institutions as Harvard law school, of which he is a graduate, and Georgetown University were endowed through the sale of slaves, yet "the people who built the wealth were never paid".

On the political front, Mr Robinson believes that the case can be pressed politically by what he calls a "year of black presence". During it, every black church, organisation and institution would choose one of the 130-odd days that Congress is in session and bring on that day 1,000 African Americans to walk the halls of Congress in support of compensation "to close the economic and psychic gap between blacks and whites".

"Congress for one year would never stop seeing our faces, never stop hearing our demands, never be relieved of our presence," he said.

A Trans-Africa spokesman said this was just one of many measures being prepared. There is widespread resentment in black political circles at the way in which President George Bush was elected and at what was seen as the disenfranchisement of many black voters in Florida. It is believed that this may help to fuel new forms of black political activity.

The movement has been encouraged by the introduction last month of a new law in California which requires every insurance company to declare any "slave insurance" policies it offered in the 19th century. Black Democrats including Jesse Jackson Jr, a congressman from Chicago, have proposed legislation to examine ways in which reparation could be made.

White and black critics of compensation claim that it is backward-looking, reinforces a victim mentality and would be impossible to administer in any meaningful way. But at least 10 cities, including Washington, Chicago and Detroit, have passed resolutions calling for federal hearings on the lasting effects of slavery.

Mr Robinson also believes that the US government has a debt to the countries the slaves were taken from. Such recompense to African and Caribbean countries should take the form of full debt relief, fair trade terms and financial compensation, he says.

The issue has been complicated by schemes, many of them bogus, which offer African Americans the chance to receive up to $500,000 in government compensation if they pay a sum, usually $50, to register their claim. These schemes have been attacked by black politicians because no money has yet been offered and there is no real possibility of these people receiving anything in the near future.

Path to reparations

1637 First American slave ship, the Desire, sets sail

1800 By beginning of 19th century up to 15m Africans had been transported as slaves to the Americas

1865 Emancipation of slaves.

1866 Congressional move to compensate ex-slaves with 40 acres and a mule, as promised by union army general William Sherman, vetoed by President Andrew Johnson. Some blacks receive land under the Southern Homestead Act

1900 onwards Various bills in Congress to pay redress fail

1915 Cornelius Jones sues US treasury for $68m, arguing that government benefited from tax on cotton produced by slaves. Appeals court ruled government could not be sued without its consent.

1963 Martin Luther King calls for reparations with a 'bill of a rights for disadvantaged'

1965 US government unsuccessfully sued for $500,000 for each descendant of a slave

2000 California law requires insurance companies that offered slave insurance policies to publicise the fact

webTitle: Chinese officials seize 18 baby boys in dawn raids

fields.headline: Chinese officials seize 18 baby boys in dawn raids
fields.trailText: Officials in a south Chinese town have snatched 18 adopted infant boys from parents who four months later are still desperately awaiting their return.
fields.body:
Officials in a south Chinese town have snatched 18 adopted infant boys from parents who four months later are still desperately awaiting their return.

The seizures have renewed popular opposition to the official one-child policy.

"We've all gone mad in our family," says Xu Xongji, whose child was taken at five in the morning from his home.

The boy's distraught grandmother watches the street outside all day long. If someone comes by with a young child, she runs out and tries to grab it, crying: "Give me back my grandson."

Mr Xu has abandoned his repair shop business to search for the boy. The authorities have tried to conceal the whereabouts of the children from their former families.

The 18 boys, aged between one and two, came to the attention of officials in Jinjiang City, Fujian province, during the national census in September. Parents throughout China were assured that they could report the existence of children without fear of reprisal if their papers were not in order.

But Jinjiang's family planning department mounted a dawn raid to "relocate" the boys, who contravened regulations.

Five had been informally adopted by infertile couples. The other 13 belonged to families which already had - legally - two girls. The parents said they were adopted, although in some cases this may be a euphemism for a third child born secretly.

The one-child policy has been relaxed in rural areas to allow parents with a girl to try for a boy. But if the second child is also a girl, they are not allowed to try again.

"They knocked on the door and told me to open up before it was light," says Zhang Qingjie, 30 "They said they were checking our household registration. One official went straight to the bedroom and seized the infant."

Ms Zhang was told that the boy was being confiscated. "He's not just a dumb object," she complains. "He already calls me Mama." Ms Zhang has searched for her child every day since he was taken.

The affair has been exposed by the popular newspaper Southern Weekend.

UN health experts say that in recent years Chinese officials in many regions have become more flexible in implementing population controls. There have even been a few experiments in lifting controls altogether.

But cases of local officials in rural areas using force against parents who fall foul of the regulations are still common.

Jinjiang family planning officials were unable to quote any section of the law under which they were entitled to seize the children. They said the adoptive parents had not followed procedures, and that those with a third child were in breach of the regulations.

But Fujian provincial law provides only for fines to be levied if controls are breached, not for seizure of the child.

Some parents who wrestled with the "confiscators" or protested too vigorously afterwards were jailed for two weeks. The city government also issued a report, claiming that it had acted "with meticulous care to adjust the situation ... of infants being cared for illegally".

Officials are worried about losing face if they hand back the infants.

Several of the adopting families have been told that they can have another child without fear of punishment if they stop complaining about the one they have lost.

"We want the one back we have raised," says one couple in response. "Besides, we have a responsibility to his natural parents."

webTitle: Comment: Our civil service is an embarrasment

fields.headline: The culture that mishandles earthquakes (and our babies)
fields.standfirst:
We used to be so proud of our civil service. Now it's an embarrassment

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: We used to be so proud of our civil service. Now it's an embarrassment
fields.body:
It has been impossible to travel in India, these past three disastrous weeks, and not feel chilled by one special aftershock of tragedy. A terrible earthquake, thousands dead, a million homeless - and a governmental machine that simply failed to cope. The chill of the crisis, for a visitor from Britain, is one of recognition. It is the red tape that binds.

Caveats first. Any nation, no matter how developed, would have struggled to cope with the quake that rocked Gujarat. The help flooding in from abroad has been magnificent. The reaction from New Delhi has gathered momentum. There has been a formidable rallying round, a sharing of grief and resolve. This is not a story for shame: when the earth shakes, the flimsy constructs of grinding poverty collapse. You may even take the predictable outrages in your stride. There were always going to be fly-by-night property developers who built frail apartment blocks; there were always going to be seedy operators at Ahmedabad railway station who wanted their palms greased before letting the blankets, tents and medicines through. What is harder to bear is the crushing weight of inert bureaucracy.

Could a Japanese team get its relief supplies out of the airport? Not for two days, because the name of the consignee had to be changed. Could the hungry and desolate on the streets find succour? Only if they queued to get a chit that enabled them to queue again for help. The form-filling that dominates Indian life never ceases.

And yet, 54 years ago when we quit the subcontinent, the greatest boon we left behind was a civil service built to Whitehall specifications. A framework for relatively efficient democratic administration, a machine that worked. Whatever became of it?

Some of the answers to that question are, of course, particular ones. Factor in the strain of running a country with 1bn inhabitants. Factor in Nehru's socialist ideals, which saw the state as the provider of jobs and patronage (however small), the ultimate tool of social control. Factor in corruption and federal glitches and the inevitable chaos of politics. Nevertheless, the chill remains.

There was a feeling of hope for the Indians who emerged from a century of direct British rule, a belief that - with government in their own hands at last - they could change their world. More than political faith: a faith in their own talents and enterprise. A post in government then was a prize worth having if you were educated and idealistic and potentially brilliant. It put you at the centre of affairs. The brightest and the best wanted that chance. And now? Government, almost universally, is seen as the problem, not the solution. The brightest and the best want to be in medicine or the hi-tech industries of Bangalore, Hyderabad and California. Public administration belongs to the place men and, at higher levels, to a fading generation of generalist intellects. It has no cachet. On the contrary, it is reviled. As the years pass, the ability to attract fresh talent wanes inexorably. Things get worse because they can only get worse as the talent pool empties.

Consider an editorial in the Hindu looking at two Delhi responses to Gujarat: a permanent disaster-management committee (including politicians across the spectrum) and a parallel group of ministers to deal with natural calamities. "But there are already crisis-management groups from the districts upwards, with the apex occupied by a committee headed by no less an official than the cabinet secretary. Yet, as a string of events has shown, all these committees either exist only on paper or are totally ineffectual in their responses."

Please, no more committees shuffling decisions ever further into forgetfulness. Please, if there's to be a new national disaster-management authority, then give it a clear run at banging heads together. The nasty comparison between a floundering Gujarat government in the first days after the earthquake and the honed speed of the international NGOs bringing relief has been painfully drawn. Sometimes, you just need to get on with the job. Always, it is results that count.

Here's the wider debate, the long-distance stretching of the red tape. India's civil service has sunk ever lower in public esteem, a self- fulfilling prophesy of inadequacy. And what of the heirs of the men who founded it, the current denizens of Whitehall? Have they proved immune to the same desultory trends - or are they, too, part of the problem? You return to a Britain where an NHS culture of "arrogance born of indifference" saw a hundred babies die from botched heart operations, where customs and excise has just lost £668m on a sting, where the aftershocks of BSE linger, where the throngs of asylum seekers awaiting a decision on their fate swells exponentially, where the crazily privatised trains don't run on time.

It is no secret that Tony Blair, after four years at the top, is depressed and infuriated by our own civil service's inability to deliver. He's into targets and incentives and monitoring: all the usual sub-McKinsey apparatus. But the lesson of India, I think, casts a longer shadow. What drags Delhi's public administrators down is a lack of pride and an absence of respect. They are, for the people they purport to serve, the enemy. And what young men and women coming onstream would want to be part of a service like that?

Do we present a keener, clearer prospect? Not really. You couldn't, a quarter of a century on, write a TV series like Yes, Minister. Sir Humphreydom is dead and gone. But there is nothing - no new image - to put in its place. All we have is a bewilderment of separate agencies and authorities and infernal committees without the hint of a career structure to them. They are blamed for their inadequacies: ministers have grown accustomed to playing the blame game. They are never loved and, thus, they languish without morale. Would you, as a matter of fact, want to join the immigration teams interviewing asylum seekers? Does that sound like a good job?

These are common, not isolated themes. Indians, talking in the aftermath of the earthquake, are commonsensical about the democratic challenge they face. Somehow they have to rebuild a trust in the mechanisms of their governance - for, without it, nothing is possible. The fabric of the state lies in pawn. And here, where the fabric of India was first woven? We have no earthquake to jolt us into desperate introspection, but we are still part of the same modern crisis.

A world that exalts private enterprise and wealth creation automatically drains the reservoirs of public service dry. Not a value judgment, a fact. So what's delivered fades; so what can be delivered shrinks. That isn't a challenge that ends at the Gujarat border. It's one that came home with me.

fields.bodyText: It has been impossible to travel in India, these past three disastrous weeks, and not feel chilled by one special aftershock of tragedy. A terrible earthquake, thousands dead, a million homeless - and a governmental machine that simply failed to cope. The chill of the crisis, for a visitor from Britain, is one of recognition. It is the red tape that binds. Caveats first. Any nation, no matter how developed, would have struggled to cope with the quake that rocked Gujarat. The help flooding in from abroad has been magnificent. The reaction from New Delhi has gathered momentum. There has been a formidable rallying round, a sharing of grief and resolve. This is not a story for shame: when the earth shakes, the flimsy constructs of grinding poverty collapse. You may even take the predictable outrages in your stride. There were always going to be fly-by-night property developers who built frail apartment blocks; there were always going to be seedy operators at Ahmedabad railway station who wanted their palms greased before letting the blankets, tents and medicines through. What is harder to bear is the crushing weight of inert bureaucracy. Could a Japanese team get its relief supplies out of the airport? Not for two days, because the name of the consignee had to be changed. Could the hungry and desolate on the streets find succour? Only if they queued to get a chit that enabled them to queue again for help. The form-filling that dominates Indian life never ceases. And yet, 54 years ago when we quit the subcontinent, the greatest boon we left behind was a civil service built to Whitehall specifications. A framework for relatively efficient democratic administration, a machine that worked. Whatever became of it? Some of the answers to that question are, of course, particular ones. Factor in the strain of running a country with 1bn inhabitants. Factor in Nehru's socialist ideals, which saw the state as the provider of jobs and patronage (however small), the ultimate tool of social control. Factor in corruption and federal glitches and the inevitable chaos of politics. Nevertheless, the chill remains. There was a feeling of hope for the Indians who emerged from a century of direct British rule, a belief that - with government in their own hands at last - they could change their world. More than political faith: a faith in their own talents and enterprise. A post in government then was a prize worth having if you were educated and idealistic and potentially brilliant. It put you at the centre of affairs. The brightest and the best wanted that chance. And now? Government, almost universally, is seen as the problem, not the solution. The brightest and the best want to be in medicine or the hi-tech industries of Bangalore, Hyderabad and California. Public administration belongs to the place men and, at higher levels, to a fading generation of generalist intellects. It has no cachet. On the contrary, it is reviled. As the years pass, the ability to attract fresh talent wanes inexorably. Things get worse because they can only get worse as the talent pool empties. Consider an editorial in the Hindu looking at two Delhi responses to Gujarat: a permanent disaster-management committee (including politicians across the spectrum) and a parallel group of ministers to deal with natural calamities. "But there are already crisis-management groups from the districts upwards, with the apex occupied by a committee headed by no less an official than the cabinet secretary. Yet, as a string of events has shown, all these committees either exist only on paper or are totally ineffectual in their responses." Please, no more committees shuffling decisions ever further into forgetfulness. Please, if there's to be a new national disaster-management authority, then give it a clear run at banging heads together. The nasty comparison between a floundering Gujarat government in the first days after the earthquake and the honed speed of the international NGOs bringing relief has been painfully drawn. Sometimes, you just need to get on with the job. Always, it is results that count. Here's the wider debate, the long-distance stretching of the red tape. India's civil service has sunk ever lower in public esteem, a self- fulfilling prophesy of inadequacy. And what of the heirs of the men who founded it, the current denizens of Whitehall? Have they proved immune to the same desultory trends - or are they, too, part of the problem? You return to a Britain where an NHS culture of "arrogance born of indifference" saw a hundred babies die from botched heart operations, where customs and excise has just lost £668m on a sting, where the aftershocks of BSE linger, where the throngs of asylum seekers awaiting a decision on their fate swells exponentially, where the crazily privatised trains don't run on time. It is no secret that Tony Blair, after four years at the top, is depressed and infuriated by our own civil service's inability to deliver. He's into targets and incentives and monitoring: all the usual sub-McKinsey apparatus. But the lesson of India, I think, casts a longer shadow. What drags Delhi's public administrators down is a lack of pride and an absence of respect. They are, for the people they purport to serve, the enemy. And what young men and women coming onstream would want to be part of a service like that? Do we present a keener, clearer prospect? Not really. You couldn't, a quarter of a century on, write a TV series like Yes, Minister. Sir Humphreydom is dead and gone. But there is nothing - no new image - to put in its place. All we have is a bewilderment of separate agencies and authorities and infernal committees without the hint of a career structure to them. They are blamed for their inadequacies: ministers have grown accustomed to playing the blame game. They are never loved and, thus, they languish without morale. Would you, as a matter of fact, want to join the immigration teams interviewing asylum seekers? Does that sound like a good job? These are common, not isolated themes. Indians, talking in the aftermath of the earthquake, are commonsensical about the democratic challenge they face. Somehow they have to rebuild a trust in the mechanisms of their governance - for, without it, nothing is possible. The fabric of the state lies in pawn. And here, where the fabric of India was first woven? We have no earthquake to jolt us into desperate introspection, but we are still part of the same modern crisis. A world that exalts private enterprise and wealth creation automatically drains the reservoirs of public service dry. Not a value judgment, a fact. So what's delivered fades; so what can be delivered shrinks. That isn't a challenge that ends at the Gujarat border. webTitle: World cup soccer games could go to pay TV

fields.headline: World cup soccer games could go to pay TV
fields.standfirst: Britons might have to pay to see top teams as firm battles over rights
fields.trailText: British football fans may have to pay to watch teams such as Brazil, Argentina and France on television during next year's World Cup final tournament under controversial plans to sell rights to their matches to pay-per-view channels.
fields.body:
British football fans may have to pay to watch teams such as Brazil, Argentina and France on television during next year's World Cup final tournament under controversial plans to sell rights to their matches to pay-per-view channels.

Kirch, a German company which holds the European television rights to the 2002 and 2006 World Cup finals claims that it does not have to honour British legislation that all matches in the tournament must be televised live on free-to-air channels, giving all football fans the chance to see the world's leading teams.

Kirch, claims that it bought the rights to the two tournaments prior to the government's decision to list the World Cup as one of several sports events of national importance that must be screened live on a free-to-air basis under the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

The culture minister, Chris Smith, has written to Kirch outlining the law and insisting that the entire World Cup must be shown either on ITV or BBC television. The company continues to challenge the ruling and is planning an auction sale of the rights, which will be open to all broadcasters, pay-per-view as well as free-to-air, and this could result in court action between Kirch and the government.

If Kirch is successful the spectacle of next year's World Cup in Korea and Japan could be ruined for thousands of British football fans watching it at home with many matches shown on BSkyB or ONDigital.

For many, the main attraction of a World Cup is the opportunity to watch teams such as Brazil on free television.

The row between Kirch and the government stems from a directive from Fifa, world football's governing body that only matches involving the national team of a country have to be shown on free-to-air television along with the opening match of a World Cup tournament, semi-finals and finals. All other matches can be sold to the highest bidder.

Kirch insists that it bought the rights to the 2002 and 2006 World Cup finals in 1996, prior to the introduction of the Broadcasting Act of the same year which contains a list of protected sports events that must be shown on free-to-air television. The other events are the FA Cup final, the Grand National, the Olympic Games, the Derby, Wimbledon, rugby league and rugby union World Cup finals and the Scottish FA Cup final.

Kirch has said that it plans to sell World Cup television rights to the highest bidder in Britain over the coming months and that an auction will take place between rival companies. The company paid over £320m for the rights to the 2002 World Cup and over £350m for the rights to the 2006 tournament which will be held in Germany. It is expected to almost double its investment after the sale of rights across Europe.

A statement from the company said: "The auction rules stipulate that whatever the outcome of the auction the successful bidder will be required to ensure certain matches will be made available on free-to-air television. These matches are the opening match, the semi-final and the final and all national team matches. It is not the intention of Kirch to deny any football fans in the UK from watching these matches."

The statement adds: "The auction process and rights available will be open to all forms of broadcasters whether free-to-air television or pay television."

The government insists it drew up its protected events list in 1985, which was reviewed in 1991, and the fact that it is contained in the 1996 Broadcasting Act, prior to Kirch's buying of the rights, is irrelevant.

In a letter to Kirch, Mr Smith wrote that the listed events apply to all broadcasters regardless of when they bought sports rights for a particular event.

Mr Smith added: "I very much hope that the proposed sale of the rights in question will be done in accordance with the provisions of our legislation, so that British people will continue to be able to watch the whole of the finals tournament live on a free-to-air public service broadcasting platform."

The Independent Television Commission has also become involved in the dispute and has warned Kirch that all World Cup matches must be shown on free-to-air television otherwise the matter may have to be taken to court.

In a letter to Kirch, the ITC stated: "That Kirch purchased the rights to the 2002 World Cup prior to the 1996 Act coming into force is therefore irrelevant. In any event, Kirch should have been aware of the fact that the tournament was included on the UK list of events of national importance."

fields.headline: Jewellery marks 'clue' to pensioner's killer
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Murder hunt detectives are checking rings worn by neighbours of a pensioner who suffocated in a fire at the locked and boarded-up house where he had tried to hide from paedophile-hunting vigilantes.
fields.body:
Murder hunt detectives are checking rings worn by neighbours of a pensioner who suffocated in a fire at the locked and boarded-up house where he had tried to hide from paedophile-hunting vigilantes.

Evidence in the graffiti-sprayed council flat of Alfred Wilkins, 67, a retired trawlerman, is thought to include possible injuries to the body from jewellery in a struggle, according to residents on the Yarborough estate in Grimsby, Lincolnshire. Six local people have been arrested and police were still questioning three teenagers last night about the death of the mild but heavy-drinking father of three, who had been targeted after a jury acquitted him of indecently assaulting a nine-year-old girl.

Mr Wilkins was taken to hospital with a head wound following an earlier attack by youths on his flat, his windows were smashed, and he was followed and shouted at.

His body was found on Saturday beside the remains of his dog, Lucky, which children had often gone to pet and feed before the court case in November.

Humberside police said that forensic evidence suggested that someone had deliberately started a fire in the house, whose boarded-up windows - painted with the word "nonce" (sex offender) - prevented smoke from seeping out.

Three men were arrested shortly afterwards and released after questioning, but detectives last night were still interviewing an 18-year-old youth and a 16-year-old girl, both arrested on Saturday, and a 19-year-old youth who was held yesterday.

Police confirmed that the death was being treated as murder.

They also appealed for a woman to come forward who rang the force on Saturday night from a telephone kiosk, saying she had information. But by the time a police car arrived, she had vanished.

The father of the child involved in the court case, who cannot be named for legal reasons, said that he had gone to the police after hearing about the fire. He said: "I didn't do it, but I knew it wouldn't be long before I got a knock on my door."

Mr Wilkins was cleared at Grimsby crown court on three counts of assault.

The case came shortly after national publicity about residents' protests against alleged paedophiles on a Southampton estate.

Grimsby council had been planning to rehouse Mr Wilkins later this spring.

fields.headline: Bodies of two potholers recovered
fields.trailText: Cave rescue teams and police recovered the bodies of two potholers yesterday from a warren of underground passages in the Pennines which have a history of sudden flooding.
fields.body:
Cave rescue teams and police recovered the bodies of two potholers yesterday from a warren of underground passages in the Pennines which have a history of sudden flooding.

The victims were found trapped in Ireby Fell cavern near Kirkby Lonsdale, on the border between North Yorkshire, Lancashire and Cumbria, after their families rang police when they failed to return home.

They were named last night by North Yorkshire police as Ray Lea, 58, of Darlington, county Durham, and Julian Carroll, 29, of Tyne and Wear.

The two men had driven down from the north-east to explore the cave which plunges down a series of steep waterfalls before narrowing into a series of crawls ending in the first of six sumps, or permanently flooded passages accessible only to cave divers.

The cave was blocked for eight years after 1954, when a sudden storm and rain deluge caused an underground landslip which sealed the shakehole, or entrance chamber, where a small stream vanishes from the flank of Leck Fell.

Cavers from the Northern Pennine Club dug a way through in 1961 and the cave has become a favourite for training, but the menace of flash-flooding remains a hazard in bad weather.

A spokesman for North Yorkshire police said: "In the early hours of Sunday morning, two cavers were reported as having not returned home by family members. A search was instigated and the cavers' car was found near Masongill, close to the Lancashire-North Yorkshire border."

Rescue teams checked the two mile track and footpath to the cavern, one of a number of potholes which form a linked but part-flooded system beneath Leck and Ireby fells.

In pouring rain, they discovered a stack of caving equipment close to the first, nine metre high waterfall, which leads to a tougher, 12 metre drop.

The bodies were found shortly afterwards but atrocious weather for most of the morning made a recovery attempt too dangerous. The police said that a fully equipped team eventually went back into the cave yesterday afternoon.

The spokesman said: "The two bodies have been recovered and we are in the process of transferring them into the hands of undertakers who will be transferring them to the mortuary at the Royal Lancaster infirmary later."

Ireby Fell cavern includes two route deviations for potholers in trouble because of rising water, but heavy rain gives them little time.

The last caving fatality in the area was at Quaking Pot on Ingleborough fell in 1996, when a 24-year-old woman slipped off a climbing ladder and died after falling 40 ft.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

A consortium of carmakers led by the head of Fiat, Paolo Cantarella, is near to buying a 25% stake in formula one from Slec, the Ecclestone family trust that owns 50% of the sport. Mr Cantarella heads the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association, which includes BMW, Ferrari, Jaguar, Mercedes and Renault, each of which owns part or all of a formula one team. The stake could climb to 35% if Bernie Ecclestone (pictured) agrees to buy back some of the shares he previously sold to German media group EM.TV.

PA Consulting is close to agreeing a merger with Arthur D Little, its US peer. The new firm would have income of £208m a year and be the seventh largest management consulting group in the country.

Sunday Telegraph

Scottish Power is considering a disposal of its Southern Water subsidiary in a deal worth more than £1bn.

TV Travel, the company that broadcasts TV Travel shop on analogue and digital satellite and cable platforms, and TV Travel Shop 2 on Sky Digital, is thought to be planning a flotation. The company is 38% owned by Barclays Private Equity and 37% by Flextech.

Mail on Sunday

A Treasury insider has said that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is reviewing the tax position of oil companies following bumper profits of £9bn from Shell last week, and a £10bn profit expected from BP Amoco on Tuesday. The Treasury is thought to be contemplating a windfall tax on British companies, or a tax on North Sea oil exploitation. A report to be published by the energy consultancy Oil Price Assessment is expected to show very thin margins on petrol.

Sunday Express

Leisure Group De Vere looks set to defeat proposals by shareholder Guinness Peat Group to break the company up.

Observer

Computer services company EDS may make a £3bn-plus offer for Sema, the troubled Anglo-French software firm. EDS declined to comment on the speculation, but observers said it was a more logical buyer than Schlumberger, the US group with which Sema is in talks.

Oftel is understood to be considering taking firm action to force BT to widen rivals' access to its network. Internet service providers AOL Europe and Freeserve have both threatened legal action unless they are given adequate access to the BT network.

Sunday Business

Barclays is to strengthen its investment bank, developing a mergers and acquisitions division to bolt on to its wholesale capital markets operation.

Doubts are emerging about the rescue of troubled Equitable Life by the Halifax amid claims of pension-misselling by the life company's salesforce.

EGMs Edinburgh New Tiger, Gartmore Shared.

Interims Easyscreen (Q3), Interregnum, NetStore, P&O Princess Cruises (Q4), Transeda. Finals Alliance & Leicester, Autonomy, BG Group, Estates & General, Green Property,

Smith & Nephew. AGMs Bass, Holidaybreak, Lonmin.

EGMs Fleming Worldwide.

Friday

Interims None scheduled. Finals Lloyds TSB. AGMs De Vere. EGMs None scheduled.

JP BoJ monthly report.

fields.headline: New head mulls LSE name change
fields.trailText: The London Stock Exchange is considering changing its 228-year-old name, as part of a radical rebranding by new chief executive Clara Furse which could horrify City traditionalists.
fields.body:
The London Stock Exchange is considering changing its 228-year-old name, as part of a radical rebranding by new chief executive Clara Furse which could horrify City traditionalists.

Ms Furse, just a week into the job, told a Sunday newspaper that the exchange was keen to develop a more modern image, and to make a fresh start following its recent battle to defeat a hostile takeover bid from Sweden's OM Group.

In addition to a name change, she said the exchange could drop the coat of arms used as its logo, with the motto "Dictum Meum Pactum" - my word is my bond.

"We are looking at it," she was quoted as saying. "But it's a very emotional issue. We would proceed with caution."

The institutions was established in the 18th century by a group of brokers who met to take advantage of an explosion in the number of joint-stock companies. They originally met in the Royal Exchange but were kicked out for being too rowdy. They formed a club meeting instead at Jonathan's Coffee House in the City.

In 1773, the club voted to change its name to the London Stock Exchange, which has remained ever since.

Ms Furse is planning other changes. She intends to move the organisation out of its headquarters in Threadneedle Street by 2004. She is likely to press ahead with a flotation later this year. At present, shares in the exchange are traded on a matched bargain basis by stockbroker Cazenove.

fields.headline: Orange pricing leaves room for profit
fields.trailText: France Télécom will decide on a price tag for the hotly anticipated Orange flotation tonight, expected to be at the bottom end of the €9.5 (606p) to €11 (705p) range.
fields.body:
France Télécom will decide on a price tag for the hotly anticipated Orange flotation tonight, expected to be at the bottom end of the €9.5 (606p) to €11 (705p) range.

The mobile phone company is expected to be valued at about £30bn when it returns to the stock market.

The final decision will be made after executives from the French company have taken soundings from its advisers.

France Télécom is spinning off 15% of Orange - raising more than £60bn, including an exchangeable bond offer.

The shares will begin limited trading in Paris and London today, with full trading starting on Thursday. Retail investors seeking to buy fewer than 500 shares will be likely to get their whole allocation, a spokesman said yesterday.

IG Index, the spread-betting agency, predicted that shares would close between 660p and 680p - ensuring investors a healthy, if unspectacular, return.

Despite being two and a half times oversubscribed, Orange has been buffeted by turbulence in the mobile sector and has had to cut its floatation price by 18%.

Retail investors in Britain have also worried that the dual-nation listing could backlash in favour of French shareholders.

While France has an online system to notify investors of their allocated shares, British investors without access to their own broker must wait for the letter of allocation to arrive by post, meaning that they will not be able to trade until at least Thursday.

Orange's spokesman said that the new investors would not worry over this delay, since most of them considered the company to be "a long-term investment".

webTitle: Wonder drug not for the poor

fields.headline: Wonder drug not for the poor
fields.trailText: Biotechnology company Acambis is set to announce startling results from trials of a pioneering vaccine for deadly Japanese encephalitis.
fields.body:
Biotechnology company Acambis is set to announce startling results from trials of a pioneering vaccine for deadly Japanese encephalitis, using technology which could tackle other viral diseases such as dengue fever, hepatitis C and West Nile fever, writes Andrew Clark.

In a study using 36 volunteers, Acambis achieved 100% success in stimulating antibodies to counter Japanese encephalitis - a mosquito-borne virus which kills 10,000 people annually.

Acambis, formerly called Peptide Therapeutics, intends to target its vaccines initially at backpackers visiting developing countries rather than sell to the "at-risk" local population.

The Cambridge-based company, which has struggled due to several product failures over the last two years, is unlikely to make much money out of sales in poor countries, who are unable to afford hi-tech medicines.

fields.headline: L&G leads bids for pubs
fields.trailText: Insurance firm Legal & General and PizzaExpress millionaire Luke Johnson could emerge among Britain's most powerful pub landlords, as auctions reach a climax for thousands of pubs put up for sale by Bass and Whitbread.
fields.body:
Insurance firm Legal & General and PizzaExpress millionaire Luke Johnson could emerge among Britain's most powerful pub landlords, as auctions reach a climax for thousands of pubs put up for sale by Bass and Whitbread.

L&G Ventures, the venture capital arm of Legal & General, is understood to be the leading bidder for 1,000 local public houses put on the block by Bass, with an offer of more than £600m. Its closest rival is the Japanese bank Nomura, which already owns more than 4,500 houses nationwide.

Bass could be in a position to announce an outcome this week. The group, which intends to concentrate on its Inter-Continental and Holiday Inn hotel chains, is scheduled to release a trading update at its annual meeting on Thursday.

Meanwhile, Mr Johnson, who is better known for running restaurant chains such as Belgo and PizzaExpress, was reported over the weekend to have teamed up with Schroder Ventures to bid for Whitbread's £1.5bn pub estate.

When contacted yesterday, Mr Johnson declined to comment, saying: "It's Sunday afternoon. Call me another time. Goodbye."

Whitbread is selling its entire 3,000-strong pub estate, which includes the Hogshead and Dome bar chains. The company wants to concentrate on restaurants, such as Pizza Hut and Beefeater, hotels and health clubs. A clutch of financial buyers, including Candover and Nomura, have been mentioned as contenders, although several hundred rebel Whitbread licencees are demanding the right to buy their pubs. Whitbread expects to conclude the sale next month.

About 10% of Britain's 65,000 pubs are on the market, as companies concentrate on trendy branded bar chains, rather than neighbourhood ale houses. There has been speculation that some of these much hyped bar brands are on the wane.

fields.headline: Pomposity among the peeresses
fields.standfirst:
JS Mill would not have had much time for the Baroness Young

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: JS Mill would not have had much time for the Baroness Young.
fields.body:
Last Wednesday, I was filmed wearing peer's robes and a cloth cap as I carried a stuffed rottweiler and a tub of lard through one of the studios in BBC Television Centre. A week ago I would have taken it for granted that my brief contribution to Comic Relief's night of madness was certain to be the most disturbing experience of my media year. But it did not even produce the greatest trauma of my broadcasting day. That came about at the Channel 4 annual political awards lunch when, for one terrible moment, I feared that I might be exposed as the sort of man who attends ceremonies to honour Baroness Young.

Baroness Young is anxious to avoid confusion with her namesake - as witness a reproof she issued in the House of Lords on April 11: "It would help the whole debate if the noble baroness did not keep saying that there are two Baroness Youngs. If I may say so, I am the only Baroness Young while she is Baroness Young of Old Scone. We would not run into such difficulties if the noble baroness would refer to herself in that correct fashion on all occasions." Revealing though that quotation is, my desire not to be in any way associated with the one and only Baroness Young is not because of her absurd pomposity. My complaint is not that she is ineffably silly but that she is insufferably self-righteous.

In order to respect her wishes, I must make clear which Baroness Young I mean. I mean the one who battles to prevent an equalisation of the age of gay and heterosexual consent, who tried to prevent the "over-the-counter" (as she called it) sale of "morning after" contraceptive pills to women above the age of 16 and whose campaign against repeal of section 28 (a measure that would allow a sensible discussion of homosexuality) has made her the toast of homophobes everywhere. She is also the Baroness Young who says, without a hint of self-parody, "My concern, as always, is the protection of young people." The rest of us want to send little boys up chimneys and sell little girls into white slavery.

Although the Baroness Young of whom I write is always anxious to emphasise the support she receives from Muslims, her attitude towards morality is identical to the one that motivated the Third Crusade. She has no doubt about what is right. And she is determined to impose her principles on people who neither share her faith nor her views. No doubt in other contexts - for example, the right to make unrestrained profits - she regards herself as a libertarian. But her behaviour is in absolute conflict with the philosophy of John Stuart Mill. A man cannot be coerced for his own good. "All the errors which he is likely to commit against advice and warning are far outweighed by the evils of allowing others to constrain him for what they deem to be his good." Baroness Young exists to force her judgment on people she believes incapable of making sensible decisions about their own destiny.

Baroness Young feels entitled to behaving that way because she regards herself as a superior person. In that capacity she admonishes bishops. "The right reverend prelates will not be surprised to hear that I am very disappointed with what they said." Typically, that reproof implies that the whole episcopate is familiar with her prejudices. There are plenty to choose from. My favourite is: "I am doubtful about the value of sex education. It seems to me that the more sex education there has been, the more difficulties young people have experienced."

Perhaps the plea for ignorance was meant as a joke. It is always difficult to tell when Baroness Young means to be funny. After criticising the late Noel Annan for his views on homosexual equality, she announced that she was never sure if he had been provost of King's or master of Queen's; her noble friends guffawed in the belief that she was indulging a previously undetected passion for lavatory wall humour. Others assumed that she was simply out of touch with the real world. Either way it was not the sort of parliamentary rhetoric that usually wins awards.

Why then would Baroness Young exalt above all other peers last Wednesday? The exclamation was provided for me by a Labour baroness - one of the sharpest (in both senses of that word) people I know. Channel 4 drew up a shortlist of four names. At least one of them had to be a Tory and Baroness Young had made a constant nuisance of herself - more than could be said for most of her noble friends. The entire House of Lords was then invited to vote. The Labour vote being split three ways, the one Conservative in contention was bound to win. In fact, all that last Wednesday's little event proved was that Baroness Young is the sort of person Tory peers admire. And that does not surprise me in the slightest degree.

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Homicide | Casino | Star Treatment
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton, Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

Homicide (David Mamet, 1991) 8pm, FilmFour
Much of the violence of Mamet's dark, intense police thriller is in the language: his cops are unremittingly foul-mouthed. Joe Mantegna is a good cop uncovering an anti-Semitic conspiracy which forces him back to his own Jewish roots in a godforsaken world. William H Macy is his hard, unsympathetic partner.

Payback (Brian Helgeland,1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Mel Gibson had a falling out with director Helgeland, replacing him to reshoot and add new scenes to a thriller that isn't as hardboiled as it would like to be. It's a rerun of Point Blank, John Boorman's version of Richard Stark's novel The Hunter, with Gibson trying to fill the weighty Lee Marvin role as a hard-as-coffin-nails hood who is double-crossed, left for dead and returns to get even with the Outfit: "I just want my money back." Veterans Kris Kristofferson and James Coburn are among the heavies.

Casino (Martin Scorsese, 1995) 1.55am, FilmFour
The very essence of Scorsese: the story of a Las Vegas casino, and the mob men who milk it dry, told with audacious sweeps of the camera and unflinching gazes into the dark shadows behind the glittering facade. Robert De Niro is Ace, a Jewish gambler who is installed as owner of the Tangiers and finds every single day a struggle for survival. It's certainly another deeply impressive performance, but De Niro is upstaged by Sharon Stone's junkie hooker, Ginger. With James Woods doing hard, Joe Pesci doing crazy, it all seems a little familiar, perhaps even soulless, but this film is also a brutally compelling tale of greed and corruption.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Premiership Football 7pm, Sky Sports 1
If you're not a football fan, leave the country now. And don't bother going anywhere else in Europe, either. After a winter break, European football is back in all its slightly dubious glory and there's very little you can do about it. To get you in the mood, there's West Ham v Coventry in our very own Premiership. This is a warning.
Simon Burnton

Lifestyle

Star Treatment 9am, 5.10pm, Living
Have you ever wondered just who it was who glued Julia Roberts' hair extensions onto her scalp for that Notting Hill look? Or spent the weekend pondering where Coronation Street's Tracey Shaw likes to shop for her designer gear to wear to that oh-so-crucial 40th anniversary party? Or asked yourself which members-only boutique Naomi Campbell once got thrown out of? Well, don't worry, because answers to all these burning issues of the day will be answered in this fluffy early morning/late afternoon show that seems to be aiming for the Style Challenge audience. Unfortunately, they don't seem to be treating us to that many stars (well, OK, Boyzone's Shane Lynch does pop up), although future episodes promise Dani Behr, and Dermot O'Leary getting a full-body massage.
Richard Vine

webTitle: Mark Lawson on BBC1's Best Of Both Worlds

fields.headline: Bigamy is a terrible thing - but makes great drama.
fields.standfirst: BBC1's Best Of Both Worlds adds a twist by making the offender a woman. Does it tell us anything about modern relationships?
fields.trailText: BBC1's Best Of Both Worlds adds a twist by making the offender a woman. Does it tell us anything about modern relationships?
fields.body:
From Madame Bovary to Brookside, adultery is one of the most popular dramatic plot-lines. School and marriage are the two things which any given artistic audience is most likely to have experienced. But, in a society where illicit lovers are unlikely to be denounced from the pulpit or paraded around town wearing a scarlet letter A, writers are increasingly seeking ways to raise the risk and shame factors. In ITV's impressive recent drama The Innocent, a husband's fling with his wife's best friend brought an accusation of rape against him.

Now, in Best Of Both Worlds - a new three-parter from Paul Abbot, writer of the superb Clocking Off and Touching Evil - adultery leads to bigamy. If this narrative escalation carries on, there'll soon be a Sunday night serial called A Man's Best Friend about a spouse who is secretly dating a labrador.

Bigamy was also the subject of a recent best-selling novel - Anita Shreve's The Pilot's Wife - in which an airline captain was discovered to have a pair of slippers by the bed on either side of the Atlantic. And, strikingly, the character with the crowded ring-finger in Best Of Both Worlds also works in the flight business. This cultural connection between bigamy and aeroplanes probably results from the general belief that air crew have more sex than most people, and the fact that flight schedules make it plausible to maintain a life in two different cities simultaneously.

The stereotypical bigamist is a shifty middle-aged man; one of those cads from the 1940s and 1950s who maintained parallel homes with rich widows in several seaside towns. I once lived in a village where a man who scarcely seemed strong enough to run one household was said to have told his wife on his deathbed about a second missus living across town. Renowned locally as someone who frequently travelled, he had in reality almost never spent a night away from home. He had given the two children from each marriage the same names to reduce the risk of slipping up on birthday cards.

In Best Of Both Worlds, however, the bigamist is a wife twice over. Diane (Alice Evans) is a stewardess on the London-Bologna route. In England, she has a husband, a son and shares in a family restaurant. One day, an Italian flying home - Mark (Cal McCanich) - asks a strange favour. In order to secure a business deal, he needs to have a wife. Diane agrees to play the part. This may be a complicated pick-up, but she increases the complexity by telling him she's single. When, after an illicit affair which he believes to be licit, her Italian lover proposes, Diane accepts.

During most of this, the viewer feels as surprised as the congregation at Elton John's wedding, but the series is driven less by psychology than by plot. The primary aim is to make sexual betrayal more complicated. Whereas lovers are deceiving only one person, the bigamist is keeping a secret from two. Even a spy who's a double agent is known to be such by one of the sides. So it's no surprise that the best-known piece of bigamist fiction - Ray Cooney's play Run For Your Wife - is a farce. The form depends on the threat of the door opening at the wrong time. Think how many doors there are in two homes.

Abbot luxuriates in the ridiculous convolutions. Fearing that their marriage is cooling because he lacks romance, Diane's English husband surprises her by turning up on one of the flights to her Bologna home. Having told her Italian husband that she has a flat in London, Diane has just a few hours, when he announces a visit, to fit out the house of her recently dead mother to resemble the flat of a single flight attendant. The fact that Diane has to be given a just-dead mum to bequeath her property, and that the threatened meeting of her two husbands at the airport is prevented by a lucky coincidence, shows the way in which the story is force-fed rather than organic.

But, within an unlikely situation, the dialogue frequently sounds right. Abbot especially enjoys giving his characters lines of unknowing irony.

"You're a different person out here", says Diane's English husband on his visit to Bologna. When she first meets her Italian relatives, Diane compliments Mark: "You've got a lovely family." He replies "So have you", meaning that she is now part of his, but accidentally acknowledging her history in England. These - neatly - are lines which have a double life.

What Best Of Both Worlds fails to provide, at least in its first two episodes, is a psychological explanation of parallel marriages. fields.bodyText: From Madame Bovary to Brookside, adultery is one of the most popular dramatic plot-lines. School and marriage are the two things which any given artistic audience is most likely to have experienced. But, in a society where illicit lovers are unlikely to be denounced from the pulpit or paraded around town wearing a scarlet letter A, writers are increasingly seeking ways to raise the risk and shame factors. In ITV's impressive recent drama The Innocent, a husband's fling with his wife's best friend brought an accusation of rape against him. Now, in Best Of Both Worlds - a new three-parter from Paul Abbot, writer of the superb Clocking Off and Touching Evil - adultery leads to bigamy. If this narrative escalation carries on, there'll soon be a Sunday night serial called A Man's Best Friend about a spouse who is secretly dating a labrador. Bigamy was also the subject of a recent best-selling novel - Anita Shreve's The Pilot's Wife - in which an airline captain was discovered to have a pair of slippers by the bed on either side of the Atlantic. And, strikingly, the character with the crowded ring-finger in Best Of Both Worlds also works in the flight business. This cultural connection between bigamy and aeroplanes probably results from the general belief that air crew have more sex than most people, and the fact that flight schedules make it plausible to maintain a life in two different cities simultaneously. The stereotypical bigamist is a shifty middle-aged man; one of those cads from the 1940s and 1950s who maintained parallel homes with rich widows in several seaside towns. I once lived in a village where a man who scarcely seemed strong enough to run one household was said to have told his wife on his deathbed about a second missus living across town. Renowned locally as someone who frequently travelled, he had in reality almost never spent a night away from home. He had given the two children from each marriage the same names to reduce the risk of slipping up on birthday cards. In Best Of Both Worlds, however, the bigamist is a wife twice over. One day, an Italian flying home - Mark (Cal McCanich) - asks a strange favour. In order to secure a business deal, he needs to have a wife. Diane agrees to play the part. This may be a complicated pick-up, but she increases the complexity by telling him she's single. When, after an illicit affair which he believes to be licit, her Italian lover proposes, Diane accepts. Even a spy who's a double agent is known to be such by one of the sides. So it's no surprise that the best-known piece of bigamist fiction - Ray Cooney's play Run For Your Wife - is a farce. The form depends on the threat of the door opening at the wrong time. Think how many doors there are in two homes. Abbot luxuriates in the ridiculous convolutions. fields.headline: You only live twice
fields.trailText: Coronation Street | It's Your Funeral | Love In A Cold Climate |
fields.body:
Last night Ken Barlow's long-lost daughter, Susan, was killed in a car crash, leaving Mike Baldwin's long-lost son, Adam, to be tussled over by the Tweedledum and Tweedledee of Coronation Street (Granada TV). I can't say I knew Susan well, if at all. She looked a completely different woman when she married Mike Baldwin 15 years ago. In fact, she was a completely different woman. And I can't say I'm surprised by her frightful fate.

Coronation Street! Home of long-lost children, sudden death, unlikely sweaters. You would think they'd run coach tours there and, of course, they do. All three occur in the Barlow family. Susan's mother, Valerie, though a hairdresser, managed to electrocute herself with a dodgy hairdryer the night before the Barlows left for Jamaica. At the time the writers toyed with the idea of sending Ken to Jamaica anyway, if only for the sake of the joke.

The news of Susan's exit from Coronation Street was broken in the bar of the Rovers. Peter, Susan's twin, came in and, snivelling in an unpractised manner, announced her death. Ken and Mike stood perfectly still, awaiting the word to break into their customary recriminations. It was like a vignette from Acorn Antiques.

The tangled tale is that Susan, who had left Mike long ago, did not tell him that they had a son. Once Mike knew the truth, he flew into one of those fits of fatherly fondness peculiar to soaps and Susan, spooked by his threats of legal action, took (a) Adam and (b) flight.

One can confidently expect fisticuffs at her funeral. I can't resist dangling this delectable titbit of a line in front of you, as a taste of things to come. "Mike, put these peas on your nose!"

Talking of funerals, Gordon Ramsay, the incendiary chef, was the subject of It's Your Funeral (Channel 5). Guests draw up their plans for their own funeral, and I can quite see the appeal. We must all feel that our loved ones will not take the occasion as seriously as we do. Lord Mountbatten spent a great deal of time planning his funeral, not, of course, anticipating the unfortunate outcome. Bernard Shaw, a vegetarian, specified a mourning procession of all the animals he had not eaten. GK Chesterton, a very fat man, offered to stand in for the elephant.

Ramsay's acrimonious arrangements zeroed in, understandably, on the funeral baked meats. Or, as he put it, "some fantastic canapes". An ingenious idea was that, instead of the usual disconcerting dissertation about the deceased only being in the next room, one of his recipes would be read in church. According to Andrew Duncan's illuminating article in the Radio Times, he picked cappuccino of haricots blancs. Soup, if you were wondering. However, possibly because the restaurant critic, Fay Maschler, said that it reminded her of toxic scum on a stagnant pool, he changed his choice to caramelised tarte tatin ("One of the most important puddings I ever cooked.") There would, he added, grinding a tooth or two, be no food critics at his funeral.

Towards the end of Love In A Cold Climate (BBC 1) Linda, Nancy Mitford's alter ego, says "We're a lost generation, you and me. We shall be squashed out of history altogether. We might as well not have lived at all. I do think it's a shame." The film too, though pretty and witty in bits, will be forgotten in a week.

Except for the memorable delight of Alan Bates' Lord Redesdale, blindly repelling boarders. He was to be enjoyed here drilling his servants in trench warfare ("That will stop the sewers for at least two hours") and dragooning his daughters ("You women must go down to the cellar while the battle is on. I've provisioned you with bully beef for a week.") The whole story turns on the marked disinclination of the women to go down to the cellar and miss all the fun.

Before the war, all women looked like Mrs Baldwin, who had no waist, or Mrs Simpson, who had no hips. From where I sit, it was perhaps a pity that the production leaned so honestly towards Mrs Baldwin. The Bolter (Frances Barber), shingled, and with every stitch she owned slipping off her shoulders, galloped in a little too late to save the day.

"I'm quite special."

- Ken Russell in the South Bank Show (ITV).

webTitle: TV: From print to TV - Hywel Williams on Andrew Marr

fields.headline: Marr's landing
fields.standfirst: TV has been the nemesis of more than one erstwhile print journalist. But the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr has confounded his critics. Hywel Williams explains how he pulled it off
fields.trailText: TV has been the nemesis of more than one erstwhile print journalist. But the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr has confounded his critics. Hywel Williams explains how he pulled it off.
fields.body:
Those jug ears were always going to be a problem. And then there was that alabaster countenance, with its delicately boned structure. Was he, many people asked at the time, a complete non-starter? Here, obviously, was someone who'd been at the midnight oil - a bit of a judicious browser and capable in his columnar authority of Proustian references. But was this really someone whom the nation wished to see palely loitering outside Downing Street, intent on broadcasting to its semi-comatose state late at night and early in the morning? In short: could Andrew Marr hack it as political editor of the BBC?

The precedents were not good. There are endless examples of print journalists who tried to parachute into television and got shot. Adam Raphael had been a coolly rational political editor on The Observer before crashing and burning on Newsnight as he stared into the headlights of the incoming lens. Catastrophe veterans fondle with loving care the case notes on Sarah Hogg - formidable as The Independent's economics editor in its early days and later head of John Major's Policy Unit. But in between these dominatrix periods came enrolment in national service with Channel 4 News. Ghouls would tune in just to watch the broadcasting equivalent of a motorway pile-up.

His immediate predecessors, admittedly, had made a successful transition from the word to the image. But they could not have been more different from him. Robin Oakley cut his teeth at the Express and the Mail, a man at ease inside his own blazer as he travelled in to work from Surrey. But Surrey is not part of Marr's mental geography, and the imputed prejudices of Middle England, from Clause 28 to asylum seekers, have felt his lash. It is, moreover, happily impossible to imagine him wearing a blazer. John Cole, on the other hand, shares with Marr a northern Celticity. But the extravagant Ulster vowels of the one are far removed from the other's faintly Scottish tones. Cole's cult status owed much to his abilities as a character actor starring in One Man And His Mike. But Marr shows no interest in being a caricatured "personality". Nor can he be. He is transparent - a cool northern light through which we see things clearly.

For the truth about Marr - now six months into the job - is that he is not only good but a star. He may not be a broadcasting dish but that is the point. He shines for all the reasons that led many to be sceptical or cross about his appointment. He is 1997 man. The fact that before and after the New Labour victory he was "the project" in print led to some silly Tory squeals upon his appointment. If Will "stake-holding" Hutton had tried to give economic ballast to New Labour, Marr had lent it some cultural weight. His journalism recycled historical references to show that Britain was just an 18th-century invention.

Unusual among journalists in refusing to accept the myth of Major's personal niceness, the sordid quality of 1992-7 touched a raw nerve in Marr's very moral fibre. But he was always keen - if only because he is naturally and intellectually curious - to discover a better kind of Tory beast. This, admittedly, was a difficult animal to track down - but, once sighted, his insider sources at Kenneth Clarke's Treasury allowed him to strip the Major sham with unusual authority. Now, perhaps stung by accusations that he is Tony Blair's glove puppet and is just one more lefty Scottish public-school boy (the Loretto lad to Blair's Fettes), he treads cautiously. Admirers may wonder why he feels the need to write a weekly "note-book" for the Daily Telegraph. And even Tory Marr sceptics will wonder at the industry which led him last week to attend a John Redwood book launch and loiter among the dispossessed. Marr has to be even-handed, but the objectivity which is broadcasting's elusive grail has not disabled him.

Political journalists have to be political themselves. And career is often the mother of inventiveness. Marr has moved on rather from the agit-prop world of the Cambridge Students Union circa 1980. It was a time when Ed Stourton, now a broadcaster on Today, trod the boards of the more august Cambridge Union. Beleaguered Keith Vaz has recalled with misty eyes the "sexiness" of Stourton's performance as a French speaker in showy Union debates. But the CSU was something different - full of coffee-mug stains and anger at early Thatcher. As mellifluous Stourton pays the price for having an Etonian son and is relegated from democratic Today to patrician yesterday, the question arises: Who's the sexy one now?

Broadcasting - and in particular television - is full of very grand personalities. Between all that make-up and the congenital scruffiness of print journalists the gap yawns. Sometimes there is a Frost-like crawling to power. Sometimes there's Paxonian inquisition. But in both cases there's an ego in flight. And the drama flatters the interrogated politician. Look! Ten rounds with Jeremy and still standing! Drama is basic to television and its naturalness is contrived: there are the research assistants who check beforehand that guests will say what they're supposed to say on air; there's the unnecessarily early arrival at the studio - just to hype things up a bit beforehand. The medium is becoming less and less adept at handling ideas, originality and oddity. It has grown away from its improvisational roots.

Marr is appealing because he's a powerful demythologiser of the medium just by being so non-histrionic. He has the print journalist's way with words and a talent for the phrase. One can see how the happy thought often comes to him on air, showing no sign of being endlessly rehearsed and therefore drained of life. This is not art concealing art - it's just coolly intuitive skill. It's also cleverness in action - and it works because, although Marr respects the camera, he neither reveres it nor is frightened of it. It's a remarkable performance - and one that establishes an easily collusive partnership between himself and the viewer. Television is full of very clever people who think their audience are dimwits, only there to be patronised since they have the attention span of labradors. But Marr is the all-purpose on-air intellectual who can spin an idea and make it live. Just by being there he makes the rest look ponderous.

Part of the problem with modern political journalism is that it agrees with Nietzsche's conjecture that there is no truth - only interpretation. There is an inevitable runic quality to the commentary which is bred out of the lobby system. This can't mean what it says it means - so what does it really mean? As a serving lobby man, Marr can play this game well enough. Blair embarks on his 10-year plan, and Marr reminds us that the whole point of such a timescale is that by the end of it you have forgotten when it started. A nice example occurred in the Prime Minister's speech at Enfield on Thursday when he said that he wanted 50% of all under 30s to be graduates by 2010. Since over a third of 18-21 year olds are already in university in 2001 this happy cohort only need to avoid death in order to gratify the statistical register.

But beyond these self-absorbed coils of interpretation, Marr offers the engaging freshness of someone who thinks that politics is about the world and its culture - not just about politicians and their personalities. Which is why truth matters and is interesting. He may lack illusions but he's no cynic. In this respect he's the heir to John Tusa, the last non-inflatable ego to achieve something comparable in television commentary on politics. Quietly and cleverly Andrew Marr shows how politics is part of something wider - the world where we all live. "Look at it this way," he seems to say, "it's really not mysterious at all." Which is why we stop and listen to him.

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Louis Theroux | The Real Hannibal Lecters
fields.body:
Any film director will tell you the same thing: it's all about casting. And that's something Louis Theroux knows only too well. Whether you think his faux-naïf persona is veiled genius, or merely underhand attention-grabbing, he knows how to pick his victims. His latest, Paul Daniels, will be squirming under his gaze on BBC2 on Tuesday 20 February. He'll have to go some to beat his portrait of Jimmy Savile, but it will certainly be must-watch TV.

On the same day, Channel 4 jumps onto the aren't-cannibals-cool bandwagon with a three-part documentary, "The Real Hannibal Lecters". Eating human flesh, say the producers, is "the ultimate taboo", a conjecture undermined by the fact that the channel said the same thing about last year's look at the funeral industry, Great Undertakings. Nevertheless, the series promises a dispassionate look at a subject more likely to be found lurking on Channel 5.

webTitle: Leader: Peace deal in Irish mist

fields.headline: Peace deal in Irish mist
fields.standfirst:
Conflicting signals offer hope and despair

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The great frustration for peacemakers is that, just when you think the two sides are closer than ever to agreement, the entire process can unravel. It happened in the Middle East and now threatens Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The great frustration for peacemakers is that, just when you think the two sides are closer than ever to agreement, the entire process can unravel. It happened in the Middle East and now threatens Northern Ireland. Before Christmas, the outgoing US president, Bill Clinton, was working feverishly behind the scenes to secure a deal which sought to put the Good Friday Agreement on a permanent footing. There was optimistic talk on both sides, with word of an IRA move on decommissioning so huge that even the most suspicious of Unionists would have to accept it. The republicans would concrete over arms dumps, while the British government would agree to demilitarise, by taking down the loathed army watchtowers that stir such resentment in nationalist areas like south Armagh.

According to the plan, the deal would first be agreed by London and Sinn Fein before being handed to the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble for his grateful acceptance. As one insider close to the talks put it, by the end of the process everyone would agree that "the Troubles are over".

That optimism has not entirely faded, but the dynamics have changed. Mr Clinton, who was doing so much behind the scenes, even until his last day in office on January 20, has gone. The disciplining effect of that deadline has been replaced with a new one: London officials have let the parties in Belfast know that Tony Blair will not spare much more of his precious time on their problems. He has an election to prepare for and has signalled that, after the next week or so, he will concentrate on that rather than them. The same goes for his chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, who has been the lead player in Northern Ireland policy, and the government's de facto chief negotiator, for some time. So Northern Ireland is on notice that a deal has to be done very soon.

Does that mean a deal is within reach, or about to disappear from view? The answer is confused. Mr Trimble himself has nodded in both directions. At the end of last month he gave an upbeat assessment of the chances of IRA disarmament; yet on Saturday he told his 110-strong party executive that he would maintain the sanctions he has imposed on Sinn Fein over the IRA's failure to disarm - and even increase them if necessary. So which is it: is there progress or isn't there?

One explanation may be that, while there has been definite movement in London's talks with republicans, the advances may not be enough. Unionists fear the British government may well agree to take down two watchtowers, for example, in return for an IRA promise merely to "re-engage" with John De Chastelain, the Canadian former general charged with overseeing the decommissioning process. "Two towers for a phonecall" would not be enough, says one Trimble aide; the UUP leader would still face a challenge from Unionist hardliners. For Sinn Fein the key obstacle remains police reform. The trouble here is that republican demands are not easy for London to meet: they would require unpicking an act of parliament that is just a few weeks old - and doing so only months before a general election.

So Northern Ireland finds itself in a strange kind of limbo, on the brink either of a deal or a collapse. With a rising wave of loyalist violence hanging over all the participants, they need all the creativity they are capable of, if they are to make Northern Ireland peace count as one of the achievements of Labour's first term - rather than as yet another item in the in-tray of the second.
