webTitle: Anthony Hopkins talks to Sally Weale

fields.headline: 'I can't take it seriously. It makes me laugh'.
fields.standfirst: Anthony Hopkins talks to  Sally Weale
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins talks to Sally Weale.
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins is suffering from jet lag. From the neck downwards, he is dapper, ship-shape, not a thread out of place - the dark suit, ribbed high-neck sweater and polished long-toed shoes are flawless. But his face is grey; those famous piercing blue eyes are pale and hooded, and from time to time he fails to stifle a yawn. The Hannibal publicity tour is taking its toll.

Last week it was New York and Rome, then Paris and London. Yesterday he left for Berlin, then it's on to Madrid, Boston, Los Angeles and Mexico. Then back to Los Angeles, then Japan. "Oh God!" He covers his face with his large, meaty yellow hands in mock horror.

As Hopkins embarks on the London round of interviews and photocalls, the figures come through for Hannibal's opening in the US and the producers are over the moon. "To me it's all hieroglyphics," says Hopkins wearily. Right now he seems all of his 63 years. "I don't know quite what they're talking about, numbers and all that. It's not that I pretend I don't know, I honestly don't know. But I'm very pleased for them, they all seem to be thrilled."

It's not until you meet Hopkins that you appreciate the scale of his success. The machinery surrounding him is enormous. We still think of him as the misfit son of a baker from Port Talbot, who used to swallow Indian ink as a party trick, then discovered an unlikely talent for acting as well as a liking for the bottle. But he's well beyond our reach now. Last year he became an American citizen; today he is one of the biggest film stars on the planet. When he comes to town, his entourage takes over much of the second floor of London's Dorchester hotel. It's a slick, professional operation - journalists are escorted from one room to the next, gradually getting closer to the man himself, then you meet him, and before you know it, it's over. It's like meeting the Dalai Lama, or Princess Di, or Michael Jackson. Hopkins, I think, would hate the comparison.

It is a decade since Hopkins was catapulted to superstardom by his Oscar-winning performance as the murderous Dr Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs. "I expected Silence of the Lambs to be a big hit; but I wasn't sure about Hannibal because it's a sequel. I was waiting for the critics to gun us down," he says. His voice is beautiful, mellifluous; when he talks it's like being dusted with deeply perfumed talcum powder.

Apart from a funky orange watch on his left wrist, Hopkins today is a picture of sobriety. The drinking may have stopped 25 years ago (he reportedly still attends AA meetings), but his life has always been rocked by an inner turbulence which has left its fair share of casualties. He left his first wife and young daughter, whom he didn't see for many years; he now lives separately from his second wife who remains in London while he is in LA; and earlier this year he was reported to have split up from a girlfriend. David Hare once said: "Tony is permanently in the grip of feelings he cannot control."

He looks more in control now than he ever has, but not long before filming Hannibal, Hopkins clearly went through some sort of life crisis. It was reported at the time that he was planning to retire but he says that wasn't true. He had had a difficult time working on Julie Taymor's Titus and made a flippant remark to a fellow actor on set, which found its way into the press. (Those "arbiters of the truth", he says sarcastically. He doesn't like the British tabloid papers very much). Still, he was sufficiently worried about his health to stop work and get himself checked out.

"I did take a year off. Just to have a rest really, to get myself into good shape. I had been working too hard and I thought it would be good to get a medical check up to make sure I was OK. I changed my diet. I started a regimen of exercise - not fanatically, but walking and climbing mountains and that sort of thing. Then I came back to Lecter feeling refreshed, and rejuvenated and happier. And I abandoned my colossal ambition to do everything, because that's always a drive driven by fear.

"I'm losing the restlessness, which is good. I'd be quite happy now if nothing happened. I really would. I think I would. I wasn't bored in my year off." Seconds later he is telling me that in the course of that year he went to a place called Ojai in northern California where he bought a nice house; but after four months he got so bored he sold it back to the owner and returned to Los Angeles. Oh, and he squeezed in a small part in Mission Impossible II, filming in Australia with Tom Cruise.

He's already done two films since Hannibal (Stephen King's Hearts in Atlantis and The Devil and Daniel Webster, directed by and starring Alec Baldwin); he's about to start on another, an action movie called Black Sheep, and he's hoping to do Prospero in The Tempest with Julie Taymor next year. He is also a gifted pianist and composer and is working on his music, and finally - well, it probably isn't finally - he's submitting his own idea for a sequel to Hannibal.

Producer Dino De Laurentiis wants to follow up Hannibal with Red Dragon, Thomas Harris's 1981 novel which first introduced the character of Lecter and is set seven years before The Silence of the Lambs, but Hopkins has reservations.

"Recently, in the last few days, I've thought if anything's going to be done I'd rather do a sequel along the lines of a mythical battle between these two figures. She's now a hero warrior and I have an idea, a theme which I've written down, that he contacts her again and he sets baits for her, just little signs and they meet very briefly. He forces the meeting; is very gentle with her and lures her into a remote wilderness, a frightening, lonely place for the final battle."

What does seem unlikely is the prospect of Hopkins following in the footsteps of Jessica Lange, Kevin Spacey and a host of other American film stars, who have temporarily abandoned the glitz of Hollywood in favour of a run in London's West End. "Oh God," he exclaims, appalled. "A wet Wednesday at the Old Vic! I'm a spoilt brat I guess, but I couldn't face it. There's nothing so demoralising as when you have an opening night and the critics rip you to pieces and you've got to go on for the rest of the run for six months. It's horrible.

"Some people, like Judy Dench, Ian McKellen and Derek Jacobi, they have tremendous stamina, I admire them for what they do. But the thing about the theatre is you've got to take it seriously all the time. I can't. I can't do it. It makes me laugh."

Hopkins is flippant about his reasons for becoming an American. "I thought it would be fun to be an American citizen. I could chew gum, take photographs, talk loud . . . No, I like their spirit and their energy." He loves America - the massiveness of it, the oblivion of it - but he still misses the British sense of humour. He loves Morecambe and Wise and he'll do his Tommy Cooper impersonation (a very good one) at the drop of a hat.

At his house in Los Angeles, he works in his garden tending the palms and banana trees, the tropical flowers and figs (he say he goes into mourning when a flower dies); he watches his Carry On films and probably - like Lecter himself - he reads about the Medicis and composes his music late into the night. And when he goes to bed he dreams - at least three times a week - about his childhood in Wales, and he's back there, back in Port Talbot, the misfit baker's son who used to drink Indian ink as his party trick.

webTitle: Arts: Neil Diamond takes on Hannibal in this week's US films

fields.headline: This time it's personal
fields.standfirst: Neil Diamond takes on Hannibal in this week's US films
fields.trailText: Neil Diamond takes on Hannibal in this week's US films.
fields.body:
Just about the last thing I felt like doing this weekend was bearing witness to the revival of Mr Neil Diamond's film career. When The Jazz Singer was remade in 1980, it starred Diamond as the singer whose choice of a secular career almost destroys his relationship with his cantor father. The movie hit an impressive triple whammy: it was a commercial, a creative, and a critical fiasco. As the film's producer, it was all Diamond's fault and he stood in the flight-path of most of the excrement flung at his labour of love.

Moviegoers probably thought they'd seen the last of Diamond as a screen performer. Not so. He's back, this time as himself, in the new comedy Saving Sliverman, which was the only movie with the temerity to open opposite Ridley Scott's overblown Hannibal this weekend.

Saving Silverman pitches itself halfway between the infantile Jerry Lewisisms of Adam Sandler and the more mean-spirited comedy of the Farrelly brothers. It has a great cast that it doesn't deserve, and though there's no shortage of laughs, the film has an ersatz, warmed-over feel. Plus it only has a PG-13 rating, so the potentially compensatory gross-out elements can only go so far.

Darren Silverman (Jason Biggs) is the lead singer of Diamonds in the Rough, a Neil tribute band that also includes his witless friends Wayne (Steve Zahn) and JD McNugent (Jack Black). Silverman hooks up with Amanda Peet's nightmare dream-girl Alison, whom JD initially describes as "the Queen of All Honeys" before he and Wayne realise that in fact she is, "Freddy Kreuger, dude, but with like, way better tits". Wayne and JD are the quintessential useless sidekick duo, insane with butthead ambitions for Neil-centric musical world-domination, and addicted to the nine-burgers-a-day diet of the classic American underachiever.

So when Alison orders Silverman to dump his bandmates, they decide to kidnap her and set Darren up with his ex, who is a week away from becoming a nun. Mini-skirted novitiates and castrating bitches: such are the movie's ideas about women.

It's a shame, because this is an energetic cast whose previous work had me hoping that Saving Silverman might be a nifty little sleeper. Peet has been the best thing in several deeply average films: her topless assassin in The Whole Nine Yards is the only thing worth remembering from that movie. Behind her slightly unnerving cinemascope dental-work there's a gifted comedian, but one on the brink of five years of negative typecasting.

Steve Zahn has worked a good line in stoner idiots and country-fried brain-donors in That Thing You Do and Out of Sight. And Jack Black made a huge splash in High Fidelity last year as one of John Cusack's taste-stalinist record-shop assistants.

Along with star Jason Briggs - who left a suspiciously shaped aperture in the crust of American Pie - the cast promises what the script and direction can't deliver. It turns out that Neil Diamond's small cameo is one of the best in the movie, with a line he wrote himself: "Love on the rocks? Ain't no surprise!"

And so to Hannibal, which I'm anxious not to bore you with, since the gusto that director Ridley Scott mustered for his energetic, if faintly ridiculous Gladiator seems to have deserted him, leaving Hannibal a curiously inert experience. Scott can create beautiful, coherent worlds on screen (Alien, Blade Runner), but usually fails to fill them with interesting characters, and Hannibal is a compendium of all his worst traits: cheesy aesthetics, flaccid storytelling. I'll settle for dubbing it the Godfather III of Hannibal Lecter movies.

fields.headline: Branson's principles
fields.standfirst:
The lottery loser is threatening charities

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson is in danger of giving business an even blacker name than it has already in the charity world. As the annual conference of voluntary organisations heard last week, only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income comes from the business sector.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is in danger of giving business an even blacker name than it has already in the charity world. As the annual conference of voluntary organisations heard last week, only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income comes from the business sector. Worse still, just 400 companies account for 97% of this modest contribution - the remainder of the 3.7m businesses in the country donating a mere £10m to charity between them. American companies are five times as generous. Now Sir Richard, who launched his People's Lottery on the prospectus that all profits would go to good causes, will be lodging a compensation claim this week over its unsuccessful bid for the national lottery.

Sir Richard is believed to have spent £30m on his bid - including £8m since August last year, when rival Camelot was initially excluded by the lottery commission from the bidding process, only to be restored by the high court. He feels he was misled by the commission and unfairly denied the contract. The commission says that if any compensation is paid, it would reduce the amount for good causes. Sir Richard has good grounds for feeling aggrieved by the five-member commission, which, having signalled its intent to award the contract to the People's Lottery, swung back to Camelot following a change of chairman. But he has no grounds for compensation. The bidding process was clear from the start: winner takes all, losers pay their own costs. It is absurd for Sir Richard to suggest compensation could come out of taxes raised by the lottery - wrongly implying there was a state responsibility for the bidding process, while ignoring the harm a reduction in taxes would inflict on good causes. Sir Richard is a billionaire. His consortium includes Bill Gates, the richest man in the world, plus major international computer and consultancy firms. The bidding costs to them are peanuts - but if awarded would be a major loss to charities.

webTitle: Arts: The decadence of the rococo

fields.headline: Little fluffy clouds
fields.standfirst: Prussian-blue skies, plump cherubs and Venetian cityscapes:  Stuart Jeffries revels in the decadence of the rococo
fields.trailText: Prussian-blue skies, plump cherubs and Venetian cityscapes: Stuart Jeffries revels in the decadence of the rococo.
fields.body:
Once upon a time people lounged on clouds a great deal. They always had drapery around their naughty bits. Often they chatted to each other and passed grapes across the void. Sometimes they sang Rolling Stones numbers. "Hey!" bawled one. "Hey!" replied the other. "You!" shouted the first. "You!" echoed the second. "Get offa my cloud!" they chorused. There were chubby cherubs, too, who flew around taking orders for grapes.

Unfortunately, flying babies frighten me. And there are a great deal of them at the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Lille. They feature in an exhibition called Settecento: Tiepolo's Century, which consists of 122 Italian paintings from the 18th century drawn from French collections. It is a show of rococo art, with all the pinks, Prussian blues, clouds and crowds that word implies. This is an historical display, not simply of Italian art at a time when it was being eclipsed by French and Dutch competition, but of what French collectors of the time bought.

Settecento has, then, the promise of more than a few mediocre paintings. This may explain why staff outnumbered me by at least five to one when I went around the exhibition. But I was entranced by most of what I saw.

There are two main kinds of paintings here - horizontal and vertical. In the former, usually by Canaletto and often involving a view of a Venice building, the horizontal plane is exaggerated, and the effect is profoundly melancholy and inert. For instance, there are two depictions by Canaletto of Notre-Dame-de-la-Salute church in Venice. One is sunny, the other gloomy. But even the sunny view makes you feel extremely miserable - which, on a wet February day in Lille, is not what you need at all.

One hurries on to Francesco Guardi's depictions of Venice, because they don't play this melancholy game. Their blue remembered skies and waters are more vivid than Canaletto's, their canal scenes more jaunty. Guardi dabs his Venice into being, like a proto-impressionist, but charges his paintings with powerful lines, like a vorticist. There's a particularly energetic Guardi painting called The Doge Carried Around St Mark's Square, with the lines of two terraces racing to converge on the cathedral at the centre of the canvas, and the Campanile thrusting upwards to the right. There's no melancholy here, just compositional verve and power.

In the middle of Guardi's canvas, a rough old vignette is played out: the doge is there high on his throne, while his henchmen beat back the thronging plebs with big sticks. The Venetian authorities don't do that sort of thing any more.

The doge is also the focus of the Guardi canvas laboriously entitled The Doge on Board Bucentaure Leaving for the Lido on Ascension Day. Everything converges on this small but extremely powerful Venetian - the sky swoops down, the coastline hems in the action, the boats on the water and assorted riff-raff on the quay all turn obligingly towards him. Even the boat's oars point at the right angle. One can't quite suppress two thoughts: what a ponce, and what a lot of fuss for a journey of a few miles across calm waters.

As for the vertical paintings in this exhibition, they work like this. Heaven is up and the Earth is down. Earthlings crane their necks skywards in some trepidation, and the heavens are filled with winged humanoids, mostly naked. In Antonio Guardi's Emmaus's Supper, for example, Jesus looks up from his meal at a skyful of writhing cherubs. He has a doleful expression that says, "Don't look now, but they're back again," while Emmaus and his friend, looking at Christ, raise their arms in disbelief.

"Jesus," they all but say. "Always making with the funny stuff."

In the Levitation of Thomas De Cori by Antonio Cavallucci, a monk suddenly rises, cassock a-flap, towards the cherubic heavens. The polite society below avert their eyes, apart from one who can't resist trying to catch a peek of what's up theholy man's skirt.

In the vertical pictures there is no melancholy, just tangled limbs and strained necks. The extension of the vertical plane produces a sense of energy and movement. The best of this second group is Francesco Trevisiani's The Conversion of Saul. It has all its artists' best touches - cleverly depicted drama, a thunderously brooding darkness, and a delicate use of colour. Here, Jesus sweeps from top left with his white robe rolling behind him and his chest resting on billowing clouds of gold and black. Below is a tangle of soldiers hurled to the ground by this heavenly storm. Saul himself is tumbling from his white charger into the bottom right corner. Sprawling, he raises his arm against the approach of heaven's raging glory, but his face undoes that gesture as it looks earnestly at the arrival of his saviour. The painting has a formidable energy.

There's a third group of paintings here that I love, and that make this exhibition worthwhile. They are portraits by Giuseppe Maria Crespi, also known as Lo Spagnolo. They put those by Giambattista Tiepolo into the shade. The gestures of Tiepolo's Saint Roch (the priest with the plague) looking heavenwards seem hackneyed; his depiction of a bearded man is poised to collapse into fluffy sentimentalism. By contrast, Lo Spagnolo's Christ Fallen from the Cross is alone worth the exhibition's admission fee. A red-faced centurion reaches over Christ's body to untie him from the cross. Christ's robe is red and blood drips on to the cross. But it is Christ's face that grabs your attention. His mouth is open as he sucks in his last breaths. His features have become animalistic, as though his ordeal is stripping him of his human qualities. One eye looks at us sidelong, tired beyond belief. It says: "I am dying for you." And it looks as though he is dying, as never before or since in painting.

Lo Spagnolo is marvellous. From a distance his Saint Madeleine just looks like a woman with an ugly face. But as soon as you study more closely this painting of a woman mourning over Christ's skull, you see something much more wonderful. The sorrowful tilt of her head, the large snotty nose, the overbite and the deep-socketed eyes all bespeak not ugliness but the very proper expressions of tearful lament. It's a really moving picture.

Perhaps the best of Lo Spagnolo's pictures here, though, is a sexier affair. The painter overcomes the trite notion of the title Love Triumphs, despite all the clunking symbols that litter the picture. Here a boy (Love) is naked to his waist, clutching a bow and arrow over his chest. He rests a toned arm on a stack of papers while standing in front of a globe. The conceit of the painting is that Love vanquishes any other human accomplishment, be it literary or scientific. Thus Love's arrow represents acuity, his chest pride, his arm strength, the globe science, the book learning.

But the brooding of his shaded brow, and the loving painting of his naked body, are what is really engaging. Love has wings and a helmet. What do they symbolise? The wings are so he can ascend to heaven if he feels like it. The helmet? To protect his head in case one of those cherubs comes crashing down to earth, or someone falls off their cloud.

 Settecento: Tiepolo's Century is at the Palais des Beaux Arts, Lille, until April 30. Details: 00 33 3 20 06 78 00.

fields.headline: Pankaj Roy
fields.standfirst: Opening batsman who set a standing Test Match record for India
fields.trailText: Pankaj Roy, the former Indian opening batsman who has died aged 72, achieved the still-standing record first-wicket Test partnership of 413 runs in 1955. Noted more for his patience and determination than for any panache or style of stroke, he played in 43 Test matches and scored 2,442 runs with an average of 32.56. Few batsmen, if any, with a long-standing world record to their credit, have been dismissed so often without scoring. Yet his achievements are remarkable for someone of stocky, somewhat squat, stature, with imperfect vision and a two-eyed stance.
fields.body:
Pankaj Roy, the former Indian opening batsman who has died aged 72, achieved the still-standing record first-wicket Test partnership of 413 runs in 1955. Noted more for his patience and determination than for any panache or style of stroke, he played in 43 Test matches and scored 2,442 runs with an average of 32.56. Few batsmen, if any, with a long-standing world record to their credit, have been dismissed so often without scoring. Yet his achievements are remarkable for someone of stocky, somewhat squat, stature, with imperfect vision and a two-eyed stance.

Roy, who was born in Calcutta into a middle-class family, captained the combined universities team against West Indian and English touring teams. He soon came to the fore on the national scene with a flurry of high scoring, which included 100 for Bengal against Uttar Pradesh on his Ranji Trophy debut in 1946-47. In his first international series in 1951-52, he scored 140 against England at Bombay and 111 at Madras when India achieved their first ever Test Match victory.

In his first overseas tour, to England in 1952, hopes that he would be a successor to Vijay Merchant and Mustaq Ali, who had delighted crowds in England six years earlier, were shattered during his first exposure to England's fast bowlers - to Freddie Trueman in particular. Roy's seven innings in that series contained five ducks - four in consecutive innings.

The Bengali owed his continued selection to high scoring in domestic competition and, in the interest of regional balance, to the selectors' reluctance to omit the East Zone's only cricket hero. After a West Indies tour in 1953 came the Test series - against New Zealand in 1955 that guaranteed his place in the record books.

But it began badly. In the opening match, he scored a further duck and was dropped from the team. It was at this point, too, that he had an eye test and began to wear glasses. He fought his way back into the team, scored 100 at Calcutta and then, in the fifth Test Match at Madras, came his triumph. Hesitant at first, he and Vinoo Mankad survived the first day and progressed cautiously into the second. The two passed the then record Test Match first-wicket partnership of 359, set by Len Hutton and Cyril Washbrook of England against South Africa in 1948/49 in Johannesburg. Then, on receiving a note from his captain, Polly Umrigar, to increase the scoring-rate, he was out after lunch for 173. The partnership stood at 413 runs.

In spite of his reputed frailty against fast bowling, Roy defied West Indians Roy Gilchrist and Wesley Hall for 444 minutes to score a match-saving 90 at Bombay in 1958. Thereafter, the West Indies pace attack swept through the country, before they were halted again by Roy with 58 in a 93-runs stand with Dattu Gaekwad in the fifth Test match at Delhi.

To Pankaj's disappointment, the aristocratic Gaekwad was appointed captain for the tour to England in 1959 with himself as vice-captain. Roy's performance there, though still disappointing, was better than it had been in 1952. He hit top-score in each innings (54 and 49) of the first Test match at Nottingham, and captained his country at Lord's.

Wisden, which noted that his batting was vulnerable because of his stance and practice of playing off the back-foot, appreciated his captaincy quality: "The side showed better form when he took over in Gaekwad's absence and his frequent consultation with other senior members of the side obviously helped in this improvement". India, however, were outplayed and lost the series 5-0.

Roy was dropped again after the first Test match against Pakistan in 1960, and, surprisingly, was never recalled. He served later on the national selection committee, and was proud that both his son, Pranab, and nephew, Ambar, played for India. Ramachandra Guha stated in his book Wickets in the East that "all the Roys retain a warm place in the affections of their townsmen, and none more so than Pankaj".

Pankaj Khirod Roy, cricketer, born May 31 1928; died February 4 2001

webTitle: The new face of the British army - young, female and ready to fight.

fields.headline: Sisters in arms
fields.standfirst: The new face of the British army - young, female and ready to fight.  Tania Branigan  on a military revolution
fields.trailText: The new face of the British army - young, female and ready to fight.  Tania Branigan  on a military revolution.
fields.body:
Perfumes and make-up clutter a shelf, a cheerful red and yellow duvet covers the bed and Titanic and Wu Tang Clan posters hide the stains on the wall. Layla Almualla's room could belong to any young university fresher but for one incongruous photograph: a shot of the squaddies from 27 Transport Regiment on exercise in Cyprus. Amid the mass of camouflage-clad masculinity, it is just possible to pick out Almualla in her battle dress.

If the army wants to argue that it is no longer a bastion of beer-soaked yobs, Almualla could be its model 21st-century soldier. A former secretary and self-confessed "girlie girl", the 20-year-old is not only an experienced and professional soldier with a stint in Kosovo under her belt; she is also female, mixed race and living evidence that the force is finally changing.

The British army has women in its sights. This is more than politically correct window dressing; it is genuinely keen to recruit women, for the simple reason that it has little choice. With a shortfall of 8,000 soldiers, the army has realised it must welcome those it once tended to shun: women, members of ethnic minorities and gay people. If it is true that a revolution is taking place in our armed forces, it is being driven less by demands for equal opportunities than by a desperate shortage of personnel.

"They are having recruitment problems because the traditional pool of white, working-class northern males has dried up - or doesn't want to join up," says Dr Rachel Woodward of the University of Newcastle, who is researching the armed forces' response to changing gender roles.

Happily for the force, applications from women are surging. They make up 8% of the total armed forces, but 13% of new recruits. When women were first admitted they were strictly segregated, but in 1992 the Women's Royal Army Corps was disbanded, and 70% of the force is now fully gender-mixed. Even the combat units may succumb; a wide-ranging study into combat effectiveness and gender is due this year.

"The army is at an absolutely crucial point," says Woodward. "It's a huge institution built on many years of pretty strong ideas about gendered identities, but all that is being challenged."

Steering a 32,000 litre fuel tanker around the regimental base at Aldermaston, Almualla says that male colleagues soon get used to working with - and being outdone by - women. Perhaps inevitably, however, inclusion remains very much on male terms. Overtly feminine servicewomen, she says, are dismissed as "combat Barbies", and in order to fit in, women tend to act like one of the boys.

"We work and live so closely with them it's second nature," says Lance Corporal Diana Ryder, a colleague and friend of Almualla.

These women are fortunate, all the same, to work in one of the more enlightened areas of the vast army machine. Women are so well integrated into the Transport Regiment that even the accommodation blocks are mixed sex. "They don't bat an eyelid if you walk down the corridor in a towel from the shower," says Ryder.

But the army is beginning to recognise that persuading women to apply for the job is not, in itself, enough. Faced with a significant retention problem, the force is taking a hard look at working conditions in an attempt to hang on to them. It is improving accommodation, trying to support soldiers better, and modernising many of the archaic and idiosyncratic regulations that staff find irksome. For instance, the ban on unmarried couples sharing soldiers' quarters is likely to be lifted, the MoD admitted last month.

Even single mothers have their place. "My friend's got pregnant and she's staying in," says Ryder. "Her mates couldn't believe it - but this way her baby will always have security, a house, food on the table. Her pay goes up a bit. What's the alternative? Move back to Rotherham and get a council flat in a run down area?"

Second Lieutenant Mitch Wollaston of the Royal Engineers says she has few anxieties about commanding men when she finishes training. "You can tell a bloke to get an effing move on and he won't hold it against you like a woman might," she says. She believes that despite their macho image, soldiers are so used to accepting orders that they will obey a woman with far less reluctance than many civilian men.

But while there are certainly reasons to be cheerful, the army still has a long way to go. Harassment and discrimination still exist, and for those ambitious to move to the very top, female role models remain scarce. There are no female generals yet and virtually no brigadiers.

And while some regiments have adopted an enlightened approach to women's recruitment, there are others that remain stubborn bastions of testosterone-charged intransigence. The different regiments that make up the army have highly distinctive identities which are often jealously guarded. Combat units, in particular, ban female recruits - and they ultimately form the core of the service.

"Combat effectiveness is not about cuddling babies and delivering tea," observed General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, in a recent speech indicating his opposition to letting women fight. "We must ensure that nothing, I repeat, nothing, damages the effectiveness of the British armed forces."

The argument is not about whether women should serve on the frontline (they already do - Royal Engineers often precede the infantry) but whether they should be there to fight. Few women, goes the argument, have the physical strength required for a combat unit - although Germany, which opened up all its regiments to women last month, has taken on 224 female recruits in combat divisions.

Yet it seems to be tacitly accepted that it is only a matter of time before a legal challenge under European law or the Human Rights Act ushers the admission of women through all ranks. Army top brass are publicly discussing preparations for their inclusion, as much to give the troops time to get used to the idea as because of an immediate need to do so.

Woodward is exasperated by claims that the inclusion of women and introduction of a more female-friendly environment will ruin the army's fighting capabilities. "There's this argument that we will have chaos and it will become all pink and fluffy," she says. "It's incredibly reactionary; no one can suggest that tolerance automatically leads to chaos."

'Killing is what we do' Private Noa Berman, one of the first Israeli women to serve in combat, is described by her fellow soldiers as a 'natural warrior'.
Ewen MacAskill

Private Noa Berman stands on a lonely outpost on the Golan Heights, Israel's key strategic defensive position in the north of the country. The enemy, Syria, is visible across the flat scrubland. She knows that a Syrian observer probably has his binoculars trained on her, one of the few women combat soldiers in the world.

Berman is one of only three women soldiers among 70 men at the base. She joined up in August, training for four months before arriving at the artillery battalion in December.

Berman is 19 and has dreamed of becoming a combat soldier since childhood. "I saw movies about war. There were no women and I wanted to be first to be there. I liked GI Jane when I was 16," she says, referring to the film starring Demi Moore as the first woman to join an elite US military unit.

Israel is far ahead of Britain - and most other countries - in allowing women to serve in frontline units. It is also just about the only country where women are likely to see active combat.

National service is compulsory for everyone in Israel, male and female. But until recently, women have been given jobs well back from the frontline: some working in areas like intelligence, but many others filling in time as secretaries.

Private Berman did not want a soft life behind the lines. Instead, according to Israeli Defence Force terminology, she is a "combat soldier", expected to go out on patrol with the men. Her unit could be swapping shells with enemy artillery at any time and even hand-to-hand fighting is possible, should the base be attacked. In May, during the Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon, her battalion saw action against Hizbullah, the Islamic fundamentalist guerilla group.

Berman carries her rifle with her all the time, either on her lap or slung over her back. "I have thought about killing people. That is the purpose of the army. That is what we do. The people we kill are against us." Caressing the gunbutt, she says: "At first it was weird and hard to have a gun." She is, says a fellow woman soldier, a "natural warrior".

War is not a new experience for Berman. She was brought up in Kiryat Shmona, the most northerly town in Israel, close to the Lebanese border and frequently under bombardment from Katyusha rockets fired by Hizbullah. Both her mother and father, who had been a sergeant in the army, were supportive of her decision to go into a combat unit.

She had a boyfriend before joining the army, but they have broken up. A factor in the split was that she spent so much time away from home, allowed back only one weekend in two. When she leaves the army, Berman wants to be a psychologist and have children.

She talks about how she and her two female comrades dug out their dresses when they went home on leave. There was nothing then to identify them as soldiers, except for the bootmarks round their ankles.

Private Alon Weinstein, 18, who joined the battalion only a week before Berman and her two female colleagues, is relaxing in the sun. How does he find working alongside female soldiers? "I do not think it matters. The commander called us and told us that if there was any trouble with the women, the punishment will be severe. So no one will mess with them. We treat them as soldiers. She is fighting alongside me. She is protecting me and I am protecting her. We are soldiers."

Layla Almualla's room could belong to any young university fresher but for one incongruous photograph: a shot of the squaddies from 27 Transport Regiment on exercise in Cyprus. Amid the mass of camouflage-clad masculinity, it is just possible to pick out Almualla in her battle dress. If the army wants to argue that it is no longer a bastion of beer-soaked yobs, Almualla could be its model 21st-century soldier. A former secretary and self-confessed "girlie girl", the 20-year-old is not only an experienced and professional soldier with a stint in Kosovo under her belt; she is also female, mixed race and living evidence that the force is finally changing. The British army has women in its sights. This is more than politically correct window dressing; it is genuinely keen to recruit women, for the simple reason that it has little choice. With a shortfall of 8,000 soldiers, the army has realised it must welcome those it once tended to shun: women, members of ethnic minorities and gay people. If it is true that a revolution is taking place in our armed forces, it is being driven less by demands for equal opportunities than by a desperate shortage of personnel. "They are having recruitment problems because the traditional pool of white, working-class northern males has dried up - or doesn't want to join up," says Dr Rachel Woodward of the University of Newcastle, who is researching the armed forces' response to changing gender roles. Happily for the force, applications from women are surging. They make up 8% of the total armed forces, but 13% of new recruits. When women were first admitted they were strictly segregated, but in 1992 the Women's Royal Army Corps was disbanded, and 70% of the force is now fully gender-mixed. Even the combat units may succumb; a wide-ranging study into combat effectiveness and gender is due this year. "The army is at an absolutely crucial point," says Woodward. "It's a huge institution built on many years of pretty strong ideas about gendered identities, but all that is being challenged." Steering a 32,000 litre fuel tanker around the regimental base at Aldermaston, Almualla says that male colleagues soon get used to working with - and being outdone by - women. Perhaps inevitably, however, inclusion remains very much on male terms. Overtly feminine servicewomen, she says, are dismissed as "combat Barbies", and in order to fit in, women tend to act like one of the boys. "We work and live so closely with them it's second nature," says Lance Corporal Diana Ryder, a colleague and friend of Almualla. These women are fortunate, all the same, to work in one of the more enlightened areas of the vast army machine. Women are so well integrated into the Transport Regiment that even the accommodation blocks are mixed sex. "They don't bat an eyelid if you walk down the corridor in a towel from the shower," says Ryder. But the army is beginning to recognise that persuading women to apply for the job is not, in itself, enough. Faced with a significant retention problem, the force is taking a hard look at working conditions in an attempt to hang on to them. It is improving accommodation, trying to support soldiers better, and modernising many of the archaic and idiosyncratic regulations that staff find irksome. For instance, the ban on unmarried couples sharing soldiers' quarters is likely to be lifted, the MoD admitted last month. Even single mothers have their place. "My friend's got pregnant and she's staying in," says Ryder. "Her mates couldn't believe it - but this way her baby will always have security, a house, food on the table. Her pay goes up a bit. What's the alternative? Move back to Rotherham and get a council flat in a run down area?" Second Lieutenant Mitch Wollaston of the Royal Engineers says she has few anxieties about commanding men when she finishes training. "You can tell a bloke to get an effing move on and he won't hold it against you like a woman might," she says. She believes that despite their macho image, soldiers are so used to accepting orders that they will obey a woman with far less reluctance than many civilian men. But while there are certainly reasons to be cheerful, the army still has a long way to go. Harassment and discrimination still exist, and for those ambitious to move to the very top, female role models remain scarce. There are no female generals yet and virtually no brigadiers. And while some regiments have adopted an enlightened approach to women's recruitment, there are others that remain stubborn bastions of testosterone-charged intransigence. The different regiments that make up the army have highly distinctive identities which are often jealously guarded. Combat units, in particular, ban female recruits - and they ultimately form the core of the service. "Combat effectiveness is not about cuddling babies and delivering tea," observed General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, in a recent speech indicating his opposition to letting women fight. "We must ensure that nothing, I repeat, nothing, damages the effectiveness of the British armed forces." The argument is not about whether women should serve on the frontline (they already do - Royal Engineers often precede the infantry) but whether they should be there to fight. Few women, goes the argument, have the physical strength required for a combat unit - although Germany, which opened up all its regiments to women last month, has taken on 224 female recruits in combat divisions. Yet it seems to be tacitly accepted that it is only a matter of time before a legal challenge under European law or the Human Rights Act ushers the admission of women through all ranks. Army top brass are publicly discussing preparations for their inclusion, as much to give the troops time to get used to the idea as because of an immediate need to do so. Woodward is exasperated by claims that the inclusion of women and introduction of a more female-friendly environment will ruin the army's fighting capabilities. "There's this argument that we will have chaos and it will become all pink and fluffy," she says. "It's incredibly reactionary; no one can suggest that tolerance automatically leads to chaos." webTitle: Interview with Stephen Gaghan, writer of Traffic

fields.headline: How to get high in Hollywood
fields.standfirst: The critics loved Traffic's realistic drug scenes. No wonder: the writer spent years taking everything he could get his hands on.  Rick Lyman met him
fields.trailText: The critics loved Traffic's realistic drug scenes. No wonder: the writer spent years taking everything he could get his hands on. Rick Lyman met him.
fields.body:
He spent one Christmas morning trying to steal crack cocaine from a dealer who pulled a gun on him. But that wasn't enough to get him out of the junkie's life. Nor was the time another dealer put a knife to his throat. Nor even when a 300lb fellow inmate strung out on PCP chased him around a Manhattan holding pen singing the theme from I Love Lucy. Not until July 1997, when Stephen Gaghan had been a drug user for more than a decade, did he finally realise that he would have to change his life or die.

"Over one long, five-day weekend, I had three separate heroin dealers get arrested," Gaghan recalls. "My dealer, my backup dealer and my backup-backup dealer. I was left alone, and I hit that place, that total incomprehensible demoralisation. That was the end of it; up five days straight, locked in the bathroom, convinced there was nowhere else to go. I had to kill myself."

You may have spotted Gaghan during the Golden Globe awards broadcast recently, grinning when he won the best screenplay award for Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, a drama set in the world of drug smugglers, dealers and users. Next, it's thought, he could be nominated for an Oscar.

Gaghan, who is 35, thin, with a rough-edged look, says he has been clean for three and a half years. But when he won his Emmy in 1997 (as one of the writers for an episode of NYPD Blue), he was in the thick of heroin and cocaine addiction. Now it is time to come clean about his past, a slow spiral that started at a private school in Louisville, Kentucky.

"People were asking me where I got the characters and situations for Traffic, and I found myself starting to speak in code," he says. He would talk about research he had done in the drug culture, about unnamed acquaintances, but he never admitted that a lot of it came from his own life.

"Part of the recovery process is a commitment to truth, and I began to feel that I was not being truthful," he says. "The shame of drug addiction is part of what makes it difficult for people to ask for help, and I felt that I was perpetuating that stigma. If there is a message to the movie, I guess it's that drugs should be a health care issue rather than a criminal issue."

He started, as young people often do, with alcohol and marijuana. "I remember, when I was writing Traffic, talking to top federal drug-enforcement officials and having them say they read it and found it very good and believable, except the scene where the girl describes her resumé," he says. In that scene a private-school student, arrested for drug possession, ticks off her academic and athletic achievements to a disbelieving social worker.

"They said to me, 'There is no way this girl could be achieving at the level you have her achieving at and be using cocaine,' " Gaghan says. "I didn't tell them that the resumé was my resumé exactly, at a time when I was drinking every day and smoking marijuana and taking cocaine."

The point, he says, is that drug addiction can attack anyone, even a high-achieving private-school student from a solid middle-class family. Many of Gaghan's school friends experimented with drugs, but for most of them it was a brief affair. But for him, it became fascinating.

"It was always just a point of trying to take it a little bit further than everybody else," he says. "You end up finding lower and lower companions. People fall out, and you end up with people who are right on the edge of criminals, people who can procure for you the various things you need."

He was thrown out of school but eventually got into a small business college in Massachusetts. There he hooked up with some venture capitalists and started a catalogue company, Fallen Empire Inc, hoping to earn enough to support his writing career and to buy booze and drugs.

One of his stories, The Year With No Winter, was published in the Iowa Review in 1990. But the business was a disaster. When he had lost everyone's money, he simply ran away to New York: "I'd get in trouble in one place, so I'd flee to someplace else."

Most of the time he was using drugs. He shifted steadily toward cocaine and eventually the sniffable heroin that became popular in the early 1990s. "It was just the thing to do," he says. "You'd walk around the East Village in your hipster boots, listening to grunge music and being the prototypes of heroin chic. It's so embarrassing."

By this time he was an addict, but he didn't know it: "I thought I was having this literary adventure, that I was really fine." There were seizures, bouts of incontinence, a steady descent into mental and physical squalor. The amazing thing, he says, is that beyond his drug friends he was able to keep it a secret. "I worked very hard on the mask. The one thing that I couldn't disguise was that I was getting arrested all the time."

There were 20 or 30 arrests, mostly on minor charges. And then he made a mistake. "I used to buy drugs from these 14-year-old kids who ran their operation out of an apartment in Manhattan. I went over there one day in late 1992. I had maybe $4 worth of heroin in my pocket, and I wanted to buy a half-gram of cocaine."

He bought the cocaine and left the building, but was arrested around the corner, caught in a police sting. This was no petty offence: this was heroin and cocaine. But Gaghan borrowed from friends, used all his savings and hired a good lawyer. He pleaded guilty to possession and was given a conditional discharge. Then he acted the way he always did when backed into a corner. He fled to Los Angeles.

It was 1993, and the worst was yet to come. He worked for a while answering phones for a production company. Then he stalked off on his own, hoping to make it as a movie writer. "I got 10,000 rejections," he says. He lived the west Hollywood life of a struggling writer, getting odd jobs, up all night, high or strung out.

"It starts out that you have a bunch of people around you, living the same drug life, and then people start to drop off," Gaghan says. "They die. They go into rehab. They disappear. Until finally you're down to a real hardcore, the iron men. After a while they're gone, too. And it's just you, locked in the bathroom. I honestly believe I spent three of the last 10 years locked in the bathroom."

There is a scene in Traffic in which Michael Douglas, playing the addict's father, breaks into the bathroom where she has locked herself. It had to be in the film, Gaghan says, because the bathroom was in his life.

By the mid-1990s, he began to get work. He had jobs on various movie lots, wrote some television shows, even shared an Emmy. But he was a drug addict the whole time. "I smoked crack in my office on the Universal lot, always with some heroin to even it out," he says.

And then came the day, in July 1997, he hit the wall. A friend led him to therapists, substance-abuse programmes and what he hopes will be a whole new life. Gaghan declines to give the name of the person who saved his life: it is a writer and actor, he says, who deserves his anonymity. He met a woman in recovery named Michael McCraine, and now they have a 9-month-old son, Gardner. It's been 43 months, he says, since he found the way out of the drug life.

"I'm happy now. No one who saw me a few years ago could believe I would be here. I don't know if drug addiction is genetic. I don't even know if it's a disease. But I do know one thing: you have to treat it like a disease. Because if you don't, you die."

webTitle: Women: A 'natural warrior' - one of the first Israeli women to serve in combat

fields.headline: 'Killing is what we do'
fields.standfirst: Private Noa Berman, one of the first Israeli women to serve in combat, is described by her fellow soldiers as a 'natural warrior'. Ewen MacAskill reports
fields.trailText: Private Noa Berman, one of the first Israeli women to serve in combat, is described by her fellow soldiers as a 'natural warrior'. Ewen MacAskill reports.
fields.body:
Private Noa Berman stands on a lonely outpost on the Golan Heights, Israel's key strategic defensive position in the north of the country. The enemy, Syria, is visible across the flat scrubland. She knows that a Syrian observer probably has his binoculars trained on her, one of the few women combat soldiers in the world.

Berman is one of only three women soldiers among 70 men at the base. She joined up in August, training for four months before arriving at the artillery battalion in December.

Berman is 19 and has dreamed of becoming a combat soldier since childhood. "I saw movies about war. There were no women and I wanted to be first to be there. I liked GI Jane when I was 16," she says, referring to the film starring Demi Moore as the first woman to join an elite US military unit.

Israel is far ahead of Britain - and most other countries - in allowing women to serve in frontline units. It is also just about the only country where women are likely to see active combat.

National service is compulsory for everyone in Israel, male and female. But until recently, women have been given jobs well back from the frontline: some working in areas like intelligence, but many others filling in time as secretaries.

Private Berman did not want a soft life behind the lines. Instead, according to Israeli Defence Force terminology, she is a "combat soldier", expected to go out on patrol with the men. Her unit could be swapping shells with enemy artillery at any time and even hand-to-hand fighting is possible, should the base be attacked. In May, during the Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon, her battalion saw action against Hizbullah, the Islamic fundamentalist guerilla group.

Berman carries her rifle with her all the time, either on her lap or slung over her back. "I have thought about killing people. That is the purpose of the army. That is what we do. The people we kill are against us." Caressing the gunbutt, she says: "At first it was weird and hard to have a gun." She is, says a fellow woman soldier, a "natural warrior".

War is not a new experience for Berman. She was brought up in Kiryat Shmona, the most northerly town in Israel, close to the Lebanese border and frequently under bombardment from Katyusha rockets fired by Hizbullah. Both her mother and father, who had been a sergeant in the army, were supportive of her decision to go into a combat unit.

She had a boyfriend before joining the army, but they have broken up. A factor in the split was that she spent so much time away from home, allowed back only one weekend in two. When she leaves the army, Berman wants to be a psychologist and have children.

She talks about how she and her two female comrades dug out their dresses when they went home on leave. There was nothing then to identify them as soldiers, except for the bootmarks round their ankles.

Private Alon Weinstein, 18, who joined the battalion only a week before Berman and her two female colleagues, is relaxing in the sun. How does he find working alongside female soldiers? "I do not think it matters. The commander called us and told us that if there was any trouble with the women, the punishment will be severe. So no one will mess with them. We treat them as soldiers. She is fighting alongside me. She is protecting me and I am protecting her. We are soldiers."

webTitle: Michele Hanson: Filth and fury from the kids of today

fields.headline: Michele Hanson
fields.standfirst: Filth and fury from the kids of today
fields.trailText: Filth and fury from the kids of today.
fields.body:
Last week, on my dog walk, I reprimanded a trio of teenage girls for scribbling vile graffiti on a white wall. "Go and fuck your dog!" they cried fiercely and carried on scribbling. It has to be true. Children are more badly behaved than ever.

In our local park, the children can be seen at play, zooming about on stolen motorbikes, vandalising, burning benches and drug dealing. Perhaps some have been trained from an early age. Janet over the road spotted a child hurling litter on to the pavement. She told him to put it in the bin, which he did. Then his mother came roaring along and ordered him to put it back on the pavement.

Perhaps, in her youth, this mother was a rude teenager and has remained rude. I suspect that nowadays, children stay ruder for longer. Things are hotting up. Fielding finds that he can scarcely take two steps outside his house before he encounters some form of rudeness. Last week he was crossing town on a jam-packed bus when a desperate man tried to get on. "Look mate," said the ex-13-year-old conductor, "just fucking piss off."

Fielding himself even behaved badly last week. London Transport fined him £10 because he couldn't find his ticket, which was hiding in his back pocket. "Fuck off!" he snapped coarsely at the inspector. The strain of teaching is obviously beginning to tell on him. After decades of good behaviour, his rudeness rather lacks polish, but many of his pupils, having practised hard, are now insolent in an off-hand way. No rebuke, however justified, bothers them. "Whatever," they drawl, or just "And?"

fields.headline: Buddy Tate
fields.standfirst: Jazz saxophonist whose relaxed grace and lyricism were born in the swing era
fields.trailText: Jazz saxophonist whose relaxed grace and lyricism were born in the swing era.
fields.body:
Jazz often confirms that the most wilfully egocentric performer can produce the most sensitive and hospitable music; but if ever temperament and style faithfully mirrored each other, it was in the case of the great swing saxophonist Buddy Tate, who has died aged 87. One of the most relaxed, humorous and amenable of musicians, Tate's personal style was glowingly reflected in the lissom and occasionally gently mocking elegance of his saxophone playing.

Like many of the lyrical and romantic jazz performers of his era, Tate could perform miniature miracles with minimal materials, and to hear him embroider a ballad like I Can't Get Started in unaccompanied performance, merely shuffling a handful of soft, buttery notes and mingling them with a textural repertoire of intimately whispering intonations, was one of the most agreeable experiences in postwar jazz. But Tate could also be an exciting, hard-swinging player too, and his control of the horn in its upper register predated many of the technical advances in saxophone playing that were made by the modernists in hard bop and the avant garde.

Tate came up in the 1930s when swing ruled popular music and instrumental stars were heroes whose reputations were not far behind those of singers. But the connection between the song and the sound of a saxophone, trumpet or clarinet was closer then. Bebop, with its intricate, cliffhanging melody lines and unpredictable resolutions had not yet arrived to launch a jazz sound very different to the shapely lyricism of vocalised instrumental methods that mimicked singing. Tate therefore learned from the examples of saxophonists Coleman Hawkins, Lester Young and Herschel Evans. Young's favourite query to an improviser who strayed too far from the fundamentals of the song was "What's your story?" That accessible notion of an improviser's narrative was Tate's too.

Tate began working with the territory bands that travelled around the southwest in the tough years following the Depression and before swing took off. He worked with McCloud's Night Owls, the St Louis Merrymakers and a band led by Terrence Holder that was later to be taken over by the celebrated Andy Kirk.

Tate worked briefly for Count Basie on Lester Young's temporary departure, but this early incarnation of the Basie band soon broke up for want of bookings. But Basie's chance came again when swing became a national craze around the mid 1930s, and in 1939 Tate got his big break when was invited to join the now successful Basie orchestra following the sudden death of tenorist Herschel Evans. The two had been old friends and Tate maintained later that he had dreamed Evans had died before he ever heard the news, and was sure that a call from Basie would come. For Basie's part, the bandleader said in his autobiography: "Buddy was enough like Herschel, so he could take care of that business, but he also had his own thing, which meant we still had two different styles, tones, and everything." Tate stayed with Basie for nine years, until postwar economics forced changes in the line-up and the saxophonist decided to look for work that would keep him closer to New York. Tate played for bandleaders Lucky Millinder and Hot Lips Page, and in Basie singer Jimmy Rushing's Savoy band. He eventually secured a residency at the Celebrity Club on 125th Street in Harlem, and stayed for 21 years until the rise of jazz-rock and the eclipse of mainstream in the 1970s.

Tate nevertheless continued to record regularly, toured with the irrepressible swing trumpeter Buck Clayton and kept himself in the public eye by preserving a Basie-influenced small-group music that was affectionately received by every kind of jazz audience.

He also appeared with Jay MacShann, the bandleader in whose outfit the young Charlie Parker's tentative bop experiments were first heard, and with trombonist Al Grey, a musician with much of Tate's own relaxed grace and lyricism.

Tate was badly scalded in an accident in 1981, but returned to playing through the 80s - sometimes with a hard-swinging ensemble also featuring the driving blues-influenced tenorist Illinois Jacquet and called the Texas Tenors.

 Buddy (George Holmes) Tate, saxophonist, born February 22 1913; died February 10 2001

fields.headline: A return to learning
fields.trailText: Professor Rennie (Letters, February 9) is correct in challenging the House of Commons education select committee's bribery tactics. Payments to universities of a few hundred pounds will not have the power to retain students from disadvantaged backgrounds in the same way as a properly funded grant system.
fields.body:
Professor Rennie (Letters, February 9) is correct in challenging the House of Commons education select committee's bribery tactics. Payments to universities of a few hundred pounds will not have the power to retain students from disadvantaged backgrounds in the same way as a properly funded grant system.

But he is misguided in claiming that access courses are the scourge of higher education. I am the product of such a course, without which, I am sure, I would not have achieved my first class honours degree. It provided me with the knowledge and confidence to study at the required level. However, if financial circumstances had been different I too could have been a casualty of the impoverishment of higher education funding. It is, therefore, not simply the lack of skills, knowledge and attitudes that determine one's success or failure but the ability to properly fund oneself.

While at university I was more concerned that my fellow students who had come directly from studying A-levels did not have the necessary skills to fully benefit from the opportunities afforded them in higher education. Any remedial teaching, I suggest, should be focussed on those students who are taught in schools to expect answers to be given rather than being provided with the ability to research answers for themselves. This is the real failure of the education system in Britain, the inability to challenge and question, especially those in power.
Graham Birtle
Colburn, North Yorkshire
gbirtle@cherrytreecottage.net


Prof Rennie betrays his own prejudice and elitist attitudes by using "remedial", a pejorative term totally out-dated in education, of foundation students. He should send them to Rugby College of Further Education, where we adopt an uncondescending attitude and teach study skills and A-level equivalent courses designed by ourselves. After nine months of study, about 24 of our students each year gain places in higher education, with minimal drop-out.
Jackie Lloyd
Rugby
JACLLO1@rugbycoll.ac.uk


I have been following the debate about getting more poor kids off the streets and into universities. I was myself a poor kid who went to a red-brick university in a year when the number of applicants was at a peak, and I feel part of the debate is missing.

Our universities are essentially middle-class institutions. Poor kids have seldom had the "benefits" of a middle-class upbringing and thus tend to feel like aliens from another planet on entering such institutions. Despite being as well qualified academically as everyone else, I had no idea what was expected of me while at university, and always felt everyone else was attending lectures I had missed.

I dropped out after a year.
Sara Covington
Basildon, Essex
sara@darkhorseuk.co.uk

fields.headline: Labour in the trenches
fields.trailText: If, as now seems likely, Labour omits from its forthcoming manifesto the specific commitment to hold a referendum on voting reform for Westminster elections, certain consequences are inevitable.
fields.body:
If, as now seems likely, Labour omits from its forthcoming manifesto the specific commitment to hold a referendum on voting reform for Westminster elections, certain consequences are inevitable.

The casual betrayal of so long-standing a commitment means that Labour is itself choosing to re-impose equidistance as the relationship between itself and the Liberal Democrats. Withdrawal from the joint cabinet committee becomes inevitable and all future cooperation on constitutional reform (which has born such fruit since the pre-1997 Cook-Maclennan commission) is put at risk.

Such a return to the trenches will be a victory for the tribalists in both parties and a vindication of those Liberal Democrat "long-marchers" who have argued that Labour is not yet ready to turn away from the winner-takes-all mindset of confrontational politics and embrace more inclusive and cooperative forms of governance for which a fairer voting system is a prerequisite.
Tom McNally
House of Lords

The idea that Labour's national executive committee is a warm and friendly body under New Labour (The four Margarets, G2, February 8) beggars belief. In my two years as a constituency representative on the NEC, discussion was entirely polarised between the New Labour majority (of 29) and the Grassroots Alliance supporters (four of us).

The New Labour majority only achieved its consensus by voting to prevent motions from being discussed, and allowing Millbank to slip controversial items through the meeting. The atmosphere was the most unpleasant that I have ever encountered in 21 years as a political activist.

Whether run by women or men, Millbank engages in the age-old political practices of manoeuvre, caucusing and deals behind closed doors. Coupled with New Labour's control-freakery, restriction of democracy within the party and hatred of dissent, the result is a deeply confrontational and anti-democratic atmosphere on the NEC.
Liz Davies
London

Would you mind printing the Labour candidates' guide to whirlwind canvassing in full (New Labour's 30-second doorstep challenge, February 8)? Then we can have it ready for their visit, perhaps in checklist form, and be able to make a full and formal complaint to Millbank should our local lickspittle accidentally depart from his or her script, bring up any "issues", or run over their allotted 90 seconds. After all, our representatives have to be accountable...
G McGregor
London

fields.headline: No 1817
fields.standfirst: St Valentine
fields.trailText: St Valentine
fields.body:
Age: Died 270 AD, probably.

Probably? Valentine, meaning healthy, was a popular Roman name. There were several martyred Saint Valentines - but the most likely candidate was a priest and doctor who rescued persecuted Christians.

Did he die a horribly romantic death? He was clubbed to death for being a Christian under the orders of the emperor Claudius II Gothicus.

Ouch. What does that have to do with hearts and flowers? Even in prison he was a kind man and, the story goes, cured his jailer's daughter's blindness. The night before he was killed, February 14, he sent her a note signed "from your Valentine".

How sweet. So will you be sending any cards this year, snugglebum? What have I said about saying that in public? Anyway, according to the Post Office, more than 12m cards will be sent.

There's still time you know, munchkin: Stop it. Before Saint Valentine, February 14 was the festival of Juno - the Godess of childbirth and marriage. Men would pick a woman's name out of a box and she would be their dance partner for the rest of the festival.

Sounds like a night out in Essex: The similarities don't stop there. The Romans also had the festival of Lupercalia on February 15. Unmarried youths would run almost naked around the town, whipping newlywed young women with animal skin.

Blimey, so many parallels, so little time. When did Valentine become the patron saint of Hallmark? By the 16th century people began to send Valentines cards - possibly the oldest form of greeting card.

So where are you taking me? Actually, I don't believe in Valentine's day - it's commerical capitalist nonsense and about as romantic as a bunch of flowers from the garage.

I can't believe you forgot, there's still time to book something. I didn't forget, and we're not having a row about this.

Oh I get it, you're planning a lovely surprise. Whatever.

fields.headline: CJD and transplants: how logical are the worries?
fields.trailText: All citizens of the UK were exposed to large doses of the agent which causes BSE/scrapies between 1981 and November 1989, because it was during those years that the brains (the infective tissue) of our cattle were being added to our "meat products" (CJD may rule out young organ donors, February 10).
fields.body:
All citizens of the UK were exposed to large doses of the agent which causes BSE/scrapies between 1981 and November 1989, because it was during those years that the brains (the infective tissue) of our cattle were being added to our "meat products" (CJD may rule out young organ donors, February 10). Those of us who had the misfortune to swallow large doses of that agent and who are genetically susceptible (about 30%) may be incubating vCJD whatever our age.

The reason most victims of vCJD have hitherto been much younger than those of classical CJD - and have manifested a much shorter incubation period than expected - is because they, being children shedding teeth during that decade, provided the organism with a direct entry into the bloodstream through the raw areas in their gums.

Of course a "rising number of people have vCJD but have not displayed signs", and it is therefore just as logical to worry about their organs for donation as those of younger people. In fact the agent only proliferates in the brain and spinal cord and, since the eyes and the pituitary - but not the teeth - develop out of the brain, the cornea is certainly an infected tissue.

In 1977 three people - one in New York and two in Bern - were infected with CJD from corneal grafts which were taken from patients who died of CJD. Apart from the pituitary (in the human growth hormone disaster) and the cornea - both central nervous system tissues - there is no evidence that any one has ever been infected with CJD either from blood transfusion or from organ donation.

Neither would it be expected, since it is only in the brain and cord that the agent proliferates; its presence in the tonsils is transient on its way from the stomach to the brain.
Dr Helen Grant
London
drhelengrant@hotmail.com

According to your report, "dentists have already been warned to change procedures". Can the public be told by whom, and with what effect? Do current procedures really protect the public?

I have recently sought information on cross-patient infection from the British Dental Association and local dentists and I am not reassured. The BDA advises a more intense programme of sterilisation (higher temperatures, for longer) and equipment disposal - but only where the dentist are dealing with patients declaring a risk of CJD.

The BDA suggests that dentists should consider using disposable instruments - but does not insist. As one dentist has told me, if burrs (drills) have to be disposed of, so does a lot else, adding to cost. He relies on the BDA's assumptions that there are only 5,000 maximum CJD cases and that the risk of coming across them is small.

If expert opinion is that there is a risk of CJD transmission through dentistry, why isn't the dental profession adopting procedures which treat all patients as at risk?
Caroline Nichols
Sunbury-on-Thames, Middx

fields.headline: Away game
fields.trailText: Why are our football authorities investigating the 20 or so Premiership players with dual nationality from other countries (Players' fake papers rock Europe, February 8)? Surely, of greater benefit to English football is to check the credentials of players with some possibility of English nationality.
fields.body:
Why are our football authorities investigating the 20 or so Premiership players with dual nationality from other countries (Players' fake papers rock Europe, February 8)? The FA should being checking on the family tree of anyone with a half-decent left foot as part of this passport investigation.
Ian Thompson
Enfield, Middx

fields.headline: Coming off the bottle
fields.trailText: The researchers looking at obesity in toddlers (One in 10 toddlers are obese, say researchers, February 9) may have overlooked one significant contributing factor - formula milk. Recent German research has shown that formula-fed children are more likely to become obese than breastfed children.
fields.body:
The researchers looking at obesity in toddlers (One in 10 toddlers are obese, say researchers, February 9) may have overlooked one significant contributing factor - formula milk. Recent German research has shown that formula-fed children are more likely to become obese than breastfed children. What's more, formula-fed children are at greater risk from respiratory disease, diabetes, allergies, diarrhoea and gastroenteritis.

Last week, new research linked breast milk with lower blood pressure in teenagers. It's been estimated that if all children were breastfed the NHS would save around £35m each year in treating infant gastroenteritis alone. How much more money - and heartache - would be saved treating adults for cardiac problems caused by obesity and high blood pressure as well?
Belinda Phipps
National Childbirth Trust

"One in 10 toddlers are obese, say researchers". But how many will learn good grammar?
Paul Goodings
Chester

fields.headline: All Wallies
fields.trailText:
In Romford in the 50s, we were never in doubt as to why we called people Wallies (Leader, February 10). On fish and chip shop counters you could find a jar of "wallies" - small pickled cucumbers. They were roughly the size and shape of the human penis.
John French
Chepstow

webTitle: Architecture: Chris Smith picks the best and worst of British architecture

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.trailText: Chris Smith picks the best and worst of British architecture.
fields.body:
Chris Smith

Wonder: Bevin Court, London
Blunder: Elephant and Castle

Choosing a favourite building has been made extremely difficult by the success of a range of large-scale lottery-funded projects in the past two years: the breathtaking Tate Modern; Norman Foster's swooping glass roof at the British Museum; the Lowry in Salford, now being matched by Daniel Libeskind's beautiful Imperial War Museum of the North across the canal. All have helped to give a real lift to the quality of architecture in Britain.

But my personal favourite would be something rather older and closer to home. It's a block of flats in my south Islington constituency called Bevin Court; it was designed by Berthold Lubetkin and was completed in 1954. It embodies Lubetkin's simple belief that nothing should be too good for ordinary people. It's a lesson we've forgotten too often in the half-century since. These are flats that are both practical and beautiful. The block has not been maintained as well as it should, over the years, but it is still astonishing.

The central staircase is the jewel in the crown. It loops upwards in a way that's worthy of an Italian palazzo.The combination of curves and flat surfaces, stairs and landings, presents the eye with a mass of complex detail but a unified whole.

Choosing a least favourite building is as difficult. Should I opt for everyone's pet hate, the towers of the former Department of the Environment building in London? Or what about Quarry House in Leeds, public offices crammed on to a site in modern-monolithic style? My nomination would be London's Elephant and Castle shopping centre - an example of urban planning its worst. The attempt to brighten it up with garish colours has hindered rather than helped. This is the most important transport hub of south London, and when the long overdue redevelopment occurs, I hope something more fitting for such a significant location can emerge.

 Chris Smith is culture secretary.

webTitle: New hygiene checks on ship and air meals

fields.headline: New hygiene checks on ship and air meals
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: New checks are to be introduced on airline meals and cruise ship catering in an attempt to halt the increase in food poisoning.
fields.body:
New checks are to be introduced on airline meals and cruise ship catering in an attempt to halt the increase in food poisoning.

Food safety watchdogs say millions of passengers a year need assurance that crews are following proper hygiene rules.

A legal loophole means that standards of food preparation and service on air and sea transport are not subject to the same checks as land-based eating places.

Environmental health officials covering ports and airports believe some outbreaks go unreported because travellers may not be struck down until hours after their flight, while holidaymakers suffering diarrhoea or upset stomachs on cruises are often reluctant to pay for a visit to the ship's doctor.

Officials who receive complaints have no right of entry to check whether airlines or ship owners are observing safety rules. Peter Rotheram, of the association of port health authorities, said: "It is very difficult to find out how big the problem is. Some of the airlines are quite cooperative, some are not.

Officials monitor preparation of food before it is taken "airside" to aircraft but after that airlines can decide whether to allow on-board checks.

Meals are sometimes transported for hours in aircraft holds, cooling as the plane cruises at high altitudes and warming as it lands, before being switched to galleys and prepared for passengers.

The public health laboratory service recently suggested that 9% of water samples taken from drinking fountains and taps in airports and on aircraft might be contaminated.

US officials regularly publish the results of hygiene checks on cruise ships, and these are believed to influence bookings.

The food standards agency plans to consult on changes. It suggests that these would "meet consumers' expectations that food hygiene standards can be enforced in all food businesses".

Roger Wiltshire, director general of the British Air Transport Association, said he would be meeting agency officials soon and would be looking for a solution.

Bill Gibbons, director of the Passenger Shipping Association, said that there was no need for any further bureaucracy.

The Consumers' Association welcomed the moves.
