fields.headline: Pharmaceutical firms attacked
fields.trailText: Animal rights activists yesterday mounted demonstrations against pharmaceutical companies which they claimed support testing of drugs on animals at Huntingdon Life Sciences.
fields.body:
Animal rights activists yesterday mounted demonstrations against pharmaceutical companies which they claimed support testing of drugs on animals at Huntingdon Life Sciences.

Hundreds of protesters were involved in a coordinated series of break-ins or demonstrations at the laboratories, offices and at the homes of directors of five leading companies.

Pharmaceutical companies condemned the attacks, which caused tens of thousands of pounds of damage, and warned that a threat of violence against them was "not conducive to medical research in the UK".

Campaigners from Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty (Shac) said the demonstrations marked the start of a new era in its protests against the company. In the past its campaign has targeted the firm's financial backers.

Police made 87 arrests after hundreds of protesters, many wearing balaclavas, broke into Bayer Plc in Stoke Poges, Berkshire. Bayer, which claims not to be a current customer of Huntingdon, said the damage was minor.

Two groups of protesters overwhelmed security guards and broke into GlaxoSmithKline's research and technical operations in Weybridge, Surrey, and its Horlick's factory in Slough, Berkshire.

More than 50 protesters broke into Eli Lilly & Co in Basingstoke, Hampshire, and demonstrated outside the company's research centre in Windlesham, Surrey, and Novartis Pharmaceuticals in Camberley, Surrey.

The campaigners said they also demonstrated outside the homes of directors of Roche and of Pharmacia Corporation.

Shac hopes to persuade the companies to withdraw their support from Huntingdon's laboratories in Cambridgeshire and in Occold, Suffolk.

A GlaxoSmithKline spokesman said: "This is a worrying escalation of animal rights extremism. It is not conducive to medical research."

fields.headline: Arguing the revolution at the Gate
fields.standfirst:
Les Justes
Gate
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Les Justes
Gate
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Last year the Almeida revived Sartre's Les Main Sales (1948) under the title of The Novice. Now Erica Whyman starts her tenancy at the Gate with a rare sighting of Camus's Les Justes (1949), in a new translation by Gillian Hanna. Both plays deal with the ethics of political murder; but it is Camus, to my surprise, who treats it in a more complex and gripping manner.

He starts with the advantage of historical truth. "All my characters," he wrote, "really existed and behaved in the way I describe." His subject is the plan by a group of Russian revolutionary socialists to assassinate the Tsar's uncle, Grand Duke Serge, in 1905. The initial failure of the poet, Kaliayev, to hurl the bomb, because of the children in the Grand Duke's carriage, prompts a fierce debate among the conspirators with the hardline Stepan arguing that violence should have no limits. But Kaliayev's eventual success leads to his imprisonment and exposure to the temptations of betraying his comrades and succumbing to Christian forgiveness at the hands of the Grand Duchess.

Camus and Sartre quarrelled in the early 1950s and you can see why. Sartre argued that in the cause of revolution, one must be willing to get one's hands dirty; Camus warns against the sacrifice of moral principles in the attack on absolutism. But Camus's strength is that he dramatises the argument in clear human terms. It is a classic revolutionary antithesis that haunts drama from Julius Caesar to Danton's Death, and it is one that Camus explores with genuine dialectical urgency.

Given the emphasis on historical truth - the bereaved Grand Duchess really did visit the assassin in his cell - one wishes Camus supplied even more detail: he never makes it clear that the Grand Duke was notorious for his brutality towards dissent. And the conflict between passion and politics leads to some oddly mixed metaphors, as when Dora, who worships Kaliayev, tells him "Love is a yoke, Jankek, however sweet." But as a study in the morality of political murder the play recalls the dark power of Dostoevsky's The Possessed, which Camus adapted for the stage in 1959.

It's given a solidly decent production by Whyman that clearly articulates the play's arguments and that is well acted by Nicolas Tennant as the conscience-stricken Kaliayev, Ruth Lass as the impassioned Dora and Stephen Ventura as the merciless Stepan, who seems a prototype Soviet apparatchik. It may be less formally adventurous than recent work at the Gate but it shows that revolutionary politics still makes good theatre.

 Until March 3. Box office: 020-7229 0706.

fields.headline: Shakespeare's high-class soap opera
fields.standfirst:
Measure For Measure
Old Tobacco Factory
Bristol
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Measure For Measure
Old Tobacco Factory
Bristol
Rating: ****
fields.body:
"'Tis one thing to be tempted, another thing to fall," professes Angelo, the newly appointed regent of the Duke. Shakespeare certainly knew how to pile on the irony, and 400 years on this notoriously difficult and morally tricky play still has the power to send you out of the theatre arguing for and against the characters and their actions.

For a modern audience, Isabella's determination to save her virginity over the life of her brother can make her seem priggish, but even if you take that view the drama is sufficiently slippery to throw up plenty of other moral propositions. Do two wrongs make a right? And what about the behaviour of the Duke? These questions become urgent, necessary and utterly contemporary in good productions of this play, and this is a very fine rendition indeed.

Director Andrew Hilton is a bit of a puritan about Shakespeare. He stages it in period costume and without embellishment. There are no tricks, just clear storytelling, excellent verse speaking and intricate, wonderfully detailed performances. The acting of every single player here, right down to the smallest role, is crystal. Even the tiny part of the Nun is beautifully done.

The production includes a new scene in which we see the coupling of the hypocritical, lustful Angelo and Marina, his rejected fiancee who undertakes to replace the virtuous Isabella in his bed. The scene neither adds nor detracts. But for the most part this is a simple and vigorous production in which the motivations and internal crises of the characters are made so palpable that the effect is like watching a piece of high-class soap opera. Even if you know the play well, it makes you want to tut and say: "Goodness, how some people behave."

In such a good cast, it is almost a shame to pick people out, but John Mackay's Angelo is wonderfully complex and right from the beginning conveys his fallibility. His reluctance to take the Duke's chair suggests that he has enough self-knowledge to be aware of his own weaknesses. That he knows that he will fall.

As Isabella, Lucy Black suggests not a saint, but a quiet woman with a steely resolve who can get quite snappy when stressed. The ending is just wonderful: with her brother unexpectedly restored to her and the Duke rushing her into marriage, Isabella doesn't look suffused with joy but has the glazed, horrified look of a woman who has just realised that a juggernaut is bearing down on her at 100 miles an hour.

 Until March 17. Box office: 0117-902 0344.

fields.headline: Halifax to give 36,000 staff options
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Halifax, which last week bought Equitable Life, is to award all of its 36,000 employees options worth 20% of their salaries through what is believed to be one of the largest share ownership schemes in the country.
fields.body:
Halifax, which last week bought Equitable Life, is to award all of its 36,000 employees options worth 20% of their salaries through what is believed to be one of the largest share ownership schemes in the country.

The bank, which converted from a building society four years ago, is to put the options scheme to its annual general meeting in May with a view to making the award of options shortly afterwards. The award will be made to all employees below executive level.

The options will be granted for a three-year period and will pay out provided the share price of the bank is above the level at which they are granted. This so-called "strike price" is yet to be set.

A spokesman for the Halifax said: "We're doing this because it's good for our business that all colleagues have a stake in the company".

Hailfax's shares ended at 713p on Friday - well above the 410p to which it sank this time a year ago. As many as 80% of the bank's staff participate in its save as you earn share ownership scheme, some of whom have suffered by the fall in the Halifax's share price since flotation.

Yesterday, doubts emerged over the sale of Equitable Life to the Hailfax amid allegations of pension misselling by the life company's salesforce. Financial advisers claimed that thousands of policyholders could have been persuaded to transfer funds from tax-efficient personal pensions to new schemes that unnecessarily expose them to income and inheritance tax.

The government is also set to face potentially embarrassing questions about its alleged role in the Equitable Life crisis this week when a Treasury select committee inquiry opens on Thursday.

fields.headline: Ian Pace
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall
London
Rating: *
fields.body:
On paper, pianist Ian Pace has all the credentials to be a noteworthy interpreter of the music of John Ogdon. Ogdon (1937-1989) was one of the most brilliant pianists of his generation, celebrated for his dynamic interpretations of the virtuoso traditions of the 19th and 20th centuries. Ogdon worked hard to explore the outer reaches of the piano repertoire, including the fiendishly difficult music of Busoni and Alkan, as well as Kaikhosru Sorabji's superhuman technical challenges.

Like Ogdon, Pace has specialised in contemporary repertoire of mind-bending complexity, giving premieres of music by such composers as Richard Barrett and Brian Ferneyhough. Pace's Wigmore Hall concert presented Ogdon's own music alongside late-romantic works by Liszt, Scriabin and Busoni. It was the kind of monumental programme Ogdon himself used to relish: the first half was 80 minutes long. However, Pace's interpretative limitations made this enthusiastic abundance of music seem more like forceful self-importance.

Ogdon's music is rooted in early 20th-century chromatic harmony. But Pace's gifts are glaringly deficient in this repertoire. His performance of Liszt's Mephisto Waltz number three was devoid of charm or virtuosic sparkle, reducing the piece to an undifferentiated barrage of notes. Pace's detachment also scarred Scriabin's Tenth Sonata. The piece contains some of the most disturbingly impassioned music in the piano repertoire. Yet Pace could only manage a monochrome texture.

In applying the same approach to Ogdon's work, Pace divorced Ogdon's music from its historical and stylistic foundations. The vast Andante of Ogdon's First Sonata was sprawling in Pace's hands, while the wit of Ogdon's Theme and Variations was crude. At least the programme allowed a glimpse of the range of Ogdon's music: from the decorum of a sonata based on Scriabin, to the fireworks of his fantasy on Varlaam's Song from Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov.

Pace's reputation is founded on his advocacy of this modernist repertoire. Yet after hearing his performances of late-romantic music, I couldn't help thinking how much richer these 20th-century masterpieces are than Pace's performances of them.

fields.headline: Ben Cook
fields.standfirst:
West Park Museum
Macclesfield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
West Park Museum
Macclesfield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
For much of the 19th century, Macclesfield was the silk capital of Britain, and one of the most affluent towns in the north. As resident artist at the town's Paradise Mill (which was operational until 1981), Ben Cook has drawn upon this heritage to develop his project of Found Paintings. Taking flawed textiles, he stretches them across a wooden frame to give the appearance of a painted canvas in an approach that is somewhere between ready-made and revisionist. And now he's gone a step further, or rather, back.

After selecting early hand-painted designs from the mill's textile design archive, Cook scanned them into a computer, played with them, and had them digitally printed on silk, and mounted on 6ft by 4ft wooden frames. It's an ingenious concept, for in taking the process back to its source and then bringing in computer-aided design, Cook is utilising design skills that are more than 100 years apart. The results are stunning.

Taking as its reference point the coloured line-blocks of the famous Macclesfield Stripe design, Cook's Study for A Macclesfield Stripe immediately challenges the barcode-like formality of the original. From a distance, the silk looks like a vivid canvas, and Cook's softened lines seem like a sketch of shimmering blinds, or diffracted rays, blurring from the centre outwards. Strikingly, the print achieves a three-dimensional effect as the lines reach towards the viewer to create the illusion of a step.

Such is the allure of these strange slats of colour that they seem to hail and hold the viewer. Painting the Void is no exception. The starting point here is an old block design of thin red, black and blue lines crossing in a kind of intense circuit diagram. Cook has exploded this into a print with a searing, cinematic feel. Like a photograph of a speeding object, the edges are wildly out-of-focus, a concrete spin with mere traces of colour. Staring at the more defined white-blue-pink lines at the centre, you feel like you're playing a computer game in which you steer a hapless vessel between ever-narrowing walls, as Cook traps the viewer in a landscape of frantic motion and space. An ideal pattern, then, for a 21st-century silk scarf or tie.

 Until February 18. Details: 01625 619831.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: The Critic makes a comeback, clowns go crazy and a mugging mishap in Central park
fields.trailText: The Critic makes a comeback, clowns go crazy and a mugging mishap in Central park
fields.body:
The Critic
(www.shockwave.com)
We're not in the habit of recommending shows which found a second home on the Net after TV tossed them out. But The Critic, with its bite-sized sequences and quick-fire wit, has made the transition seamlessly. In fact, Al Jean and Mike Reiss's crisp scripting shows up just how thinly conceived and executed many of the animated "web-hit-wonders" are (Zombie College, anyone ?). Lovers of their chubby, schlubby acid-tongued movie critic Jay Sherman can revel in four (yes, four) new episodes in which Jay "outs" Pikachu, pans The Patriot and says something nice about Arnold Schwarzenegger's movies. "The good thing is that they seem to come further apart these days." Baby, he's back! (KS)
 View the film

Bingo
(www.scifi.com)
File this one under "deliciously odd." Bingo is a super-lively experimental CGI animated short in which a group of demented clowns try repeatedly to convince Dave that he is indeed Bingo the Clown. Based on a theatre piece by Chicago's Neo Futurist troupe, it crackles with inventive energy and fiercely funny performances from Dave and his tormentors The Money Guy and The Button Girl. Director Chris Landreth gives his animation a sheeny, fabulously realistic quality which helps to throw a scare into the viewer. For anyone who's ever wondered what it would be like to drop acid at the circus, this may be the closest you'll get. (KS)
 View the film

Thugs
(www.evilfilms.com)
Patrick and Josh, a pair of art-loving criminals, are short on dough. They decide to chance their arm at a spot of mugging in Central Park. But the hapless pair are clearly not up to it - Josh even wears his spectacles on the outside of his balaclava. The film's principal merit is its acting. Both Patrick Gallo and Joshua Cary - a couple of stars from the New York comedy circuit - are superb. A witty New York comedy that makes a couple of subtle digs at gangsta culture. (SD)
 View the film

fields.headline: Texas
fields.standfirst:
Wembley Arena
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wembley Arena
Rating: ****
fields.body:
One of Texas's many endearing traits is their bloody-minded straightness. A greatest hits show was promised; a greatest hits show is delivered. The results are predictable: a sell-out arena tour and an assured place for The Greatest Hits, their singles compilation, in the top 10 until at least Easter. Yet it takes even Texas 30 minutes to negotiate the usual Wembley hurdles of atrocious sound and cowed crowd. Halo, Black Eyed Boy and In Our Lifetime are received as if Sharleen Spiteri is picking up awards for best marrow at the local village fete.

For all their musical accomplishments, Texas are not especially showy and you would plump for any of his eight on-stage colleagues as being Texas's musical brains before alighting upon woolly hatted bassist Johnny McElhone, bobbing away in his own world, avoiding spotlights and video cameras alike.

Inevitably, then, Texas live is the Spiteri show. More mobile than of yore, she works hard, offering the crowd the carrots of tales about cab rides, plus the stick of admonishment: "You're a bit bloody quiet." On their first of two diversions (the second will be Suspicious Minds), she plucks an extraordinarily self-confident Spaniard from the crowd to gyrate with her during Grace Jones's Pull Up to the Bumper. With all the braggadocio the Iberian peninsular can muster, he does indeed pull up close to Spiteri's bumper. She removes his hands from her buttocks and looks delighted to have found someone in the building as feisty as her.

Signally, the tide does not turn until Spiteri, alone but for her acoustic guitar, wrestles with Put Your Arms Around Me. It's a deceptively simple song, but she wrings a plethora of new nuances from it, underlining what a genuinely outstanding soul voice she has.

That flicks the switch. The crowd rouse themselves and what had seemed a Sisyphean struggle was now downhill until the close. I Don't Want A Lover showcases Ally McErlaine's cut-throat guitar, Eddie Campbell's keyboards thunder through the anthemic Summer Son, and Spiteri dresses in the manner of Elvis Presley's comeback special for the encores.

A fine British band playing all their hits and taking nothing for granted? Texas certainly keep their promises.

 Texas play Manchester Arena (0161-930 8000) tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Exasperating conundrums from Wynton Marsalis
fields.standfirst:
Wynton Marsalis/ LCJO
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Wynton Marsalis/ LCJO
Barbican
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The musical conservatism of Wynton Marsalis, the New Orleans trumpeter, is as profound as his influence is formidable. Recently, his role in Ken Burns's conservative US television history of jazz has brought the "Marsalis issue" back to the fore. That was the backdrop to this visit with the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, with a programme devoted to Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington. It was always going to be one of the box-office draws of the jazz year, and one of its exasperating conundrums.

As always, the stagey informality of the banter between the players sounded as if its intention was to massage hip-jazzbo stereotypes in the expectations of an upmarket mainstream audience, rather than reveal the truly wayward spontaneous impulses among the players that brought jazz into being in the first place.

But the music certainly represented what Marsalis always protests is his intention - to recast the early music with a contemporary spin. The first part of the programme was devoted to Louis Armstrong's early work, and the orchestra adopted a policy with this almost eight-decade-old music of shifting between the two-beat chug-chug of an early swing rhythm and a more contemporary feel. The soloists correspondingly operated in a crossover territory between the raw, blues-rooted directness of the old improvising styles, and a more complex and intricate post-John Coltrane, post-Miles Davis manner.

Marsalis himself delivered some masterly instances of this. At the close of Tight Like This, with the orchestra recapping the tune in its authentic tempo, the trumpeter repeated a single note instead of the theme, but kept varying its duration and placement with the deceptive effect that the repeating undertow seemed to be constantly changing shape. Mahagony Hall Stomp was peppered with the kind of bebop sax solos still 15 years away when it was first conceived (tenorists Victor Goines and Walter Blanding Jnr swerved divertingly into Lady Be Good during their duet variations on it), and Marcus Printup confirmed that Marsalis wasn't the only trumpeter who could combine the bravura 1920s manner and postbop's capricious melodies without losing the plot.

An uptempo train-rhythm swinger was one of the concert's few originals, and the musical and conceptual success of Marsalis's music for the 1994 Blood on the Fields oratorio (it remains a high point for him) was confirmed by the swaggering Mingus-like roar of Back to Basics, with its barging, colliding brass lines and wheeling, yelping sax melodies. Marsalis's solo of wah-wah effects, indignant, grimacing slurs, manic giggles, and deft, dancing runs was his solo of the night. It highlighted his pleasure in his work rather than his sense of missionary duty to build a classical edifice for jazz, and it's the part of his shows that stays longest in the memory.

 Wynton Marsalis plays the Corn Exchange, Brighton (01273 709709), tomorrow, then tours.

webTitle: Opera review: The Marriage of Figaro

fields.headline: The comedy of Figaro
fields.standfirst:
The Marriage of Figaro
New Theatre
Cardiff
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Marriage of Figaro
New Theatre
Cardiff
Rating: ****
fields.body:
It has been said that you come out of Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro either laughing at the jokes or humming the tunes. It doesn't have to be either-or, but there is a point to the saying. A Figaro that is equally sublime as music and as comedy is a blue moon event.

There was no blue moon shining over Cardiff on the opening night of Welsh National Opera's new production of Figaro. As comedy it was excellent. You could hear people laughing all the way through - real laughter, not polite opera-house titters. The acting was lively, fresh, and on the whole well-staged. Nicola Ulivieri and Nuccia Focile made a genuinely likable Figaro and Susanna. Gidon Saks's Count Almaviva was outstanding - a great big testosterone-enriched baby, swinging between lecherous ecstasy and furious desire for vengeance, and finally repenting like a chastened three-year-old.

All the characters sparked off each other continuously. The action was taut, never limp. Full marks for comedy then. But the music was more variable, even though good singing wasn't lacking. Saks's round, fruity bass-baritone and nicely over-the-top phrasing heightened his triumph as the Count. Focile's clear, bright Susanna always sounded secure and alive. Marcellina even emerged as a creature with some depth of feeling, thanks to Anne Mason's impassioned singing.

Ulivieri's Figaro, however wasn't quite as charming to the ear as he was to the eye. And Geraldine McGreevy's Countess was a disappointment. She had her moments, but her two great numbers, Porgi amor and Dove sono, weren't among them. Conductor Rinaldo Alessandrini sounded as though he couldn't decide whether to set the tempo or follow McGreevy, with the result that the rhythmic glue sometimes came unstuck. Generally speaking, the Welsh National Orchestra played cleanly and enthusiastically for Alessandrini, but faltering voice-orchestra ensemble and unsteady tempo were recurring problems.

Somehow though, spirit won out over technical imperfections - and over passing oddities in Neil Armfield's production, such as the Countess's 1960s industrial hair-drier in the corner of her baroque boudoir, and the first scenes of the first and third acts, which look as though they take place inside a half-unpacked IKEA furniture kit. In the end WNO's Figaro is a thoroughly enjoyable evening's theatre. And for those who still need to be convinced that classic opera can actually be alive and funny, this might just be a conversion experience.

 In rep until March 2. Box office: 029-2087 8889. Tours to Birmingham, Southampton, Swansea, Oxford and Bristol.

Tours to Birmingham, Southampton, Swansea, Oxford and Bristol.

fields.headline: Ceal Floyer
fields.standfirst:
Ikon Gallery
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Ikon Gallery
Birmingham
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Can a cartoon mouse hole be art? Drawn on a piece of white card and propped at the foot of the wall, it would fool no gallery visitor, mouse or human. The mouse would pass it by without another thought. For some reason, some of us humans stop and wonder.

The recurrent theme of art of the past 100 years has been: what is it? Innovative artists see how far they can push art towards non-art. Non-art, when placed in a gallery, is art with a bit of edge to it. How far before it goes over the edge and leaves us as indifferent as the mouse? Ceal Floyer is an artist worth noticing because she makes such well-worn questions seem once again intriguing and amusing.

Floyer's consumer minimalism aims for meaningful irreverence rather than transcendence. The catalogue quotes a Ceal Floyer joke: "A woman walks into a bar, goes up to the barman, and asks him for a double entendre. So he gives her one." Her visual jokes are on the gallery and on the visitor. It's hard to say where the art is. What little there is is obviously not what it seems. A light switch is a projection of a light switch. Light seeping under a door is also a projection. Floyer makes no effort to hide the projectors. Disbelief is stressed rather than suspended. The sound of water dripping into a bucket comes from a CD player in a bucket. The label reads Bucket, 1999, CD player, CD. Garbage Bag, 1996, is a black plastic bin bag filled with thin air.

Many of these pieces have a room all to themselves. Floyer makes you see just how empty a virtually empty gallery can be. Maybe the gallery space, filled with the cultural unease brought to it by the half-amused visitor, becomes the artwork more than the artworks themselves. Here's Monochrome Till Receipt (White), 2001. It's what it says on the label. It doesn't take long before you notice that Floyer's purchases are all on a theme of white: Polo Mints, Salt, Single Cream, Lard, Dove Bar. Untitled (Twin Decks), 1999, is two record decks holding two revolving records. From two speakers comes the sound of two scratches, repeating with monotonous regularity. Is this minimalist enchantment? No. Is it silly bugger stuff? Not entirely. If it's not art what is it? Nothing. So it must be art, then.

 Until March 25. Details: 0121-248 0708.
